Authors: Amos N., Block M.M., Bobbink G.J., Botje M., Favart D., Leroy C., Linde F., Lipnik P., Matheys J.-P., Miller D., Potter K., Shukla S., Vander Velde-Wilquet C., Zucchelli S.
Title: Measurement of small-angle antiproton-proton and proton-proton elastic scattering at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Université Catholique de Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Amos, N., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Block, M.M., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Bobbink, G.J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Botje, M., State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Favart, D., Université Catholique de Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Leroy, C., Université Catholique de Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Linde, F., State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Lipnik, P., Université Catholique de Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Matheys, J.-P., Université Catholique de Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Miller, D., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Potter, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Shukla, S., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Vander Velde-Wilquet, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Zucchelli, S., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Abstract: Antiproton-proton and proton-proton small-angle elastic scattering was measured for centre-of-mass energies s=30.6, 52.8 and 62.3 GeV at the CERN Intersectung Storage Rings. In addition, proton-proton elastic scattering was measured at s=23.5 GeV. Using the optical theorem, total cross sections are obtained with an accuracy of about 0.5% for proton-proton scattering and about 1% for antiproton-proton scattering. The measurement of the interference of the Coulomb scattering and the hadronic scattering permits a determination of the ratio of the real-to-imaginary part of the forward hadronic scattering amplitude. Also presented are measurements of the hadronic slope parameter. © 1985.

Title: On the efficient evaluation of analytic energy gradients
Affiliations: University Chemical Laboratory, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rice, J.E., University Chemical Laboratory, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom; Amos, R.D., University Chemical Laboratory, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom
Abstract: Methods for the efficient evaluation of analytic energy gradients with correlated wavefunctions are discussed. It is concluded that no gradient, and in particular the CI gradient with MC SCF orbitals, requires the storage or transformation of the atomic orbital derivative integrals. © 1985.

Authors: Kamke W., Kamke B., Kiefl H.U., Hertel I.V.
Title: Intramolecular penning ionization in benzonitrile-rare gas clusters
Affiliations: Institut für Molekulphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kamke, W., Institut für Molekulphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Kamke, B., Institut für Molekulphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Kiefl, H.U., Institut für Molekulphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Hertel, I.V., Institut für Molekulphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: A supersonic beam of benzonitrile (Bn) seeded into He, Ar, or Kr was ionized by VUV photons from the electron storage ring BESSY at Berlin. Photoionization efficiency curves were measured for Bn, Bn2, BnAr and Bn-Kr. Resonance peaks in the PIE curves show that excitation energy of the rare gas atom is transferred to the Bn molecule within the heterogeneous cluster, leading to ionization of the molecule and fragmentation of the cluster. © 1985.

Authors: Kamke W., Kamke B., Kiefl H.U., Hertel I.V.
Title: Intramolecular penning ionization in benzonitrile-rare gas clusters
Affiliations: Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kamke, W., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Kamke, B., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Kiefl, H.U., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Hertel, I.V., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: A supersonic beam of benzonitrile (Bn) seeded into He, Ar or Kr was ionized by VUV photons from the electron storage ring BESSY at Berlin. Photoionization efficiency curves were measured for Bn, Bn2, Bn-Ar and Bn-Kr. Resonance peaks in the PIE curves show that excitation energy of the rare gas atom is transferred to the Bn molecule within the heterogeneous cluster, leading to ionization of the molecule and fragmentation of the cluster. © 1985.

Authors: Higuti I.H., Murata L.Y., Stencel M., Nascimento K.H., Cruz A.O., Nascimento A.J.
Title: Studies on rat liver mitochondria in vitamin E-deficiency and during storage at 0-4°C
Source title: Research Communications in Chemical Pathology and Pharmacology
Affiliations: Departamento de Bioquimica da Universidade Federal do Parana, 80000 Curitiba PR, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Higuti, I.H., Departamento de Bioquimica da Universidade Federal do Parana, 80000 Curitiba PR, Brazil; Murata, L.Y., Departamento de Bioquimica da Universidade Federal do Parana, 80000 Curitiba PR, Brazil; Stencel, M., Departamento de Bioquimica da Universidade Federal do Parana, 80000 Curitiba PR, Brazil; Nascimento, K.H.; Cruz, A.O.; Nascimento, A.J.
Abstract: Isolated rat liver mitochondria, freed from microsomes and lysosomes contaminants, were maintained at 0-4°C for several days using an appropriate medium and energy source. It was observed that the phospholipase A2 activity of mitochondria deficient in vitamin E is higher than in normal mitochondria, and that the presence of vitamin E in the preservation medium diminishes the phospholipase A2 activity in deficient mitochondria. In vitamin E deficient mitochondria up to 45% of phospholipids was digested by the endogenous phospholipase with little loss in the energy linked function or without considerable activation of the latent enzyme monoamine oxidase and ATPase. These results are consistent with the occurrence of phospholipids in the mitochondrial membrane which would render it more accessible to the action of phospholipase A2.
Index Keywords: liver enzyme; phospholipase a2; alpha tocopherol deficiency; animal cell; liver; mitochondrion; nonhuman; priority journal; rat; Adenosine Triphosphatases; Animals; Cold; Male; Mitochondria, Liver; Organ Preservation; Oxygen Consumption; Phospholipases A; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Vitamin E Deficiency; Animalia

Authors: Tsybyshev V.P., Shtemler V.M., Kuznetsov A.N.
Title: Influence of a u.h.f. electromagnetic field on the reduction of ferricyanide by human erythrocytes in the presence of methylene blue
Affiliations: Institute of Chemical Physics, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Tsybyshev, V.P., Institute of Chemical Physics, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Shtemler, V.M., Institute of Chemical Physics, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kuznetsov, A.N., Institute of Chemical Physics, U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors have studied the effect of a u.h.f. e.m.f. with the frequency 1000 ± 10 MHz and specific absorbed power in the range 220-580 mW/g on the reduction of ferricyanide by human erythrocytes in the presence of methylene blue, a carrier of redox equivalents across the membrane, at different temperatures in the region 23-34 °C. In the temperature dependence of the rate of reduction of ferricyanide in Arrhenius coordinates two narrow "anomalous" portions are found with zero or negative activation energy in the regions 26-27 and 29-30°C. A significant increase in the rate of reduction of ferricyanide on irradiation with the u.h.f. e.m.f. was observed only in the temperature regions corresponding to the anomalous portions of the temperature dependence. The width of the anomalous portions and the degree of the effect of the u.h.f. e.m.f. increased on storage of the blood. © 1986.

Authors: Zediker M.S., Prelas M.A., Miley G.H.
Title: Energy storage of the atomic carbon laser in an electrical discharge
Affiliations: University of Illinois, Fusion Studies Laboratory, 103 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zediker, M.S., University of Illinois, Fusion Studies Laboratory, 103 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Prelas, M.A., University of Illinois, Fusion Studies Laboratory, 103 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Miley, G.H., University of Illinois, Fusion Studies Laboratory, 103 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: An experimental investigation of the atomic carbon laser's energy storage was conducted with a rotating back mirror. The high rotational speed of the mirror allowed the laser cavity to be switched to a high Q configuration for various time delays after the discharge. This study, which combines results from experiments and computer simulations, revealed a short upper laser level lifetime of about 2 μsec. Thus, the lifetime of the upper laser state is too short to account for the delay observed (∼5 msec) in previous experiments on the atomic carbon nuclear-pumped laser.

Title: Efficiency of passive magnetic-confinement methods for rapidly rotating rings
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hull, J.R., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: Rapidly rotating, large-diameter rings have potential for use as low-cost electrical-energy storage devices. The efficiency of passive electromagnetic and electrodynamic methods to confine the rotating rings is investigated. Confinement methods examined include repulsive image force, repulsive null flux, attractive image force, and radially stable attractive. For each method the decay time is given in terms of the ring material properties and design parameters. The repulsive techniques are shown to have decay times of less than a day when optimized within a set of practical design constraints. The two attractive levitation methods result in the largest decay times, but are inherently unstable. When null-flux stabilizers are used with attractive levitation, the decay time is shown to depend on magnetic field inhomogeneity. Finally, an inherently stable and very efficient attractive levitation method is proposed. The new method is based on an analogy with alternating-gradient synchrotrons and should have application in high-speed ground transportation.

Authors: Sasaki K., Kawagishi H., Ishijima Y.
Title: Phase-matched second harmonic generation by a surface polariton along a silver layer on a slab-type optical waveguide
Affiliations: Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi, Yokohama 223, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sasaki, K., Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi, Yokohama 223, Japan; Kawagishi, H., Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi, Yokohama 223, Japan; Ishijima, Y., Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1, Hiyoshi, Yokohama 223, Japan
Abstract: Phase-matched second harmonic generation by a surface-plasmon polariton was observed along a silver layer on a slab-type optical waveguide with a Q-switched neodymium:yttrium aluminum garnet laser (1.064 μm). A numerical analysis previous to the experiment was carried out by a perturbation method employing the conception of coupled modes between surface polariton waves and guided waves. In this case the slab-type optical waveguide played the role of an energy storage layer to realize a longer macroscopic propagation length.

Title: Discharge-pumped gold-vapor laser operating in a low-temperature range using chloroauric acid as a lasant
Affiliations: Department of Electronic Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Iwate University, Ueda 4-3-5, Morioka-shi 020, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Taniguchi, H., Department of Electronic Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Iwate University, Ueda 4-3-5, Morioka-shi 020, Japan; Saito, H., Department of Electronic Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Iwate University, Ueda 4-3-5, Morioka-shi 020, Japan
Abstract: Laser oscillation has been obtained from a discharge-pumped gold vapor at 627.8 nm of a neutral gold atom in a low-temperature range of about 70 -150 °C by using chloroauric acid as a lasant. A laser is operated by successive pulsed discharges of a storage capacitor through a spark-gap switch. Excitation is done in an aperiodic pulse train with a compact device by a boosted-ac (50 Hz) high voltage of up to 5.4 kV rms. A maximum laser peak power of about 1.3 W and a laser-pulse energy of 27 nJ are obtained.

Title: Undulator-wiggler magnets for low energy storage rings
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik B Condensed Matter
Affiliations: Institut für Festkörperforschung der KFA Jülich, Postfach 1913, Julich 1, D-5170, Germany; Berliner Elektronen-Speicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung, Berlin 33, D-1000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gudat, W., Institut für Festkörperforschung der KFA Jülich, Postfach 1913, Julich 1, D-5170, Germany; Pflüger, J., Berliner Elektronen-Speicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung, Berlin 33, D-1000, Germany
Abstract: We briefly review undulators and wigglers (u/w) as radiation sources. We restrict our attention to transverse alternating polarity devices to be used in low energy storage rings, particularly to the case of the 0.8 GeV electron storage ring BESSY in Berlin. We discuss the spectral properties of u/w radiation and some aspects of magnet technology relevant to the construction of such devices. Finally we comment on the application of novel devices offering variable polarization. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Kinetics of hydrogenation of benzene to cyclohexane using the catalysts Co-Mo, Ni-Mo and Ni-W supported on alumina
Affiliations: LEMIGAS R/D Center of Oil and Gas Technology, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Nasution, A.S., LEMIGAS R/D Center of Oil and Gas Technology, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Hydrotreating is an important hydroconversion process to improve the quality of petroleum products by reaction with hydrogen in the presence of a catalyst. The improvement may be in burning quality, reducing air pollution, improving storage stability, and reducing the tendency to deposit gum, and improving odor, color, etc. Burning quality of jet fuel and kerosene can be improved by saturation of aromatic rings to form cycloparaffins. To obtain more information on the saturation of aromatic rings, an experiment has been carried out to study the kinetics of benzene hydrogenation at operating temperatures from 270° to 370°C; pressures, from 10 to 60 kg/cm2, and H2/HC ratios, from 4 to 14 mole/mole with three catalysts: Co-Mo, Ni-Mo and Ni-W supported on alumina by using a Catatest Unit apparatus in a continuous system. Gas and liquid products were analyzed by gas-liquid chromatography. The experimental data show: Reaction rates for benzene hydrogenation to cyclohexane for three hydroconversion catalysts supported on alumina as follows: (equation presented) The activation energy of benzene hydrogenation suggests that the activity of these three hydroconversion catalysts is as follows: Co-Mo/Al2O3 < Ni-Mo/Al2O3 < Ni-W/Al2O3 Reaction order of benzene hydrogenation for three hydroconversion catalysts, i.e. total and partial orders, increase with the catalyst activity but the ratio of partial order between benzene and hydrogen is almost the same, i. e., an average value of about 2.5. This value is close to the stoichiometry of benzene hydrogenation (i. e. 3. 0).

Authors: Creedon J.M., Demeter L.J., Ecker B., Eichenberger C., Glidden S., Helava H., Proulx G.A.
Title: The reflex switch: A new vacuum opening switch for use with magnetic energy storge
Affiliations: Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States
Authors with affiliations: Creedon, J.M., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States; Demeter, L.J., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States; Ecker, B., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States; Eichenberger, C., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States; Glidden, S., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States; Helava, H., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States; Proulx, G.A., Physics International Company, 2700 Merced St., San Leandro, CA 94577, United States
Abstract: A new type of high-power, high-voltage vacuum opening switch is described. This switch has been used in a magnetic energy storage system with a peak current of 340 kA to produce a 2.7-MV pulse with a risetime of ∼15 ns.

Title: ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY FOR EXTENDED ENDURANCE ALKALINE FUEL CELLS.
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sheibley, Dean W., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Space Station design requirements for the energy storage system options dictate long-life (5 yr) and high electrical efficiency. These two requirements have been the primary drivers for the NASA sponsored fuel cell technology advancement program conducted with United Technologies Corporation. Over the last 4 yr, the program has focused upon the development of stable, corrosion-resistant cell components for application in Orbiter-type alkaline fuel cell stacks. Furthermore, the advanced components have contributed to a reduction in cell weight and have the potential to reduce cell cost. NASA plans to incorporate most or all of the improved technology components discussed in this paper into fuel cell stacks to be used in the Space Station program. All of the advanced technology fuel cell components have been incorporated into multicell stacks of up to 6 cells and evaluated for at least 5000 hr. Endurance testing of the Orbiter-size cell stacks has demonstrated long-term performance stability.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL - Corrosion; MATERIALS - Corrosion Resistance; SPACECRAFT - Fuel Cells; ALKALINE FUEL CELLS; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; FUEL CELL STACKS; MULTICELL STACKS; ORBITER-SIZE CELL STACKS; SPACE STATION; FUEL CELLS

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains extended abstracts of 529 papers on various aspects of electrochemistry. The main topics include: electric batteries and their charging, monitoring, control, and corrosion; corrosion effects of acid deposition and corrosion of electronic materials; dielectric and insulating materials for electronic devices, including dielectric films on compound semiconductors, thin film interfaces, and alloy deposition; electrodeposition and industrial electrolytic processes; energy technology with emphasis on novel approaches to energy conversion and storage; luminescence and display materials; high temperature materials; and physical electrochemistry.

Title: ENERGY TRANSPORT AND STORAGE BY CONJUGATING BINARY SOLUTIONS.
Affiliations: Lockheed-Huntsville Engineering, Cent, Huntsville, AL, USA, Lockheed-Huntsville Engineering Cent, Huntsville, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Grodzka, Philomena G., Lockheed-Huntsville Engineering, Cent, Huntsville, AL, USA, Lockheed-Huntsville Engineering Cent, Huntsville, AL, USA
Abstract: Conjugating binary solutions (CBSs) are solutions formed when two essentially immiscible liquids attain a critical solution temperature (CST). The feasibility of using CBSs in a variety of storage and transport applications was evaluated in a number of prior studies. These applications include chill storage for commercial building, dual temperature storage for home heating and cooling, high temperature applications, and spacecraft thermal control. Materials considered for these applications included various pairs of organic or inorganic liquids with water or other solvents, supercritical gases, and molten salts and metals. Dual temperature storage is theoretically possible with systems that either undergo clathration at the lower temperature and CBS at the higher temperature or endothermic phase separation at the lower temperature (closed-loop CBSs). Preliminary technical and economic analyses predict promise for a number of the systems investigated.
Index Keywords: INORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Chemical Reactions; LIQUIDS - Mixing; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Chemical Reactions; SOLUTIONS - Thermodynamic Properties; CLATHRATION; CONJUGATING BINARY SOLUTIONS; CRITICAL SOLUTION TEMPERATURE; DUAL TEMPERATURE STORAGE; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Ravi V., Thacker W., Varol I., Mobley C., Rapp R.
Title: HYPEREUTECTIC HEAT STORAGE SHOT.
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ravi, V., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Thacker, W., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Varol, I., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Mobley, C., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Rapp, R., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: A number of metallic eutectic alloys have been recognized as promising candidates for heat exchange and storage applications. The relatively large entropy change for melting of silicon makes the metal-silicon eutectic systems, such as the aluminum-silicon alloy system, particularly attractive as the phase change materials in packed bed heat exchangers. Selected candidate metal-silicon eutectic alloy systems, their eutectic temperatures, and heat storage capacities are given.

Authors: Kontominas M.G., Gupta C., Gilbert S.G.
Title: Interaction of vinylchloride with polyvinylchloride in model food systems by HPLC-chromatography: Migration aspects
Affiliations: Department of Food Chemistry, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece; Department of Food Science, Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kontominas, M.G., Department of Food Chemistry, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece; Gupta, C., Department of Food Science, Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Gilbert, S.G., Department of Food Science, Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Abstract: The migration of vinylchloride monomer (VCM) from its polymer polyvinylchloride (PVC), has been studied in the past by Inverse Gas Chromatographic techniques (IGC) that employ relatively high temperatures and gas-solid phase systems. In order to simulate actual storage conditions of foods packaged in PVC plastic materials, Inverse High Pressure Liquid chromatography (IHPLC) has been employed in this work at temperatures 8, 18.5, and 27 °C using distilled water as the solvent system. Concentrations of 0.34, 0.48, 0.80, 1.20 and 2.38 μg of VCM/g of unplasticized PVC resin were introduced into the HPLC column containing the PVC resin (stationary phase). The specific retention volume (V °g) of VCM was found to be highly dependent upon both concentration and temperature. V °g increased as the concentration of VCM injected decreased in accordance with the "active site" hypothesis. The thermodynamic parameters namely, enthalpy of sorption (ΔHs), entropy of sorption (ΔSs) and free energy of sorption (ΔGs), were all negative corresponding to a spontaneous exothermic process. The activity coefficient was much smaller then 1 indicating strong attractive forces between polymer and monomer. These results indicate that at very low concentrations of VCM in the PVC packaging material, active site binding is dominating and hence "essentially zero" migration of the monomer from the package into a foodstuff occurs. © 1985.

Title: USING THE PRESSURE-TIME SLOPE TO TERMINATE CHARGING OF NICKEL/HYDROGEN BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bush, Donald, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: A nickel/hydrogen battery for terrestrial applications is being developed Sandia National Laboratories. The goal is to be cost competitive with lead-acid batteries in a system for solar application having a 20-year life requirement. A design entirely different from that for aerospace applications has evolved. A series of tests was run with a six-cell battery in which the charge was terminated for different values of the slope of the pressure-time curve. The results indicate that reducing the amount of overcharge increases the efficiency without a large penalty in capacity. Terminating charge when the pressure slope has reached one-half of its original value results in a coulombic efficiency of over 90% and an energy efficiency of almost 80%.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Efficiency; ELECTRODES - Nickel; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; COULOMBIC EFFICIENCY; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; NICKEL/HYDROGEN BATTERIES; OVERCHARGE; SANDIA NATIONAL LABORATORIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR SOLAR SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kreith, Frank, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; West, R.E., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: This paper presents an overview of various options for thermal energy storage in solar systems. In many applications it is economical to use stratified thermocline sensible heat storage, with the hot fluid stored above the cold fluid in the same tank. Before a full-scale high temperature sensible heat stratified storage system can be built with confidence, additional design information needs to be obtained by further R & D. The paper concludes by outlining the steps necessary to obtain the information required for the engineering design of high temperature sensible heat storage systems.
Index Keywords: LIQUIDS - Heat Transfer; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE; STRATIFIED STORAGE SYSTEM; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; THERMOCLINE SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Performance of laser dye solutions under high signal fluxes: An analysis of signal propagation and excited-state energy extraction in mobile and rigid media
Affiliations: 1939 Neptune Road, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hammond, P.R., 1939 Neptune Road, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: As a continuous-wave signal builds up in an energized laser dye solution, the lifetimes for the excited state of the molecules become shorter than their orientational relaxation time. Physical consequences of the phenomomenon are considered for two extreme situations - transmission through pure mobile and pure rigid media continua, respectively. The dye is treated as a linear oscillator and spectral properties are assumed to be unchanged between the media. Two problems are examined, namely signal propagation and the extraction of energy at a point in the medium for a number of configurations of pump and signal polarizations, transverse or longitudinal excitations. Signal gradients and steady-state conversion efficiencies are presented algebraically and graphically. A mobile medium has one of the steepest gradients, the largest energy storage, and one of the highest conversion efficiencies. Nevertheless, performance of a transversely excited, single-pass amplifier for the commonly used configuration where pump and signal are plane polarized and have a shared polarization axis (Configuration C) shows little difference between rigid or mobile media, according to this analysis. For a rigid Configuration C, only about 21% of the dye molecules carry most of the signal load, in contrast with a mobile medium where all molecules work equally, and such a restricted distribution undergoes rapid turnover of its excited state. Twisting of the signal plane of polarization in a dye amplifier is confirmed.

Title: Magneto-optic recording technology (invited)
Affiliations: Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kryder, M.H., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: Magneto-optic recording has great potential as an erasable/rewritable storage technology. Bit densities of 108/cm2 are being achieved and improvements can be expected. This paper reviews the status and discusses the most critical issues of the technology. It is shown that the fundamental broadband signal-to-noise ratio in existing rare-earth transition-metal media is well above 20 dB and therefore adequate to maintain error rates less than 10-12. Substrate imperfections in optical media lead to error rates of 10- 5-10-6, but even these relatively high raw bit error rates are corrected to 10-13 by error correction codes and hardware being used in write-once optical disk storage systems. The stability of magnetic domains recorded into magneto-optical materials may be explained by a model involving wall energy, demagnetizing fields, applied fields and wall coercivity, and there exist materials which fulfill the requirements necessary to have recorded data remain stable against fields up to 100 Oe and temperatures from 0 to 100 °C. Of more concern is the stability of the amorphous thin films against long-term annealing. Passivation with optical dielectrics is essential, and preliminary data on some rare-earth transition-metal alloys indicate that recorded data would be stable for five years when stored at 50 °C and that the media could withstand in excess of 1010 write/erase cycles with less that 10% change in minimum stable domain size. It is concluded that magneto-optic recording technology is a promising high-density recording technology with a place in the digital storage hierarchies of the future.

Title: Myopathies due to enzyme deficiencies
Affiliations: Neuromuscular Research Centre, Istituto Neurologico 'C. Besta', via Celoria 11, Milan, 20133, Italy; Laboratory of Neurometabolic Diseases, Istituto Neurologico 'C. Besta', via Celoria 11, Milan, 20133, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cornelio, F., Neuromuscular Research Centre, Istituto Neurologico 'C. Besta', via Celoria 11, Milan, 20133, Italy; DiDonato, S., Laboratory of Neurometabolic Diseases, Istituto Neurologico 'C. Besta', via Celoria 11, Milan, 20133, Italy
Abstract: After the discovery in 1959 of myophosphorylase deficiency, at least 15 myopathies due to deficiency of enzymes involved in energy substrate utilization have been described. In this review two main categories of enzymopathies, glycogenosis and mitochondrial disorders, are discussed. Clinically, the patients with these categories of enzyme defects present two major syndromes: (a) acute recurrent muscle impairment, generally related to exercise, associated with cramps and/or myoglobinuria; (b) progressive muscular weakness and wasting eventually associated with signs of affected organs other than skeletal muscle. Defects of glycogen breakdown and of the first step of glycolysis are more frequently associated with acute exercise intolerance, such as in myophosphorylase and phosphofructokinase deficiencies, but may be associated with progressive muscle weakness and wasting, such as in acid maltase and debrancher enzyme deficiency. Clinical heterogeneity is common in these disorders, but a biochemical explanation for their different clinical expression is still lacking. Defects of the second step of glycolysis, phosphoglycerate kinase, phosphoglycerate mutase and lactate dehydrogenase deficiencies, have been discovered recently and are associated with exercise intolerance. The reason for muscle weakness and atrophy in glycogenosis is still unclear, although it has been suggested that excessive protein catabolism occurs in myophosphorylase, debrancher and acid maltase deficiencies. Myopathies due to deficiencies of mitochondrial enzymes are less well defined, as a group, than the glycogenoses. They are currently considered to fall into three main groups: (a) defects of substrate utilization, such as carnitine palmitoyltransferase deficiency; (b) defects of respiratory chain complexes, such as cytochrome-c-oxidase deficiency and (c) defects of phosphorylation-respiration coupling, such as Luft's disease. Again, severe and benign exercise intolerance or progressive life-threatening myopathic syndromes may be the clinical expression of these disorders. Detailed biochemical and morphological studies of muscle biopsies are needed in these patients to obtain a definite diagnosis and prognosis, and to decide on eventual treatment. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: carnitine palmitoyltransferase; cytochrome c oxidase; etiology; glucan 1,4 alpha glucosidase deficiency; glycogen storage disease type 3; glycogen storage disease type 5; heredity; human; mitochondrial myopathy; muscle; phosphofructokinase deficiency; priority journal; review; Adult; Carnitine; Carnitine O-Palmitoyltransferase; Enzymes; Female; Glucan 1,4-alpha-Glucosidase; Glycogen Storage Disease; Glycogen Storage Disease Type III; Glycogen Storage Disease Type V; Human; Metabolic Diseases; Mitochondria, Muscle; Muscles; Muscular Diseases; Oxygen Consumption; Phosphofructokinase-1; Phosphorylation; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Title: Glucose transport in adipocytes and its regulation by insulin
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kono, T., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States
Abstract: Several lines of recent evidence indicate that in the absence of insulin glucose transport activity in the basal form of adipocytes is mostly associated with certain itracellular vesicles, and that the function of insulin is to translocate the glucose transport activity from the intracellular storage site to the plasma membrane. Upon sucrose density gradient centrifugation, the two subcellular structures associated with the glucose transport activity were fractionated into the plasma membrane-rich and Golgi-rich fractions. In our laboratory, the glucose transport activity in the subcellular fractions was assayed after reconstruction into egg lecithin liposomes. The apparent translocation of the glucose transport activity from the storage site to the plasma membrane was reversible, energy dependent, protein synthesis independent, almost completed in 5-10 min at 37°C when the hormone concentration was 1 nM, and very slow at a low temperature (for example 15°C). These results are consistent with the hypothesis that insulin regulates glucose transport activity in adipocytes by causing translocation of the glucose transport apparatus in a reversible manner, and that the translocation, or recyclng, of the glucose transport apparatus is brought about by exo- and endo-cytosis.

Title: SEQUENTIAL COMMUTATION DEVICE WITH REGENERATIVE STORED-ENERGY TAKEOFF.
Authors with affiliations: Bulatov, O.G.; Shitov, V.A.
Abstract: A circuit is proposed for a sequential commutation device in which recovery of the energy stored in the commutation loop reduces the increase in voltage across the capacitor. Three operating regimes of the commutation device are considered. Commutation-process calculations are used to determine the duration of the regeneration interval. Converter circuits are shown that make use of the proposed commutation device; an analog model of the device is also shown.

Title: THERMALLY STIMULATED CURRENT BEHAVIOUR OF POLYVINYLIDENE FLUORIDE FILMS ON THERMOMAGNETIC TREATMENT.
Affiliations: Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India, Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhatnagar, C.S., Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India, Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India; Khare, M.L., Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India, Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India; Meenakshi, G., Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India, Maulana Azad Coll of Technology, Bhopal, India
Abstract: Thermally stimulated discharge current (TSDC) in the case of polyvinylidene fluoride film treated thermomagnetically has been studied at different linear heating rates. Samples were prepared at various polarizing fields (H//F ) and temperatures (T//F ). TSDC spectra consist of two peaks at different temperatures: 1) 60 degree to 70 degree and 2) 190 degree to 195 degree , termed as alpha - and rho -peaks respectively. The values of activation energy were calculated by two different methods, and the existence of two types of traps was revealed. TSDC with different heating rates suggests that low heating rates are preferable. The effect of thickness and storage time was also studied. 19 refs.

Title: U plus U COLLISIONS NEAR THE COULOMB BARRIER BY CROSSING TWO CO-CIRCULATING BEAMS.
Affiliations: Gesellschaft fuer, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt,, West Ger, Gesellschaft fuer Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Franzke, B., Gesellschaft fuer, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt,, West Ger, Gesellschaft fuer Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, West Ger; Schmelzer, Ch., Gesellschaft fuer, Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt,, West Ger, Gesellschaft fuer Schwerionenforschung mbH, Darmstadt, West Ger
Abstract: Experiments with colliding heavy-ion beams seem to become feasibile by means of beam cooling techniques. The authors consider, in particular, an alternative to the use of two intersecting storage rings: crossing of two high energy beams cocirculating in one single ring, e. g. in the experiment storage ring (ESR), on separate closed orbits due to their different magnetic rigidity. Low-energy collisions near the Coulomb barrier between two heavy nuclei both highly or even fully ionized or, more generally, systems not accessible to fixed-target experiments could be investigated. Estimates for the attainable collision energy, energy resolution and luminosity are given together with a tentative outlook on the experimental arrangement.
Index Keywords: ION BEAMS; BEAM COOLING; COULOMB BARRIER; EXPERIMENT STORAGE RING; ACCELERATORS

Title: MATCHING A SOLAR BATTERY WITH A BUFFER STORAGE BATTERY IN AN AUTONOMOUS PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Doroshenko, V.G.; Semenko, E.A.
Abstract: The effect of PV operating temperature and illumination on a solar battery's (SB) energy output is shown, and also the effect of a storage battery's operating voltage as it changes from the SB. An attempt is made to evaluate possible losses of SB energy output which arise when it is designed according to averaged load characteristics of PSS subsystems and the advisability of using, in connection with this, functional dependences of the parameters. The volt-ampere characteristics (VAC) of an SB are described, taking into account changes in its temperature and illumination. It is shown that the use of average-time parameters of a PV system in designing it can appreciably reduce the potential energy output of PV cells which make up a nonconstant-temperature SB.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; SOLAR CELLS; POWER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Title: PERFORMANCE CHARACTERISTICS OF CONVENTIONAL X-RAY GENERATOR, ISOTOPE SOURCE AND HIGH ENERGY ACCELERATOR IN ROCKET MOTOR EVALUATION.
Affiliations: SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India, SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India
Authors with affiliations: Viswanathan, K., SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India, SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India; Rao, Venkata K., SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India, SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India; Subbaiah, C., SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India, SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India; Uttam, M.C., SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India, SHAR Cent, Sriharikota, India
Abstract: Induced load during handling and transportation and normal aging during extended storage may lead to flaws in a solid motor. During the operation of the motor, these defects generate additional burning surface for the advancing flame front. Thus, the burning inside the defect will affect the performance of the rocket motor and under certain conditions it may lead to its failure. Radiography is the most useful NDT method to detect these defects. It is applied to the inspection of rocket motor cases, insulated hardware, nozzles and fully assembled motor. This paper deals with radiographic procedures/techniques used for the inspection of solid rocket motors, nozzles and igniters using different X-ray sources such as conventional X-ray machines, Cobalt-60 and high energy radiographic accelerator.

Abstract: Performance of a 2. 4m long by 1. 8m wide by 1. 2m high rockbed thermal storage module designed to provide sensibly cooled ventilation air for 8000 mature broilers during hot weather was evaluated. The module was capable of providing air sensibly cooled below ambient for 6. 5 hours or longer. Module dimensions were determined from simulation of summer brooding conditions with a two-phase finite difference model of the rockbed.

Abstract: Electron beam testing of passivated integrated circuits (IC) seems to be possible without any time consuming technological preparation and without radiation damage by application of the capacitive coupling voltage contrast. This effect occurs when operating at low primary energies with an electron yield of the passivation greater than 1. Then changes of signals at the covered conductor tracks can be detected within a typical storage time. This storage time depends on parameters of electron irradiation, of passivation and of voltages applied to the IC. The experimentally found dependences are described in a physical model and theoretical values of storage times evaluated by computer simulations agree with those determined by experiment.

Title: INTERIM COST STUDY OF A TERRESTRIAL HYDROGEN/NICKEL OXIDE BATTERY.
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Burant, Leonard J., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI, USA; Gentry, William O., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Abstract: A study of cost reduction is presented on a life-cycle basis for the hydrogen/nickel oxide batery to be competitive with the lead/acid battery without negatively impacting performance. The approach taken was to extend the manufacturing technology of the low cost, mass produced lead/acid battery to the assembly of the hydrogen/nickel oxide battery while, at the same time, research went forward on reducing the material and process costs of its components. Six-cell, 1-kWh hydrogen/nickel oxide modules have been fabricated and a conceptual design for a 15-kWh battery has been made. An interim cost study confirms the technical and economic suitability of the hydrogen/nickel oxide battery as the storage medium for terrestrial photovoltaic electricity.

Abstract: A new, high capacity withdrawal gate employing a mass flow pattern, controllable flow rate, low energy consumption, and reduced space requirement is presented. The bulk material parameters and analytical methods used for predicting the gate flow rate are given as well as the field performance of the gate at coal silo installations. In one application, the center outlet of a coal silo with seven outlets was refitted with the variable-flow rate gate. The variable-flow rate gate permitted total silo withdrawal to be generated and controlled through the one center outlet with the perimeter feeders activated only for clean-out purposes.

Abstract: A number of attractive options are available for the space station power system. These include a photovoltaic system or solar dynamic system for power generation, batteries or fuel cells for energy storage, and ac or dc for power management and distribution. These options are explored in the present preliminary design and definition phase of the space station program. The major issues for power management and distribution are system voltage and distribution system frequency. All of the issues are addressed during the present phase of the program.

Abstract: Summary form only given. A long-pulse XeCl laser is described based on a magnetically induced pulser laser excitation scheme recently developed by the authors. By choosing correctly the dc-charging voltage, capacitance, and laser gas mix, 600-ns duration discharges have been achieved. Optical pulses with 350-ns duration and energies of 100 mJ as well as pulses with energies of 280 mJ and pulse durations of 240 ns have been obtained. The efficiencies based on the energy stored on the dc-charged capacitors were 2. 1 and 2. 6%, respectively.

Abstract: The simulation code presented in this paper, SESAM-DCS ('Solar Energy System Analysis Model for Distributed Collector Systems'), is a detailed simulation model of the DCS plant in Almeria, in southern Spain. The code has been used as a tool during the evaluation of the plant and also for studying possible hardware improvements. The code has shown its ability to realisticly simulate the behaviour of a relatively complicated system. The simulated plant consists of three collector fields, two storage tanks and a power conversion system.

Authors with affiliations: Mitani, Y., Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn; Tsuji, K., Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn; Ise, T., Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn; Murakami, Y., Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn
Abstract: This paper summarizes the results of an investigation concerning electrical power network stabilization using superconducting magnet energy storage (SMES), and provides information useful for designing magnets for electrical power system stabilization. The major results are as follows: 1) Experimental results of simultaneous control of active and reactive power using two sets of 16 KVA GTO converter bridges, a 500 KJ superconducting magnet and a microcomputer based controller, confirmed that the characteristics of SMES in electrical power systems can be represented by an independent, first order time lag for P and Q control. 2) The results of simulation of stabilization control using SMES are presented for a power system with longitudinal interconnected structure. 3) It was shown that the tradeoffs between the MVA capacity, the MJ capacity and the maximum dB/dt of SMES are required to achieve stabilization for a given power system, can be obtained by specifying the waveforms of P and Q control that are effective for stabilization.

Title: CURL-SETTING DURING STORAGE OF THERMOMECHANICAL PULP AT HIGH CONSISTENCY.
Source title: Pulping Conference, Proceedings of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry
Affiliations: Pulp & Paper Research Inst of, Canada, Pointe Claire, Que, Can, Pulp & Paper Research Inst of Canada, Pointe Claire, Que, Can

Abstract: The effect of storing hot thermomechanical pulp at high consistency directly after the refiners has been investigated. Experiments showed that the latency took several times as long to remove in a disintegrator after the pulp had been stored. Pulp stored above 65 degree C also developed a residual latency which could not be removed even after a long period of disintegration. The residual latency was attributed to curl-setting in the fibres. It was usually accompanied by a loss in brightness which was attributed to accelerated ageing of the pulp. An activation energy was derived for the changes in pulp properties, which may allow the effects of storage under any conditions to be predicted.
Index Keywords: 100 C. STORAGE EFFECTS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; CURL-SETTING; DISINTEGRATION TIME; PULP CONSISTENCIES; RESIDUAL LATENCY; PULP

Title: GENERALIZED WASTE PACKAGE CONTAINMENT MODEL.
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Liebetrau, A.M., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Apted, M.J., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) is developing a performance assessment strategy to demonstrate compliance with standards and technical requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) for the permanent disposal of high-level nuclear wastes in geologic repositories. One aspect of this strategy is the development of a unified performance model of the entire geologic repository system. Details of a generalized waste package containment (WPC) model and its relationship with other components of an overall repository model are presented in this paper. The WPC model provides stochastically determined estimates of the distributions of times-to-failure of the barriers of a waste package by various corrosion mechanisms and degradation processes. The model consists of a series of modules which employ various combinations of stochastic (probabilistic) and mechanistic process models, and which are individually designed to reflect the current state of knowledge.

Authors with affiliations: Rhodes, Suzanne H., Governor's Div of Energy Policy,, Columbia, SC, USA, Governor's Div of Energy Policy, Columbia, SC, USA
Abstract: The Department of Energy describes the Monitored Retrievable Storage facilities as a staging area for the high-level nuclear waste repositories. What is being proposed is unnecessary to repository operations and is at this time inappropriate to the mandate of the Civilian Radioactive Waste Management Office. Utilities have been charged with the responsibility for storing spent fuel, and are making significant progress. The DOE should focus its attention on establishing a suitable repository, as required by law.

Abstract: Solid-state phase-change materials (SS PCMs) exhibit reversible, energetic changes in their crystal structures at temperatures well below their melting points. Characteristics of some of the more promising materials are listed.

Abstract: This lecture considers double-diffusive systems which are characterized by two (or more) gradients that promote the transport of two (or more) quantities by diffusion in the same or opposite direction. The paper also reviews qualitative and quantitative observations of fluid motions in two component systems in which the density of the fluid depends not only on the temperature but also on the concentration. The flow phenomena occurring in double-diffusive systems are described, and engineering applications are identified and discussed. Reference is made to existing reviews in other fields, such as metallurgy, oceanography and geology. Experimental and theoretical studies recently completed in our laboratory in connection with energy storage in solar ponds are reviewed and modeling of salt-stratified thermohaline solutions heated from below is discussed.

Authors with affiliations: Myrick, T.E., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Coobs, J.H., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: The Surplus Facilities Management Program (SFMP) at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) is part of the Department of Energy's (DOE) National SFMP, administered by the Richland Operations Office. This program was established to provide for the management of certain DOE surplus radioactively contaminated facilities from the end of their operating life until final facility disposition is completed. As part of this program, the ORNL SFMP oversees some 75 facilities, ranging in complexity from abandoned waste storage tanks to large experimental reactors. This paper describes the scope of the ORNL program and outlines the decommissioning activities currently underway, including a brief description of the decontamination techniques being utilized.

Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)

Abstract: A method is suggested for calculating the nonsteady-state temperature field in a thermal storage system which is used to maintain the optimum regime in a silkworm-breeding room.

Title: USE OF EXHAUST GASES FOR THE GENERATION OF COLD IN TRANSPORT STORAGE ROOMS.
Affiliations: Hochschule fuer Verkehrswesen, 'Friedrich List' Dresden, East Ger, Hochschule fuer Verkehrswesen 'Friedrich List' Dresden, East Ger
Authors with affiliations: Henatsch, A., Hochschule fuer Verkehrswesen, 'Friedrich List' Dresden, East Ger, Hochschule fuer Verkehrswesen 'Friedrich List' Dresden, East Ger; Metz, S., Hochschule fuer Verkehrswesen, 'Friedrich List' Dresden, East Ger, Hochschule fuer Verkehrswesen 'Friedrich List' Dresden, East Ger
Abstract: Exhaust gases of internal combustion engines could be utilized, for example the generation of additional 'cold' with a coupled RANKINE vapor refrigerating machine cycle in transport storage rooms, as it is explained in the article. An improvement of the total energy conversion and savings of costly primary energy in extreme load cases should be of some more important results if 'cold' generated from exhaust gases completely corresponded to the designed 'reserve capacity'. The coupling cycle is described in the article and the results of the thermodynamic calculation are presented. Cooling curves of a 4-axle mechanical refrigerated wagon without additional refrigeration capacity from exhaust gases is shown. 1 ref.
Index Keywords: CARS - Refrigerator; CONTAINERS - Refrigerated; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Absorption; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; COOLING CURVES; COUPLING CYCLE; RANKINE CYCLE; RECUPERATOR; RESERVE CAPACITY; TRANSPORT STORAGE ROOMS; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES

Title: CONVECTIVE FLOW IN A STABLY STRATIFIED ENVIRONMENT.
Affiliations: Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jaluria, Yogesh, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
Abstract: This paper discusses the basic considerations relevant to convective flow in a stably stratified environment. The conditions for a stratification to be stable are considered first, leading to the limiting circumstance of adiabatic stratification. Similarity solutions for buoyancy-driven flows in stratified media are considered in detail, in order to discuss the underlying physical mechanisms. The nature of the resulting flow and of the associated thermal field is discussed and related to the effect of stratification on the local buoyancy level. The decay of a given stratification with time due to diffusion and heat loss is discussed. The rise of thermal plumes and buoyant jets in a stratified environment is considered in detail. Buoyancy-driven flows in enclosed regions of stratified fluids are important in heat rejection, energy storage and enclosure fires. This flow circumstance is discussed, along with penetrative convection that arises in certain practical problems.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS; CONVECTIVE FLOW; THERMAL STRATIFICATION; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: HYDRATED INORGANIC SALTS AS PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS FOR PASSIVE ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA, NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Struble, L., NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA, NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA; Brown, P., NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA, NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Abstract: A number of hydrated inorganic salts have been studied to assess their potential as phase change materials for passive solar energy storage. The salts fall in the general class of Candlot's salt, a calcium aluminum hydroxide sulfate hydrate. These salts undergo partial dehydration at temperatures below 100 degree C, a phase change that offers potential for passive energy storage. The materials appear to offer other advantages, including low cost, low flammability, low toxicity, and convenient incorporation into a cement-based system. This report describes the synthesis, characterization, and thermal properties of four candidate materials.
Index Keywords: INORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Thermodynamic Properties; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; CALCIUM ALUMINUM HYDROXIDE SULFATE; CANDLOT'S SALT; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; HYDRATED INORGANIC SALTS; PASSIVE ENERGY STORAGE; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; SALTS

Authors with affiliations: Nishina, H., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Takakura, T., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Using two kinds of phase change materials (PCMs), two experiments of solar-heating were carried out in a greenhouse with floor area of 352m**2 in the winters of 1983 and 1984. As the results, the inside air temperature was almost kept above the set point (8 degree C) without use of auxiliary heating systems in the experiment where the PCM of 2,500kg with a melting point about 20 degree C was used. In the case of the experiment where the PCM of 1,800kg with a melting point about 15 degree C was used, it was estimated that approximately seventy-five percent of oil consumption was saved.

Title: PREDICTING LIFE OF ELECTRIC VEHICLE AND LOAD-LEVELLING LEAD ACID BATTERIES FROM INITIAL ACCEPTANCE TEST DATA BY USE OF PATTERN RECOGNITION ANALYSIS.

Authors with affiliations: Perone, Sam P., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Spindler, William C., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: A novel approach to battery lifetime prediction was applied to life-cycling data for 108 ESB EV-106 6V golf cart batteries (tests conducted by TRW for NASA-Lewis). Computerized pattern recognition methods were used to examine initial cycling measurements and to classify individual batteries into 'long-lived' or 'short-lived' classes with greater than 85% accuracy. The results of this study were used to formulate a fabrication and test program for 340 GNB lead-acid cells in a 500 kWh load-levelling battery to be tested at the Battery Energy Storage Test Facility. Preliminary observations on initial test data are reported here.

Abstract: The Department of Industrial Chemistry was created as one of the departments in the College of Science & Engineering. The laboratory of industrial electrochemistry has been actively involved in the basic and engineering fields of electrochemistry, inorganic synthesis, conversion and storage of chemical energy, and metallic corrosion and protection. Recent research in the following fields is briefly described: reaction mechanisms in primary and secondary batteries and development of high energy batteries; development of new systems of industrial electrolysis; electrochemical problems relating to new or future energy systems; metallic corrosion and its prevention, and application of electrochemical processes to environmental chemistry.

Title: SORGHUMS FOR METHANE PRODUCTION.
Affiliations: Texas A&M, TX, USA, Texas A&M, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hiler, Edward A., Texas A&M, TX, USA, Texas A&M, TX, USA; Isaacson, H.Ronald, Texas A&M, TX, USA, Texas A&M, TX, USA
Abstract: This paper provides a summary of first-year research activities in the sorghums-for-methane program sponsored by Gas Research Institute (GRI) and cofunded by Texas Agricultural Experiment Station (TAES). The overall objective of this research is to develop an integrated system for methane production utilizing high-energy sorghum as the feedstock. Researchers in the program include plant breeders, sorghum physiologists, agronomists, agricultural and systems engineers, and agricultural economists. Major research emphases are genetic manipulation, physiology and production systems; harvesting, storage, processing and conversion systems; and economic and systems analyses. First-year results indicate that (1) the proposed sorghum-methane system is in the realm of economic feasibility, (2) research emphases in storage and high-efficiency conversion are critical to the economic implementation of the system, and (3) an improved economic situation can be realized if it is feasible to harvest the grain and vegetative material for separate purposes, food and energy.

Abstract: This report includes the summary of a solar system which has been designed to store the solar energy collected through a passive/active system once in concrete floors and operation results of the system in winter time. The object of this plan is to save energy for the sake of residence groups located on the Pacific side in Tohoku District, where the quantity of solar radiation is comparatively rich even in winter time, and the effect of thermal storage/radiation floors made of concrete was measured by applying these floors principally to a dormitory where heating is essential in night time.

Title: COMPARISON OF LAND AND OCEAN DISPOSAL ALTERNATIVES FOR BULK WASTES CONTAINING NATURALLY OCCURRING RADIONUCLIDES.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stull, E.A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA; Merry-Libby, P., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: Land and ocean disposal alternatives for a large volume of wastes and residues containing naturally occurring radionuclides are assessed. These wastes and residues are currently stored at the U. S. Department of Energy's Niagara Falls Storage Site near Lewiston, New York. The land and ocean disposal alternatives share similar engineering considerations, occupational and transportation risks, and radiological risks. Impacts from placement of the wastes in the ocean would be negligible. However, the land-based activities required to transport the wastes to the ocean would account for most of the potential impacts associated with the ocean disposal alternatives. Thus, the land and ocean disposal alternatives are comparable in terms of potential environmental impacts.
Index Keywords: NUCLIDES - Radioactive; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; WASTE DISPOSAL - Research; LAND DISPOSAL; NATURALLY OCCURRING RADIONUCLIDES; NIAGARA FALLS STORAGE SITE (NFSS); OCEAN DISPOSAL; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Abstract: A simulation model to examine the thermal behavior of a greenhouse equipped with underground heat storage units was developed. During the daytime inside air is circulated through pipes buried in the soil and thus the excessive heat is stored in the soil. At night inside air is circulated again to release heat. With the simulation model the effects of pipe pitch and depth and methods of operation of fans for circulating the air on the inside air temperature were studied.

Abstract: An application of a unique latent heat thermal energy storage/heat pump system using spherical capsules to a solar system is presented in this paper. It is shown that the supercooling of the phase change material can be resolved through the aid of a heat pump. The effects of variation of various parameters, such as flow rate, collector number, ambient temperature, and the capsule diameter, etc. on the thermal performance are clarified in detail.

Abstract: A solar desiccant cooling system using a rotary desiccant wheel was developed and in June, 1983, it was set up, as a part of the energy research in Tokai University, by Sanyo Electric Co. , Ltd. in cooperation with Tokai University at the Marine Research Station of Tokai University in Iriomote Island of Okinawa Prefecture. The climate of Iriomote Island is subtropical. At this research station, cooling machines were driven by an independent power plant using a diesel engine. A reduction of the fossil fuel and peak cut of the power load is objective of this solar desiccant cooling system. This system consists of evacuated glass tube solar collectors, a storage tank, a desiccant cooling unit and a hot water tank. This paper describes the performance of the system and the desiccant cooling unit.

Abstract: The Department of Energy is constructing the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) in Southeastern New Mexico. Abstract: The Department of Energy is currently evaluating the need for and feasibility of a Monitored Retrievable Storage facility (MRS) as an integral part of the nuclear waste management system. The results of this investigation, with accompanying recommendations, will be provided to the Congress of the United States for their consideration. As part of the evaluation of the integral MRS facility an assessment of the impacts to the waste management system are being studied. Abstract: This paper describes the concept of a chemical heat pump-storage system for comfort heating and cooling. The storage capability is implemented with the working fluid of the heat pump cycle, i. e. an ammoniated complex compound. The design allows for a heat and chill storage capacity of six to eight hours of medium load. It can be used as load leveling device during the peak power demand period from 10 a. m. to 6 p. m. The coefficient of performance and load leveling predictions are based on the results of a subscale prototype using ammonia and sodium bromide as the working fluid pair. This complex consists of a solid adsorbent and a gaseous adsorbate.

Abstract: This paper presents a state-of-the-art methodology of on-line input output curve identification based on the sequential regression technique implemented at the Energy Control Center of the Southern California Edison Company. Abstract: This paper reports the experimental results of the performance evaluation of direct gain systems using a twin-type test house. Bricks or water is used as heat storage material. Before starting the experiment, it was confirmed that the two test rooms had the same degree of air-tightness and the same daily temperature profile. For purpose of our investigation, one test room usually had a brick floor with a depth of 30 cm as a reference, while the other room had various types of direct gain systems. After measurement of such things as the temperature at various points and the amount of solar radiation over a period of two to three weeks, the effect of factors such as the depth of the bricks, the surface area of the bricks in contact with room air, the carpet covering the brick floor, etc. , on the room temperature profiles was evaluated by examining the two factors, the daily mean room temperature based on outdoor temperature and the width of room temperature swing.

Abstract: A simple method for calculating monthly useful solar energy of solar water heating systems is described in this paper. The method proposed is to estimate monthly useful solar energy of a solar water heating system in question, as the product of solar heat collection of a collector with inlet temperature equal to city water temperature and a system factor associated with the characteristics of the system such as heat capacity and heat loss of the storage tank, the pattern of hot water use and water heating load. Example calculations show that annual values of useful solar energy estimated by the simple method proposed in this paper agreed with those calculated by computer simulation within the error of plus or minus 10%. The difference of 10% in annual useful solar energy between estimated and simulated may be allowed in practical design of solar water heating systems.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HOT WATER USE; USEFUL SOLAR ENERGY; WATER HEATERS

Abstract: A new two layer energy storage solenoid is presented as a replacement for the recent two layer radially rippled Wisconsin design. An inner and an outer layer of turns wound inside and outside a cylindrical structure are simply mounted because of the large attractive force between layers. The cylindrical structure reacts axial forces and, by tapering together at the ends, provides a good mounting surface for end turns. Rippled and unrippled solenoids designs are discussed. Magnetic and mechanical design are given for the newest design which is rippled axially.

Authors: Joosten A.P.B., Arnold C.P., Arrillaga J.
Title: STATE VARIABLE DEPENDENCE IN STATE SPACE ANALYSIS OF ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: New Zealand Electricity, NZ, New Zealand Electricity, NZ
Authors with affiliations: Joosten, A.P.B., New Zealand Electricity, NZ, New Zealand Electricity, NZ; Arnold, C.P., New Zealand Electricity, NZ, New Zealand Electricity, NZ; Arrillaga, J., New Zealand Electricity, NZ, New Zealand Electricity, NZ
Abstract: State space analysis is widely used in the simulation of electric power systems, particularly when non-sinusoidal waveforms and time varying and/or nonlinear parameters are involved. This method has been used to investigate the behavior of h. v. d. c. converters. The state space technique demands that the space variables which describe the electric power system must be independent. A convenient choice of state variables is the electric charge of capacitors and the magnetic flux within inductors, which gives a direct correspondence between the energy storage elements of the physical system and the state variables of the mathematical model. However, this choice does not guarantee variable independence and for complex systems, variable dependence may not be apparent when assembling the equations. Equations describing electric power systems are developed. It is shown that when the network equations are organized using nodal analysis, all state variables describing electric charge are independent.
Index Keywords: NODAL ANALYSIS; STATE SPACE ANALYSIS; STATE VARIABLE; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: X-RAY PHOTOSWITCHING OF 1-J EXCIMER LASER.
Affiliations: Lab de Marcoussis, Fr, Lab de Marcoussis, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Vannier, C., Lab de Marcoussis, Fr, Lab de Marcoussis, Fr
Abstract: Summary form only given. A new laser device resulting from the combination of X-ray preionization and preionization switching has been constructed and tested. It consists of a low-inductance laser head connected directly to two energy storage water lines. A compact X-ray gun is located inside the inner volume of the cathode. It has a characteristic impedance of 15 OMEGA and incorporates a Soller slits spatial filter to avoid X-ray irradiation outside the 4- multiplied by 4- multiplied by 72-cm**3 discharge volume. Several X-ray gun electrical feeding circuits have been tested. The measured variations of the laser energy and efficiency as a function of X-ray rise time and intensity are presented.
Index Keywords: X-RAY TUBES - Performance; X-RAYS - Applications; PREIONIZATION SWITCHING; X-RAY GUN FEEDING CIRCUITS; X-RAY PREIONIZATION; LASERS, EXCIMER

Title: ADAPTIVE FINITE ELEMENT APPROACH TO A PLATE PROBLEM.
Affiliations: Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Rank, E., Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: A general problem in finite element analysis is the design of optimal FE-meshes, which should be fine enough to produce sufficient accuracy. At the same time too large a number of elements has to be avoided in view of computer time and storage requirements. Therefore an optimal mesh should be graded according to a uniform error distribution. As the error can hardly be predicted by the data, the finite element solution itself should provide some information on the magnitude and distribution of the error. These a-posteriori-estimates have been put on a reliable mathematical foundation for a class of bilinear forms by Babuska et al. in the energy norm. Computer error estimators for the magnitude and error indicators for the distribution of the error have been obtained for some one-dimensional problems and for the problem of plain strain and plane stress. In this paper the general theory of Babuska is applied to plate-problems according to Mindlin's plate theory. In contrast to Kirchoff's theory shear forces are considered. Thus, better results near corners are obtained and, furthermore, thick plates can be treated. For quadrilateral elements an error indicator is derived, which is composed of element residuals and of the jumps of bending moments and shear forces across element edges.
Index Keywords: PLATES - Stresses; STRESSES - Shear; ABSTRACT ONLY; ERROR ESTIMATORS; POSTER PAPER; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES

Title: US SOLAR THERMAL RESEARCH PROGRAMME.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This article reports on the latest solar thermal research which appeared in In Review, a research update from America's Solar Energy Research Institute (SERI). The Solar Thermal Research Program, managed by SERI, has conducted basic amd applied research in materials, thermal sciences, chemical sciences, and engineering analysis needed to provide the knowledge base for new technology. Notable results in the materials research area include progress toward development of polymer-based mirrors for solar application, understanding of the mechanisms that affect silver/glass mirror lifetime, development of high-temperature fluids, and development of high-temperature optical and containment materials for solar receivers. Thermal sciences research has included high-temperature heat-transfer research, air and liquid receiver concept studies, and storage research. In engineering analysis and research, concepts for low-cost heliostats were evaluated and definitive recommendations made to pursue the stretched membrane heliostat concepts based on scaled membrane evaluation in the laboratory.
Index Keywords: ELECTROCHEMISTRY - Research; HEAT TRANSFER - High Temperature Effects; MATERIALS SCIENCE - Research; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; SOLAR ENERGY RESEARCH INSTITUTE (SERI); SOLAR ENERGY

Title: INTERCALATION COMPOUNDS.
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Material
Affiliations: Schlumberger-Doll Research, Rock, Science Dep, Ridgefield, CT, USA, Schlumberger-Doll Research, Rock Science Dep, Ridgefield, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Whittingham, M.Stanley, Schlumberger-Doll Research, Rock, Science Dep, Ridgefield, CT, USA, Schlumberger-Doll Research, Rock Science Dep, Ridgefield, CT, USA
Abstract: Many inorganic and organic structures can react with atoms or molecules without substantial modification of their crystalline structures. In many cases these reactions are totally reversible and occur with a large evolution of energy allowing their use in energy storage devices. In other cases the reactions occur with color changes forming the foundation of electrochromic displays. These absorptive reactions also lead to the swelling properties of clay, the superconducting properties of the transition metal sulfides, and the rapid diffusion of some elements into metals, semiconductors and other compounds at ambient temperatures. The properties and formation of these compounds are discussed.
Index Keywords: INORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Physical Chemistry; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Physical Chemistry; ABSTRACT ONLY; ADSORPTIVE REACTIONS; INTERCALATION COMPOUNDS; CRYSTALS

Authors: Kanematsu K., Hori A., Abe T., Hamakawa Y.
Title: DYNAMIC CHARACTERISTIC ANALYSIS FOR THE INVERTER/BATTERY COMBINED POWER CONDITIONING.
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn, Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kanematsu, K., Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn, Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn; Hori, A., Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn, Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn; Abe, T., Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn, Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn; Hamakawa, Y., Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn, Hitachi Zosen Corp, Osaka, Jpn
Abstract: A method is presented for analyzing the dynamic characteristics of a small-scale photovoltaic power generation system with a built-in inverter and storage battery. Graphic expressions of the photovoltaic I-V characteristics together with the inverter and battery loading dynamic characteristic are presented. To analyze the utilization of photovoltaic energy output, a systematic investigation is made with this chart of the shifting of operation on the load line and the switching between the battery charging mode and discharging mode. A system design concept for the optimization of power conditioning, including energy balance of the components and their economics, is also discussed.

Title: ELECTRIC CHOREMASTER I: TEST PROCEDURES AND RESULTS.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thoreson, B.P., South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA; Alcock, R., South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA; Christianson, L.L., South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA
Abstract: Maximum, continuous power take-off and draft power outputs are 12. 2 aand 34. 7 kilowatts, respectively, for the battery-powered Electric Choremaster I. Winter, on-farm tests indicated that chore task power requirements averaged from 9. 3 to 12. 7 kilowatts. Using multiple regression, a model was developed which predicts energy required for standard task segments. Model accuracy, using independent data, was plus or minus 10 percent for standard, hard-surface cycles.
