Authors: Brown G.M., Perren J.D., Musumeci P.C.
Title: ELECTRICAL ENERGY USAGE RECORDER.
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust, Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Brown, G.M., Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust, Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust; Perren, J.D., Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust, Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust; Musumeci, P.C., Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust, Queensland Electricity Commission, Aust
Abstract: Many electrical energy distribution authorities employ peak load billing schemes for industrial consumers. Incentives to reduce peak loading of the system would be more attractive for the industrial consumer if a reliable and economically viable method was available to monitor industrial loads. The numerous applications of dynamic load information have prompted many local distribution authorities to operate energy usage recording schemes. The recorders used are usually based on a magnetic tape cartridge. This storage system has a limited reliability. As site installation information such as input variable names and scaling factors is not recorded onto the tape, correct data interpretation depends on the careful handling of tapes by the operators. The aim of this project is to produce a solid state memory based energy recorder that will overcome these difficulties. Periodic uploading of the data to a computer is required to free the recorder memory for future use and to allow analysis of the recorded data to be performed. This paper will describe the design and implementation of the hardware and software components. Data samples from field testing are included to confirm the operation of the recorder.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER HARDWARE; COMPUTER SOFTWARE; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Applications; ELECTRICAL ENERGY USAGE RECORDER; FIELD TESTING; HARDWARE DESIGN; SOFTWARE DESIGN; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION

Title: SWITCHING CONTROLLER CHIP HANDLES 100 W FROM A 5-PIN PACKAGE.
Affiliations: Linear Technology Corp, Milpitas,, CA, USA, Linear Technology Corp, Milpitas, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, Carl, Linear Technology Corp, Milpitas,, CA, USA, Linear Technology Corp, Milpitas, CA, USA
Abstract: Three-terminal linear IC regulators are popular because they are simple to use and have all kinds of built-in protection circuits. Switching regulators are avoided by most engineers since those circuits require components and design techniques not often seen in other areas of electronics - linear or digital. In the past, designers who created their own switchers first had to choose from among the many switching regulator control chips. Those devices contain much of the logic and analog control circuitry needed to implement a switching regulator. But some of the most difficult parts of such a design are the sections not on the control chip-namely, the power switch, the driver network, the energy storage elements and steering diodes. Designers may now employ the LT1070, an easy-to-use, 'bulletproof' switching-mode regulator chip that handles power. Its switch, rated at 75 v and 5 A, can drive 100-w loads directly. All the other circuits usually found on a controller chip, plus the driver network, are integrated with the switch and housed in a five-pin TO-220 package.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, SWITCHING; IC REGULATORS; SWITCHING CONTROLLER CHIP; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Title: NUCLEAR POWER AND THE DEVELOPING WORLD.
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institu
Authors with affiliations: Mustafa, Adnan
Abstract: Growing worldwide experience with light water reactors enabled the nuclear power industries to mount a major challenge to conventional fossil-fired power plants by the beginning of the present decade. There was still politically activated public opposition to nuclear power; but the public's concerns about safe operation, safe storage and disposal of nuclear wastes, and horizontal proliferation, can really only be satisfied on the basis of experience, over time. There is still work to be done on the safety side; but it is in the safety field that nuclear power already shows very striking advantages over conventional power plants.
Index Keywords: ENERGY MANAGEMENT; ENERGY RESOURCES; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR REACTORS; INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY; LIGHT WATER REACTORS; NUCLEAR POWER INDUSTRY; NUCLEAR ENERGY

Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gross, Sidney, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Regenerable hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell systems have good potential for space stations relative to batteries, offering advantages of lower weight, higher efficiency, extended capacity for emergencies, and reduced resupply. Integration of the energy storage system with the reaction control system has large weight savings possibilities through the electrolysis of resupply water to provide hydrogen and oxygen reactants for orbit makeup, rather than the use of hydrazine.

Title: RECENT PROGRESS IN THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF BEAM AND DETECTOR MAGNETS.

Authors with affiliations: Desportes, H., CEN/Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN/Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr
Abstract: Superconducting magnets have now evolved into a second technology and are taking a noticeable place in equipment for high energy physics. However, conventional magnets remain competitive in important areas such as low field electron storage rings and most of beam line equipment. The new trend of high energy physics is towards large colliders, where beam lines are no longer needed and where the detectors are in small number but have grown to enormous sizes. We concentrate on the developments applied in recent years to large detector magnets.

Affiliations: Rockwell Hanford Operations,, Richland, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Randkley, E.H., Rockwell Hanford Operations,, Richland, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: To receive nuclear waste forms for disposal in a mined geologic respository, acceptance specifications must be established for each reference waste form and canister, if used. Such specifications provide the requirements that must be met and the respective compliance tests to use in determining whether the requirements have been satisfied. The Basalt Waste Isolation Project (BWIP) has begun the development of the site-specific acceptance specifications relative to U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) reference waste forms and canisters for commercial light-water reactor spent fuel and for commercial and defense high-level nuclear wastes from reprocessing.

Title: STATUS OF DOE-SPONSORED RESEARCH ON ADVANCED SECONDARY BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: McLarnon, F.R., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Cairns, E.J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: Types of advanced secondary batteries and cells under consideration include high temperature cells, flow batteries, metal/air batteries, and ambient temperature lithium cells. High temperature cell research encompasses the identification of new electrolytes for Na/S cells, the characterization of molten salt cells, the development of corrosion-resistant current collector and cell container materials, and the study of new solid electrolytes for Li/S cells. Flow battery (Zn/Br//2, Zn/Cl//2) research efforts are focussed on the identification of conditions leading to smooth, compact Zinc deposits, as well as cell modeling. Metal/air battery R&D activities include the engineering development of mechanically-rechargeable Al/air batteries, and research on O//2 electrodes, Zn electrodes, and separators. Ambient temperature lithium cell work encompasses the development of rechargeable Li/SO//2 cells, the characterization of new liquid organic electrolytes, and the study of novel polymeric electrolytes.

Affiliations: Int Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, Austria, Int Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Saire, Donald E., Int Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, Austria, Int Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency's program activities in the field of handling, treatment, conditioning and storage of all levels of radioactive waste are described. The early phases of the program, current emphasis and planned activities in the post-1985 period are presented. Particular attention is given to the mechanisms used by the Agency to carry out its mission to disseminate technical information and support research and development efforts in areas of major interest to Member States of the Agency. Several of the planned Coordinated Research Programs (CRP) are discussed including Member State participation, scope of work planned and the time-frame of the programs.

Title: THERMAL SYSTEM IMPROVEMENT UTILIZING HIGHLY LOADED PHASE CHANGE SLURRIES.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kasza, K.E., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: This paper describes a new concept for improving thermal system performances by utilizing the combined mechanisms of enhanced heat transfer, transport, and thermal energy storage associated with a phase-change slurry as the working fluid. Specifically, it is felt that combined utilization of the phenomenon of increased energy transport due to the phase transition of an immiscible change-of-phase additive to a carrier fluid (slurry) with the recently recognized phenomenon of enhanced heat transfer at a surface due to particle/fluid boundary-layer interaction could be used to enhance overall thermal system performance. Some specific benefits accruable from using phase-change slurries in thermal systems rather than single-phase sensible heat working fluids are considered.

Abstract: This experimental study is aimed at the development of a Crystalliser/Separator to be integrated with the refuelable aluminum-air battery that is being developed as an automotive energy source for general purpose vehicles. The function of the Crystalliser/Separator is to precipitate hydrargillite from the electrolyte and to remove and wash the mature particles at an expected rate of 13 kg/hour. In particular, this study examines the efficiency of solids/liquid separation and solids/solids segregation by hydrocyclones, the kinetics of hydrargillite crystallisation at high supersaturation between 60 degree C and 90 degree C, and the particle size dynamics under varying conditions of temperature, turbulence, supersaturation and solids concentration.

Recent progress at EDA has included: (a) a 500k Wh zinc-chloride load-levelling battery system under test at the BEST Facility; (b) two commercial vehicles - a Renault 'Trafic' van and a Gurmman 'Kubvan' - successfully retrofitted with zinc-chloride batteries; and (c) 6kWh, 12V reserve batteries - based on the use of cylinder chlorine-built and operated. In 1983, EDA initiated a 12MW demonstration programme of commercial hardware for the electric utility industry in the United States, which will lead to the installation of six 2MW Flexpower battery plants in selected electric utilities.

Abstract: Various factors affecting passive solar heating as reflected by room temperature profile were systematically computed by a simulation program based on the response factor method under various standardized climatic conditions. A single room model was used. Such factors include the thickness of thermal insulation of building envelope, the area of south-facing window and the depth of thermal storage material. An important aspect of this computerized calculation method is that it takes account of the solar radiation distributed to all inner surface sections as well as the heat transfer due to the radiation exchange from surface to surface.

Abstract: Two solar systems are installed in Sagiyama Solar House, i. e. , Solar Air Space Heating System and Solar Domestic Hot Water Supply System. Collectors for both systems are roof-integrated. Integration of solar collectors into roof is one of the effective solutions to reduce the costs of solar collecting system. As a result of the experiment, the efficiency of the roof-integrated solar water collector is about same as usual unit type flat plate collector on the market. Solar air collector also showed fairly high efficiency and could heat gravel storage as high as 50 degree C.

Authors: Machida Y., Kudoh Y., Takeda T.
Title: PCMs OF GLAUBER'S SALT-BASED EUTECTIC MIXTURES FOR GREENHOUSE HEATING.
Affiliations: Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn, Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Machida, Y., Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn, Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn; Kudoh, Y., Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn, Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn; Takeda, T., Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn, Matsushita Research Inst Tokyo Inc, Kawasaki, Jpn
Abstract: Latent heat thermal energy storage materials were studied for the use in the greenhouse heating system. Two suitable phase change materials (PCMs) were developed on the base of sodium sulfate decahydrate (Glauber's salt). One is of sodium sulfate decahydrate-sodium carbonate decahydrate-sodium chloride system with the latent heat of about 40 cal/g and completely melts at 24 degree C. The other is of sodium sulfate decahydrate-urea system with the latent heat of about 40 cal/g and completely melts at 22 degree C. The use of cross-linked sodium polyacrylate as a thickening agent was found to reduce remarkably the degradation of the PCMs ability by melt-freeze cycles. Two types of thermal storage units with these PCMs were made for greenhouse heating experiments.

Abstract: This paper is a report on the analysis of a solar house by experiment and simulation. This house was built in 1972, and retrofitted with the solar system combined with the long-term underground heat storage and the air to air heat pump. The experiments of this solar house started in April 1981. The experiments during two years and the analysis made it clear that the heat pump was operated in a high degree of efficiency, when the heat storage space was used as the pre-cooling space for the condenser in the cooling season. In the heating season, the heat pump could stably operated at a high degree of efficiency. Thus, this system is considered effective and practical.

Title: MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE - A CONGRESSIONAL PERSPECTIVE.
Affiliations: US Senate, Committee on Energy &, Natural Resources, USA, US Senate, Committee on Energy & Natural Resources, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, Benjamin S., US Senate, Committee on Energy &, Natural Resources, USA, US Senate, Committee on Energy & Natural Resources, USA
Abstract: The evolving role of MRS - monitored, retrievable storage - in Federal nuclear waste policy is reviewed and discussed in this paper. A decision by the Department of Energy to seek Congressional authorization for an MRS-like facility as an integral part of the Federal program to dispose of spent fuel and high-level radioactive waste seems both justified and likely. However, such a decision could bring other aspects of the DOE nuclear waste program before Congress for review and possible amendment. This is a colorful prospect, but it is a risk that must be taken if the Federal government seriously intends to assume by a date certain the long-standing Federal responsibility to finally do something about the management of nuclear waste.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION - Legislation; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Disposal; DOE'S NUCLEAR WASTE PROGRAM; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE (MRS); NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT (NWPA); NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: FOUR NUCLEAR PARADOXES WHICH AFFECT JAPANESE PUBLIC OPINION.
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institu
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, Yasumasa
Abstract: Four major paradoxes - sociological, political, economic, and psychological - are briefly illustrated with respect to the contemporary use of nuclear energy, drawing attention to Japan. It is concluded that public acceptance seems to be both an institutional and a psychological process; consequently a close examination of the cross-pressures resulting from sociological, political, economic, and psychological factors is needed, with a view to achieving a greater degree of public acceptance. Finally, it seems important to take into consideration cultural uniqueness as well as cross-cultural similarities, because cultural difference could account for the difficulty, or the ease, with which public acceptance can be achieved.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS - Accident Prevention; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Safe Handling; NUCLEAR ACCIDENT; NUCLEAR PARADOXES; NUCLEAR WASTE STORAGE; RADIOACTIVE LEAKS; THREE MILE ISLAND ACCIDENT; NUCLEAR ENERGY

Authors: Higashihara M., Takaoka D., Kanatani K.
Title: SOLAR DEHUMIDIFIED AIR DRYING SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn, Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Higashihara, M., Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn, Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn; Takaoka, D., Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn, Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn; Kanatani, K., Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn, Sanyo Electric Co, Hirakata, Jpn
Abstract: This paper describes the simulation of a solar unhulled rice drying system which is carried out by passing the dehumidified air through the moist unhulled rice. And this system is suitable to the high temperature and humidity area in the meteorlogical conditions(especially in south east Asia). In addition, hot air drying system is simulated for the comparison with the dehumidified air drying system. The dehumidified air drying system consists of solar collectors, a heat storage tank, an auxiliary boiler, 2 units of dehumidifier layer, and unhulled rice drying machine.
Index Keywords: AIR - Drying; HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION; DEHUMIDIFICATION; RICE DRYING; DRYERS

Title: SEPARATOR TECHNOLOGY FOR ELECTROCHEMICAL APPLICATIONS: DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY-SPONSORED RESEARCH.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kinoshita, K., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: The Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory (LBL) is the Lead Center for management of the Technology Base Research (TBR) Project, which is supported by the Office of Energy Systems Research, Energy Storage Division of the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE). Of the numerous research programs that are supported by the TBR project, many programs are directly involved with research and development of improved separators for batteries and other electrochemical systems. In addition, several of the programs are directed at investigating the electrochemical and physiochemical properties of available separators and electrolytes. Four generic types of separators are considered: microporous separators, ion exchange membranes, solid ion conductors, and supported-liquid membranes. A brief overview of the programs supported since 1980 by the TBR project that relate to separators is presented.
Index Keywords: ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING - Research; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ENERGY STORAGE - Research; MEMBRANES; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Research; ELECTRIC VEHICLE ENERGY STORAGE; ION EXCHANGE MEMBRANES; MICROPOROUS SEPARATORS; SOLID ION CONDUCTORS; SUPPORTED-LIQUID MEMBRANES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: ZEOLITES: SYNTHESIS, STRUCTURE, TECHNOLOGY AND APPLICATION, PROCEEDINGS OF AN INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM.
Source title: Studies in Surface Science and Catalysis
Abstract: This conference contains 79 papers. The papers presented concentrate on the possible ways of synthesising the silica-high types of zeolites, like ZSM-5, ZSM-11, NU-3, erionite, offretite, L-type zeolite, etc. , from the four-or five-component system. Detailed explanations are given of the processes in solutions, during the nucleation period and during crystallization. Special emphasis is given to the use of modern physical techniques, e. g. neutron diffraction, X-ray diffraction using synchrotrom radiation, nuclear magnetic resonance of samples spinned at 'magic' angle (MAS NMR), in the determination of the structure and distribution of framework and exchangeable ions. Descriptions are given of the possible technological use of synthetic zeolites in the fields of adsorption, catalysis, the production of laundry detergents, the removal of radioactive wastes, and the technological use of natural zeolites in the fields of municipal water treatment, paper and cement production and energy storage.
Index Keywords: ADSORPTION; CATALYSTS - Zeolites; CRYSTALLIZATION; CRYSTALS - Growing; MOLECULAR SIEVES; EIREV; HIGH SILICA ZEOLITES; TEMPLATE AGENTS; ZEOLITE APPLICATIONS; ZEOLITE STRUCTURE; ZEOLITES

Title: CASE HISTORIES OF ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT DOCUMENTS FOR NUCLEAR WASTE.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vocke, Robert W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: Nuclear power programs and policies in the United States have been subject to environmental assessment under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) since 1971. NEPA documentation prepared for programmatic policy decision-making within the nuclear fuel cycle and concurrent federal policy are examined as they relate to radioactive waste management including among others the Department of Energy (DOE) statement on management of commercially generated radioactive wastes, which focussed on development of deep geologic repositories. DOE is currently pursuing the deep geologic repository option, with monitored retrievable storage as a secondary option.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT - Evaluation; ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION - Legislation; WASTE DISPOSAL - Research; NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT (NEPA); U. S. DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE); U. S. NUCLEAR REGULATORY COMMISSION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: EVALUATION OF CEMENT STABILITY.
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Chino, K., Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Yusa, H., Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn
Abstract: Cement stability is theoretically evaluated to provide stable cement packages and storage methods without deterioration. A computer code was developed to calculate equilibrium composition based on minimization of Gibbs free energy of the system considered. It is found that increase of storage temperature and addition of NaOH are two effectual methods to avoid sulphate attack.
Index Keywords: CEMENT - Stability; CONTAINERS - Manufacture; PACKAGING MATERIALS - Corrosion; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Packaging; EQUILIBRIUM COMPOSITION CALCULATIONS; LONG TERM STABILITY EVALUATION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: SURVEY OF SOLAR RESEARCH ACTIVITES IN ISRAEL'S NEGEV HIGHLANDS.
Affiliations: Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Sde Boqer, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Sde Boqer, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Govaer, David, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Sde Boqer, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Sde Boqer, Isr
Abstract: The Applied Solar Calculations Unit (ASCU) of the Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University, at Sde Boqer, is a unit of engineers, physicists, and a chemist working to advance the exploitation of solar energy to the fullest extent possible through original research, and service to government, industry, and the public at large. Generally speaking, the research activities fall into five areas: 1) passive heating of buildings; 2) active heating of water, steam production, and space heating; 3) heat storage in phase change materials and unsaturated soils; 4) collector development; and 5) photovoltaic systems analysis. A description of one or two projects will serve to illustrate the activities: the zero energy house and an elementary school solar retrofit.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING - Solar; HOUSES - Israel; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Danila Nicolae, Stan Mihaela, Stan Nicolae, Ionescu Cezar
Title: MODELLING OF A STORAGE SYSTEM FOR SOLAR ENERGY BY SENSITIVE HEAT.
Affiliations: Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom
Authors with affiliations: Danila, Nicolae, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom; Stan, Mihaela, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom; Stan, Nicolae, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom; Ionescu, Cezar, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Univ Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom
Abstract: Study is made of a storage system operated by sensible heat and made up of identical solid plates between the channels of which a fluid agent is circulating. The aim of the present paper was to model the storage system with the simultaneous solving of the energy equation both in a fluid and a solid by using the conjugated boundary value problem. These attempts were made to determine a class exact analytical solution for a model as near as possible to the real system which, should make it possible to examine the role played by axial conductions in a solid.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Mathematical Models; CONJUGATED BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: NEW HYBRID UPS-SYSTEMS, PREFERABLY FOR LARGER POWER OUTPUT.
Affiliations: Ad Struever GmbH, Hamburg, West Ger, Ad Struever GmbH, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Krausse, Ernst A., Ad Struever GmbH, Hamburg, West Ger, Ad Struever GmbH, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: Hybrid UPS-systems have been developed by combining the main elements of the so-called static UPS systems with the synchronous motor drive preferably used in dynamic UPS systems. The resulting system combines many advantages of both technologies. The advantage of dynamic UPS systems in general, particularly at larger outputs, is that no electric-chemical energy storage, and in many cases no additional standby generating set, is needed. At higher power outputs, kinetic energy storage (fly-wheels) has economic and financial limits. Research work is being done with the aim of completing or replacing the flywheel with hydrostatic storage devices.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC GENERATORS, SYNCHRONOUS; ELECTRIC MOTOR GENERATOR SETS; ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEELS; BRUSHLESS ROTATING MACHINES; HYDROSTATIC STORAGE DEVICES; SYNCHRONOUS MOTOR DRIVES; UNINTERRUPTIBLE POWER SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER SUPPLIES TO APPARATUS

Title: LITHIUM-SO//2 : A BATTERY SYSTEM FOR TELECOM. EQUIPMENT.
Affiliations: Silberkraft Leichtakkumulatoren GmbH, Duiburg, West Ger, Silberkraft Leichtakkumulatoren GmbH, Duiburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Heydecke, Juergen, Silberkraft Leichtakkumulatoren GmbH, Duiburg, West Ger, Silberkraft Leichtakkumulatoren GmbH, Duiburg, West Ger
Abstract: Performance of the lithium-sulfur-dioxide system for possible application to communications is discussed. Its application as CMOS-memory back-up is assessed in terms of storage capability, and its operation under a weak load is illustrated. Safety aspects of use and handling are also discussed. All data given refer to the smallest cell type, 1/2 AA. Portable telecommunication equipment requires high energy density over a wide temperature range with maximum of safety. These qualities of the Li-SO//2 -system are illustrated for the G2O cell (size D), and the costs of this system are compared to traditional aqueous systems.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ELECTROLYTIC CELLS; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; CMOS-MEMORY BACK-UP; COMMUNICATION SYSTEM POWER SUPPLIES; LITHIUM-SULFUR-DIOXIDE SYSTEM; PORTABLE TELECOMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT; TELECOMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT

Title: LUZ PROJECTS.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The Luz system is not only a clean and efficient energy producer; it is cost-competitive today with conventional fossil fuel power stations. Under the guidance of a sophisticated and yet simple network of microcomputers, the sun is tracked along its east-west course so that hundreds of solar parabolic trough collectors may focus sunlight onto vacuum-tight heat collection elements (HCEs). A thermal fluid is heated by the sun's rays to more than 550 degrees Fahrenheit as it is pumped through the HCEs. The thermal fluid circulates from the solar collectors to either a thermal storage unit, or directly to a solar boiler where steam is produced. The steam then drives a turbine generator which produces electricity. The Luz Group has already completed SEGS I, the world's largest solar electric generation project to date located in Southern California. A second project is already under construction, SEGS II.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, MICROCOMPUTER; INDUSTRIAL ECONOMICS; LUZ SOLAR ELECTRICAL GENERATING SYSTEM; SEGS I; SEGS II; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: AUTONOMOUS PHOTOVOLTAIC DIESEL POWER SYSTEM DESIGN.
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Calloway, Terry M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: A methodology for designing an autonomous photovoltaic power system in conjunction with a diesel-fueled electric generator and a battery has been developed. It is hypothesized that logistical support is infrequent, so the hybrid photovoltaic-diesel power system is designed to consume only 10% as much fuel as would a diesel-only system. This constraint is used to generate a set of possible combinations of array area and battery energy-storage capacity. For each combination, a battery-life model predicts the time interval between battery replacements by deducting the fraction of total life consumed each day. An economic model then produces life-cycle system cost. Repeating this process for different combinations of array area and battery capacity identifies the minimum-cost system design.
Index Keywords: DIESEL ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; AUTONOMOUS POWER SYSTEMS; PHOTOVOLTAIC-DIESEL POWER SYSTEM; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Kotera N., Shigeta J., Ueyanagi K., Miyazaki M., Yanazawa H., Imamura Y., Tanaka H., Hashimoto N.
Title: HIGH PERFORMANCE MESFET TECHNOLOGY FOR GaAs ICS USING SHALLOW N-CHANNELS.
Source title: Technical Digest - GaAs IC Symposium (Gallium Arsenide Integrated Circuit)
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kotera, N., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Shigeta, J., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Ueyanagi, K., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Miyazaki, M., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Yanazawa, H., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Imamura, Y., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Tanaka, H., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn; Hashimoto, N., Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: A comprehensive experimental study of GaAs MESFET design principles has been made. A fabrication process is described for WSi//x -gate self-aligned MESFETs, that improves performance by a factor of 2 through reduction of implant energy from 75 to 40 keV. Transconductance coefficients, K, as high as 2 mA/V**2 for EFETs and 1. 2 mA/V**2 for DFETs have been attained at 1- mu m gate length and 10- mu m channel width. Consistent, fundamental data on K values and gate capacitance have been obtained. High-performance MESFETs successfully used in a 4-Kb GaAs SRAM experiment are described.

Title: SPECTROSCOPIC AND THERMOMECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF NEW NEODYMIUM-DOPED LASER MATERIALS.
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stokowski, S.E., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Marion, John E., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given. To evaluate the suitability of materials for fusion laser applications, the authors measured the spectroscopic properties of many new laser glasses and the thermomechanical characteristics of glasses and crystals. The information found is listed in tabular form. It is found that crystals have higher thermal shock figures of merit than glasses, primarily because of their higher thermal conductivities. However, in large-aperture systems, laser glasses have an advantage in energy storage efficiency because of their lower cross sections and their subsequently lower amplified spontaneous emission losses.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS - Thermal Conductivity; GLASS - Thermodynamics; AMPLIFIED SPONTANEOUS EMISSION LOSSES; FUSION LASER; LASER GLASSES; THERMAL SHOCK; LASERS, SOLID STATE

Title: HEAT- AND MASS-TRANSFER IN DISSOCIATING SOLID-GAS SYSTEMS.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Svinarev, S.V.; Trushevskii, S.N.
Abstract: Dissociatiang solid-gas systems are promising for thermal storage and cold production in solar technology. Among them are classified ammoniates and crystal hydrates, hydroxides of alkali and alkali-earth metals, and certain other compounds. At present, studies have appeared which use metallic hydrides for these purposes. The latter are also promising material for storing hydrogen. Such absorbents are powders, therefore, gas fills the whole free volume of a layer and can be absorbed or desorbed at a high rate, with a corresponding thermal effect. It is shown that, as a consequence of poor heat transfer in the layer, a completely different sorption may be realized, when it proceeds in a narrow area near the front moving through the layer. A mathematical model of the sorption process is suggested applicable to calculation of the process in metallic hydrides used in a hydrogen storage cell, which works using a solar battery.
Index Keywords: ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN - Absorption; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METALLIC COMPOUNDS; AMMONIATES; CRYSTAL HYDRATES; DISSOCIATING SOLID-GAS SYSTEMS; HYDROXIDES OF ALKALIA METALS; METAL HYDRIDES; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Fernandes P., Parodi R., Salvo C., Spataro B.
Title: DESIGN OF TE CAVITIES FOR RF ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy, CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fernandes, P., CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy, CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy; Parodi, R., CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy, CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy; Salvo, C., CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy, CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy; Spataro, B., CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy, CNR - Inst Matematica Applicata, Genoa, Italy
Abstract: The design of high Q TE resonators for high efficiency RF pulse compression is considered. This kind of resonator is used to double the energy gradient of linear accelerators. In order to study the influence of the geometry of the resonator on the Q//O, a computer code named OSCAR2D was developed. By means of this code an optimum geometry for TE storage cavities was found. The results of the computer simulation are compared with experimental measurements performed on a TE cavity prototype.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; RESONATORS, CAVITY - Computer Aided Analysis; HIGH-Q TE RESONATORS; OSCAR2D COMPUTER CODE; RESONATOR GEOMETRY; RF PULSE COMPRESSION; ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Authors: Akhmedov R.B., Danilov A.V., Zhogin D.Yu., Pozharnov V.A., Chakhovskii V.M.
Title: COMPARISON OF THERMOCHEMICAL HEAT ACCUMULATORS FOR SOLAR STATIONS.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Akhmedov, R.B.; Danilov, A.V.; Zhogin, D.Yu.; Pozharnov, V.A.; Chakhovskii, V.M.
Abstract: Some promising reversible reactions for the purpose of heat accumulation are considered. On the example of a thermochemical accumulator (TCA) with Ca(OH)//2 as a working medium, the efficiency of TCA using the selected reactions are evaluated. The other substances considered were: calcium carbonate, ferrous sulfate, sulfur trioxide, magnesium hydroxide, and magnesium carbonate. It is concluded that TCA based on the two hydroxides, caustic soda and magnesium hydroxide, are free from the shortcomings of other substances.

Title: EFFECT OF SOME PRIMARY ALIPHATIC AMINES ON ARMCO IRON CORROSION IN 0. 5 m H//2SO//4.
Affiliations: Italian Electricity Board, Milan, Italy, Italian Electricity Board, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Perboni, G., Italian Electricity Board, Milan, Italy, Italian Electricity Board, Milan, Italy; Rocchini, G., Italian Electricity Board, Milan, Italy, Italian Electricity Board, Milan, Italy
Abstract: The behaviour of Armco iron in 0. 5 m H//2SO//4 solutions with some primary aliphatic amines has been investigated and it has been found that n-hexylamine has no inhibiting effect by itself, while the inhibitor effectiveness of n-octylamine, n-decylamine, and n-dodecylamine toward high concentrations is about 80%. The compounds examined are, therefore, useful only for a theoretical investigation into the physical mechanisms of inhibition. The absorption isotherms of the last three amines are described quite well by Frumkin's isotherm, but the variations of standard free energy are slightly different from those found in literature. The potentialities of a computerized measurement technique allowing interpretation of experimental results through storage and use of various numerical methods are briefly discussed.
Index Keywords: ABSORPTION; AMINES; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; IRON AND ALLOYS - Corrosion; SULFURIC ACID; ISOTHERMS; CORROSION PROTECTION

Authors: Oda Tetsuji, Utsumi Tomoaki, Kumano Teruhisa, Itami Makoto
Title: OBSERVATION OF PHOTO-STIMULATED DETRAPPING CURRENTS OF FEP TEFLON ELECTRETS.
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Oda, Tetsuji, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Utsumi, Tomoaki, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Kumano, Teruhisa, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Itami, Makoto, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Photo-stimulated detrapping currents (PSDCs) of FEP-Teflon electrets charged by corona at 150 degree C were observed in an effort to understand the charge storage mechanism. Monochromatic light of a deuterium lamp (4-6. 5 eV) or a mercury lamp (4. 9 eV) was directed on the sample electrets at room temperature. The threshold energy of light to generate PSDCs was found to be 4. 9 eV. The experimental results indicate that there exists only a single trapping level (4. 9 eV) to be activated by a deuterium lamp. However, at a higher temperature, another photosensitive detrapping current was also observed by the irradiation from the same light.
Index Keywords: ELECTRETS; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; FLUOROETHYLENE PROPYLENE (FEP); PHOTO-STIMULATED DETRAPPING CURRENTS; TEFLON; POLYMERS

Title: BULK MODIFICATION OF CHARGE TRAPPING AND CONDUCTIVITY IN LINEAR LOW DENSITY POLYETHYLENE.
Affiliations: Coll Militaire Royal de St. Jean, Que, Can, Coll Militaire Royal de St. Jean, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Perlman, M.M., Coll Militaire Royal de St. Jean, Que, Can, Coll Militaire Royal de St. Jean, Que, Can; Haridoss, S., Coll Militaire Royal de St. Jean, Que, Can, Coll Militaire Royal de St. Jean, Que, Can
Abstract: Antioxidants, neutral phthalocyanine, and titanium dioxide were added to 'pure' linear, low-density polyethylene resin, and films were extruded. Charge storage and conduction properties were measured using TSCD and open and short circuit TSC and TSPC, respectively. Antioxidants increased negative and positive storage level and reduced conduction activation energies, but had little effect on lifetime. Defect traps were annealed out at low concentrations, and new deep traps introduced by the titanium dioxide itself at all concentrations. Additive-matrix boundary trapping is another possibility for the latter two additives.
Index Keywords: ELECTRETS; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; ELECTRIC INSULATING MATERIALS - Plastics; CHARGE TRAPPING; POLYETHYLENE INSULATION; POLYETHYLENES

Title: THERMAL STORAGE IN A PASSIVE HEATING SYSTEM.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Dymov, G.I.; Orlov, A.Yu.; Chuppin, V.M.
Abstract: An analytical solution is suggested for determining changes in air temperature in a thermal storage system of pipes, taking into account aerodynamic regimes of heat-carrier movement and the nature of temperatures, which varies in time and with the depth of the storage system.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE; PIPING SYSTEMS; SAND AND GRAVEL - Applications; SOLAR ENERGY; CONCRETE MASS WITH PIPES; CONSTRUCTION RUBBLE; GRAVEL; PASSIVE SOLAR-HEATING SYSTEMS; THERMAL STORAGE; HEATING

Title: CHOOSING THE VOLUME OF A THERMAL-STORAGE TANK IN SOLAR-HEATING SYSTEMS.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Valov, M.I.
Abstract: In solar-heating systems, thermal-storage tanks are used to store energy during periods when the input of heat from the sun exceeds the system's heat demand. Investigation of solar-heating systems shows that the productivity of a solar device and, consequently, the annual economic benefit from introducing a solar-heating system depends on the choice of size for the thermal-storage tank. The specific size of the tank depends on characteristics of the tank itself and the solar collector, on the nature of the heating system's heat demand, and the unit cost of the whole assembly and the thermal-storage tank. A method is presented for selecting the size of the solar heating thermal storage tank.

Title: MODELLING OF HEAT STORAGE IN AQUIFEROUS LAYERS.

Authors with affiliations: Walgorzata Wolska, Elwira, Inst of Biocybernetics &, Biomedical Engineering, Pol, Inst of Biocybernetics & Biomedical Engineering, Pol
Abstract: The mathematical modelling of heat flow and thermal energy storage in aquiferous layers is presented in the paper. Water, with the temperature higher than underground water, is stored in the aquiferous layers and it is the carrier of thermal energy. The steady state filtration equation and thermal equation are solved. Some results are presented.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Mathematical Models; HEAT FLOW MODELING; STEADY STATE FILTRATION EQUATION; THERMAL EQUATION; AQUIFERS

Title: EVAPOTRANSPIRATION DYNAMICS FOR LARGE RIVER BASINS.
Affiliations: NOAA, Ann Arbor, MI, USA, NOAA, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Croley II, Thomas E., NOAA, Ann Arbor, MI, USA, NOAA, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Abstract: This paper explores the difference between the classical and complementary approaches for estimating evapotranspiration in a tank-cascade model applied to river basins emptying into the Great Lakes. The model uses interdependent storages and employs analytical solutions of the mass balances for snowpack, upper and lower soil zones, groundwater, and surface water. These are coupled with physically-based concepts of linear reservoir storages, partial-area infiltration, and degree-day determinations of snowmelt and net supply. Evapotranspiration losses are determined from joint consideration of available energy and available moisture in the soil horizons by using the complementary and moisture- and heat-dependent concepts. The model's mathematical structure allows the use of analytical solutions, bypassing the inaccuracies and convergence problems associated with numerical solutions. The structure of the mathematical models, and particularly the evapotranspiration - soil moisture concept, is presented.
Index Keywords: HYDROLOGY; RIVERS; SOILS - Moisture; ET DYNAMICS; LARGE RIVER BASINS; TANK-CASCADE MODEL; WATER RESOURCES

Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy,, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Nippes, E.F., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy,, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, NY, USA; Balaguer, J.P., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy,, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, NY, USA
Abstract: The impact absorption energy of the weld HAZ does not increase below the limit of 34 J at minus 196 degree C, as specified in ASTM 553-I. The upper shelf of curve was lowest for material thermally cycled to a peak temperature of 1000 degree C. The impact absorption energy, at minus 196 degree C was lowest for material thermally cycled to a peak temperature of 1300 degree C. Material thermally cycled to peak temperatures of 500 and 1000 degree C and impact tested at minus 196 degree C failed by a mixed mode of microvoid coalescence and ductile tearing. Material thermally cycled to a peak temperature of 1300 degree C and impact tested at minus 196 degree C failed by a mixed mode of transgranular quasi-cleavage and microvoid coalescence. Synthetic thermal cycling to 500 and 1300 degree C decreases the retained austenite content and impact toughness.
Index Keywords: GAS STORAGE; NATURAL GAS, LIQUEFIED; PRESSURE VESSELS - Steel; TANKS - Steel; WELDING - Steel; ABSTRACT ONLY; IMPACT PROPERTIES; LNG STORAGE TANKS; LOW TEMPERATURE PROPERTIES; THERMAL CYCLING; UPPER SHELF ENERGY; WELDS

Title: FUTURE COAL UTILISATION TECHNOLOGIES.
Affiliations: Natl Coal Board Staff Coll, Natl Coal Board Staff Coll
Authors with affiliations: Merrick, D., Natl Coal Board Staff Coll, Natl Coal Board Staff Coll
Abstract: For direct combustion applications, coal is often less convenient to use, particularly with regard to storage and handling. Also, combustion equipment to use coal is often significantly more expensive than for the premium fuels and this offsets the fuel price advantage. The above factors represent some of the major challenges to which developments in coal utilization technology are directed, and with which improvements are required in order for coal to make the fullest contribution to future energy supplies. The purpose of the present paper is to summarize some of the main lines of current research and development.

Authors with affiliations: Strayer, Richard D., R D Strayer Inc, Dublin, OH, USA, R D Strayer Inc, Dublin, OH, USA
Abstract: The environmentally sensitive solar/earth architectural style is the first dramatic change in architecture since Frank Lloyd Wright. Energy costs and other environmental issues have fashioned this new style. While new to the public, solar-heated, earth-protected buildings utilize ancient proven concepts. This paper will address the critical factors to achieve comfortable and practical solar/earth structures in the Midwest. Masonry construction is the most cost-effective form of thermal storage as no extra cost is required above that for structural purposes. Comfortable and practical passive-solar heated earth-protected structures utilizing earth/air tube cooling designed for the Midwest climate will be presented.

Abstract: The performance of prototype-sized 400cm**2 iron air cells was evaluated under a simplified electric vehicle driving cycle. The weight of the cell components used in the computation of the total cell weight and in turn, in the calculation of energy and power densities are given. These are the values projected for an optimized cell as part of a battery module. The prototype-size cells were not designed for optimum power or minimum weight, but rather to demonstrate the successful scale-up of the technology to the 400cm**2 prototype size.

Title: MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF A Zn/Br//2 CELL ON CHARGE.
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mader, M., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA; White, R.E., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: A model of the charge mode of an individual cell in a Zn/Br//2 flow battery will be presented. The cell model consists of parallel plate electrodes separated by a porous separator. Analysis of the model shows that four independently adjustable parameters exist for the system. A physically meaningful set of these independent variables consists of the effective separator thickness, the residence time of the electrolyte within the cell, the flow channel gap, and the applied potential driving force. The model is used to predict cell performance as determined by such things as the electrochemical energy efficiency on charge, the rate of storage of the products (Br//2 and Zn) on charge, and the specific energy consumed to store the products. Predictions of cell performance at an initial state of charge and during the charging process are presented for various values of the four independent variables.

Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE COMPOSITE THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS FOR INDUSTRIAL APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Petri, Randy J., Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA; Ong, Estela T., Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA; Marianowski, Leonard G., Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: An advanced, thermal energy storage (TES) subsystem is being developed by the Institute of Gas Technology (IGT) which employs composite phase change material (PCM)/sensible heat media (CompPhase). This medium/ subsystem is amenable to high temperature thermal storage applications such as industrial reject/process heat recovery and utilization, off-peak utility, and solar thermal and solar dynamic space power system. The CompPhase concept allows for direct contact heat exchange between the latent/sensible storage media and compatible working fluids. A number of potentially significant TES system performance and cost advantages are offered over conventional tube intensive indirect contact molten-salt latent-heat-based storage subsystems. The CompPhase composite TES media concept involves retention and immobilization of a phase-change salt (latent-heat phase) within the submicronsized porous microstructure of a particulate ceramic matrix or porous sintered ceramic body (sensible-heat phase).

This meeting served as a forum to assess the progress made in the efficiency of photovoltaic cells and new energy storage systems.

Abstract: Solid-state junctions between redox containing solid polymer electrolytes (SPE) and intercalating photoelectrodes from the transition metal Group IV (zirconium and hafnium) layer-type disulfides and diselenides have been shown to be viable candidates for photoelectrochemical energy storage. Previous work has shown that zirconium and hafnium dichalcogenides can reversibly electrochemically intercalate copper and iron in aqueous electrolytes. In this work the reversible intercalation process occurs at photoelectrode/SPE junctions. Emphasis was placed on redox containing SPE materials of both poly(ethylene oxide) and the perfluorinated cation exchange membrane, Nafion. The overall approach represents a novel solidstate cell for the reversible storage of electrochemical energy.

Abstract: This paper presents historical data on commercial spacecraft power systems and relates their power requirements to the growth of satellite communications channel usage. On the basis of these data as well as input from other sources, some approaches for estimating future power requirements of this class of spacecraft through the year 2000 are proposed. The key technology drivers in satellite power systems are also addressed. The paper concludes with a description of several technological trends in such systems, focusing on the most useful areas for research and development of major subsystems, including solar arrays, energy storage, and power electronics equipment.

Authors: Feero W.E., Jones R.H., Bassett D.L.
Title: RELAYING CONSIDERATIONS FOR INTERCONNECTING SMALL POWER PRODUCERS.
Source title: Annual Conference for Protective Relay Engineers
Affiliations: Electric Research & Management, Inc, Electric Research & Management Inc
Authors with affiliations: Feero, W.E., Electric Research & Management, Inc, Electric Research & Management Inc; Jones, R.H., Electric Research & Management, Inc, Electric Research & Management Inc; Bassett, D.L., Electric Research & Management, Inc, Electric Research & Management Inc
Abstract: This paper demonstrates that abnormally high and possibly damaging overvoltages can occur on isolated feeders connected to Dispersed Storage and Generation (DSG). Since DSG installations are becoming more numerous, and since the conditions which allow the overvoltages to exist are possible in many practical DSG connections, the overvoltages must be controlled. The first step in mitigation is to understand the source of the overvoltage and the energy levels which must be controlled or dissipated. The mechanisms for producing the overvoltages are based on ferroresonance phenomenon and are not extremely sensitive to types of generators, types or connections of transformers, location of capacitors, or other equipment parameters. The overvoltage depends on the establishment of a harmonic resonant circuit utilizing transformer saturation characteristics, the existence of power factor correcting capacitors on the feeder and a source of energy sufficient to maintain transformer saturation.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER FACTOR - Correction; ELECTRIC TRANSFORMERS; DISPERSED STORAGE AND GENERATION (DSG); FERRORESONANCE; HARMONIC RESONANT CIRCUIT; TRANSFORMER SATURATION; OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION

Title: CLATHRATES FOR COOL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olszewski, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Tomlinson, J.J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: Gas hydrates, which form a subset of clathrates, are composed of gaseous molecules contained within a cage-like crystalline water structure. Gas hydrates can be properly considered as 'ices' since each water molecule is hydrogen bonded to its four forms of ice. The presence of the guest molecule allows the hydrate crystal to form at a higher temperature than pure ice or, equivalently, the effect of the guest molecule is to raise the freezing point of water. In addition, a large quantity of energy must be removed from the gas/water mixture to form the hydrate crystal. Many species of guest molecules form gas hydrates including the noble gases, halogens, and hydrocarbons. Of particular interest are the halogenated hydrocarbons or common refrigerants which are potentially suitable for cool storage. Dichlorodifluoromethane (R-12) is one such refrigerant and is considered as a representative guest molecule in this paper.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Materials; FREONS - Hydration; REFRIGERANTS - Freons; CLATHRATES; DICHLORODIFLUOROMETHANE; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; GAS HYDRATES; HALOGENATED HYDROCARBONS; REFRIGERATION

Title: STORING ENERGY BY PHASE CHANGE IN SALT HYDRATES.
Affiliations: Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA, Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lane, George A., Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA, Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA
Abstract: Attempts have been made to use salt hydrate phase change materials (PCMs) for heat storage applications for nearly a century. The first home heated by PCM was completed in 1948. The energy crises of recent years provided the impetus to perfect PCM energy storage, but it has taken nearly a decade for this technology to begin to be accepted in the marketplace. Utilization of PCMs has depended on the development of a variety of formulated salt hydrate compositions which are stable, available, and economical. These materials have become practical only through diligent attention to the fundamentals of physical chemistry applicable to PCM sciences: phase equilibria, crystal nucleation and growth, crystallography, solution chemistry, and thermochemistry. Commercial application of these materials, however, has depended on developing well-engineered, encapsulated forms, based on careful consideration of heat transfer, physical properties, materials compatibility, stability, and application design.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Heat Exchangers; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Materials; HEAT TRANSFER; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; HEAT STORAGE; PHASE CHANGE; SALT HYDRATES; SALTS

Authors: Ananthanarayanan V., Sahai Y., Mobley Y., Rapp R.
Title: COMPUTER MODEL FOR FIXED BED HEAT EXCHANGERS UTILIZING PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS.
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ananthanarayanan, V., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Sahai, Y., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Mobley, Y., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Rapp, R., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: A computer program has been developed to calculate the heat exchanged between a porous packed bed of self-contained phase change materials and any inert fluid flowing through the bed. This model was developed specifically for analyzing the heat exchanged and temperature profiles of porous beds packed with hypereutectic aluminum-silicon alloy shot as the phase change material in direct contact with hot or cold gases. The bed was modeled by considering it a series of connected equal height cells and performing energy balances between neighboring cells. The computer model for the porous packed bed with phase change material was then used to define bed heating and cooling cycles to efficiently utilize the heat storage and exchange capabilities of a bed containing hypereutectic aluminum-silicon alloy shot. A cyclic cocurrent fluid flow configuration was one method which was found to efficiently use the large heat of fusion of the aluminum-silicon alloy phase change bed particles and would allow the bed to function as a near-isothermal (about 577 C) recuperator.

Abstract: The High Temperature Thermal Energy Storage project in the CSIRO Division of Energy Technology is presently focussed on research into methods of achieving high effective conductivities in packed beds. One proposed method is natural convection with coupled mass transfer in these beds when the particle surfaces are wet, and a gas/vapour mixture is present in the voids. Title: DEVELOPMENT OF LIQUID ICE DISTRICT COOLING SYSTEMS.
Source title: Official Proceedings - Annual Conference of the International District Heating Association
Authors with affiliations: Margen, Peter
Abstract: District cooling systems using chilled water extract heat more efficiently than smaller systems because of economies of scale and because of their heat retention capabilities. They do, however, have relatively expensive distribution systems due to the small temperature difference between delivered water and return water. This requires that the system use large diameter pipes. The system described in this paper uses 'liquid ice. ' Liquid ice is a solution of a substance such as a salt or sugar in water to form crystallization nuclei for ice formation at temperatures somewhat below 32 degree F. The mixture of ice crystals and liquid behaves like a liquid and can flow through pipes. It can, therefore, be used as both a cold transport medium and a cold storage medium. The energy capacity per unit volume is a factor of 5 greater than that for chilled water. Piping dimensions are much reduced and cold storage becomes economically feasible, allowing the reduction of daily and seasonal cooling peaks by heat storage. Heat pump operation is also concentrated during periods when lower off-peak electricity rates apply.
Index Keywords: HEATING - District; ICE; WATER PIPING SYSTEMS; CHILLED WATER SYSTEMS; DISTRICT COOLING; LIQUID ICE; AIR CONDITIONING

Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy has assigned to the Defense Transuranic Waste Program responsibility for long-range planning for management of defense transuranic (TRU) waste. Four computer models are used to provide rapid, inexpensive analysis in support of this program. M-PLAN is a waste inventory buildup and workoff model, which tracks TRU waste inventory changes through waste generation, certification, storage, processing, and disposal activities. TRUSIM is a transportation simulation model, which calculates transportation fleet requirements based on packaging characteristics and inventory work off strategies. TRUCOST is a database management and spreadsheet model, which analyzes system-wide cost impacts of program alternatives. Project management codes, such as Project/2 and LisaProject, are used to determine project activity logic and perform critical path analysis.

Abstract: In this study, a large scale industrial hot water system at the CIAS 'Flight Kitchen', which caters for many of the airlines at the Singapore Changi Airport, is investigated. A computer simulation is carried out to evaluate the system performance and the cost effectiveness of such a system. The predicted values of the performance parameters agree well with the experimental results obtained. The contribution from solar energy towards the total energy demand remains high around 50% even under fairly poor weather conditions. The computer simulation indicates that the solar fraction is strongly dependent on the required temperature of hot water and with a temperature of 55 degree C almost all the energy requirement is provided by solar heating. The optimum storage capacity for water heating systems of this kind is estimated to be about 25 L-SCRIPT /m**2.

Abstract: The experimental results and energy analyses on open cycle solar absorption system are described. The improved version of packed column type dehumidifier was made and experimented. The contact factor was around 0. 7-0. 9 over the dehumidification period. From energy analyses on the improved dehumidifier over-all mass transfer coefficient on 28 September, 1984 was 2350 g/m**3h DELTA x when air flow rate was 31m**3/h, and on 1 October, 1984 1350 g/m**3h DELTA x with the air flow rate of 19 m**3/h, and on 17 October, 1984 790 g/m**3 h DELTA x with the air flow rate of 7 m**3/h. The natural convective type regenerator was fabricated and experimented. During the 6 hours experiment on 24 September, 1984, total mass transfer rate was 1320g/kg when solar radiation on regenerator surface was 3765 Wh/m**2. Dry storage tank was proposed to use the merit that LiCl solution can be cooled without extracted mass transfer potential.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; DEHUMIDIFICATION; SOLAR ABSORPTION SYSTEMS; SOLAR COOLING; AIR CONDITIONING

Abstract: The authors describe the first practical design of a superconducting coil (SAGE 7) for a fullscaled electromagnetic thruster (EMT) ship. SAGE 7 has a racetrack configuration with a circular cross-section, a energy storage capacity of 660 MJ, a magnetic flux density at electrodes of 4 Teslas. The 12 superconducting coils generate the maximum thrust of 25 mn.

Title: 500 WATT(e) RADIOISOTOPE THERMOELECTRIC GENERATOR FUELED WITH STRONTIUM-90 FLUORIDE FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY'S WASTE ENCAPSULATION AND STORAGE FACILITY.
Affiliations: Teledyne Energy Systems, Timonium,, MD, USA, Teledyne Energy Systems, Timonium, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vogt, John F., Teledyne Energy Systems, Timonium,, MD, USA, Teledyne Energy Systems, Timonium, MD, USA
Abstract: A 500 watt(e) radioisotope thermoelectric generator (RTG) is being designed and fabricated by Teledyne Energy Systems for the Department of Energy. The BUP-500 RTG has a five-year design life and consists of the following components: multiple strontium-90 fluoride heat sources (three different types can be used), a tungsten shield, six series-connected thermoelectric conversion assemblies, thermal insulation, and a finned cylindrical housing. The generator will be mounted on isolators within an expanded metal cage to reduce shocks and vibration incident to transportation and handling. A separate power conditioner will allow a user to adjust the RTG's output voltage between 24 and 32 volts.

Abstract: A study is being performed at the Department of Energy's Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) to determine the most feasible options for the management of INEL radioactive mixed waste and to develop a program plan for implementing the selected options. This paper will discuss the type and volume of radioactive mixed waste generated at the INEL; selection criteria used to determine the most viable option (i. e. , technical, economic, and regulatory constraints); and available options for treatment, storage, and/or disposal.

Title: SPENT FUEL STORAGE REQUIREMENTS.
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Libby, R.A., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Cole, B.M., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Long before a permanent nuclear waste disposal system is available in the United States, several of the operating commercial nuclear power plants will exhaust their existing spent fuel storage capabilities. Studies to define the magnitude of this interim problem were conducted by the Department of Energy through the Commercial Spent Fuel Management (CSFM) Program at the Pacific Northwest Laboratory. Based on information supplied by the nuclear utilities, these studies indicate that if new storage concepts are not available by 1986 some reactors could encroach on their storage pool's full core reserve (FCR), and ultimately, be forced to shut down.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Disposal; COMMERCIAL SPENT FUEL MANAGEMENT (CSFM) PROGRAM; FULL CORE RESERVOIR (FCR); PACIFIC NORTHWEST LABORATORY; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, Sakura-mura, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Sakura-mura, Jpn

Abstract: A prototype latent thermal storage unit using form-stable high density polyethylene (HDPE) and its fundamental characteristics are briefly described. Also presented are conceptual designs and cost evaluations of three solar thermal application systems with this storage system. The solar air conditioning system is feasible. On the other hand, the solar thermal power generation systems with collectors of non-tracking and non-concentrating type are not cost-effective mainly due to the low conversion efficiency arising from the low operating temperature.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Solar Energy Systems; HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR ENERGY; HIGH DENSITY POLYETHYLENE; LATENT THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Alefeld G., Brandl F., Opitz U., Voelkl J., Ziegler F.
Title: ADVANCED CYCLES FOR THE USE OF SOLAR ENERGY.
Affiliations: Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Alefeld, G., Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Brandl, F., Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Opitz, U., Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Voelkl, J., Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Ziegler, F., Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Technische Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: A two-stage zeolite/H//2O - LiBr/H//2O system which, besides a high COP, has also storage capability of solar energy, is presented. Furthermore thermally actuated absorption cycles are described which can replace mechanical vapor recompression or multi-stage distillation processes. The absorption cycles combine the properties of absorption heat pumps with those of heat transformers. These devices may be used for solar water distillation, yielding large performance ratios. The heat pump transformer processes described thus can compete with high efficient mechanical vapor recompression processes.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERATION - Solar; SOLAR RADIATION; ABSORPTION CYCLES; PROCESS HEAT; SOLAR COOLING; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: REGULATORY AND ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIONS IMPACTING ON SPENT FUEL STORAGE FUNCTIONS.
Affiliations: Lowenberg Associates Inc, Rockville,, MD, USA, Lowenberg Associates Inc, Rockville, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lowenberg, Homer, Lowenberg Associates Inc, Rockville,, MD, USA, Lowenberg Associates Inc, Rockville, MD, USA
Abstract: Interim or longer term storage of spent fuel by utilities or the Federal government that may be required prior to disposal in a deep geologic repository may be impacted in a variety of ways by regulatory and administrative actions. The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 (NWPA) provides for interim storage of spent fuel by both utilities and the Department of Energy (DOE). The Utilities owning spent fuel have primary responsibility for interim spent fuel storage at reactor sites. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's (NRC) Waste Confidence Rulemaking addressed the environmental and safety implications of both onsite and offsite storage of spent fuel.

Title: HEAT OF OXIDATION OF COAL NEAR AMBIENT TEMPERATURES AND THE PROBLEM OF SPONTANEOUS COMBUSTION.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Ryde, Aust, CSIRO, Ryde, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Nordon, P., CSIRO, Ryde, Aust, CSIRO, Ryde, Aust
Abstract: A model is discussed which treats self-heating and spontaneous combustion in coal stacks due to oxidative weathering on a quantitative basis. A new simultaneous measurement of oxygen consumption and heat evolved ensures that compatible data are used for conservation of mass and energy. Results from calculations and conclusions are presented which give an insight into the various mechanisms.

Authors with affiliations: Hata, Tsutomu, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn; Sakai, Tsutomu, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn; Ishida, Susumu, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn; Toyama, Tsuyoshi, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn; Harima, Hirokazu, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami, Jpn
Abstract: A new test method was found, which can obtain a data retention time of EPROMs in actual use temperature. Under the high temperature stress, logarithmic shift of threshold voltage in memory transistor was found to be linear to time. The simple model shows that the activation energy for data loss can be obtained from the slope of this line. The obtained value of activation energy agreed well with that from conventional method using the relationship between reciprocal temperature and logarithmic retention time. As a result of this finding, without the data of several temperature conditions, the retention time of EPROMs in actual use temperature is derived from high temperature storage test data at only one test condition.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE UNITS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; EPROM; RETENTION TIME; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL

Authors: Oren Tuncer I., Elzas Maurice S., Sheng Grant
Title: MODEL RELIABILITY AND SOFTWARE QUALITY ASSURANCE IN SIMULATION OF NUCLEAR FUEL WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Oren, Tuncer I., Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Elzas, Maurice S., Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Sheng, Grant, Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Univ of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: As is the case with all scientific simulation studies, computerized simulation of nuclear fuel waste management systems can introduce and hide various types of errors. Frameworks to clarify issues of model reliability and software quality assurance are offered. Potential problems with reference to the main areas of concern for reliability and quality are discussed; e. g. experimental issues, decomposition, scope, fidelity, verification, requirements, testing, correctness, robustness are treated with reference to the experience gained in the past. A list comprising over 80 most common computerization errors is provided. Software tools and techniques used to detect and to correct computerization errors are discussed.
Index Keywords: FAILURE ANALYSIS - Computer Simulation; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; QUALITY ASSURANCE; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; RELIABILITY - Mathematical Models; ATOMIC ENERGY OF CANADA LIMITED (AECL); NUCLEAR WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; SOFTWARE QUALITY ASSURANCE; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Authors with affiliations: Koizumi, H., Toshiba House & Living Industry, Co, Tokyo, Jpn, Toshiba House & Living Industry Co, Tokyo, Jpn; Wakisaka, Y., Toshiba House & Living Industry, Co, Tokyo, Jpn, Toshiba House & Living Industry Co, Tokyo, Jpn; Matsui, K., Toshiba House & Living Industry, Co, Tokyo, Jpn, Toshiba House & Living Industry Co, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The residential engineering model A with a floor area of 140 m**2, based on a solar air circulation system has been designed and constructed by Jan. 1984 in Gotemba as part of the MITI project. The model consisted of two zones with the same configuration; (1) the west zone applying an air type heat collecting roof, heat collecting blind, and concrete block heat storage with a forced air circulation system. (2) the east zone applying the heat collecting blind and concrete heat storage wall with a natural air circulation system. In order to ascertain the feasibility of these systems, a one-year period performance test was carried out by using a data acquisition system. The results showed that these systems could provide uniform room temperature distributions with aid of the air circulation systems.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR AIR CIRCULATION SYSTEM; HOUSES

Abstract: The Super-ACO radiation source under construction at Orsay has a nominal energy of 800 Mev. The storage ring circumference is 72 m and the light from bending magnets has a characteristic wavelength of 18. 5 Angstrom. The design, construction and testing of the 8 main dipoles and of the 32 quadrupole magnets are presented, including: optimization of magnet ends, magnetic measurement bench for dipoles, special coils for sextupolar field generation within the quadrupole magnets, and automatic measuring apparatus for quadrupoles. The preseptum magnet of the beam transport line is described.

Title: ECONOMIC STUDY OF A SOLAR HEATING & COOLING SYSTEM WITH A COMBINED SINGLE & DOUBLE EFFECT ABSORPTION CHILLER AND FLAT PLATE HIGH EFFICIENCY COLLECTOR.

Authors with affiliations: Matsumoto, Hirosuke, Yazaki Corp, Hamamatsu, Jpn, Yazaki Corp, Hamamatsu, Jpn
Abstract: One of the most important factors to estimate the economic feasibility of a solar cooling and heating system is the recovery period which is the number of years required to recover the initial investment. The recovery period is calculated by the payback method which is the ratio of the initial investment over the annual energy cost savings. Therefore, various collector areas and heat storage capacities for a solar cooling and heating system with high efficiency collectors and a combined single and double effect (CSDE) absorption chiller were studied to obtain the minimum payback period.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Solar Energy Systems; HEATING - Solar; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Climate Control; SOLAR COOLING; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: The Department of Energy and Rockwell Hanford Operations developed the Hanford Waste Management Plan to identify preliminary long range plans for the disposal of radioactive waste currently being stored and to be generated in the future at the Hanford Site near Richland, Washington. The plan also discusses low-level pre-1970 transuranic contaminated solid waste and soil sites that have already been disposed of at Hanford, but which is being evaluated for possible remedial actions to assure maximum long-term safety. The Hanford Waste Management Plan and a companion document, the Hanford Waste Management Technology Plan are used as the basis for all ongoing efforts associated with the final disposal of radioactive waste at Hanford.

Abstract: For clarifying the feasibility of introduction of solar total energy system into various factories, the experimental facility was constructed at Tsukuba Second Research Center on March 1982 and the experimental studies are being continued over a long period of time. This facility is operated by selecting one of three operating modes according to the intensity of insolation and the thermal condition of heat storage unit in order to improve the operating rate and to collect effectively solar energy under a fairly bad weather condition. In this paper, the outline of the facility is described and it is made clear from the experimental results that the operating rate increases in the system.

Authors with affiliations: McNair, G.W., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Cashwell, J.W., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: To assist the U. S. Department of Energy's effort in potential facility site screening in the nuclear waste management program, a computerized model, TRANSIT, is being developed. Utilizing existing data on the location and inventory characteristics of spent nuclear fuel at reactor sites, TRANSIT derives isopleths of transportation mileage, costs, risks and fleet requirements for shipments to storage sites and/or repository sites. This technique provides a graphic, first-order method for use by the Department in future site screening efforts.

Abstract: Photochemical isomerization of trans-azobenzene to cis-homologue, and its inverse cis-trans isomerization were investigated for the purpose of constructing the thermal energy storing system by conversion of solar light energy.
