Abstract: A building element (BE) using phase change material (PCM) was developed. The main material was Sodium Sulfate Decahydrate which was dispersed in unsaturated polyester matrix. The field tests showed reduction of heat storage capacity and deformation of the BE, if used for a long term. These problems could practically be solved by making liquid phase of the PCM gelatinous and optimizing the water content in the PCM. Trial samples of the BE showed wide applicability to floor, wall and ceiling in passive solar residential systems.

Title: SEASONAL HEAT STORAGE IN ROCK AT LULEA SWEDEN.
Affiliations: Lulea Univ of Technology, Lulea, Swed, Lulea Univ of Technology, Lulea, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Nordell, Bo, Lulea Univ of Technology, Lulea, Swed, Lulea Univ of Technology, Lulea, Swed
Abstract: A seasonal heat storage system was constructed in 1982-83 at Lulea University of Technology. The heat extraction from the storage system, 2 GWh, corresponds to the heat demand of 100 one-family-houses in northern Sweden. The store has been in operation since July, 1983. The borehole heat store consists of a rock volume of 100,000 m**3, perforated by 120 vertical boreholes to a depth of 65m. The heat is stored in the rock volume itself. The boreholes work as heat exchangers. During the summer the heat store is supplied with heat via the district heating network. During the winter the heat is utilized for heating of one of the university buildings. Construction, operation and functioning of the heat store is evaluated in a research project conducted by WREL.

Authors with affiliations: Prado, Mark, US Patent Office, Washington, DC,, USA, US Patent Office, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: This study compared three pulsed power sources: 1) capacitor banks (which S. S. I. Inc. uses), 2) homopolar generators (HPG), and 3) alternators (compensated pulsed alternators, or 'rotary flux compressors'). Comparison criteria were mainly: performance, efficiency, operational complexity, reliability, energy density (mass), and manufacturability in space using nonterrestrial resources. Capacitor banks appear to be the most attractive overall, for operating an early Mass Driver based on the lunar surface. Nonetheless, homopolar generator technology is evolving from near infancy and holds promise, especially for inter-orbital propulsion. Alternators were deemed unfeasible for precise trajectories due to timing considerations.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC GENERATORS, SYNCHRONOUS; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ENERGY TRANSFER; LUNAR-BASED MASS DRIVER; PULSED POWER SOURCES; MOON

Abstract: The paper presents preliminary results of an Solar Power Satellites design study based on the use of lunar materials. Commercial feasibility is emphasized in designs. Several power conversion concepts are considered. Photovoltaic systems are found to require least non-lunar materials. Use of a microwave lens is found to allow economic construction of smaller SPSs. Flywheel energy storage probably requires less non-lunar material than chemical or thermal storage.

Title: ELECTRIC EXPLORATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE MILOS ISLAND, GREECE GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES.
Affiliations: Public Power Corp, Athens, Greece, Public Power Corp, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Adamis, P.N., Public Power Corp, Athens, Greece, Public Power Corp, Athens, Greece
Abstract: Milos resources have been investigated since 1971. Five deep wells have been drilled in the eastern part of the island, identifying a high-temperature and high-enthalpy geothermal reservoir. Reservoir characteristics and the thermodynamic properties of the fluid suggest a fluid and heat storage capacity that could support geothermoelectric power plants with a 120 MWe capacity at least. Late in 1985 a 2 MWe geothermal pilot plant will be placed in commercial operation on Milos in order to prove the long term reservoir efficiency. At the same time Public Power Corporation (PPC) will carry out the feasibility study of an initial 60 MWe development on Milos with the longer term objective being the installation of the total possible generating capacity. This paper describes briefly the main features of the Milos geothermal resource, the 2 MWe geothermoelectric power plant, the feasibility study to be carried out, and the development plans.

Authors with affiliations: Fu, Changqing, Nanjing Aeronautical Inst, Nanjing, China, Nanjing Aeronautical Inst, Nanjing, China; Wang, Shicun, Nanjing Aeronautical Inst, Nanjing, China, Nanjing Aeronautical Inst, Nanjing, China
Abstract: The finite element formulation based on the principle of minimum potential energy for the spatial discretization of the equations of motion governing rotor blade aeroelastic problems is presented. A numerical lifting surface method based on the velocity potential is used to evaluate the unsteady airloads on a hovering rotor in compressible flow. The blade is divided into a number of equally spaced elements. Instead of the Hermite polynomials in helicopter dynamics new polynomials are used to define the shape functions so as to reduce both the computer storage and time required. The equations of motion are linearized assuming blade motion to be a small perturbation about the steady deflected shape.

Title: EFFECTS OF gamma -IRRADIATION ON POLYOLEFINES.
Affiliations: Natl Research Council of Canada, Can, Natl Research Council of Canada, Can
Authors with affiliations: Wiles, D.M., Natl Research Council of Canada, Can, Natl Research Council of Canada, Can
Abstract: Polymer degradation upon exposure to high-energy radiation is important in several areas including the sterilization of disposable medical supplies, the use of plastics in the vicinity of nuclear reactor cores, and the controlled modification of polymers for industrial purposes. The gamma -radiation-induced, oxidative deterioration of polypropylene film has been investigated by infrared and electron spin resonance spectroscopy. Two stages of the degradation are apparent: chemical modification during the irradiation itself, followed by a slow but highly significant post-irradiation deterioration during months or years of storage in air. Emphasis is placed on the oxidation during storage by performing irradiations at minus 78 degree C and by following subsequently the formation and reaction of various polypropylene oxidation products at ambient or higher temperatures.

Title: PROPOSED SHENZHEN PUMPED-STORAGE SCHEME.
Authors with affiliations: Northgreaves, K.R.; Wong Oi Ying
Abstract: The Guangdong Nuclear Power Project (GNPP) at Daya Bay is now under construction and, in addition, a 1000 Mw coal-fired power station is expected to be commissioned about 1988. This paper, based upon a recent feasibility study, describes the proposed Shenzhen pumped-storage scheme in relation to electricity consumption in Shenzhen and Hong Kong. P-s plant shares the flexibility in operation of conventional hydro-electric (h-e) plant in the ability to start and stop at short notice and to vary load almost instantaneously. Whilst p-s lacks the 'free fuel' of h-e plant, it does not need large reservoirs and so the capital cost per kilowatt is generally very much lower for p-s plant.

Abstract: The heating ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system for a 2100 m**2 laboratory and office complex of the Berea Forestry Sciences Laboratory of the United States Forest Service was evaluated. The system consists of flat plate water cooled solar collectors, a storage tank, two small wood or gas backup boilers and an absorption cooler. Initial startup and shakedown problems were encountered ranging from premature deterioration of collector panels, system layout limitations to corrosion and misfunction of check valves. Efficiencies of all components were measured and combined into an overall computer model of the building and HVAC system to arrive at a predictable analog for aid in system operation.

Abstract: The integration of dissimilar (CAD/CAM) hardware and software on local and grographically distributed networks is the major problem faced by large organizations today. We begin by examining the existing system for storage, retrieval, control, and distribution of design information at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) and describe a new prototype Engineering Information System (EIS). We then discuss the Department of Energy neutral Data Exchange Format (DOE/DEF) for the sharing of mechanical drawings among DOE installations. Finally, we discuss the potential role of the Intelligent Gateway Processor (IGP) as a transaction controller for engineering resources among contractors of the Air Force Logistics Command (AFLC). IGP capabilities include a unique interpreter-driven user interface which permits the installation and modification of resources and the translation of dissimilar data formats, commands, and protocols, in a unified manner while running non-stop.

Abstract: The term 'Champagne Effect' has been used to describe the tendency for liquids rising in a vertical column to release dissolved gas in the form of bubbles. When such a column is used to seal a pressurized liquid reservoir, as has been proposed for Compressed Air Energy Storage Systems, the formation of these bubbles could result in a loss of sealing head and the subsequent rapid discharge of the reservoir liquid. This paper describes the analytical and experimental modeling of the phenomena and identifies areas which require further investigation.

Title: Seasonal storage of solar heat with large-scale heat pumps
Affiliations: VBB-SWECO Malmoe, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Lemmeke, L., VBB-SWECO Malmoe, Sweden
Abstract: At the end of 1980, one of the municipalities in the south of Sweden invited VBB-SWECO to submit a basic proposal for a heat supply plant to serve the central part of the municipality. According to the terms established by the municipality, the proposal was to be based on the utilization of local energy resources. In this context, particular mention was made of local resources in the form of ground water and sea water. The basic proposal, in which the solution accounted for in this report was presented for the first time, was submitted before the end of the same year. (An indication was also given in the original proposal of the limitations that apply for different heat sources as regards heat pump utilization.) In order to be able to make optimum use of solar radiation and to have the possibility of applying heat pump techniques on a large scale, it was proposed that combined use should be made of surface and ground water. The proposal has so far resulted in work commencing on the construction of a small-scale heat supply plant. This plant can subsequently be extended along the lines of the submitted proposal. © 1985.
Index Keywords: HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HEATING; SEASONAL STORAGE; SOLAR HEAT; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Seasonal thermal energy storage (STES)
Affiliations: Minnesota Geological Survey, University of Minnesota, Twin CitiesUSA
Authors with affiliations: Walton, M., Minnesota Geological Survey, University of Minnesota, Twin CitiesUSA
Abstract: Solar energy, seasonal energy, and energy lost as waste heat provide alternatives to the use of high-grade fuels for low-grade energy needs. The key is Seasonal Thermal Energy Storage, or STES, which requires large heat reservoirs capable of exchanging heat efficiently with natural sources and sinks at very low unit cost. Geologic formations, structures, and materials provide this capacity. Thermal energy may be drawn at relatively high temperatures by direct heat exchange from energy conversion and industrial processes, waste incineration, and stand-by heating capacity, as well as solar radiation. Heat is available at lower temperatures from ambient air, soil and rock, surface water, ice, and ground water. In this article a number of different systems and configurations are described for exchanging heat between seasonal sources and sinks and natural storage media. Clearly a versatile technology, STES has promise as a new, environmentally benign, and socially desirable industry. © 1985.
Index Keywords: GEOLOGY - Engineering; HEAT TRANSFER; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TUNNELS AND TUNNELING; HEAT RESERVOIRS; SEASONAL STORAGE; THERMAL ENERGY; ENERGY STORAGE

Abstract: The transient behavior of packed columns in response to a time-varying inlet depends on intraparticle heat conduction, fluid-particle heat transfer, longitudinal dispersion, and heat losses to surroundings. Approximate analytical solutions are presented in terms of temporal moments of the temperature profile. Superposition of solutions, quick-estimate procedures, sensitivity of the solution to heat transfer coefficients, and optimization of heat storage are discussed.

Authors with affiliations: Tomantschger, K., Inst for Hydrogen Systems,, Mississauga, Ont, Can, Inst for Hydrogen Systems, Mississauga, Ont, Can
Abstract: Although the lead-acid system has been subject to research and development for over 100 years, further improvements are progressing. More manufacturers are incorporating new technology into their batteries increasing energy density, reliability and cycle life. Worldwide efforts focus on a reduction of the internal resistance through radial and other grid designs and a reduction in the weight of grids and cell interconnections by the incorporation of lighter materials. Active mass utilization can be increased by maintaining the electrolyte flow in traction battery cells using inserted air-lift pumps. Pheripheric equipment such as electrolyte circulation, thermal management and over- and under-voltage protection devices are important additions in achieving the high performance required in multimode batteries.

Abstract: The rapid progress in membrane science has shown possible applications of polymer membranes to, for example, energy conversion and storage, transducers and sensors, and artificial organs. As a part of a research program designed to develop reversible control of membrane characteristics, such as ion permeability and membrane potential, we have been engaged in photochemical and electrochemical research on polymer membranes. The purpose of this article is to describe the preparation method and photochemical properties of polymer membranes pigmented with specific dyes. Photoresponse of the membrane potential across the PVC membranes was studied. The reversible potential changes across the membranes upon UV and visible light irradiation have been revealed.

Authors: Hull John R., Schertz William W.
Title: MAGNETICALLY CONFINED KINETIC - ENERGY STORAGE RING - A NEW FUNDAMENTAL ENERGY - STORAGE CONCEPT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hull, John R., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA; Schertz, William W., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: A new fundamental type of energy-storage device which has the potential for low-cost diurnal storage of electrical energy is described. The magnetically confined kinetic-energy storage ring (MCKESR) stores kinetic energy as mass circulated at high velocity around a circular loop. The constraining force necessary to keep the circulating mass (essentially a ring) from flying apart is provided by radial, inwardly directed forces exerted along the perimeter of the loop by magnetic fields. The magnets and ring are contained in a tunnel, which may be buried in the ground. Levitational support against gravity is also provided by magnetic fields. Electrical energy insertion or extraction is similar to that for a synchronous motor/generator. Major advantages of the MCKESR concept are that large devices seem feasible and that costs are inversely related to size. The use of superconducting magnets is expected to result in a very high energy recovery efficiency.
Index Keywords: KINETIC-ENERGY STORAGE RING; LOW-COST DIURNAL STORAGE; KINETICS; MAGNETIC DEVICES; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: ACTIVELY CONTROLLED PENDULOUS FLYWHEEL WITH MAGNETIC BEARINGS.

Abstract: The modeling of the dynamics of a pendulously supported energy storage flywheel with low-loss magnetic bearings is described. The existance of electric, mechanical, and magnetic energy domains motivate the use of bond graph techniques. Bond graph models of the flywheel and bearing are developed separately and then coupled to yield the total system model. The magnetic circuit techniques used in the formulation of the bearing dynamic model are treated in detail. Although design of active control is not incuded, its need is shown by an open-loop eigenanalysis.
Index Keywords: GRAPH MODELS; PENDULOUS FLYWHEELS; BEARINGS - Magnetic; FLYWHEELS

Title: REVIEW OF AN OPERATING ICE STORAGE SYSTEM PERFORMANCE.

Authors with affiliations: McNeil, W.P., Commonwealth Edison Co, Chicago, IL,, USA, Commonwealth Edison Co, Chicago, IL, USA; Mathey, J.D., Commonwealth Edison Co, Chicago, IL,, USA, Commonwealth Edison Co, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: Ice storage systems have the potential to save building owners a substantial portion of their air conditioning costs. In addition, electric utilities see this technology as one method to reduce summer peak demands on their systems. Most utilities offer rate incentives to encourage customers to consider this alternative. When one commercial customer decided to install an ice storage system in its new office, the local utility installed additional metering to monitor its performance. Several other ice storage installations are also being monitored. This report represents the results of the data analysis for the first two cooling seasons. It compares the system performance to a standard centrifugal chiller and also points out opportunities for maximizing the savings with the existing system.

Authors with affiliations: Ceylan, H.T., Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Industrial, & Mechanical Engineering,, Platteville, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Industrial & Mechanical Engineering, Platteville, WI, USA; Myers, G.E., Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Industrial, & Mechanical Engineering,, Platteville, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Industrial & Mechanical Engineering, Platteville, WI, USA
Abstract: Solutions to heat-conduction transients with time-dependent input forcing functions may be required in thermal-design problems, the best-known area of applications being heating and air conditioning. The response-coefficient method can be used to find long-time solutions to heat-conduction transients with time-dependent input forcing functions. The method is economical and applicable to a wide variety of problems. Applications of the method to one- and two-dimensional heat-conduction problems are discussed in this paper. A two-dimensional illustrative example of an underground solar energy-storage tank is included.

Title: ADVANCED PHASE-CHANGE MATERIALS FOR PASSIVE SOLAR STORAGE APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA, Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Salyer, Ival O., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA, Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA; Sircar, Anil K., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA, Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA; Chartoff, Richard P., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA, Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA; Miller, Daniel E., Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA, Univ of Dayton Research Inst, OH, USA
Abstract: The objectives of the research were to find, test, and develop low-cost, effective phase-change materials that freeze and melt near 25 degree C, and can be economically incorporated into common building materials (cement, concrete, plaster, plasterboard, floor tiles) by processes that are readily adaptable to the manufacture of these building materials. The goals were successfully attained using low-cost, crystalline, alkyl hydrocarbons and economic processes for containment in building materials. The melting and freezing temperatures of the phase-change material can be 'tailored' and thereby precisely located in the desired temperature range by blending the nearest neighbors. This can be done without loss in the heats of fusion and crystallization.
Index Keywords: ALKYL HYDROCARBONS; PASSIVE SOLAR STORAGE; PHASE-CHANGE MATERIALS; BUILDING MATERIALS; ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROCARBONS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: FEASIBILITY OF FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE IN SPACECRAFT APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: AiResearch Manufacturing Co, USA, AiResearch Manufacturing Co, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olmsted, Donald R., AiResearch Manufacturing Co, USA, AiResearch Manufacturing Co, USA
Abstract: A large-scale, high-energy-density, composite flywheel energy storage unit for use in an electric-vehicle propulsion system is described. The flywheel has a total energy storage capacity of 16 kWh, of which 12. 5 kWh are available as usable energy. This rating is suitable for use in multiple-unit systems to meet the anticipated energy storage capacity requirements of the space station. With further enhancement of flywheel energy storage capability, it will be technically feasible to use this unit design as the basis for a large-scale flywheel unit for spacecraft applications.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC-VEHICLE PROPULSION; FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEELS; PROPULSION - Electric Energy; SPACECRAFT

Authors: Faget Nanette M., Fraser Jr. Wilson M., Simon William E.
Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR A SPACE SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA
Authors with affiliations: Faget, Nanette M., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA; Fraser Jr., Wilson M., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA; Simon, William E., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, USA
Abstract: The solar dynamic power system (SDPS) uses rotating or reciprocating heat engines to convert the sun's energy into electricity. Three heat-engine types, based on the Brayton, Rankine, and Stirling cycles, are described. Because the engine requires a relatively constant-temperature source of energy throughout the orbit, a thermal energy storage (TES) system is needed for dark-side operation. A TES system which uses a phase-change material to absorb energy at essentially constant temperature on the light side of the orbit and releases this energy to the engine at the same temperature for use on the dark side is described. Both latent- and sensible-heat systems are described. Integrating the TES system into the overall electrical power system is discussed. Required technology and ongoing TES efforts for SDPS development are assessed.
Index Keywords: SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEMS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; HEAT ENGINES

Authors: Isshiki Naotsugu, Kurosaki Yasuo, Okada Keiji, Sawase Kazuhisa
Title: THERMAL AND ECONOMIC EVALUATIONS OF THE SNOW-MELTING SYSTEM ON THE TRACK UTILIZING NATURAL HEAT SOURCES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Nihon Univ, Jpn, Nihon Univ, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Isshiki, Naotsugu, Nihon Univ, Jpn, Nihon Univ, Jpn; Kurosaki, Yasuo, Nihon Univ, Jpn, Nihon Univ, Jpn; Okada, Keiji, Nihon Univ, Jpn, Nihon Univ, Jpn; Sawase, Kazuhisa, Nihon Univ, Jpn, Nihon Univ, Jpn
Abstract: Two new snow-melting systems using natural heat sources to conserve energy are described. One consists of engine heat pumps and thermal storage tanks, and the other is a solar collector coupled to an aquifer that stores solar energy from the track in summer to be pumped in winter. These systems consume much less fuel than the conventional system which sprinkles boiler-heated water of approximately 15 degree C to remove snow.
Index Keywords: NATURAL HEAT SOURCES; SNOW-MELTING SYSTEMS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SNOW MELTING SYSTEMS

Title: OPERATION AND CONTROL OF ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Honeywell Inc, Commercial Div,, Arlington Heights, IL, USA, Honeywell Inc, Commercial Div, Arlington Heights, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Shavit, Gideon, Honeywell Inc, Commercial Div,, Arlington Heights, IL, USA, Honeywell Inc, Commercial Div, Arlington Heights, IL, USA; Goodman, Harrison, Honeywell Inc, Commercial Div,, Arlington Heights, IL, USA, Honeywell Inc, Commercial Div, Arlington Heights, IL, USA
Abstract: The successful implementation of control strategies based on three energy storage systems is discussed. The types of storage systems are hot water for false loading of the chiller plant to generate the necessary heating load during the heating season; storage of hot and cold water for time-of-day peak demand reduction; and storage of cold water for a full day operation. The last two systems implement the empty cell type of storage system. Control of the storage system in all cases was done by defining several modes of operation to satisfy the various requirements. A computer control system implemented the modes of operation in all three systems. Modes of operation for the building with time-of-day energy changes are described in detail. In addition, the lessons learned from operation of these buildings are discussed.
Index Keywords: COLD STORAGE; COMPUTERS - Applications; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; REFRIGERATION; TANKS; BUTTERFLY VALVES; CHILLER COEFFICIENT OF PERFORMANCE (COP); CHILLER PLANT; V-BALL VALVES; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: UNIFIED GAS SUPPLY SYSTEM OF THE USSR.

Abstract: The gas industry is one of the most important sectors of the fuel-energy complex of the USSR. It is based on a unified system for supplying gas that consists of all technologically interrelated objects for production, mainline transportation, storage, refining, and distribution of gas. In this paper, the most important stages in the formation and development of the unified gas supply system and its separate elements are examined. The basic provisions of the technical policy of the industry concerning the problems of improving the technology and the technical means for developing gas and gas-condensate fields, and the treatment, transportation, underground storage, and refining of gas are formulated.

Title: STORAGE BIN-HOPPER SYSTEM FOR PREVENTING FLOW PROBLEMS OF POWDER AND GRANULAR MATERIAL.
Source title: EFCE Publication Series (European Federation of Chemical Engineering)
Affiliations: Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, USA, Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Huq, M.U., Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, USA, Univ of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, USA
Abstract: A storage bin-hopper system has been developed to have a fundamental understanding of material flow. It is specifically designed to study controlled, predictable discharge rates of cohesive, floodable, hard to handle powdery and coarse materials - without arching, bridging, flushing or sporadic flow, by the creation of a pseudo angle of repose. This is accomplished by the introduction of ridges along the wall of the bin-hopper system. This study shows that the ridged bin-hopper system reduces stress on particulate materials, thus preventing bridging and enhancing flow. It also lowers the surface energy layer thickness along the wall, thus lowering cohesion with time within the bin, preventing bridges and voids to form at the transition between the cylinder and the hopper in a storage bin, developing mass flow with minimum aggregation. In this investigation, the flow problems with several powders and granular materials have been studied.
Index Keywords: BINS; FLOW OF SOLIDS - Granular Materials; MATERIALS HANDLING - Hoppers; FLOW PATTERNS; MULTI-PRODUCT STORAGE BIN; PARTICULATE MATERIALS; RIDGED BIN-HOPPER; STORAGE BIN-HOPPER SYSTEM; BINS

Authors: Welty D.L., Sutton A.L., Jones D.D., Nye J.C., Vetter R.L.
Title: LABOR, EQUIPMENT AND ENERGY REQUIREMENTS FOR HANDLING SWINE AND DAIRY MANURE WITH AN ABOVE-GROUND STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, USA, Purdue Univ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Welty, D.L., Purdue Univ, USA, Purdue Univ, USA; Sutton, A.L., Purdue Univ, USA, Purdue Univ, USA; Jones, D.D., Purdue Univ, USA, Purdue Univ, USA; Nye, J.C., Purdue Univ, USA, Purdue Univ, USA; Vetter, R.L., Purdue Univ, USA, Purdue Univ, USA
Abstract: With the diversity of opinion amongst researchers on the value of above-ground storage systems, a case study was conducted to investigate the labor, equipment and energy requirements of Slurrystore manure management systems on 3 dairy operations and 1 swine operation in central Indiana. Practices for manure collection and transport into storage were dependent on weather conditions for the open lot facilities. When the paved collection area was under roof, most of the weather variability was removed and scraping time and frequency was more predictable. Scraping was the most time consuming operation on the dairy farms. For both manure collection and removal, labor was the largest expense. These and other aspects of the study are discussed in the paper.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Storage; MATERIALS HANDLING - Equipment; PERSONNEL; ABOVE-GROUND STORAGE SYSTEM; DAIRY MANURE; LAND APPLICATION; MANURE COLLECTION; SLURRYSTORE MANURE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; SWINE MANURE; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Authors: Merlina S., Peluso G., Rossati C., Sorokin A.
Title: PUMPING STATION FOR FRESH WATER SUPPLY.

Abstract: The Zambelli photovoltaic pumping station supplies drinking water to the Lessinia mountain area near Verona. The specific design of this stand alone plant is characterized by direct connection, i. e. without intermediate battery storage, between PV-generator and the variable frequency inverters powering two asynchrone motored piston pumps. Completely automatic operation, including maximum power tracking is assured by a process controller providing also data monitoring of the system, of which first operating data are presented.

Title: ON THE OPTIMUM DESIGN OF A STEEL FLYWHEEL FOR A HYBRID CITY BUS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Politecnico di Turino, Italy, Politecnico di Turino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Genta, Giancarlo, Politecnico di Turino, Italy, Politecnico di Turino, Italy
Abstract: The design of a flywheel energy storage unit for a hybrid city bus and its optimization, which aimed at obtaining a fairly high energy density with the lowest possible complexity and cost are described. A simple analytical expression for the disk profile is suggested. The optimization is performed using a simple one-dimensional routine based on the finite-difference integration of the so-called called disc equation. The stress field in the flywheel is then computed using an axisymmetrical finite-element model.
Index Keywords: HYBRID CITY BUSES; STEEL FLYWHEELS; FLYWHEELS; FLYWHEELS - Design; MOTOR BUS TRANSPORTATION; MOTOR BUSES

Title: CONSTRUCTION AND TESTING OF A COMPACT PULSED HOMOPOLAR GENERATOR POWER SUPPLY.
Affiliations: Parker Kinetic Designs Inc, Austin,, TX, USA, Parker Kinetic Designs Inc, Austin, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Martin, A.M., Parker Kinetic Designs Inc, Austin,, TX, USA, Parker Kinetic Designs Inc, Austin, TX, USA; Weldon, J.W., Parker Kinetic Designs Inc, Austin,, TX, USA, Parker Kinetic Designs Inc, Austin, TX, USA
Abstract: The authors have constructed and tested a compact pulsed-homopolar generator power supply designed to drive electromagnetic launch (EML) systems. The power supply couples a 6. 7-MJ compact homopolar generator to a coaxial aluminum inductor to provide the pulse conditioning required for EML applications. A portable, ancillary power supply was constructed to house the generator controller as well as its hydraulic, pneumatic, and electric auxiliaries; also included in this EML power supply is a crowbar system for generator protection. This particular power supply is configured to operate with the inductor at room temperature, although the inductor is designed so that it may be cryogenically cooled with liquid nitrogen to maximize energy storage. At room temperature, 1. 25 MJ is stored in the inductor at 610-kA peak current.
Index Keywords: ELECTROMAGNETS - Electric Power Supplies; COMPACT PULSED HOMOPOLAR GENERATOR; ELECTROMAGNETIC LAUNCH SYSTEM; PULSE GENERATORS

Authors: Gehman Jr. V.H., Fenneman D.B., Gripshover R.J.
Title: EFFECTS OF ALLOYS AND SURFACE TREATMENTS ON ELECTRICAL BREAKDOWN STRENGTH OF WATER AND WATER MIXTURES.
Affiliations: US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gehman Jr., V.H., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA; Fenneman, D.B., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA; Gripshover, R.J., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA
Abstract: Many pulsed-power machines use purified water as the high-voltage dielectric in intermediate storage capacitors. Another candidate dielectric liquid for future pulsed-power devices is a mixture of ethylene glycol and water, because this mixture can extend the intrinsic time constant from hundreds of microseconds to tens of milliseconds. A longer intrinsic time constant eases the requirements for the charging portion of the pulsed-power train. An important characteristic of the liquid dielectric is the energy density. Since energy density varies as the square of the electric field, electrical breakdown is an important physical phenomenon for dielectric mixtures. The effect on breakdown of several alloys and surface treatments are examined for stainless steel and aluminum electrodes in subzero temperature mixtures of ethylene glycol and water, and in near-zero temperature purified water.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES; GLYCOLS - Applications; LIQUIDS - Electric Breakdown; WATER - Applications; ALUMINUM ELECTRODES; STAINLESS STEEL ELECTRODES; WATER-ETHYLENE GLYCOL MIXTURES; DIELECTRIC MATERIALS

Authors: Angrilli Francesco, Basso Roberto, Rossi Aldo
Title: DIAGNOSIS AND MAINTENANCE SYSTEM FOR AN ELECTROMECHANICAL ENERGY STORAGE MACHINE BASED ON A NEW TYPE OF FLUIDIC TRANSDUCER.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ di Padova, Italy, Univ di Padova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Angrilli, Francesco, Univ di Padova, Italy, Univ di Padova, Italy; Basso, Roberto, Univ di Padova, Italy, Univ di Padova, Italy; Rossi, Aldo, Univ di Padova, Italy, Univ di Padova, Italy
Abstract: A measurement system for the diagnosis and maintenance of an electromechanical energy storage machine is described. The machine is a compact, low-weight homopolar generator, consisting of two concentric counter-rotating drum rotors, which store 2 MJ of kinetic energy. The rotors are mounted on air bearings, and operate continuously in the transient mode in the range of 3000-6000 rpm. The strong magnetic and electric fields present in the machine do not allow use of normal displacement transducers. Therefore, a fluidic sensor, coupled with an ultra-miniature solid-state pressure transducer is used to allow accurate measurements within a range of 2 mm and 0-200 Hz. A survey control system composed of ten fluidic transducers and two spin velocity transducers is described.
Index Keywords: ELECTROMECHANICAL ENERGY STORAGE; FLUIDIC TRANSDUCERS; TRANSDUCERS - Energy Storage; FLUIDIC DEVICES

Title: STUDY AND APPLICATION OF NON-LINEAR TURN-OFF SNUBBER FOR POWER ELECTRONIC SWITCHES.
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Rand Afrikaans Univ, Johannesburg, S Afr, Rand Afrikaans Univ, Johannesburg, S Afr
Authors with affiliations: Steyn, C.G., Rand Afrikaans Univ, Johannesburg, S Afr, Rand Afrikaans Univ, Johannesburg, S Afr; Van Wyk, J.D., Rand Afrikaans Univ, Johannesburg, S Afr, Rand Afrikaans Univ, Johannesburg, S Afr
Abstract: A nonlinear capacitive turn-off snubber is discussed. Customarily, only linear capacitors are used in high frequency power electronic switches. However, ceramic ferroelectric materials, with ratios of initial to final capacitance of 25, are found suitable and are investigated. The energy stored in these nonlinear capacitors, with an initial capacitance of 300 nF, amounts to only about 1. 1 mJ at 300 V, compared to 13. 5 mJ in a 300 nF linear capacitor. The differences in switching behavior and switch turn-off loss in these two cases are negligible. This nonlinear snubber is analyzed approximately by assuming an exponential relation between capacitance and voltage; it is also subjected to a more accurate analysis by means of a computer program. The latter uses an exact capacitance-voltage curve stored on data file.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; CERAMIC MATERIALS - Ferroelectric; CAPACITANCES-VOLTAGE CURVE; FREQUENCY POWER ELECTRONIC SWITCHES; NONLINEAR CAPACITIVE TURN-OFF SNUBBERS; CAPACITORS, CERAMIC

Authors: Hoberecht Mark A., Rieker Lorra L.
Title: DESIGN OF A REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL SYSTEM FOR SPACE STATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hoberecht, Mark A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA; Rieker, Lorra L., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Abstract: The alkaline regenerative fuel cell (RFC) system is the sole electrochemical energy storage system technology selected for NASA's Advanced Development Program for Space Station. It was selected for its advanced state-of-technology readiness and high degree of system-level design flexibility. The goal is to deliver a 10-kw alkaline engineering model system (EMS) by 1987. This is to be a fully autonomous high-voltage system (120 V), capable of demonstrating good overall round-trip electrical efficiency (55%) with extended life (20,000 hr). The EMS must meet or exceed all these goals in order to be suitable for the space station.
Index Keywords: NASA; REGENERATIVE FUEL CELLS; SPACE STATIONS; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; FUEL CELLS

Authors: Dicello J.F., Schillaci M.E., McCabe C.W., Doss J.D., Paciotti M., Berardo P., Dicello J.F.
Title: MESON INTERACTIONS IN NMOS AND CMOS STATIC RAMS.
Affiliations: Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dicello, J.F., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Schillaci, M.E., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; McCabe, C.W., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Doss, J.D., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Paciotti, M., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Berardo, P., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Dicello, J.F., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA
Abstract: The rate of error induction in 4K static RAMs from high-energy pion and muon beams has been measured at three energies and as a function of depth in plastic. Preliminary data for 16K NMOS and 64K CMOS static RAMs were also obtained. Only two errors were observed from muon beams incident upon 4K chips for 1. 4 multiplied by 10**1**0 particles/cm**2 . In contrast, energetic pion beams produced errors in the same chips at the rate of typically 5 multiplied by 10-**8 errors per incident particle per cm**2 . In the pion beams the rate decreased slowly with decreasing energy until the particles approached the end of their range. In the stopping region, the error rate continued to decrease for positively charged pions but increased about a factor of seven for negatively charged pions. Monte Carlo programs have been run both to simulate the production of pions in the atmosphere as a function of elevation and to simulate the interactions of pions in the 4K chip.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; CMOS TECHNOLOGY; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Authors: Browning John S., Koga R., Kolasinski W.A.
Title: SINGLE EVENT UPSET RATE ESTIMATES FOR A 16-K CMOS SRAM.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Browning, John S., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Koga, R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Kolasinski, W.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: A radiation-hardened 16-K CMOS SRAM has been developed for satellite and deep space applications. The RAM memory cell was modeled to predict the critical charge, necessary for single-particle upset, as a function of temperature, total dose, and hardening feedback resistance. Laboratory measurements of the single-event cross section and effective funnel length were made using the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory's 88-in. cyclotron to generate high-energy krypton ions. The combination of modeled and measured parameters permitted estimation of the upset rate for the ramcell and the mean time to failure for a 512-K word, 22-bit memory system using error detection and correction circuits while functioning in the Adam's '90% worst case' cosmic ray environment. The presentation is in the form of a tutorial review, summarizing the results of substantial research efforts within the single-event community.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MOS; SINGLE EVENT UPSET; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Title: CURRENT-MODE CONTROL, FIVE DIFFERENT TYPES, USED WITH THE THREE BASIC OF POWER CONVERTERS: SMALL-SIGNAL AC AND LARGE-SIGNAL DC CHARACTERIZATION, STABILITY REQUIREMENTS, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PRACTICAL CIRCUITS.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Design Automation Inc, Lexington,, MA, USA, Design Automation Inc, Lexington, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Redl, Richard, Design Automation Inc, Lexington,, MA, USA, Design Automation Inc, Lexington, MA, USA; Sokal, Nathan O., Design Automation Inc, Lexington,, MA, USA, Design Automation Inc, Lexington, MA, USA
Abstract: Current-mode control effectively eliminates the phase lag of the control function, associated with the output filter inductor or the energy-storage inductor. The several types of current-mode controllers differ slightly in their phase-lag characteristics, but they are all far superior to the commonly used PWM duty-ratio controllers. Unfortunately, industry has been slow to appreciate and exploit the considerable advantages of current-mode control. There seem to be two reasons for that: (a) the unavailability of integrated circuits which are well-suited to implementing current-mode controllers and (b) the lack of detailed, systematically organized, theoretical and practical information on current-mode controllers. The authors provide a well-organized compendium of useful information for the design engineer who wants to understand the operation of a current-mode controlled power converter and to accomplish an optimal design.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE - Control; PULSE WIDTH MODULATION; SYSTEM STABILITY; CURRENT-MODE CONTROLLED POWER CONVERTER; LARGE SIGNAL DC CHARCTERIZATION; PWM DUTY-RATIO CONTROLLERS; SMALL SIGNAL AC CHARACTERIZATION; CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES

Authors: Gahn Randall F., Hagedorn Norman H., Johnson Jerome A.
Title: CYCLING PERFORMANCE OF THE IRON-CHROMIUM REDOX ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gahn, Randall F., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Hagedorn, Norman H., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Johnson, Jerome A., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Extended charge-discharge cycling of this electrochemical storage system at 65 degree C was performed on 14. 5 cm**2 single cells and a four cell, 867 cm**2, bipolar stack. Both the anolyte and catholyte reactant fluids contained 1 molar concentrations of iron and chromium chlorides in hydrochloric acid and were separated by a low-selectivity, cation-exchange membrane. The effect of cycling on the chromium electrode and the cation-exchange membrane was determined. Bismuth and bismuth-lead catalyzed chromium electrodes and a radiation-grafted polyethylene membrane were evaluated by cycling between 5 and 85 percent state-of-charge at 80 mA/cm**2 and by periodic charge-discharge polarization measurements to 140 mA/cm**2. Gradual performance losses were observed during cycling but were recoverable by completely discharging the system. Good scale-up to the 867 cm**2 stack was achieved.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ELECTROCHEMICAL POWER STORAGE; FLOW BATTERIES; REDOX; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Kukreja L.M., Sehgal S.K., Chatterjee U.K.
Title: Pulsed operation of a segmented longitudinal discharge CO2 laser without ballast impedance
Affiliations: Laser Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Bombay 400 085, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kukreja, L.M., Laser Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Bombay 400 085, United States; Sehgal, S.K., Laser Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Bombay 400 085, United States; Chatterjee, U.K., Laser Division, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Bombay 400 085, United States
Abstract: It is shown that a longitudinal CO2 laser with two discharge tubes electrically coupled in parallel can be operated in pulsed mode without ballast impedance. This scheme not only yields much higher efficiency (up to 13% at the maximum output energy) and eliminates component failure at high pulse repetition frequency (prf) but also facilitates short pulse availability. In the absence of ballast, current and laser pulse width decrease on increasing the voltage applied to the discharge tubes but these quantities remain unaffected on varying the value of the energy storage capacitor. This enables an independent control of the laser pulse duration and energy. Threshold energy for the onset of nonuniformities in the glow discharge reduces almost exponentially on increasing the discharge current pulse duration but rises on decreasing the operating value of E/N, the electric field to neutral gas density ratio. The maximum output laser energy of about 1 J/pulse, adjustable pulse duration from 30 μs to about 2 ms, and prf up to 50 Hz have been obtained.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide laser; energy yield; nonhuman; pulsed laser; theoretical study

Title: MECHANISM OF PHOTOTRANSFORMATIONS IN MEDIA FOR AN OPTICAL MEMORY.
Source title: Optoelectronics, Instrumentation and Data Processing (English translation of Avtometriya)
Authors with affiliations: Malinovskii, V.K.
Abstract: Experimental data on the manifestations of a memory when light acts on various types of materials are analyzed. It is shown that in media with spatial dispersion, the energy of the absorbed light quantum is localized in small spatial scales ( LT AN BR v RT AN BR approximately 10** minus **2**2cm** minus **3). The mechanism by which the dimensions are limited (the localization radius) is different for different materials: in the case of crystals (i. e. , crystals with impurities, defects, and structural disturbances, etc. ) the radius of the distorted lattice in the region of the impurities and natural defects plays the role of the characteristic dimension; in glasses it is the correlation radius of the structure, and in complex molecules it is individual fragments. It is concluded that the two-stage process by which the energy of the absorbed light quantum is transferred to the lattice serves as the microscopic basis for explaining photophase phenomena.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS - Optical Properties; FERROELECTRIC MATERIALS; GLASS - Optical Properties; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS; PHOTOTRANSFORMATIONS; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: The rheological behaviour of suspensions of fat particles in oil interpreted in terms of a transient-network model
Affiliations: Rheology Group, Department of Applied Physics, Twente University of Technology, Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kamphuis, H., Rheology Group, Department of Applied Physics, Twente University of Technology, Enschede, Netherlands; Jongschaap, R.J.J., Rheology Group, Department of Applied Physics, Twente University of Technology, Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: The transient-network model for concentrated dispersions, described in a previous paper, is used to describe the rheological behaviour of dispersions of glyceryl tristearate crystals in paraffin oil. The model prediction of the storage modulus of this system is compared with corresponding expressions given in literature. Model calculations are carried out to fit the linear viscoelastic behaviour of the system as well as its stress response in large amplitude shear experiments. Information is thus obtained about the stiffness and strength of the interparticle bonds, and the chance of them breaking in a state of rest or as the result of flow. It is concluded that the probability of interparticle bond fracture strongly depends on the measure of bond stretching. The general findings link up with the Lennard-Jones potential which is assumed to describe the potential energy of the bonds between the particles. Accurate measurements of the temperature dependence of the dynamic moduli by making use of a torsion resonator lead to the conclusion that the energy dissipation at a high frequency originates mainly from the flow of liquid around the particles. © 1985 Steinkopff.
Author Keywords: fat particles; rheological behaviour; structured dispersion; Suspension; transient-network model

Title: MARS SURVIVAL KIT ENGINEERING.
Affiliations: Space Ho Ltd, La Jolla, CA, USA, Space Ho Ltd, La Jolla, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Love, Budd, Space Ho Ltd, La Jolla, CA, USA, Space Ho Ltd, La Jolla, CA, USA
Abstract: To identify unsolved design and manufacturing problems in Mars survival equipment, the processing of Mars raw materials to provide fuel, air and water is evaluated and food, shelter, and power requirements are examined. Dependence is placed upon reports that water (ice) is abundant on Mars, because hydrogen and oxygen may possibly be obtained by water electrolysis. Power from solar and nuclear sources is seen as a critical problem because of the large quantities of energy required and the demand for high-output low-mass storage batteries.
Index Keywords: AEROSPACE ENGINEERING; MANNED MARS MISSION; MARS; SPACE MANUFACTURING; SPACE PROGRAM; SPACE FLIGHT

Title: HIGH SPEED REACTION WHEELS FOR SATELLITE ATTITUDE CONTROL AND ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Studer, Philip, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Rodriguez, Ernest, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: Attitude control and energy storage (ACES) is a concept which synergistically combines two key spacecraft functions into common hardware capable of maintaining three-axis control over the attitude of the spacecraft and supplying spacecraft electrical power during the eclipse. High-speed reaction wheels produce control torques by reaction with the spacecraft structure via a high-efficiency bidirectional energy conversion device (motor/generator). Recovery of the energy stored in the reaction wheel drastically changes the optimization criteria normally applied to reaction wheels for spacecraft. The power dissipated in the armature of the motor/generator is found to be independent of wheel design speed. Therefore attitude control torques can be efficiently provided with high-speed reaction wheels. A minimum of four wheels are necessary to control the four variables, three torque vectors, and power. Low earth orbiting spacecraft with a typical orbit period of 90 minutes place stringent demands on the energy storage element of the power system. An integrated flywheel system that meets these demands is described.
Index Keywords: ATTITUDE CONTROLS; REACTION WHEELS; CONTROL, MECHANICAL VARIABLES - Position; ENERGY STORAGE; SATELLITES

Abstract: Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) has potential as a viable technology for use in electric utility load leveling. The advantage of SMES over other energy storage technologies is its high net round-trip energy efficiency. The major features and costs of an improved SMES design are reviewed.

Abstract: A flywheel-powered propulsion system for full-size transit buses is described. The system design is based on the use of a large-capacity, high-energy-density composite flywheel, used in conjunction with state-of-the-art power and control electronic components. The feasibility of a new alternative propulsion system for transit buses that is economical, energy-efficient, ecologically acceptable, and not directly dependent on petroleum-based fuels is discussed.

Abstract: The conceptual design of spacecraft thermal management systems and their components is described in order to provide a basis for the development and implementation of future technologies. The components of the spacecraft thermal management system include heat pipes, latent thermal energy storage materials, radiators, and other thermal structures. The design problem becomes one of selecting a combination of these components subject to both spacecraft mission and launch requirements. To facilitate this design process, a knowledge-based design assistant is being developed in the artificial intelligence programming language, PROLOG. The goal has been to amplify the capabilities of an experienced designer by putting significant decision-making, and search and retrieval facilities at his or her disposal.

Abstract: For grid independent wind energy applications it is necessary to smooth the substantial power fluctuations associated with turbulence, and an energy buffer with a storage capacity of approximately one or two minutes (at average power levels) has been shown to give good smoothing. This paper discusses an experimental assessment of such an energy buffer, using a hydraulic accumulator as the storage device, and quantifies - for a wind/diesel system - the beneficial effect that such an energy buffer has on the system fuel saving and the number of diesel starts.

Abstract: The handling of coal liquid mixtures involves preparation of a stable slurry, together with the problems associated with storage, mixing and pumping. A knowledge of the rheological properties of coal slurries is therefore important for the effective application of these processes and more efficient use of energy. This paper is concerned with the rheological behavior of water and oil based coal slurries, specifically with respect to the effects of particle size distribution and pH of the suspending medium.

Abstract: The paper describes the philosophy, design and installation of an almost all electric hotel, whose only other energy utilisation is that of gas for kitchen hob units. The hotel, located in England, has been built in a project period of twelve months, comprising one hundred bedrooms, and function facilities for some six hundred persons. The basic components of the system are: lighting using modern energy efficient light sources; bedroom heating of the convecter type; heating in public areas by means of heat pumps; hot water utilising bulk electric water storage heaters.

Abstract: With the passage of the National Waste Policy Act of 1982 it became the responsibility of nuclear utilities to store their spent fuel on site until the Department of Energy has put in place those facilities necessary to accept spent fuel for disposition. According to DOE's present planning, that facility might be a monitored, retrievable storage system located in the eastern part of the United States. The National Waste Policy Act requires DOE to initiate the acceptance of fuel in 1998. Placing this interim storage responsibility on the shoulders of the utilities has caused, at least at some utilities, some consternation. This paper discusses the dilemma confronting utilities concerning what to do with spent fuels.

Title: WIND POWER AND CAPACITY CREDITS: RESEARCH AND IMPLEMENTATION ISSUES ARISING FROM AGGREGATION WITH OTHER RENEWABLE POWER SOURCES AND UTILITY DEMAND MANAGEMENT MEASURES.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Library of Congress, Congressional, Research Service, Washington, DC,, USA, Library of Congress, Congressional Research Service, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sissine, Fred, Library of Congress, Congressional, Research Service, Washington, DC,, USA, Library of Congress, Congressional Research Service, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: This paper suggests that there are at least four technical options which can be employed, separately or together, to improve the capacity displacement ability derived from high penetrations of windfarms and other renewable power sources. The three most familiar options combine a windfarm with energy storage, other dispersed windfarms, or with other renewable power sources. The latter two options aggregate generation sources into a more constant and predictable total output that more closely approximates the utility's load curve. Another way to improve wind (or other renewable power) capacity credits is to plan installations so that they correspond with utility efforts to shape its load curve with demand management activities.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY RESOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; CAPACITY CREDITS; CAPACITY DISPLACEMENT ABILITY; LOAD CURVE SHAPE; RENEWABLE ENERGY RESOURCES; UTILITY DEMAND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES; WIND FARMS; WIND POWER

Authors with affiliations: Giorgi, D., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA, Energy Compression Research Corp, Del Mar, CA, USA; Lindner, K., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA, Energy Compression Research Corp, Del Mar, CA, USA; Long, J., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA, Energy Compression Research Corp, Del Mar, CA, USA; Navapanich, T., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA, Energy Compression Research Corp, Del Mar, CA, USA; Zucker, O., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA, Energy Compression Research Corp, Del Mar, CA, USA
Abstract: The inductive and kinetic energy transfer efficiencies for a single-stage Meatgrinder circuit are compared with two other circuits (the parallel storage inductor-switch-load inductor circuit, and the transformer circuit). The transformer circuit is the least practical. The one-stage Meatgrinder circuit provides the highest energy and current to the load as well as the highest energy available to the implosion. With these parasitic factors included, the performance of the three circuits described is inferior to the idealized theoretical case. Nonetheless, the Meatgrinder circuit still surpasses the other in overall magnetic and kinetic efficiency.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INDUCTORS, POWER TYPE; IMPLODING PLASMA LOADS; INDUCTIVE ENERGY TRANSFER; ELECTRIC NETWORKS

Authors: Tripoli G.A., Turchi P.J., Conte D., Seiler S.W.
Title: DESIGN AND OPERATION OF A 0. 4 MJ CURRENT MULTIPLIER INDUCTIVE STORE WITH MULTIPLE EXPLODING FOIL SWITCHING.
Affiliations: R & D Associates, Alexandria,, VA, USA, R & D Associates, Alexandria, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tripoli, G.A., R & D Associates, Alexandria,, VA, USA, R & D Associates, Alexandria, VA, USA; Turchi, P.J., R & D Associates, Alexandria,, VA, USA, R & D Associates, Alexandria, VA, USA; Conte, D., R & D Associates, Alexandria,, VA, USA, R & D Associates, Alexandria, VA, USA; Seiler, S.W., R & D Associates, Alexandria,, VA, USA, R & D Associates, Alexandria, VA, USA
Abstract: For high-current experimentation on plasma-flow switching, a pulse generator incorporating magnetic energy storage, current multiplication, and exploding-foil switching has been developed. In this system, a 400-kJ-20-kV capacitor bank is ignitron-switched into a magnetic store and switching circuit consisting of a 12-turn toroidal transformer primary with an exploding-foil opening switch in each turn. At peak current, the foil fuses explode and a single-turn secondary circuit, in common volume with the primary, is closed through a plasma-flow switch. Uniform distribution of alternating primary turn-inductances and fuse-resistances reduces component voltage levels to 1/12 that of a single-fuse equivalent circuit. The operation of the current multiplier is described, and system performance is evaluated.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC SWITCHES; PLASMAS - Flow; CURRENT MULTIPLIER INDUCTIVE STORE; MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; MULTIPLE EXPLODING FOIL SWITCHING; PLASMA-FLOW SWITCHING; PULSE GENERATORS

Affiliations: Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia,, PA, USA, Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Laing, Thomas D., Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia,, PA, USA, Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Abstract: Utility interactive photovoltaic systems will offer a viable alternative to centrally generated electricity if the proper incentives are created. It is necessary for utilities to design buy-back rates that both encourage investment in intermittent technologies and ensure that utilities and rate payers benefit from dispersed power sources. This paper examines the disincentives created by Florida's buy-back scheme. A study of photovoltaic performance data and load profiles of a typical Florida utility shows that the pricing formula discourages investment in photovoltaics and may increase variance in the demand for utility generated electricity.

Title: DIGEST OF TECHNICAL PAPERS - 5TH IEEE PULSED POWER CONFERENCE.
Abstract: The following topics are dealt with: diagnostics; capacitor banks; gas discharge; switching; diodes and beams; pulsers; data and control; multi-megampere generation; open switching; pulse power switching; foil fuses and open switches; power flow and insulation; microprocessor-based data acquisition and control; high current and gas discharges; high voltage and plasma switching; photoconductive switching and electric guns; gas discharge and solid-state fast switching; rotating machines and pulsers; cryogenic generators; and energy storage systems. 260 papers were presented, of which 211 are published in full in the present proceedings.

Title: ENGINEERING HIGH RELIABILITY, LOW-JITTER MARX GENERATORS.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, L.X., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Lockwood, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Multimodule pulsed-power accelerators typically require high module reliability and nanosecond regime simultaneity between modules. Energy storage using bipolar Marx generators can meet these requirements. Experience gained from computer simulations and the development of the DEMON II Marx generator has led to a fundamental understanding of the operation of these multistage devices. As a result of this research significant improvements in erection time jitter and reliability have been realized in multistage, bipolar Marx generators. Erection time jitter has been measured as low as 2. 5 ns for the 3. 2 MV, 16-stage PBFA I Marx and 3. 5 ns for the 6. 0 MV, 30-stage PBFA II (DEMON II) Marx, while maintaining exceptionally low prefire rates. Performance data are presented from the DEMON II Marx research program, as well as discussions on the use of computer simulations in designing low-jitter Marx generators.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE - Computer Simulation; BIPOLAR MARX GENERATORS; ERECTION TIME JITTER; ACCELERATORS

The individual switch power is reduced to 1/18 of the load power.

Abstract: Two 1600 Wh-ring-rotor designs, which utilize prestressing concepts, are presented. Both designs consist of an iron inner ring (required for magnetic levitation) and five filament-wound composite material rings. Prestressing results in a 120% increase in specific energy density, compared to an unstressed design. Abstract: A solar dynamic power generation subsystem (PGS) for the spaces station offers significant advantages over photovoltaic solar arrays. Title: DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS FOR HEAT EXCHANGERS IN SOLAR INSTALLATIONS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Rockwell Int Corp, Canoga Park, CA,, USA, Rockwell Int Corp, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Billings III, G.J., Rockwell Int Corp, Canoga Park, CA,, USA, Rockwell Int Corp, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: This paper presents a simplified method for determining the impact of heat exchangers on collector loop performance and energy delivery performance in solar installations. The increase in collector fluid inlet temperature as a function of heat exchanger in comparison to a direct (i. e. , no heat exchanger) system is determined. Using the increase in collector fluid inlet temperature and the ASHRAE 93-77 collector test curve at specific levels of insolation, the decrease in collector loop performance caused by the heat exchanger is determined. Specific design considerations can be determined from this collector performance analysis. The impact of heat exchanger effectiveness on the rate at which energy is transferred to storage or the load is discussed. A drainback system with an independently controlled drainback-tank-to-storage-tank transfer loop is presented as the optimum configuration to minimize the negative performance impact of using a heat exchanger. An analytical method to select a cost-effective heat exchanger design is presented and an example given for a specific system. Finally, a typical specification for a heat exchanger based on the selected effectiveness is presented.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; STANDARDS; HEAT EXCHANGERS

Title: SOLID-FLUID RESPONSE OF PACKED-BED REGENERATORS BY CRUMP'S NUMERICAL INVERSION OF LAPLACE TRANSFORMS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln,, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lu, P.-C., Univ of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln,, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, USA
Abstract: The temperature histories in the fluid and the solid phases of a fixed-matrix (packed-bed) thermal storage unit in the regenerative mode of operation, with complete reversals of the flow direction, are traced. The heat conduction and energy storage are considered in the solid, but neglected in the fluid. The problem is solved numerically by the technique of Laplace transforms, with the inversion effected by a fast and robust scheme due to Crump (1976). Sample results are plotted, and discussed in physical terms.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT - Packed Beds; MATHEMATICAL TRANSFORMATIONS - Laplace Transforms; HEAT EXCHANGERS

Authors: Ferrieux Jean-Paul, Toutain Emmanuel, Le-Huy Hoang
Title: MULTIFUNCTION DC-DC CONVERTER AS VERSATILE POWER CONDITIONER.
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble,, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin, d'Heres, Fr, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin d'Heres, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Ferrieux, Jean-Paul, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble,, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin, d'Heres, Fr, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin d'Heres, Fr; Toutain, Emmanuel, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble,, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin, d'Heres, Fr, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin d'Heres, Fr; Le-Huy, Hoang, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble,, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin, d'Heres, Fr, Inst Natl Polytechnique de Grenoble, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. Martin d'Heres, Fr
Abstract: A multifunction dc/dc converter is described which can be used as a single power conditioner connecting the source, the storage, and the load in solar or wind energy systems. The converter, which is basically of the capacitive storage type, uses a single transistor as power switch. The configuration and function of the converter can be modified by an appropriate combination of three contactors. In each configuration, energy flow is controlled by the duty cycle of the power switch. Operation of the converter in four configurations is analyzed and simulated. Application of the converter is discussed and experimental results obtained with a prototype circuit are given.
Index Keywords: SOLAR POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER - Energy Storage; ENERGY FLOW CONTROL; POWER CONDITIONER; POWER SWITCH DUTY CYCLE; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Authors: Sterrett Richard H., Brzeczak Martin E.
Title: PREFEASIBILITY STUDY FOR A SOLAR THERMAL CENTRAL RECEIVER POWER PLANT FOR THE FARAFRA OASIS, EGYPT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sterrett, Richard H., Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA; Brzeczak, Martin E., Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA
Abstract: The current and projected electrical power requirements of the Farafra Oasis reclamation area are evaluated to assess the practicability of providing this power from a solar energy source and to establish a design and development plan for the required power plant or plants. Based on the information received from the Ministry of Development (MOD), the recommended system is a 21. 5 MWe solar thermal central receiver (STCR) power system with a 0. 75 capacity factor and eighteen hours of molten salt storage. The study further recommends that a 1 MWe STCR pilot plant be built to demonstrate the effectiveness of the STCR technology.
Index Keywords: FARAFRA OASIS RECLAMATION AREA; FEASIBILITY STUDY; SOLAR THERMAL CENTRAL RECEIVER POWER PLANT; POWER PLANTS - Egypt; POWER GENERATION

Title: THEORETICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR KINETIC AND POTENTIAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS FOR MOTOR VEHICLES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Qian, R., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA; Frank, A.A., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: Energy storage system as related to motor vehicle applications are discussed, along with some technical problems associated with the storage media. Auxiliary energy storage, the vehicle, the driving cycle, and the present available transmission technologies are compared to conventional systems. Some economically viable motor vehicle applications for each type of energy storage system are discussed.
Index Keywords: KINETICS AND POTENTIAL ENERGY; MOTOR VEHICLES; VEHICLES - Energy Storage; AUTOMOBILES

Title: LIFE TEST RESULTS OF THE INTELSAT-V NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ford Aerospace & Communication, Corp, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communication Corp, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hudak, Ronald E., Ford Aerospace & Communication, Corp, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communication Corp, USA
Abstract: The baseline power subsystem for the INTELSAT V communications satellite contains two nickel-cadmium (Ni-Cd) batteries for energy storage. The 28-cell battery assemblies, having a nameplate capacity of 34 ampere-hours, are designed for a maximum depth of discharge of 55% over a mission life of 7 years. The battery design has been successfully flown now on five INTELSAT V spacecraft, the first being launched in December 1980 and the fifth in September 1982. Flight model 6 was the first INTELSAT spacecraft to be launched with the nickel-hydrogen battery, which is now the battery system being used on the remainder of the 15 satellite series. The results of the life tests which are being conducted on the Ni-Cd battery are summarized.
Index Keywords: INTELSAT-V; NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERIES; SATELLITES - Power Supply; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: SPACE STATION POWER SYSTEM CHALLENGES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW Electronics & Defense,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW Electronics & Defense, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reppucci, G.M., TRW Electronics & Defense,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW Electronics & Defense, Redondo Beach, CA, USA; Sorensen, A.A., TRW Electronics & Defense,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW Electronics & Defense, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: The two primary candidate power systems for the initial station are photovoltaic and solar dynamic. Nuclear systems are candidates to supply power needed for growth to 300 kW and beyond. Various concentrator optical geometries, such as simple paraboloid and Cassegrain optics, are discussed. The influence of heat engine technology choice (Rankine, Brayton) on the optical performance requirements is described. Preliminary selection of thermal energy storage materials is discussed. The advantages and disadvantages of the integral receiver/energy storage approach are cited. Radiator configurations which satisfy candidate engine heat rejection requirements are discussed. Parametric comparison of photovoltaic and solar dynamic approaches is made, based on drag area, channel sizing, efficiency, life, and weight. A preliminary risk assessment is discussed, based on technology status and advanced development program goals.
Index Keywords: SPACE STATIONS; POWER GENERATION - Space Applications; HEAT ENGINES

Title: ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PLANNING MODEL AS APPLIED TO THE U. S. STRATEGIC PETROLEUM RESERVE OCEAN MONITORING PROGRAM.
