Abstract: The model is general and universally applicable to government and private enterprise. It can be augmented to any level of sophistication to reflect a particular organization's procedures, but a major benefit is the cycling of design iterations and the inclusion of more elaborate review mechanisms for project approval. We examine how this model has worked using the Strategic Petroleum Reserve as a case study.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - Management; ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING - Project Management; INDUSTRIAL MANAGEMENT - Computer Applications; MANAGEMENT SCIENCE - Computer Applications; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS - Storage; DESIGN ITERATIONS; ENVIRONMENTAL & SOCIAL CONSIDERATIONS; EVALUATION PHASE; MONITORING PHASE; REVIEW MECHANISMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT

Title: INTELLIGENT DATA ACQUISITION.
Affiliations: Hatfield Polytechnic, Engl, Hatfield Polytechnic, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Barnard, R.H., Hatfield Polytechnic, Engl, Hatfield Polytechnic, Engl
Abstract: This paper describes a low-cost microprocessor-based distributed data acquisition system, and illustrates its application by reference to a large-scale experiment and demonstration in low energy housing. The acquisition modules accept multiple analogue and digital inputs, and provide front-end pre-processing with short-term data storage. They may also be used for control purposes using digital output signals. A full technical description is given. In the low-energy housing project, the units are located in a number of occupied dwellings where they monitor such items as energy input, room temperature, window opening etc. The houses are constructed to a high level of insulation and contain energy-saving features such as solar water heating.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Insulation; HOUSES - Energy Conservation; COST SAVINGS; LOW ENERGY HOUSES; REMOTE SITE OPERATION; DATA PROCESSING

Title: PV-POWERED ICE MAKING MACHINE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Renault Automation, Bois d'Arcy, Fr, Renault Automation, Bois d'Arcy, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Selles, Laurent, Renault Automation, Bois d'Arcy, Fr, Renault Automation, Bois d'Arcy, Fr; Aubert, Bernard, Renault Automation, Bois d'Arcy, Fr, Renault Automation, Bois d'Arcy, Fr
Abstract: In the framework of an R & D contract of the French Agency for Energy Management (AFME), SERI/RENAULT AUTOMATION studied a PV-powered ice making machine, designed to produce ca 100 kg of ice blocks daily. The purpose of the work was the technical study of a fully innovative design rather than just an assembly of the existing components which have already been in use in the PV cold production field for a few years. The idea was to consider and use the ice produced as a storage in itself. Thus, no buffer battery is needed to ensure the continuous operation of the compressor. Ice is produced during sunlight hours only, for a better efficiency (no storage losses) and for a lower cost/performance ratio.
Index Keywords: ICE - Manufacture; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; BATTERY STORAGE; PV POWERED ICE MAKING MACHINE; POWER GENERATION

Authors: Blok K., Alsema E.A., van Wijk A.J.M., Turkenburg W.C.
Title: VALUE OF STORAGE FACILITIES IN A RENEWABLE ELECTRICITY SYSTEM.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Blok, K., State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth; Alsema, E.A., State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth; van Wijk, A.J.M., State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth; Turkenburg, W.C., State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ of Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth
Abstract: In electricity systems in which wind generators and photovoltaic cells play a large part in the production of electricity, a major problem is the matching of production and demand. This problem can be solved by means of storage facilities together with back-up generating capacity. To analyse the value of short-term as well as long-term storage facilities, a computer model has been developed which can simulate electricity systems that are fed largely by renewable energy sources. A brief description of the model is given. With this model calculations have been made for a possible situation where electricity in the Netherlands is supplied mainly by wind generators and PV cells, whereas and combined cycle units and gas turbines are used as back-up power.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; LONG TERM STORAGE; RENEWABLE ELECTRICITY SYSTEMS; SHORT TERM STORAGE; STORAGE FACILITIES; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Title: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF A PHOTOVOLTAIC ARRAY AND AEROGENERATOR IN A HYBRID RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEM.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: GEC, Leicester, Engl, GEC, Leicester, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Hayward, K., GEC, Leicester, Engl, GEC, Leicester, Engl; Parry, G.A., GEC, Leicester, Engl, GEC, Leicester, Engl
Abstract: A hybrid renewable energy system comprising a photovoltaic array and low cost aerogenerators has been assembled and evaluated to provide information to assist in the design of systems for remote application. It is shown that systems can be configured with flexibility to meet various operating conditions and present a practical alternative to either wind or photovoltaic stand-alone systems, with cost advantage because of reduced storage requirements. Simulation of the system on a micro computer allows the study of battery charge/discharge control strategies, and the effect of component sizing on dynamic performance is easily assessed.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Economics; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Computer Simulation; AEROGENERATOR; HYBRID RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEM; PHOTOVOLTAIC ARRAY; STAND-ALONE PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM; POWER GENERATION

Affiliations: Arco-Solar Corp, Chatsworth, CA, USA, Arco-Solar Corp, Chatsworth, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chapman, Harlen, Arco-Solar Corp, Chatsworth, CA, USA, Arco-Solar Corp, Chatsworth, CA, USA; Codron, Leon, Arco-Solar Corp, Chatsworth, CA, USA, Arco-Solar Corp, Chatsworth, CA, USA
Abstract: The Navajo Nation (pop. 90,000) is located 700 miles N. E. of Los Angeles, California, on a large desolate, but beautiful plateau 5,700 ft. above sea-level. They are a mining and agrarian nation with the majority of the population living in remote locations, not served by mains electricity. A stand-alone photovoltaic power system, was installed for individual houses, under a U. S. (D. O. E. ) grant, in 1981. Operation commenced early in 1982. This paper describes the system and its use by the inhabitants.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; BATTERY STORAGE; NAVAJO; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEM; SOLAR MODULES; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: MICROCOMPUTER CONTROLLED DC CHOPPER FOR OPTIMAL OPERATION OF A SOLAR GENERATOR-MOTOR SYSTEM.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Berlin, West Ger, Technical Univ of Berlin, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Hanitsch, R., Technical Univ of Berlin, West Ger, Technical Univ of Berlin, West Ger; Hauk, R., Technical Univ of Berlin, West Ger, Technical Univ of Berlin, West Ger
Abstract: In a photovoltaic drive system each of the components is characterized by its operating plane and there exists an optimal operating line for each component which again defines the optimal operating efficiency of the complete system. Because of the high cost for the solar generator the user is interested to operate close to the maximum efficiency of the solar cell array. Therefore a control algorithm was developed for the microcomputer which controls the complete system. In this contribution a solution to the problem is given and the constraints are discussed. The design is suitable for stand-alone systems with and without battery storage and no auxiliary energy is needed for the electronic control system.
Index Keywords: HELICOPTERS; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; DC CHOPPER; MICROCOMPUTER CONTROLLED; SOLAR GENERATOR MOTOR SYSTEM; AIRCRAFT

Title: MICROMAGNETICS OF DOMAIN WALLS IN HIGH-DENSITY VERTICAL RECORDING.
Affiliations: Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA, Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oyler, M.R., Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA, Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA; Soohoo, R.F., Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA, Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA
Abstract: A model for Bloch walls in high-density perpendicular recording media is presented. The resulting analytical expressions give the wall configuration and wall energy in terms of elliptic integrals of the first kind. These results show that when the wall width PARTIAL greater than 10 (A/K//1)**1**/**2 where A and K//1 are, respectively, exchange and anisotropy constants, a complete reversal of the magnetization occurs within a domain wall. However, when PARTIAL less than 10(A/K//1)**1**/**2 occurring at bit densities approaching the theoretical limit, the rotation is incomplete. As PARTIAL decreases, TRIAN OP theta within the wall decreases until PARTIAL yields pi (A/K//1)**1**/**2, whereby TRIAN OP theta vanishes altogether. The magnetization is then independent of position and there is no playback signal. For a CrCo vertical recording medium, the corresponding maximum recording density limit is approximately equals 4 equals 10** plus **7 reversals per meter ( approximately equals 10**6 TPI).
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC MATERIALS; MAGNETIZATION; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Integral Equations; PERPENDICULAR RECORDING MEDIA; PLAYBACK SIGNAL AMPLITUDE; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: ELECTRICAL RELIABILITY OF SILVER FILLED EPOXIES FOR DIE ATTACH.
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Holmdel, NJ, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Holmdel, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Opila, R.L., AT&T Bell Lab, Holmdel, NJ, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Holmdel, NJ, USA; Sinclair, J.D., AT&T Bell Lab, Holmdel, NJ, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Holmdel, NJ, USA
Abstract: Silver-filled epoxies used in manufacturing for die attachment have sometimes been found to exhibit high resistance approximately 24 hours after warming to room temperature. In this study devices from good and bad lots and commercially available silver-filled epoxies have been examined. Comparison of secondary electron images with absorbed current micrographs indicates that conduction occurs through a percolative network. The sensitivity of resistivity as a function of silver concentration to formulation shows that conductivity through the percolative network is strongly affected by a complex interplay between the silver flake and the epoxy matrix. The amount of insulating amorphous carbon layer immediately surrounding the silver flake, as demonstrated by Raman scattering, is related to the storage time and conductivity. The bulk conduction mechanism probably involves a combination of direct contact of silver flakes and tunneling through the insulating layer. This insulating layer can be electrically broken down to form a mechanically fragile pathway. Secondary electron micrographs demonstrate that the silver flakes are randomly oriented throughout the bulk but, near interfaces between the metallization or air, they tend to align parallel to the interface. The minimum free energy configuration near the interface appears to be driven by the specific surfaces areas and the interfacial free energies. The orientational ordering near the interface undoubtedly alters the resistivity in that region.
Index Keywords: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS; SILVER AND ALLOYS - Electric Conductivity; DIE ATTACHMENT; ELECTRON MICROGRAPHS; SILVER FILLED EPOXIES; ELECTRIC CONNECTORS

Authors: Spears John W., Howard Bion D.
Title: CONSERVATION, SOLAR, MASS AND AUXILIARY: ACHIEVING A BALANCED APPROACH.
Affiliations: NAHB Research Foundation Inc,, Rockville, MD, USA, NAHB Research Foundation Inc, Rockville, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spears, John W., NAHB Research Foundation Inc,, Rockville, MD, USA, NAHB Research Foundation Inc, Rockville, MD, USA; Howard, Bion D., NAHB Research Foundation Inc,, Rockville, MD, USA, NAHB Research Foundation Inc, Rockville, MD, USA
Abstract: The Griffin's Gate home is an example of the emerging architecture of 'Micro-load' homes. This integrated thermal design stresses cost effectiveness and an appropriate combination of conservation, passive solar, thermal storage and efficient auxiliary systems. Extensive computer analysis in the design phase indicated proper levels of thermal protection and passive solar use at minimal levels of purchased energy cost. Less than 200. 00 per year will be spent on conventional heating. The Griffin's Gate home demonstrates how today's construction materials may be optimally used to obtain thermal protection, comfort, minimal operating cost and a low maintenance building.
Index Keywords: ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN; ENERGY CONSERVATION; MAINTENANCE; 'MICRO-LOAD' HOMES; EMERGING ARCHITECTURE; ENERGY SIMULATION; GRIFFIN'S GATE HOME; BUILDINGS

Title: 10-JOULE 200 KV MINI MARX.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Platts, David, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: A low-energy Marx generator was designed at Los Alamos as a spark gap trigger. The Mini Marx has a risetime of less than 2 ns to over 200 kV measured into a 23- OMEGA load. The power output approaches one gigawatt. The Mini Marx can multichannel field distortion gaps or fire a number of gaps with little gap-to-gap isolation. It has also been used to power a small X-ray tube. The author describes the construction and improvements that have been made on the Mini Marx. Design features and electrical characteristics are also presented.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC SPARK GAPS; MARX GENERATOR; SPARK GAP TRIGGER; PULSE GENERATORS

Title: PBFA-II ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM CONFIGURATION AND CHARACTERISTICS.

Abstract: PBFA-II is the second 36-module particle beam accelerator built by Sandia National Laboratory for ICF fusion feasibility studies. Each module of the machine is designed to deliver 2. 8 TW to a central experimental chamber. The total power delivered (100 TW) is expected to permit ignition scaling studies beginning in 1986. The authors present an overview of the configuration and characteristics of this storage system.

Abstract: EEPROMs emerged as an extension of the existing EPROM technology. In-socket re-programmability is provided by means of replacing the slower UV-light energy gathering 'window' with circuitry allowing direct high voltage input for cell erasure. The history of EEPROM's is discussed, along with present by offered features.

Authors: Salge Juergen G.H., Loeffler Markus J., Braunsberger Ulrich E., Synofzik Reinhard
Title: INTEGRATED MAGNETIC ACCELERATION AND ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger, Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Salge, Juergen G.H., Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger, Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger; Loeffler, Markus J., Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger, Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger; Braunsberger, Ulrich E., Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger, Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger; Synofzik, Reinhard, Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger, Technische Univ Braunschweig, West Ger
Abstract: The authors discuss the properties of integrated acceleration and energy storage systems and point out different possibilities of their realization. Experiments with a compact railgun system of 0. 7-m length confirm the considerations. Initial masses of 7. 3 g have been accelerated up to 500 m/s. The construction of the railgun investigated demonstrates that simple and compact integration of storage inductors can be realized. Results obtained with this small accelerator can be extrapolated for larger devices.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; INTEGRATED MAGNETIC ACCELERATION/ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; RAILGUN SYSTEM; STORAGE INDUCTORS; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Humphries Jr. S., Savage M., Woodall D.M.
Title: RECENT RESULTS ON THE PLASMA FLOW OPENING SWITCH.
Affiliations: Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Humphries Jr., S., Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Savage, M., Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Woodall, D.M., Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The plasma flow opening switch utilizes biased grid control of electrons from an independent, pulsed-plasma source. The device is well-suited to magnetic energy storage applications; it has low conducting state impedance and fast switching time. Theory predicts high energy transfer efficiency for pulses in the 0. 1- mu s regime. Recent experiments demonstrate reliable circuit interruption at 6 MW.
Index Keywords: PLASMAS - Applications; CIRCUIT INTERRUPTION; ENERGY TRANSFER EFFICIENCY; PULSED POWER SOURCE; ELECTRIC SWITCHES

Title: SHORTENING OF ELECTRON CONDUCTION PULSES BY ELECTRON ATTACHERS.
Affiliations: San Diego State Univ, CA, USA, San Diego State Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, L.C., San Diego State Univ, CA, USA, San Diego State Univ, CA, USA; Wang, W.C., San Diego State Univ, CA, USA, San Diego State Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: The shortening of electron-conduction pulses by adding electron attachers into buffer gas was investigated for gas discharges using a parallel-plate drift-tube apparatus. Electrons were produced by an irradiation of the cathode or trimethylamine with excimer laser photons. The electron-conduction pulses induced by the electron motion between electrodes were observed. The pulse durations were shortened when small amounts of electron attachers were added to a buffer gas. The electron-attachment-rate constants were measured for various gas mixtures as a function of E/N (density-normalized electric field). The electron attachment rate constants for the gas mixtures of C//3 F//8 -CH//4 , N//2 O-N//2 and H//2 O-Ar, increase with increasing E/N. These characteristics are desirable for designing the opening switches. The electron-drift velocities of various gas mixtures were also measured.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONS; ENERGY STORAGE - Switching; BUFFER GAS ADDITION; DENSITY NORMALIZED ELECTRIC FIELD; ELECTRON ATTACHERS; ELECTRON-CONDUCTION PULSES SHORTENING; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES

Title: RESIDENCE FOR SENIOR CITIZENS USING PASSIVE SOLAR SYSTEMS IN MEXICO CITY, MEXICO.
Affiliations: Ecosfera, Mexico City, Mex, Ecosfera, Mexico City, Mex
Authors with affiliations: Giron de la Pena, Hector, Ecosfera, Mexico City, Mex, Ecosfera, Mexico City, Mex
Abstract: This project intends to share the perspective of the Architect/Developer/Owner and the Manager in developing and operating a retirement complex for Senior Citizens powered by them and with the main important back up by the sun. The complex consists of six units of 8 dwellings integrated each of them by a central greenhouse patio, that is regarding the traditional concept of the Mexican Central Patio with a concept of climatization. One of the major goals was to locate self-sufficient type of units with a closed system of space heating and natural lighting effect. The private units are located around the atrium area, allowing the opportunity for interaction and important energy savings. The second major aspect of the atrium approach is in keeping with the rural background of many of the residents. It allows them through its greenery to keep their relationship with the countryside and its environment.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Mexico City, Mexico; GREENHOUSES - Climate Control; HEATING - Solar; ATRIUM; SENIOR CITIZEN RESIDENCES; SUNSPACE; WATER STORAGE GREENHOUSE; HOUSES

Authors: Hoshi Y., Naoe M., Yamanaka S.
Title: IRON THIN FILMS WITH UNIAXIAL MAGNETIC ANISOTROPY BY HIGH RATE SPUTTERING.
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Hoshi, Y., Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn; Naoe, M., Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn; Yamanaka, S., Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Atugi, Jpn
Abstract: Effects of the oblique incidence of sputtered particles to the substrate on magnetic properties of iron thin films have been investigated with a targets facing type of sputtering (TFTS) system. The film deposited at a substrate temperature T//s below 300 degree C and Ar gas pressure around 5 mtorr is composed of elongated flakelike grains and has a large uniaxial magnetic anisotropy energy ( approximately equals 5 multiplied by 10**5 erg/cm**3), which originates in the shape anisotropy of the grain. The formation of the flake-like grain is caused by the oblique incidence of sputtered particles. Accordingly, the oblique incidence of sputtered particles should be taken into account when sputtering is performed at an Ar gas pressure below 10 mtorr.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC; FILMS - Preparation; MAGNETIC MATERIALS - Anisotropy; NICKEL AND ALLOYS - Microstructure; HIGH RATE SPUTTERING; SPUTTERING SYSTEM SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM; IRON AND ALLOYS

Title: PREDICTING THE RETARDATION PERFORMANCE OF VEHICLES EQUIPPED WITH HYDRO-PNEUMATIC ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Research Council of Canada,, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Natl Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Davies, Anthony S., Natl Research Council of Canada,, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Natl Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Heggie, William, Natl Research Council of Canada,, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Natl Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: The predicted retardation performance and fuel economy of a city bus equipped with an add-on hydropneumatic energy storage system is presented. A fuel economy improvement of 26. 9% is projected for a vehicle of 13,600 kg (30,100 lb) weight, running on the US Department of Transportation Advanced Design Bus driving cycle. A significant finding is that the thermodynamically ideal accumulator (that which provides a given energy storage capacity at the minimum gas volume) does not provide optimum performance, considering overall energy conservation, over the range of real driving situations. The performance analyses are presented that allow the design parameters for a prototype vehicle to be optimized to significant advantage.
Index Keywords: CITY BUSES; HYDROPNEUMATICS; RETARDATION; MOTOR BUS TRANSPORTATION; PNEUMATICS - Applications; MOTOR BUSES

Title: RECOVERY OF LEAD/ACID BATTERIES FROM ABUSIVE DEEP DISCHARGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hodgson, Robert L., Boeing Aerospace Co, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, USA; Oman, Henry, Boeing Aerospace Co, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, USA
Abstract: Today's common electrochemical energy storage medium is some variation of a lead-acid battery. These batteries are used for load leveling, peak shaving, motive power, engine starting, and emergency standby power. Extremely deep discharge, while not intended in any of these applications, does inadvertently occur and it shortens battery life. Deep discharge also makes charge recovery difficult because a double sulfate reaction drives the electrolyte into a state of low conductivity. Sometimes a special charge technique is needed to salvage the battery. The recharge performance of new maintenance-free lead-acid batteries which have endured extremely deep discharges is described. These batteries were tested by discharging them into a short-circuit for extended periods and then attempting to recharge them. All of the tested maintenance-free batteries recovered from deep discharge, even with marginal charging voltage.
Index Keywords: DEEP DISCHARGES; LEAD/ACID BATTERIES; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: SPACE POWER SYSTEMS - 'SPACECRAFT 2000'.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Faymon, Karl A., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Spacecraft-2000 is a program that seeks to determine critical spacecraft technologies and to formulate, advocate, and manage the requisite technology development programs. The program is a joint effort of NASA and various industry spacecraft designers and manufacturers. The technology areas being explored include spacecraft power/energy storage; thermal control/thermal management; power management and distribution; and on-board system integration. The way in which the program will further the goals of future space programs is outlined.
Index Keywords: FUTURE SPACE PROGRAMS; NASA; SPACE POWER; ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Space Applications; SPACECRAFT

Title: ASHRAE TRANSACTIONS: TECHNICAL PAPERS PRESENTED AT THE 1985 WINTER MEETING.
Abstract: This conference proceedings appears in two bound volumes: Vol. 91 part 1A with 30 papers, and Vol. 91 part 1B with 75 papers. The titles of some articles are cited as illustrations of areas of interest: the effect of indoor air temperature and humidity on the performance of a heat pump; energy performance and savings potentials with skylights; moisture control by attic ventilation; a general computer simulation model for furnaces and boilers; system analysis for a campus-type chilled water system; review of a smoke control system; variable-base degree-day correction factors for energy savings calculations; and College Park thermal storage experience.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING; FIRE PROTECTION; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HUMIDITY CONTROL; VENTILATION; CHILLER; DRINKING WATER COOLERS; EIREV; HVAC SYSTEM; HYDRONIC HEATING; LO-CAL HOUSE; BUILDINGS

Title: UNIQUE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF STORAGE-FREE SPACE-HEATING RETROFITS: OR, SOME OBSERVATIONS ON HOW PEOPLE ACTUALLY USE SOLAR HEAT.
Affiliations: Urban Solar Energy Assoc,, Somerville, MA, USA, Urban Solar Energy Assoc, Somerville, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Brandt, Barbara, Urban Solar Energy Assoc,, Somerville, MA, USA, Urban Solar Energy Assoc, Somerville, MA, USA
Abstract: Storage-free space-heating retrofits, also known as localized day-heat systems, are an important but still largely unrecognized part of the solar mix. Widely varied and adaptable to many buildings and uses, these systems are easily installed and often uniquely cost-effective. Although the remarkable fuel savings frequently attributed to these systems are in fact due primarily to various kinds of occupant interaction with such systems, this finding should not be written off as unscientific. The special suitability of day-heat retrofits for zoned heating applications is noted, and three types of solar-based zoning identified: time-related zoning, space-related zoning, and amenity zoning.

Abstract: Analysis of certain types of industrial heat transfer problems including phase transition are presented. The finite element method is used and the program THAFEM is utilized for the calculations. THAFEM - Thermal and Heat Analysis by Finite Element Method - is a special purpose program for heat transfer analysis. The program is intended for medium size problems. Latent heat storage is studied.

Title: ACCEPTANCE TESTING AND MONITORING THE CEC PHOTOVOLTAIC PLANTS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Blaesser, G., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy; Krebs, K., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy; Ossenbrink, H., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy; Rossi, E., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy
Abstract: The EC contracts for the construction of 15 photovoltaic pilot plants included on-site acceptance tests in order to verify that the rated power was within the contractual limit. The present paper sums up the results of these measurements which have been performed on 14 installations, as well as the methods used to extrapolate the actual data to standard test conditions; it is shown that indoor and outdoor results are in good agreement, and that array matching losses were kept small. The second phase of the EC pilot plant project is concerned with the monitoring of the operational behaviour of these installations; we have developed a comprehensive scheme for the handling and analysis of these monitoring data. Data storage and access techniques are discussed and some typical results like system availability, subsystem energy efficiencies and power input/output balances are presented.

Authors: Converse James C., Holmes Brian J.

Abstract: Nutrient retention in manure handling systems is receiving renewed interest because of increased production costs and low prices received by the farmer. Manure nutrients can be lost during the collection, storage, storage unloading, land application, and in the soil system. The objectives of this study were to 1) evaluate nutrient retention of nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium in above-ground storages, and 2) evaluate energy and labor requirements in handling the manure with these systems.

Abstract: Research activities that are being cooperatively conducted by the Goddard Space Flight Center and the University of Maryland are reported. The design, fabrication and testing of an experimental energy storage flywheel system (Prototype II) and the conceptual design of a 300-Wh flywheel is described. The successful design of the 300-Wh flywheel system is shown to depend on solving problems involving the composite material flywheel, motor/generator, and magnetic suspension.

Title: TETRAHEDRON ARRAY OF REACTION WHEELS FOR ATTITUDE CONTROL AND ENERGY STORAGE.

Affiliations: NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Flatley, Thomas W., NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: A spacecraft subsystem, which works in conjunction with a solar array and provides 3-axis attitude control as well as some power system functions is described. Four flywheels, driven by variable-field dc motors and arranged in a tetrahedron configuration, are used. In sunlight, the system provides voltage regulation while the wheels are accelerated to some maximum speed. In the dark, the motors become flywheel-driven generators which provide regulated power to other spacecraft electrical loads. A microprocessor is used to compute field current levels for each of the four motor/generators, based on measurements of the system voltage level, the flywheel speeds, and the attitude control torques desired.

Title: EFFECTS OF POWER-TRAIN PARASITIC CAPACITANCE ON THE DYNAMIC PERFORMANCE OF DC-TO-AC CONVERTERS OPERATING IN THE DISCONTINUOUS MMF MODE.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ,, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: McArdle, James, AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ,, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ, USA; Wilson Jr., Thomas G., AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ,, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ, USA; Wong, Ronald C., AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ,, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Parsippany, NJ, USA
Abstract: The authors investigate a widely observed phenomenon whereby a dc-to-dc converter operating in the discontinuous mmf mode with a constant-frequency control law can exhibit wide variations in dynamic performance over a narrow range of input voltage or output load. This behavior is related to the sinusoidal energy exchange between the parasitic capacitances of the power stage and the energy-storage reactor during the discontinuous mmf mode of operation. The resulting ringing can cause dramatic variations in the apparent gain of the power train, thereby affecting the dynamic performance of the power supply. The objective is to provide the power supply designer with insight into this phenomenon. In this endeavor, a new large-signal computer simulation technique is used to compare theoretical results with actual measurements.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS - Transients; DISCONTINUOUS MMF MODE OPERATION; DYNAMIC PERFORMANCE; POWER-TRAIN PARASITIC CAPACITANCES EFFECTS; SINUSOIDAL ENERGY EXCHANGE; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Title: EVALUATION OF NONLINEAR RESISTORS FOR PULSE POWER SWITCHING.
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ford, R., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Kahn, M., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Inductive storage power supplies are capable of providing high pulsed power with relatively low weight, except that the energy transfer to a load circuit in such a system requires the opening of the initial current storage circuit. The switch required for this has to be able to interrupt a substantial current, as well as permit a rapid build-up of a high voltage across its opened terminals. A nonlinear resistor can change its resistivity in response to an external stimulus. Resistors that are sensitive to temperature are used in this evaluation; specifically positive temperature coefficient PTC resistors that can exhibit increases in resistance over three orders of magnitude when their temperature exceeds a critical value. These are particularly attractive since the application of a current can be used to raise their temperature relatively uniformly throughout their bulk. Relatively fast switching speeds can therefore be attained. The implementation of successful PTC resistors has so far been most successful in dual-phase materials. Switching speeds of milliseconds are easily attainable, even without triggering. The large-scale availability of commercially made PTC resistors should make their early application in pulse switching circuits feasible.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC SWITCHES; NONLINEAR RESISTORS; PULSE POWER SWITCHING; RESISTORS

Authors: French Richard H., Mongeau Peter P.
Title: TWO MEGAWATT BATTERY FACILITY.
Affiliations: Electromagnetic Launch Research,, Cambridge, MA, USA, Electromagnetic Launch Research, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: French, Richard H., Electromagnetic Launch Research,, Cambridge, MA, USA, Electromagnetic Launch Research, Cambridge, MA, USA; Mongeau, Peter P., Electromagnetic Launch Research,, Cambridge, MA, USA, Electromagnetic Launch Research, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: A 2-MW power supply is in operation in a 10,000-ft**2 machine shop, test cells, and real-time data acquisition equipment. The parallel and series battery banks provide a cost-effective, reliable, and safe environment for the development of pulsed-power components. The virtually unlimited energy storage capacity make the facility useful for long time-constant inductor charging, high-current switch development, and repetitive tests where long duration (several seconds) current pulses are required.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTROMAGNETIC LAUNCH RESEARCH; TW MW POWER SUPPLY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: SCOPE OF PHOTOVOLTAIC APPLICATIONS IN INDIA.
Affiliations: Chloride India Ltd, Calcutta, India, Chloride India Ltd, Calcutta, India
Authors with affiliations: Roy, S.B., Chloride India Ltd, Calcutta, India, Chloride India Ltd, Calcutta, India; Saha, H., Chloride India Ltd, Calcutta, India, Chloride India Ltd, Calcutta, India
Abstract: The potential of Solar Photovoltaic Systems (SPS) in six different applications in India has been considered in details. A methodology has been proposed to estimate quantitatively the economic viability of the Solar Photovoltaic Systems with reference to stand alone conventional power sources for these applications. For lighthouse beacons, SPS is economically viable right now even with a storage facility of thirty days. For all other applications, SPS become cost-effective with storage provision of seven to ten days. Use of backup diesel/petrol generators appear to be more attractive than the provision of battery storage for a period of longer than ten days. In all these cases, however, a long term financial policy is needed to justify the economic viability of SPS.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION - India; SOLAR ENERGY - Economics; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY; ECONOMIC VIABILITY; PHOTOVOLTAIC APPLICATIONS SCOPE IN INDIA; SOLAR PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS (SPS); PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Title: IMPACT RESPONSE AND DYNAMIC MECHANICAL ANALYSIS OF EPOXIDE/POLYURETHANE ELASTOMER BLENDS.
Affiliations: AERE Harwell, Engl, AERE Harwell, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Davidson, R., AERE Harwell, Engl, AERE Harwell, Engl
Abstract: Epoxide resins and polyurethane elastomers have been co-cured to produce polymeric materials with tailored stiffnesses and damping. The impact characteristics of a range of polymer blends have been investigated using an instrumented drop weight impact test. The effect of test temperature on a 50:50 blend has also been studied. Dynamic mechanical analysis has been used to measure the storage and loss moduli and damping characteristics in the polymer blends as a function of temperature. Both techniques are invaluable and complementary for impact studies in polymeric materials. In particular a correlation between the impact energy to fracture and the loss moduli of the polymer has been demonstrated.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS TESTING - Impact; POLYURETHANES - Blending; DAMPING CHARACTERISTICS; DYNAMIC MECHANICAL ANALYSIS; EPOXIDE/POLYURETHANE ELASTOMER BLENDS; INSTRUMENTED DROP WEIGHT IMPACT TEST; LOSS MODULI; POLYMERS

Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM

Abstract: Researchers have developed a unique methodology for examining sodium/sulfur cells after testing to learn more about their behavior. The new techniques described in this report allow scientists to discern the physical and chemical states of these high-energy cells and to develop hypotheses about degradation mechanisms. This information may provide a basis for building cells with longer lives.

Abstract: Various inertial energy storage concepts and their relative merits are described. Important design parameters such as energy density, depth-of-discharge, and turnaround efficiency are discussed along with their influence on system design. Three critical technology areas are assessed: rotor materials, magnetic suspension, and motor-generators. Conclusions on the viability of inertial energy storage systems are presented. Finally, recommendations are made for areas of further work in flywheel technology.

Abstract: The findings of research on possible agricultural applications of radiofrequency (rf) and microwave energy are briefly summarized. Included are discussions on stored-grain insect control, agricultural seed treatment, and processing of agricultural products.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS - Processing; GRAIN - Storage; MICROWAVES - Applications; AGRICULTURAL SEED TREATMENT; RF APPLICATIONS; STORED-GRAIN INSECT CONTROL; AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING

Title: HOW FOREIGN CULLET USAGE AFFECTS CONTAINER PRODUCTION.
Affiliations: Consumers Glass Co, Toronto, Ont,, Can, Consumers Glass Co, Toronto, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, Gordon M., Consumers Glass Co, Toronto, Ont,, Can, Consumers Glass Co, Toronto, Ont, Can
Abstract: The better qualities of postconsumer cullet can be advantageously incorporated into the glass container-manufacturing process. Supplies of suitable foreign cullet are not abundant and are seen to increase at rates not exceeding 10 per cent per year. Although not achieving all its proponents' claims, raw material cost savings, melt energy efficiency improvements, and reduced operating temperatures do result from cullet usage above 20 per cent. Reduced glass furnace pollution emissions are expected to result from increased cullet usage. Increased furnace lifetimes and higher outputs have yet to be confirmed in practice. Suitable glass quality and preservation of furnace refractories do result from the well-supervised mechanical beneficiation of foreign cullet. Separate foreign cullet storage and proportioning systems and the use of electric boosting are seen to maximize the benefits of high cullet ratios.
Index Keywords: BOTTLES - Glass; ENERGY CONSERVATION; GLASS FURNACES; CULLET; GLASS MANUFACTURE

Authors: Picard P., Armstrong P.R., Winn C.B., McCaffrey W.J.
Title: IMPLEMENTATION OF AN OFF-PEAK STORAGE SYSTEM IN A RESIDENTIAL PASSIVE SOLAR BUILDING.
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Picard, P., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Armstrong, P.R., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Winn, C.B., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; McCaffrey, W.J., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Abstract: The design and implementation of an off-peak storage system for a passive solar system with thermal storage wall is described. A constant off-peak charge of a brick wall is intended to meet part of the heating load of the residence, with the complement provided by a conventional baseboard heater. A two-node model of the system is used to predict the performance of the installation under typical meteorological data. The control of the charge is then defined on a monthly basis. For the same energy consumption, the new system improves the comfort by raising the mean radiant temperature of the enclosure, while the utility benefits from a higher load factor.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; OFF-PEAK STORAGE SYSTEM; RESIDENTIAL PASSIVE SOLAR BUILDING; THERMAL STORAGE WALL; BUILDINGS

Title: PARAMETER ANALYSIS OF A SINGLE STAGE INDUCTION MASS DRIVER.
Affiliations: US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bernardes, J., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA; Merryman, S., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, Dahlgren, VA, USA
Abstract: The electromechanical behavior of a single-stage induction mass driver (SSIMD) has been modeled and analyzed with the aid of a computer. The generic SSIMD consists of an energy storage (normally a capacitor bank), a switch, a drive coil, and a driven ring. The coil and ring are concentric and typically of equal diameter (the condition for maximum magnetic coupling). When a current pulse is applied to the drive-coil, a current is magnetically induced in the ring. The interaction between this ring current and the magnetic field (between the coil and the ring) produces a Lorentz force which drives the ring. The analysis focuses on the effects of circuit parameters on projectile velocity and system efficiency. A description of the model along with general rules for the design of efficient SSMID systems are presented.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE; CIRCUIT PARAMETERS; ELECTROMECHANICAL BEHAVIOR; SINGLE-STAGE INDUCTOR MASS DRIVER; ACCELERATORS

Abstract: Power conditioning circuits for a superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) coil will require many parallel SCR devices because the operating current is planned to be as high as a few hundred thousand amperes. In order to maintain current balance in the parallel units, a microcomputer controlled system that adjusts the delay angle of individual units is envisioned. Authors with affiliations: Widmer, Johann, ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz; Asper, Hans K., ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz
Abstract: A flywheel rotor for the use in a flywheel energy storage unit is described. The flywheel design uses unidirectional glass-fiber weft, wound on a self-centering hub and is called the woven ribbon flywheel. Disk/rim hybrid and disk flywheels have been manufactured with the new ribbon winding technique. The elastic properties of the ribbon material used, the woven ribbon process itself, elastic body mode studies of the woven ribbon-wound disk and results of spin tests with flywheels on self-centering hubs are described. Analytical and experimental results are reported. The new process exhibits advantages over to the filament winding technique. An energy storage unit for a flywheel-assisted battery/diesel engine hybrid passenger car using composite material flywheels is described.

Authors with affiliations: Bindin, Peter J., Chloride Silent Power Ltd, Chloride Silent Power Ltd
Abstract: A unique sodium sulfur cell design, which enhances the potential cell energy density to over 200 Wh/kg and has a dramatic impact on projected vehicle battery reliability is described. Performance and reliability results on previous generations of cells show that over the long term, stable resistance and capacity maintained in cells operating for up to 2500 cycles. The essential design aspects of vehicular and utility batteries are presented, together with projected performance. The combined advances in cell technology, cell designs and battery design make it possible to plan for a vehicle battery which does not require cell replacement for up to a five-year period. These advantages have eased many of the battery design constraints, and the resulting design proposals produce compact, efficient and high-performance batteries with a flexible packaging capability.
Index Keywords: ENERGY DENSITIES; SODIUM SULFUR CELLS; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: ECONOMIC SURVEY OF WIND GENERATED ELECTRICITY FOR HEAT PUMPS AT A COMMUNITY SCHOOL ON THE WESTERN ISLES.
Source title: Proceedings of the BWEA Wind Energy Conference (British Wind Energy Association)
Affiliations: Univ of Strathclyde, Energy Studies, Unit, Glasgow, Scotl, Univ of Strathclyde, Energy Studies Unit, Glasgow, Scotl
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, J.R.M., Univ of Strathclyde, Energy Studies, Unit, Glasgow, Scotl, Univ of Strathclyde, Energy Studies Unit, Glasgow, Scotl; Twidell, J.W., Univ of Strathclyde, Energy Studies, Unit, Glasgow, Scotl, Univ of Strathclyde, Energy Studies Unit, Glasgow, Scotl
Abstract: An aerogenerator is proposed to augment the electricity supply of a new school in the Outer Hebrides, heated entirely by heat-pumps. The wind resource was estimated and the performance of 12 commercial machines predicted. From the manufacturers' prices and with estimates of other capital and recurring costs, the financial benefits of aerogeneration at this site were studied. Machines with capacities of about 60 kW would have the shortest pay-back times. Larger machines would be attractive investments if grid buy-back prices were higher. The building fabric and swimming pool will provide important energy storage to smooth both wind operation and grid peak demand.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS - Economics; SCHOOL BUILDINGS; WIND TURBINES; AEROGENERATORS; COST EFFECTIVENESS; LOADS; WIND POWER

Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Dep of Agricultural, Engineering, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, Ithaca, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Novak, S., Cornell Univ, Dep of Agricultural, Engineering, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, Ithaca, NY, USA; Albright, L.D., Cornell Univ, Dep of Agricultural, Engineering, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, Ithaca, NY, USA
Abstract: A greenhouse heat loss model is modified to apply to a plastic row cover used for early season production of fresh vegetables. The model is based on two sets of balances: (1) an energy balance on each participating surface and the inside air mass, and (2) a thermal radiation balance among all the participating surfaces. Thermal storage within the soil under the row cover is permitted, and a finite difference solution is used to solve for time dependent effects.

Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR AN ORGANIC RANKINE CYCLE SOLAR DYNAMIC POWERED SPACE STATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Downing, R.S., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; Parekh, M.B., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Abstract: The organic Rankine cycle solar dynamic power system (ORC SDPS) is an attractive candidate for power generation on the space station. The ORC SDPS consists of a concentrator, a power conversion unit, and a receiver with a thermal energy storage system. Excess thermal energy must be stored during the period of solar insolation to power the ORC engine during orbital eclipse. Various thermal energy storage materials are considered and lithium hydroxide (LiOH) is selected as a primary material. Its melting point is in the range desirable for the ORC SDPS working fluid (toluene) and it has one of the highest specific thermal energy storage capacities and a low volume change upon fusion. Alternate phase change materials are also evaluated. The criteria used in designing the thermal energy storage system are presented and discussed. Salts generally have poor thermal conductivities which result in poor heat transfer within the thermal energy storage system. Therefore, potential heat transfer enhancement schemes are identified and evaluated. A material compatibility study is briefly discussed.
Index Keywords: RANKINE CYCLE; SOLAR DYNAMIC POWERED SPACE STATIONS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SPACECRAFT - Energy Storage; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Magal B.S., Purushothaman A., Chandrasekhar N.S.
Title: MATHEMATICAL MODELS FOR LATENT HEAT THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India
Authors with affiliations: Magal, B.S., Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India; Purushothaman, A., Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India; Chandrasekhar, N.S., Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India
Abstract: A number of heat transfer phenomena models are analyzed and compared. It is shown that while interface movement cannot be predicted by the integral as well as by the similarity solutions, the predicted liquid temperatures are close to the exact solution. Further, numerical substitutions using thermophysical properties of inorganic salts indicate that high latent heat and high thermal diffusivity are desirable for phase-change materials. Quasi-steady-state models are useful in predicting the influence of convective boundary conditions and can be used to evaluate alternative designs before design specification are evolved.
Index Keywords: LATENT HEAT; THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER

Abstract: The objective of this Japanese National Research Project is an electric energy storage system with a load-leveling function, in which electric energy is stored (charged) during off-peak hours and discharged during peak hours, utilizing electrochemical reactions in a large-scale battery storage system. Advanced storage batteries, including sodium-sulfur, zinc-chloride, zinc-bromide and redox-flow, and the system necessary for linking these batteries to a commercial electric power system are discussed. The goal of this project is to develop and demonstrate a 1-MW (8-MWh) electric energy storage system to establish the feasibility of its practical application by the year 1990.

Abstract: This paper reports upon research activities on the design, fabrication and testing of a magnetically suspended experimental energy storage flywheel system. The successful design of the flywheel system is dependent upon composite materials, motor/generator, and magnetic suspension. Current studies indicate that the critical problems in these areas can be successfully addressed for the design and construction of much larger systems.

Authors: Nakanishi K., Christophorou L.G., Carter J.G., Hunter S.R.
Title: PENNING IONIZATION TERNARY GAS MIXTURES FOR DIFFUSE DISCHARGE SWITCHING APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Nakanishi, K., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA; Christophorou, L.G., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA; Carter, J.G., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA; Hunter, S.R., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Abstract: The increase in the total ionization produced by high-energy alpha particles in Ar/C//2 F//6 mixtures (which have conduction and insulation properties appropriate for use in diffuse-discharge-switching applications) by addition of low-ionization-energy additives has been quantitatively studied. The energy to produce an electron-ion pair (ip), W, in C//2 F//6 was found to be 34. 7 eV/ip; this rather high value is attributed to the large cross section for electron impact-induced dissociation of C//2 F//6 . The W values of Ar/C//2 F//6 mixtures have also been measured and are reported; they increase with increasing C//2 F//6 content. The W values of Ar/C//2 F//6 binary gas mixtures have been found to decrease - higher total ionization - by addition of C//2 H//2 or 2-C//4 H//8 . Measurements of the W values of the ternary gas mixtures are reported. The amounts of C//2 H//2 or 2-C//4 H//8 in Ar/C//2 F//6 which maximize the increase in total ionization have been estimated; some of these ternary gas mixtures may be useful in e-beam sustained diffuse-discharge switches.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRON BEAMS; ENERGY STORAGE - Switching; PARTICLE BEAMS; DIFFUSE-DISCHARGE-SWITCHING; ELECTRON-ION PAIR; HIGH-ENERGY PARTICLES; TERNARY GAS MIXTURES; GASES

Title: SYSTEM STUDY FOR AN INDUCTIVE GENERATOR.
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ottinger, P.F., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Commisso, R.J., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Lupton, W.H., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Shipman Jr., J.D., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: A system study has been initiated to aid in the design of the inductive pulsed-power generator prototype, CHECMATE. Because of the highly interactive nature of the opening switches with the other elements of the pulsed-power system, this study requires that realistic physics models of the switch and load elements be coupled to the circuit in a self-consistent manner. This has been accomplished using a transmission-line code in conjunction with an empirical model for fuse resistivity and various physics models for a plasma flow switch and a load. System optimization is discussed. This system analysis technique can be applied to higher energy inductive generators.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC NETWORKS - Transmission Line Theory; ELECTRIC NETWORKS, SWITCHING; ENERGY STORAGE; INDUCTIVE PULSED-POWER GENERATOR PROTOTYPE; PLASMA FLOW SWITCH; PULSED-POWER SYSTEMS; PULSE GENERATORS

Authors: Chang D.D., Karp A., Lorimer D.H.
Title: MULTILAYER CERAMIC CAPACITOR ACCELERATED LIFE TEST SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings - Electronic Components and Technology Conference
Affiliations: AT&T Technologies Inc,, Princeton, NJ, USA, AT&T Technologies Inc, Princeton, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chang, D.D., AT&T Technologies Inc,, Princeton, NJ, USA, AT&T Technologies Inc, Princeton, NJ, USA; Karp, A., AT&T Technologies Inc,, Princeton, NJ, USA, AT&T Technologies Inc, Princeton, NJ, USA; Lorimer, D.H., AT&T Technologies Inc,, Princeton, NJ, USA, AT&T Technologies Inc, Princeton, NJ, USA
Abstract: Multilayer ceramic capacitors (MLCs) are used extensively in modern electronic equipment due to their high energy storage density and low cost. Because of the large numbers of these capacitors used in electronic equipment and their propensity to fail when short-circuited, the overall system reliability can be significantly affected by the reliability behavior of the multilayer ceramic capacitor. A computer-based test system is described here which continuously monitors the leakage current of up to l60 MLCs simultaneously at life test conditions. A unique feature of this system is that all measurements are made on the devices at the elevated temperature and voltage conditions present during the test. Special shielding and grounding techniques are used to allow measurements down to 10 pA. The leakage current data are logged and can be converted to insulation resistance to provide a complete insulation resistance history for each device under test. This information can provide insight to failure mechanisms and life behavior unobtainable by the conventional 'blown fuse' test.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES - Current; ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS - Monitoring; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT - Components; ACCELERATED LIFE TEST; DEVICE UNDER TEST (DUT); INSULATION RESISTANCE; LEAKAGE CURRENT; MULTILAYER CERAMIC CAPACITORS (MLC); CAPACITORS, CERAMIC

Title: SECOND LAW ANALYSIS OF A THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM WITH JOULEAN HEATING OF THE STORAGE ELEMENT.
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical, & Aerospace Engineering,, Knoxville, TN, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Knoxville, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Krane, Robert J., Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical, & Aerospace Engineering,, Knoxville, TN, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Knoxville, TN, USA
Abstract: The techniques of Second Law analysis are applied to the optimal design of a thermal energy storage system with Joulean heaters. The resulting model accounts for three major sources of entropy generation: (1) Joulean heating, (2) heat transfer through finite temperature differences between the gas in the heat exchanger duct and the storage element, and (3) viscous losses in the heat exchanger duct. The model is used in conjunction with an optimization program to perform a parametric study for ranges of the independent variables which include most systems of practical interest. The results of this study indicate that the systems examined destroy approximately 60 to 80 percent of the entering availability. Thus, the thermodynamic efficiency of a thermal energy storage system with Joulean heating of the storge element is extremely low.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRICALLY-HEATED THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; ENTROPY GENERATION SOURCES; OPTIMIZATION PROGRAM; PREVIOUS SECOND LAW ANALYSES; REMOVAL PROCESS ANALYSIS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES) THERMODYNAMIC EFFICIENCY; THERMODYNAMICS

Abstract: Mass, area, and station-keeping propellant needs are estimated for a typical system. And, although important criteria such as cost, Shuttle packaging, and erection/deployment schemes were not considered, the document trends should aid in many of the design choices to be made. Effects on system characteristics were examined for: three heat storage salts with melting temperatures from 743 to 1121 K; parabolic and Cassegrainian mirrors; module power levels of 20 and 40 kW; and alternate pumped-loop, tube-and-fin radiator configurations with and without micrometeoroid armoring.

Abstract: Single-event-upset (SEU) response of a bipolar low-power Schottky-diode-clamped TTL static RAM has been observed using Br ions in the 100-240 MeV energy range and ions in the 20-100 MeV range. These data complete the experimental verification of circuit-simulation SEU modeling for this device. The threshold for onset of SEU has been observed by the variation of energy, ion species and angle of incidence. The results obtained from the computer circuit-simulation modeling and experimental model verification demonstrate a viable methodology for modeling SEU in bipolar integrated circuits.

Abstract: Thermal storage systems offer the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) a means to change customer end-use energy patterns to defer new capacity needed in the 1993-2000 timeframe. TVA's power system and ratepayers can both benefit from thermal storage systems for water heating and space conditioning. This paper presents the results of a study undertaken to quantify the economic benefits and proactive load shaping potential of residential storage water heating and thermal storage systems. Authors with affiliations: Carroll, M.M., Univ of California, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: Needed advances in various areas of energy resource recovery, underground construction, earthquake hazard reduction, and conventional and nuclear defense depend critically on the development of improved theories for mechanical and thermal behavior of geological materials. The areas include oil and gas (including off-shore and Arctic production), mining and in situ recovery, geothermal production , nuclear waste isolation, under-ocean tunneling, underground storage, nuclear test containment, and effects of surface explosions. The needed developments, some of which are detailed in earlier National Academy of Science reports, include constitutive theories for inelastic deformation, failure, and post-failure behavior, influence of microstructure and macrostructure, rock fracture (direct breakage, hydraulic fracture explosive fracture), frictional sliding, soil liquefaction, mechanics of ice, determination of in situ conditions, flow through porous media, and thermal effects.

Abstract: The authors have designed a homopolar generator (HPG) intended to function as an industrial pulsed-power supply. This machine, which carries the trade name FARA-DRUM 15, is a truncated drum-type HPG that stores 15. 4 MJ inertially, has an open circuit voltage of 72 V, and a 1. 5 MA peak current rating. The generator rotor is supported by rolling element bearings and has a maximum design speed of 3600 rpm. Machine features include water cooling of all current-carrying conductors and quick-access brush mechanisms for easy servicing. The generator is designed to continuously produce one full energy discharge every 2 min. Internal impedance is approximately 4. 5 mu OMEGA and 27 nH with an effective capacitance of 5940 F.

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A UNIPOLAR CONVERTER FOR VARIABLE RELUCTANCE MOTOR DRIVES.

Abstract: A new converter concept to drive the switched reluctance motor has been developed. It has only one switching device per phase, uses a unipolar dc supply, returns all the trapped energy to the source, and does not require bifilar windings. This converter is called a C-dump converter because the trapped energy is dumped in a capacitor and then returned to the dc source. The topology for several different C-dump converters is presented. The design and experimental results for a C-dump converter using a chopper to recover the energy dumped on the capacitor are outlined.

Abstract: The CESA-1 project involves the design, construction, operation, and evaluation of a 1. 2 MW//E experimental central receiver solar power system. The CESA-1 plant, located within the boundaries of 'Plataforma Solar' in Tabernas (Almeria), includes a collector field of 300 heliostats, a water/steam cooled cavity-type receiver, a dual admission steam turbine, molten salt heat storage, and the associated controls and auxiliary subsystems. The authors present an overview of the evaluation activities carried out up to the end of 1984. The evaluation has been devoted mainly to the collector systems and receiver systems, with very few tests on the power conversion and storage systems.

Abstract: Results of feasibility study of a subsurface latent heat storage for greenhouse heating are presented in this paper. For greenhouse without insulation curtains, the phase change storage media can supply 37% of annual heating demand. This fraction can be as high as 80% for an insulated greenhouse. Preliminary financial analysis indicates that installed cost of latent heat storage subsystem is high.

Abstract: Transient thermal characteristics of a thermal energy storage system using encapsulated phase-change material (PCM) are presented. A simulation program to test the effect of system parameters, namely, capsule diameter, flow rate, PCM characteristics and the geometry of the storage system, is described. This simulation facilitates the future optimization of such a device.

Abstract: The component and system design characteristics of zinc-bromine storage batteries are described. The chemistry of the couple is discussed, along with the engineering considerations involved in configuring an efficient working battery system. Operational characteristics of single-cell and multicell battery systems incorporating various levels of the developing technology are described. The relevance of the work to stationary energy storage applications is discussed.
Index Keywords: STATIONARY ENERGY STORAGE; ZINC-BROMINE BATTERIES; ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: ICE-MAKER HEAT PUMPS OPERATION AND DESIGN.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Extension, Energy, Technology Cent, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Extension, Energy Technology Cent, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dorgan, C.E., Univ of Wisconsin-Extension, Energy, Technology Cent, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Extension, Energy Technology Cent, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: This paper discusses the operating experience of two ice storage systems in Wisconsin. Both systems were designed and sized for winter heating loads. The Reedsburg Center, on-line since 1978, has the lowest energy usage of all facilities in the Wisconsin VTAE system. The Oshkosh facility was completed in 1982. Both systems have performed well in furnishing low-cost stored energy. They have proved that an ice-maker heat pump (IMHP) system will operate effectively, under various levels of operational care, even though the building system may not be operated at optimum design. The IMHP system's heating and cooling storage lends itself to effective energy savings without complex control and monitoring. However, as is true of all energy storage systems, optimum energy savings are obtained through either a good operator or a properly conceived computer control program.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Cold Storage; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ICE - Manufacture; ICE STORAGE SYSTEMS; ICE-MAKER HEAT PUMPS (IMHP); WINTER HEATING LOADS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Abstract: Electromechanical characteristics of a homopolar generator are described with particular reference to the rotor system, and its effectiveness for realizing compact, low-weight energy storage and conversion devices is discussed. Performance in terms of stored energy, output voltage and power is reviewed. The main design aspects of the two counterrotating rotors and the manufacturing processes are considered. The partial-arc, flexure-mounted pneumostatic bearings are described, as are the current collection system and the main results of a series of tests on brushes and sliprings.
Index Keywords: HOMOPOLAR GENERATORS; PNEUMOSTATIC BEARINGS; PNEUMATICS - Bearings; ROTORS - Design; ELECTRIC GENERATORS, DC

Abstract: The authors describe a magnetic modulator which was designed for second-generation use in the proton storage ring at the Los Alamos National Laboratory meson physics facility. The three-stage machine delivered a 25-kV, 100-ns pulse to a 3-ohm load at pulse repetition rates of up to 1 kHz. A principle function of this system was to serve as a test bed for the measurement of energy losses in magnetic switches. The magnetic switch cores were built from materials of two different alloys, and were tested in both as-cast and annealed states. The performance data acquired indicates that annealing of the core material reduces energy loss by up to a factor of five and that, as expected, losses are lower in the higher resistivity materials.

Abstract: This paper considers the behavior of an MHD/steam-combined cycle plant under the dynamic operating conditions prescribed by the transient stability regime (50 msc to 10 sec after a disturbance on a power system). Using a three-phase fault to ground to test the model developed, it is shown that: (1) in this regime, the MHD generator acts as a current source to provide damping and consequent increased network stability; (2) the low energy storage capability of the MHD generator reduces fault currents and plant surges relative to those of a similarly rated conventional plant; and (3) load tripping introduces special requirements which are discussed.

Abstract: The main objective of the Lyckebo project described was to develop and demonstrate a large-scale solar district heating system with seasonal storage in a rock cavern. Performance data from one year of operation with the plant were measured. The results showed that effective production and storage of solar energy is possible with highly efficient flat plate collectors and rock cavern seasonal storage. The operation of the Lyckebo system shows that solar district heating with seasonal storage in a rock cavern is a technically realistic alternative in the Swedish energy system. The relatively high investment needed for the system makes it at present not competitive with oil, heat-pumps or electric resistant heating.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Solar; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; LYCKEBO PROJECT; SEASONAL STORAGE; SOLAR DISTRICT HEATING; HEATING

Abstract: The objective of this study was to test an active charge-passive discharge rock heat storage system to determine the location of heat stored in the rockbed and the timing of the heat discharge by conduction through the concrete floor. Test data on heated air charging of a horizontal rock heat storage under a concrete floor and the passive dissipation of heat from the heat storage is presented. The velocity of a heat wave in the rockbed was less than predicted from previous work.

Title: CONTROL CONCEPTS FOR THERMAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Engineering Interface Ltd,, Willowdale, Ont, Can, Engineering Interface Ltd, Willowdale, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Tamblyn, R.T., Engineering Interface Ltd,, Willowdale, Ont, Can, Engineering Interface Ltd, Willowdale, Ont, Can
Abstract: Chilled water and ice storage require close control of electric demand at the chiller to minimize energy cost in each billing period. Care is required also in the matching of storage to chiller for each operating mode. This paper reviews a logical approach to optimizing control for typical storage installations. In summary, the principles for control of chilled water and ice storage systems are: 1) optimize the demand shaving for each billing period; 2) use storage as little as possible; and 3) store only as much as required to complement the refrigerating capacity for a particular billing period.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Climate Control; ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION; ICE - Storage; REFRIGERATION; CHILLED WATER; ON-LINE CHILLER; TEMPERATURE STRATIFICATION; COLD STORAGE

Authors with affiliations: Salter, S.H., Univ of Edinburgh, Dep of Mechanical, Engineering, Edinburgh, Scotl, Univ of Edinburgh, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Edinburgh, Scotl; Rea, M., Univ of Edinburgh, Dep of Mechanical, Engineering, Edinburgh, Scotl, Univ of Edinburgh, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Edinburgh, Scotl
Abstract: High-pressure oil is used successfully in earth-moving plant, flight control actuators, mining equipment, machine tools, fighting vehicles, robots, ship-steering gear and anywhere where large forces must be controlled in an intelligent way. The intelligent control of large forces is not a bad description of the requirements of renewable energy. This paper is written in an attempt to show that the reputation of high-pressure oil is ill-deserved and that with the right designs and precautions it can provide for energy generation the same advantages that electronics has provided in so many other fields. A constantly recurring theme is the need to provide energy storage. The ability of hydraulic techniques to provide high speed interfaces to energy stores gives them an added attraction.

Title: TRANSURANIC (TRU) WASTE MANAGEMENT AT SAVANNAH RIVER - PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE.
Affiliations: Savannah River Operations Office,, Aiken, SC, USA, Savannah River Operations Office, Aiken, SC, USA
Authors with affiliations: D'Ambrosia, Julie T., Savannah River Operations Office,, Aiken, SC, USA, Savannah River Operations Office, Aiken, SC, USA
Abstract: Defense TRU waste at Savannah River (SR) results from the Department of Energy's (DOE) national defense activities, including the operation of production reactors and fuel reprocessing plants and research and development activities. The major objective of the TRU program at SR is to support the TRU National Program, which is dedicated to preparing waste for, and emplacing waste in, the WIPP. Thus, the SR Program also supports WIPP operations. The SP Site specific goals are to phase out the indefinite storage of TRU waste, which has been the mode of waste management since 1974, and to dispose of SR's Defense TRU waste.

Title: PLASTIC-BONDED, NON-SINTERED NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERIES FOR SUBMARINES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Charkey, Allen, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA; Ferreira, Elio, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA; Glenn, Donald, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Abstract: Batteries currently deployed in virtually all of the world's submarines, including nuclear-powered, are based on lead-acid chemistry. While advances have been recently incorporated, these systems achieve gravimetric and volumetric energy densities of only 26 Wh/kg and 65 Wh/l respectively. The application of a nonsintered, plastic-bonded electrode technology to very large nickel-cadmium cells has culminated in the development of an 8000-Ah cell. The new cell has almost twice the storage capacity (at 46-48 Wh/kg) and 30-50% improvement in volumetric density (at 100 Wh/l) over lead-acid cells. The cell, designed to meet high discharge rates and rapid charge acceptance, has a life expectancy of over 750 cycles and will provide both diesel-electric and nuclear-powered submarines with improved performance.
Index Keywords: NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERIES; PLASTIC-BONDED ELECTRODES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ELECTRODES - Plastics Applications; SUBMARINES

Title: ALUMINUM - AIR POWER CELL - A PROGRESS REPORT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Maimoni, A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: The aluminum-air power cell as a power source for general purpose electric vehicles is described. Program developments since the 1983 IECEC meeting and more recent reviews are summarized. Estimates of the cell's energy efficiency, using coal as the primary energy source, indicate that it is substantially better than the internal combustion engine using synthetic fuels derived from coal. With improved materials is it likely to approach the overall energy efficiency of rechargeable battery systems. Three experiments involving a 600-cm**2 wedge cell coupled to a crystallizer and a hydrocyclone are described. Substantial progress has been made in the development of the air cathode and aluminum anode materials. The status of various system components is summarized. Crystallization experiments indicate that secondary nucleation of small particles can be controlled by operation of the crystallizer at 80 degree C, and agglomeration of fine particles occurs readily under low shear conditions.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM-AIR POWER-CELLS; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; ENERGY STORAGE; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES
