Authors with affiliations: Koehler, C.W., Ford Aerospace & Communication, Corp, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communication Corp, USA; Applewhite, A.Z., Ford Aerospace & Communication, Corp, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communication Corp, USA; Hall, A.M., Ford Aerospace & Communication, Corp, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communication Corp, USA; Russell, P.G., Ford Aerospace & Communication, Corp, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communication Corp, USA
Abstract: The bipolar nickel-hydrogen (Ni-H//2 ) battery is an excellent energy storage system candidate for low earth orbits (LEO), medium altitude orbits (MAO) and geostationary orbits (GEO). Ford Aerospace & Communications Corporation and Yardney Battery Division are developing a bipolar Ni-H//2 battery under NASA-Lewis Research Center (LeRC) sponsorship. The initial design of the battery is now complete, a scale model has been tested, and fabrication of two 10-cell, 75 Ah boilerplate test batteries is under way. A comparison of the bipolar Ni-H//2 battery with other energy systems is provided. The initial design developed under the NASA-LeRC contract, including an evaluation of the candidate stack components, and manufacturing and prototype test results are described.
Index Keywords: NASA; NICKEL-HYDROGEN BATTERIES; SATELLITES - Power Supply; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Forestieri A.F., Baraona C.R., Valgora M.E.
Title: SPACE STATION POWER SYSTEM ADVANCED DEVELOPMENT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Authors with affiliations: Forestieri, A.F., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA; Baraona, C.R., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA; Valgora, M.E., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Abstract: The power system advanced development program includes tasks in power generation, energy storage, and power management and distribution. All key activity elements are addressed. In power generation, technical issues in photovoltaic arrays and solar dynamic power systems are examined. The electrical energy storage system being advanced is the regenerative fuel cell, and a status report on that technology is discussed. Power management and distribution tasks are at present concerned with evaluating automated power system control, component and device development, and power system hardware. The results to date of those evaluations are reported. Finally, a status report on power system test bed and flight experiments is presented. Since the contracts for the space station definition and preliminary design for the power system will include an advanced development effort, a status report on that activity is also presented.
Index Keywords: SPACE STATIONS; STATUS REPORTS; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ENERGY STORAGE; SPACECRAFT

Title: GENERAL COMPUTER SIMULATION MODEL FOR FURNACES AND BOILERS.
Affiliations: Univ Stuttgart, Abteilung, Heizung-Lueftung-Klimatechnik,, Stuttgart, West Ger, Univ Stuttgart, Abteilung Heizung-Lueftung-Klimatechnik, Stuttgart, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Claus, G., Univ Stuttgart, Abteilung, Heizung-Lueftung-Klimatechnik,, Stuttgart, West Ger, Univ Stuttgart, Abteilung Heizung-Lueftung-Klimatechnik, Stuttgart, West Ger; Stephan, W., Univ Stuttgart, Abteilung, Heizung-Lueftung-Klimatechnik,, Stuttgart, West Ger, Univ Stuttgart, Abteilung Heizung-Lueftung-Klimatechnik, Stuttgart, West Ger
Abstract: A computer simulation model for furnaces and boilers was developed which calculates the thermal state of a boiler using the method of indirect determination of the boiler efficiency. All the variables used in the model are measurable on a test bench under standardized conditions. As the profile of the flue gas temperature and the air temperature at the outlet of the boiler can easily be determined, it is possible to calculate the losses through the chimney during the burner-on and the burner-off times, respectively. However, the temperatures and the heat transfer within the boiler are not generally measured. Therefore, the boiler is considered as an ideal storage unit with an evenly distributed temperature. The surface losses of the boiler are computed using two mean U. A. -values. Several parametric studies are made using this model.
Index Keywords: BOILERS - Computer Simulation; CHIMNEYS; ENERGY UTILIZATION; HEAT TRANSFER; VENTILATION; AIR EXCESS RATIO; FLOW RESISTANCE FACTOR; FUEL MASS FLOW RATE; FURNACES, SPACE HEATING

Authors: Phillips Wayne M., Stearns John W.
Title: ADVANCED LATENT HEAT OF FUSION THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR SOLAR POWER SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, Wayne M., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA; Stearns, John W., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA
Abstract: An advanced materials system for space and terrestrial solar thermal power applications which require long life and efficient thermal energy storage is described. The system is based on a mixture of alkali metals and their halides, forming two immiscible melts. The problems usually encountered when thermal energy is stored as heat of fusion of salts, such as thermal ratcheting usually associated with large volumetric changes, are moderated by the introduction of alkali metal. Testing with Na/NaCl and NaF/MgF//2 eutectic, in capsules of 321 SS and 9Cr-1Mo containing tensile samples is described. Enhanced heat transfer via boiling and condensing the alkali metal also appears feasible. Thus the concept seems to offer the design flexibility needed in thermal power systems using solar energy coupled with common methods of energy conversion such as Stirling and Brayton cycles. The overall concept may be applicable to other slurry systems of the alkali metal/alkali salt type with melting points compatible with lower-temperature-conversion organic Rankine systems.
Index Keywords: LATENT HEAT; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SPACECRAFT - Energy Storage; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Loewenthal Stuart H., Scibbe Herbert W., Parker Richard J., Zaretsky Erwin V.
Title: OPERATING CHARACTERISTICS OF A 0. 87 KW-HR FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE MODULE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Authors with affiliations: Loewenthal, Stuart H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA; Scibbe, Herbert W., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA; Parker, Richard J., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA; Zaretsky, Erwin V., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Abstract: The design and loss characteristics of 0. 87-kW-hr (peak) flywheel energy storage module suitable for aerospace and automotive applications are described. The maraging steel flywheel rotor, a 46-cm (18-in) diameter, 58-kg (128-lb) tapered disk, delivers 0. 65 kW-hr of usable energy between operating speeds of 10,000 and 20,000 rpm. The rotor is supported by 20- and 25-mm bore diameter, deep-groove ball bearings, lubricated by a self-replenishing wick-type lubrication system. To reduce aerodynamic losses, the rotor housing was evacuated to vacuum levels from 40 to 200 mtorr. Dynamic rotor instabilities uncovered during testing necessitated the use of an elastomeric-bearing damper to limit shaft excursions. Spindown losses from bearing, seal, and aerodynamic drag at 50 mtorr. typically ranged from 64 to 193 W at 10,000 and 20,000 rpm, respectively. The discharge efficiency of the flywheel system exceeded 96% at torque levels greater than 21% of rated torque.
Index Keywords: FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEEL ROTORS; AUTOMOBILES - Energy Storage; FLYWHEELS; AEROSPACE VEHICLES

Abstract: A small-sized analog scheme battery energy storage system simulates the various characteristics from transient to steady-state response. Results from this simulation indicate the ability of obtaining accurate charge and discharge characteristics of each battery and the steady-state controlling performances of a battery-powered energy storage system connected with a utility network. In addition, the protection schemes needed when faults occur in the battery system, power conditioning system, or utility network are clarified.

Authors: Gahn Randall F., Hagedorn Norman H., Johnson Jerome A.
Title: CYCLING PERFORMANCE OF THE IRON-CHROMIUM REDOX ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gahn, Randall F., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Hagedorn, Norman H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Johnson, Jerome A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Extended charge-discharge cycling of this electrochemical storage system at 65 degree C was performed on 14. 5-cm**2 single cells and a four-cell 867-cm**2 bipolar stack. Both the anolyte and catholyte reactant fluids contained 1 molar concentration of iron and chromium chlorides in hydrochloric acid and were separated by a low-selectivity, cation-exchange membrane. The effect of cycling on the chromium electrode and the membrane was determined. Bismuth and bismuth-lead catalyzed chromium electrodes and a radiation-grafted polyethylene membrane were evaluated by cycling between 5 and 85% state-of-charge at 80 mA/cm**2 and by periodic charge-discharge polarization measurements to 140 mA/cm**2 . Gradual performance losses were observed during cycling but were recoverable by completely discharging the system. Good scale-up to the 867 cm**2 stack was achieved. The only difference appeared to be an unexplained resistive-type loss which resulted in a 75% W-hr efficiency (at 80 mA/cm**2 ) versus 81% for the 14. 5 cm**2 cell. A new rebalance cell was developed to maintain reactant ionic balance. The cell successfully reduced ferric ions in the iron reactant stream to ferrous ions while chloride ions were oxidized to chlorine gas.
Index Keywords: CHARGE-DISCHARGE CYCLING; IRON AND CHROMIUM CHLORIDES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ENERGY STORAGE

Abstract: This paper reviews the current status for harvesting, handling and storing of herbaceous crops utilized as an energy source. These crops include sugarcane, sweet sorghum, forage grasses (perennial and annual), root crops and other special crops. Research recommendations are made for future biomass energy production.

Authors: Ofoli Robert Y., Merva George E.
Title: MODEL FOR OPTIMIZING VENTILATION RATES FOR POTATO STORAGE.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Michigan State Univ, Dep of, Agricultural Engineering, East, Lansing, MI, USA, Michigan State Univ, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, East Lansing, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ofoli, Robert Y., Michigan State Univ, Dep of, Agricultural Engineering, East, Lansing, MI, USA, Michigan State Univ, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, East Lansing, MI, USA; Merva, George E., Michigan State Univ, Dep of, Agricultural Engineering, East, Lansing, MI, USA, Michigan State Univ, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, East Lansing, MI, USA
Abstract: A scheme is developed for the optimization of the ventilation rate for potato storages based on the principle of minimum entropy production. The scheme involves calculating a parameter defined as the energy dissipation index (EDI). When the EDI is plotted against the ventilation rate, the graph provides a zone of minimum system entropy production. The procedure may be used to optimize the ventilation rate.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING; FARM BUILDINGS - Ventilation; ENERGY DISSIPATION INDEX; MINIMUM ENTROPY PRODUCTION; POTATO STORAGE; VENTILATION RATE OPTIMIZATION; AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

Title: OVERVIEW OF CRITERIA FOR SELECTION OF PHOTOVOLTAIC PUMP STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Global Energy Group, Global Energy Group
Authors with affiliations: Sonti, Pat Venkatesh, Global Energy Group, Global Energy Group
Abstract: In photovoltaic water pumping systems, storage of energy and water is often required due to several usage factors such as periodic and nighttime irrigation, ample supply during cloudy periods, and on-demand domestic requirements. The two forms of storage are batteries for electrical energy and tanks for water storage. An evaluation of the interrelationship between the usage applications and the types of storage options available is presented and discussed in order to successfully design an efficient photovoltaic water pumping system.

Authors with affiliations: Bullock, K.J., Univ of Queensland, Dep of, Mechanical Engineering, St. Lucia,, Aust, Univ of Queensland, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, St. Lucia, Aust
Abstract: The utilisation of a hybrid vehicle concept enables the vehicle to be designed for specific traffic situations. The paper describes the context in which any hybrid vehicle might have an application either to save fuel, reduce emissions, improve performance, reduce noise or improve driveability. The paper also describes the experience with the design of five vehicles in the Department of Mechanical Engineering, two of which have been extensively road tested and two of which are currently undergoing road tests.

Affiliations: Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Welty, D.L., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Sutton, A.L., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Jones, D.D., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Nye, J.C., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Vetter, R.L., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Abstract: Producers need information to evaluate the total manure management system, including labor, energy and equipment requirements as well as the initial capital investments. Several attempts have been made to evaluate various types of manure management systems for all species or more specifically for dairy and swine. Economic analyses have been conducted on more specific components of manure management such as injection of manure with tank wagons and the fuel and labor requirements of an above-ground manure storage system. With the diversity of opinion amongst researchers on the value of above-ground storage systems, a case study was conducted to investigate the labor, equipment and energy requirements of Slurrystore manure management systems on 3 dairy operations and 1 swine operation in central Indiana.

Title: COMPUTER MODELING OF ENERGY SYSTEMS INCORPORATING WIND GENERATING UNITS.
Affiliations: Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Greece, Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Machias, A.V., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Greece, Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Greece; Dialynas, E.N., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Greece, Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Greece
Abstract: The authors present an energy system which can be used to supply the electrical power demand and the hot water requirements of one or more buildings. This energy model can be regarded as an alternative design of fuel-fired central heating and central hot water supply systems. One of its major advantages is the ability to permit decentralized planning of hot water supply networks; circulating pipe runs are largely eliminated and therefore the heat losses are minimized. An efficient computational algorithm has also been developed for simulating the performance of the proposed energy system. This algorithm can be used in selecting the requirements of hot water storage cylinders and the optimal number and operational characteristics of the wind generators. Finally, two application studies are examined and the results presented.
Index Keywords: WIND POWER - Applications; COMPUTER MODELING; ENERGY SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: ANALYSIS OF WIND-POWER SYSTEMS CONNECTED TO AIR-LIFT PUMP.
Affiliations: Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of, Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz, Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz
Authors with affiliations: Feitosa, E.A.N., Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of, Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz, Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz; Cirilo, J.A., Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of, Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz, Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz; Soares Jr., A.M.C., Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of, Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz, Federal Univ of Pernambuco, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Recife, Braz
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of the air-lift pump driven by simple fixed-geometry wind turbines (multi-blade type). An air compressor is directly coupled to the windmill. Advantages of pneumatic transmissions are discussed. These include overall system simplicity, energy storage and the fact that the windmill and the well can be separated. Experimental and theoretical results indicate the great potential use of the system. A simulation strategy was developed to analyse the load matching effects due to the water level variation in wells. The results of an experimental application in the arid region of Brazil are presented.

Abstract: This paper addresses the concerns of the utilities and the possibilities of energy storage, wind forecasting, and other options that may minimize utility interface problems. Department of Energy, Electric Power Research Institute, utilities, and wind farmers are discussed.

Title: DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT OF AN INERTIAL POWER SUPPLY UNIT FOR CARRIER-BASED AIRCRAFT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hockney, Richard, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Eisenhaure, David, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; O'Dea, Stephen, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Johnson, Bruce, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Mariano, Rhonda, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA
Abstract: A flywheel energy storage unit which performs as a form, fit, and function replacement for a nickel-cadmium battery is described. The battery, which provides a source of uninterrupted power to the inertial navigation system of an aircraft, has proved unreliable in field use. Corrosion of the terminals, self-discharge and premature loss of capacity have necessitated frequent maintenance. The inertial power supply unit (IPSU) has a designed operating lifetime of 20,000 hrs. It offers the additional advantages of unlimited charge/discharge cycling, long shelf life, and capability for monitoring both state-of-charge and bearing condition.
Index Keywords: FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE; INERTIAL POWER SUPPLIES; NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Space Applications; FLYWHEELS; AIRCRAFT CARRIERS

Authors: Loewenthal Stuart H., Scibbe Herbert W., Parker Richard J., Zaretsky Erwin V.
Title: OPERATING CHARACTERISTCS OF 0. 87 kw-hr FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE MODULE.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Loewenthal, Stuart H., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Scibbe, Herbert W., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Parker, Richard J., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Zaretsky, Erwin V., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Discussion is given of the design and loss characteristics of 0. 87 kw-hr (peak) flywheel energy storage module suitable for aerospace and automotive applications. The maraging steel flywheel rotor, a 46-cm- (18 in-) diameter, 58-kg (128-lb) tapered disk, delivers 0. 65 kw-hr of usable energy between operating speeds of 10,000 and 20,000 rpm. The rotor is supported by 20- and 25-mm bore diameter, deep-groove ball bearings, lubricated by a self-replenishing wick type lubrication system. To reduce aerodynamic losses, the rotor housing was evacuated to vacuum levels from 40 to 200 millitorr. Dynamic rotor instabilities uncovered during testing necessitated the use of an elastomeric-bearing damper to limit shaft excursions.
Index Keywords: FLYWHEELS - Space Applications; ROTORS; FLYWHEEL ROTORS; FLYWHEELS

Title: TAIPOWER'S WIND ENERGY PROJECT ON THE CHI MEI ISLAND.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Dep of, Civil Engineering, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Dep of Civil Engineering, Columbia, MO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Liu, H., Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Dep of, Civil Engineering, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Dep of Civil Engineering, Columbia, MO, USA; Liao, T.L., Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Dep of, Civil Engineering, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Dep of Civil Engineering, Columbia, MO, USA
Abstract: The Taiwan Power Company is pursuing a wind energy project on a remote island called 'Chi Mei' in the Pescadores. At present, a diesel power plant of a total capacity of two megawatts supplies the electricity to the islanders. High cost in diesel fuel combined with transportation difficulties renders the power plant expensive to operate. Because the island is in the trade wind zone having strong wind, Taipower intends to use wind turbines to generate electricity in order to reduce diesel consumption. Sea water will be pumped into a reservoir on the top of a hill for storing the wind energy. Use of solar energy to supplement wind in summer is also contemplated. Based on a year's measurements, the average wind speed at 30 m height of the proposed WECS site is 11 m/s in October through April, and 6 m/s in May through September.
Index Keywords: DIESEL ENGINES; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; WIND TURBINES; FUEL CONSUMPTION; TAIWAN POWER COMPANY; WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEM; WIND ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: ENERGY FUTURES: A WORLD STUDY.
Affiliations: Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spinrad, Bernard I., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Abstract: Between 1973 and 1979, a major energy project was conducted at the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA) in Laxenburg, Austria. The results of the study were published in the form of a book, Energy in a Finite World: A Global Systems Analysis (1981). This article is an interpretation of the results achieved so far. The IIASA studies indicate that we have plenty of energy resources. If we follow the path of least resistance, we can shoot for a 'low'-energy world or 'high'-energy world. Neither is very desirable. The low-energy world doesn't develop the economies of poor regions very well - it just drags the current picture further along. The high-energy world does marginally better on economic development, but it pulls us down the road of depleting resources and increasing emissions. A moderate policy of energy investments in various energy resources and research is urged.
Index Keywords: ENERGY POLICY; FUELS; NUCLEAR ENERGY; PETROLEUM, CRUDE; SOLAR ENERGY; ELECTROLYSIS OF WATER; ENERGY STORAGE; FUEL CELLS; NUCLEAR FUSION; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SOURCES; ENERGY RESOURCES

Title: CONTROL OF BRINE-TYPE ICE STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Calmac Manufacturing Corp,, Englewood, NJ, USA, Calmac Manufacturing Corp, Englewood, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: MacCracken, Calvin D., Calmac Manufacturing Corp,, Englewood, NJ, USA, Calmac Manufacturing Corp, Englewood, NJ, USA
Abstract: Brine-type ice storage systems are attractive to many engineers and companies since they are compact, may be used with standard package chillers including centrifugals, and are uniquely adaptable to lower cost partial storage or demand-limiting systems. System designers are faced with a number of control choices: 1) operating strategy, such as partial or full storage, demand-limited storage, economizer cycle vs. ice, and schematic arrangements for locating chiller either before, after, or beside the storage; 2) use of presently available controls needed to implement the strategy, such as the type of time-of-day controls, temperature-controlled blending valves, and four-way rotary valves; and 3) new controls, such as the ability to limit building demand by controlling chiller operation, an ice-inventory sensor to level out night chiller operation, and a new comfort control that biases indoor temperature to balance lower relative humidity caused by colder coils. Methods of arriving at these answers, including their relation to particular design jobs, are given. A full description of the need for each control and its importance to the system are covered.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; COLD STORAGE; ENERGY MANAGEMENT; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; VALVES AND VALVE GEAR; CHILLER; FOUR-WAY ROTARY VALVES; ICE-INVENTORY SENSOR; TEMPERATURE-CONTROLLED BLENDING VALVES; ICE

Title: SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR POND.
Affiliations: Natl Univ of Singapore, Kent Ridge, Singapore, Natl Univ of Singapore, Kent Ridge, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Hawlader, M.N.A., Natl Univ of Singapore, Kent Ridge, Singapore, Natl Univ of Singapore, Kent Ridge, Singapore
Abstract: This description of the development of a salt-gradient solar pond - its construction, operation, performance and applications - starts with a brief history of solar ponds. The working principle of the pond and the absorption of radiation in salt water have been described and the factors affecting the performance of the solar pond have been identified. The methods of construction, operation and maintenance of the salt-gradient solar pond have been dealt with in detail. Finally, the possible applications of the solar pond have been discussed.

Abstract: An exact solution was obtained for the problem of determining the non-steady-state temperature field around a below-ground cylindrical heat accumulator. On the accumulator's surface, convective heat exchange occurs with the soil according to Newton's law.

Abstract: The volume contains 168 papers presented at the meeting, 11 of which are in abstract form only. Title: ALTERNATIVE FUELS, FUEL CYCLES, AND REACTORS: ARE THEY USEFUL? ARE THEY NECESSARY?
Affiliations: Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spinrad, Bernard I., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Abstract: The search for reactors, fuel cycles, and fuel production concepts other than those considered conventional in the nuclear community is motivated by two separate interests. One is to look for improvements with the aim of providing cheaper and more durable energy systems. The other is to contribute toward solution of the threat of weapons material diversion and weapons proliferation problems. Various alternative schemes are considered and it is concluded that the most robust and workable option is a simple variant of what has been considered all along to be the 'standard' nuclear fuel cycle of the world. This is one in which breeder reactors are deployed within fuel-cycle parks. Their fuel is reprocessed in a quick turnaround, so that the quantity of plutonium in storage is small. Their blankets can be thorium, from which denatured or undenatured fuel elements (containing **2**3**3U diluted in **2**3**8 U, or thorium, respectively) can be derived. These can be shipped to dispersed LWR reactor sites.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Reprocessing; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR REACTORS; NUCLEAR REACTORS, FAST; NUCLEAR REACTORS, LIGHT WATER; LMFBR; PLUTONIUM; SYMBIOTIC REACTOR SCHEMES; THORIUM; URANIUM; NUCLEAR REACTORS, BREEDER

Title: EVOLUTION OF THE DESIGN OF SOLAR WATER HEATERS IN NORTH AMERICA.
Affiliations: Community Environmental Council,, Santa Barbara, CA, USA, Community Environmental Council, Santa Barbara, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Perlin, J., Community Environmental Council,, Santa Barbara, CA, USA, Community Environmental Council, Santa Barbara, CA, USA
Abstract: Because fuel was scarce and expensive, many Californians turned to the sun for heating water. The first commercial solar water heater, a glass-covered box with water tanks placed inside, was patented in 1891. Refinements on the 1891 patent which were made in 1909 resulted in the configuration still in use today--a glass covered box containing pipes soldered to a metal plate through which water flowed to a storage tank. Home built solar water heaters using these two configurations were also popular. The construction of these solar water heaters is simple and can be easily built to provide hot water for those currently living in the developing world.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; BARE TANK HEATERS; ENCLOSED TANK HEATERS; WATER HEATERS

Title: TRANSWALL VRS. TROMBE WALL: RELATIVE PERFORMANCE STUDIES.
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India
Authors with affiliations: Nayak, J.K., Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Bombay, India
Abstract: This paper compares the performance of two types thermal storage wall, namely Transwall and Trombewall. Both of them are located directly behind the south facing glazing of a building. The relative performance of these have been studied to find out their suitability for a cool climate of North India. Mathematical models have been developed to predict the thermal performance in terms of the heat flux entering the living space through these walls. Numerical calculations for Srinagar (India) climatic conditions show that Transwall is more effective than the Trombe wall as a passive heating system.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; RELATIVE PERFORMANCE STUDIES; THERMAL STORAGE WALL; TRANSWALL; TROMBE WALL; HEATING

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 146 papers, 5 of which are in abstract form only. Main topics discussed include: solar energy, passive solar energy, utilities applications and daylighting applications. Implementation of passive solar into the total building concept has been covered. Daylighting and other livability issues, directly or indirectly associated with solar energy, have been investigated. Utilities, in an effort to control peak load and avoid the construction of new generating facilities, have initiated or are considering solar energy as a viable alternative.

Abstract: The article discusses the 'storage/loss' time for a building as an estimate for the building response time, t//r. Using data for an actual building, values of t//r are estimated using thermal models, and observational values for t//r are given, based on cooling curve information, and also using a novel autocorrelational approach. Authors with affiliations: Chowdhuri, P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: A new concept for the synchronous-machine commutating reactance is presented. A simple and fast, but accurate, method of analysis is developed to design a pulsed-power system containing a rotating machine. The use of the same power supply for both the magnetizing and the flat-top periods is economically attractive, and technically feasible, particularly because the changeover switches do not have to interrupt power. The author analyzes the electrical requirements that will be imposed on the alternator and the converter.

Abstract: An inductive energy storage experiment using plasma opening switches has been run at the 3- OMEGA , 0. 1-TW pulse power generator Pollux. It was the aim of this experiment to obtain voltage and power multiplication and to study POS switching under different operating conditions: Cathode magnetic fields of 6 and 12 kG, diode loads with falling and rising impedance characteristics, and series configurations of two POS-sets as well as one switch integrated into the diode have been investigated. In addition, a series of experiments was run injecting the plasma from the cathode side.

Title: ENERGY STORES ON INDEPENDENT POWER SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Kuz'min, M.A.; Chilin, Yu.N.
Abstract: A method is presented for approximate determination of the areas of rational application of energy stores on independent power systems with impulse utilization devices. Dimensionless criterial parameters are proposed that govern the desirability for utilization of stores from the viewpoint of minimizing power-system weight. The way in which the functional conditions of impulse utilization devices and the specific characteristics of power-system elements affect selection of a rational type of heat-takeoff system, power-supply system, and the complex of such systems is investigated.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; ENERGY STORES; HEAT-TAKEOFF SYSTEMS; IMPULSE ENERGY UTILIZATIN DEVICES; INDEPENDENT POWER SYSTEMS; POWER-SUPPLY SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors: Simoens H., Baert D., Kuyken H.
Title: 5 kW PEAK PHOTOVOLTAIC DEMONSTRATION PROJECT FOR RESIDENTIAL APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg, State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg
Authors with affiliations: Simoens, H., State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg, State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg; Baert, D., State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg, State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg; Kuyken, H., State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg, State Univ of Ghent, Ghent, Belg
Abstract: A 5 kWp photovoltaic power plant has been put into operation since June 1984. The maximum solar panel output is only little lower than the average maximum output at STC and the efficiency was 10% instead of 10. 7%. The average efficiency was about 7%. This paper describes a photovoltaic plant in Ghent, consisting of a 5 kW peak solar panel, a 24 kWh storage battery, a 5kW grid-connected inverter and a control computer. The influence of the different control strategies on the energy production, is also discussed.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR CELLS; PHOTOVOLTAIC DEMONSTRATION PROJECT; RESIDENTIAL APPLICATIONS; SOLAR PANELS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Zhang Z., Liu T., Pate M., Nelson R.
Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF A RESIDENTIAL SOLAR SYSTEM COUPLED TO A RADIANT PANEL CEILING.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Z., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA; Liu, T., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA; Pate, M., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA; Nelson, R., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Abstract: An experimental study of a solar-radiant heating system was performed at Iowa State University's Energy Research House (ERH). The ERH was constructed with copper tubes embedded in the plaster ceilings, thus providing a unique radiant heating system. In addition, twenty-four water-glycol, flat-plate solar collectors were mounted on the south side of the residence. The present study uses the solar collectors to heat a storage tank via a submerged copper tube coil. Hot water from the storage tank is then circulated through a heat exchanger, which heats the water flowing through the radiant ceiling. This paper contains a description of the solar-radiant system and an interpretation of the data that were measured during a series of transient experiments. A study of this data has led to an understanding of the dynamic characteristics of this system. In addition, the feasibility of heating an enclosure using a radiant-panel heating system supplied by solar energy has been demonstrated.
Index Keywords: HOUSES - Ceilings; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HEATING

Authors: Alsema E.A., van Wijk A.J.M., Turkenburg W.C.
Title: EFFECTS OF FUTURE ELECTRICITY SCENARIOS ON PHOTOVOLTAIC ENERGY VALUE IN THE NETHERLANDS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Alsema, E.A., State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth; van Wijk, A.J.M., State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth; Turkenburg, W.C., State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth, State Univ Utrecht, Utrecht, Neth
Abstract: The value of photovoltaic energy to the electric utility of the Netherlands is evaluated on the basis of two electricity supply scenarios for the year 2000, each with and without an integrated central storage system operating mainly in a peak-shaving strategy. Utility avoided cost, determined by fuel savings and the impact of PV systems on utility system reliability, is calculated using two computer models, one that simulates the total demand and supply of electricity, and another that analyses the Loss-of-Load Probability. Assuming fuel savings only, the allowable cost of PV electricity is found to be about 0. 045 ECU/kWh. If capacity savings are assumed too, the allowable cost increases to about 0. 06 ECU/kWh. For different scenarios these figures can change by about 10%. On the basis of these results a cost target of 900 ECU/kWp is set for PV systems in the Netherlands.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Netherlands; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; FUEL SAVINGS; PHOTOVOLTAIC ENERGY VALUES; SYSTEM RELIABILITY; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Authors: Weller Patricia, Clark Gene, Collins William
Title: INDOOR TESTING OF AN INTEGRAL PASSIVE SOLAR WATER HEATER.
Affiliations: Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Weller, Patricia, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA; Clark, Gene, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA; Collins, William, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA
Abstract: Indoor tests have been made on a commercial integral passive water heater (Gulf Thermal PT-40) to study energy losses through the top cover and heat storage delivery efficiency. Results showed that energy losses can be represented using a simple lumped cooling model. The overall heat transfer coefficient for top losses was measured to be slightly higher than predictions from flat plate correlations. Collector tilt and uneven temperature distribution were found to have a significant effect on the measured heat loss coefficient. The average heat storage delivery efficiency from complete draw tests was 0. 82. The rate of water draw had a significant effect on heat storage delivery.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Testing; INDOOR TESTING; INTEGRAL COLLECTOR/STORAGE (ICS) SOLAR WATER HEATERS; INTEGRAL PASSIVE SOLAR WATER HEATER; HEATING

Authors: Burns Scott, Zeenni Elias, Guven Halil M.
Title: STRATIFICATION AND PERFORMANCE CHARACTERISTICS OF A SOLAR BREADBOX WATER HEATER.
Affiliations: Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point, Mugu, CA, USA, Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point Mugu, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Burns, Scott, Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point, Mugu, CA, USA, Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point Mugu, CA, USA; Zeenni, Elias, Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point, Mugu, CA, USA, Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point Mugu, CA, USA; Guven, Halil M., Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point, Mugu, CA, USA, Pacific Missile Test Cent, Point Mugu, CA, USA
Abstract: Solar breadbox water heaters show great promise as effective and low cost means of utilizing solar energy to lower monthly hot water heating bills. Although the basic components of solar breadbox design are well established, a coherent analytical method of designing them had not been developed. This paper presents the formulation of a design/optimization method which incorporates a model for predicting the behavior of a stratified collector/storage tank, and an interactive computer program in which the breadbox design parameters (e. g. , tank geometry, orientation, heat transfer characteristics, etc. ) can be changed. The results of the performance model are validated by comparing them with those obtained from an experimental study. Results have shown that thermal stratification in the tank can be as high as 45 degree F on a sunny day.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; DESIGN/OPTIMIZATION METHOD; PERFORMANCE MODEL; SOLAR BREADBOX WATER HEATER; STRATIFIED COLLECTOR/STORAGE TANK BEHAVIOR PREDICTION; WATER HEATERS

Title: EXPERIMENTAL TEST OF COUPLED WAVE MODEL OF LARGE COILS.
Affiliations: Univ of Notre Dame, IN, USA, Univ of Notre Dame, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gabriel, G.J., Univ of Notre Dame, IN, USA, Univ of Notre Dame, IN, USA
Abstract: Recent data from time-domain pulse reflectometry experiments on a three-turn coil in the form of a 'race track' corroborate the theory of the coupled-wave model for large coils. The data demonstrate effects of turn-to-turn coupling, pulse travel time, reduced damping at liquid nitrogen temperature, and the relation between short-term and long-term transient behavior. The use of large superconductor coils as energy storage elements inherently poses the problem of dealing with fast electromagnetic transients in the vicinity of superconductor boundaries. Treatment of such coils as the lumped inductors of circuit theory is grossly inaccurate when events are on a nanosecond scale. Rigorous treatment from the standpoint of electrodynamic field theory has resulted in the coupled-wave model which is based on the theory of multiple-conductor transmission structures.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Coils; COUPLED WAVE MODEL; LARGE SUPERCONDUCTING COILS; ELECTRIC COILS

Authors: Ramshaw R.S., Xie G., Deacon R., Fyfe V., Henderson B.W., Jones E., Jurek K., Lenson D., Opie M.
Title: POWER CONDITIONING IN A SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEM WITH MICROPROCESSOR CONTROL.
Source title: Conference Digest - International Electrical, Electronics Conference and Exposition
Affiliations: Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Ramshaw, R.S., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Xie, G., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Deacon, R., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Fyfe, V., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Henderson, B.W., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Jones, E., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Jurek, K., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Lenson, D., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can; Opie, M., Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can, Univ of Waterloo, Ont, Can
Abstract: A progress report is presented on the control of a photovoltaic array with an interconnected system of loads, a storage unit, and a utility backup. The dc load is a variable-speed pump drive controlled by a chopper. The ac loads are the fixed-frequency utility and adjustable-frequency ac drives. Energy storage is provided for intermittent duty, sized from simulation studies, for provision of drive-starting current and short-term reduction in insolation levels. A dc converter provides power from the utility in order to make the system versatile. The sources and loads have their individual power conditioning controllers and processors.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Computer Applications; MICROPROCESSOR CONTROL; POWER CONDITIONING; SOLAR CELLS

Title: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE SCALED PROTOTYPE FOR THE LOS ALAMOS UTILITY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, J.D., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA; Kiburz, M.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: A complete analysis of the combined Department of Energy (DOE) - Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos County electric utility was performed to determine the differential cost saving for diurnal load leveling by displacing one of several energy sources with energy stored from the Western Area Power Administration in a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit. The base case for the model for comparison is the best concept considered to date (the planned DOE/County power pool composed of a number of sources). Advantageous displacement costs appear available based upon a SMES unit rated at 144 MWh and 20 MW. The prospect of a prototype SMES plant to demonstrate the technology seems to be favorable.
Index Keywords: DISPLACEMENT COSTS; ELECTRIC UTILITY LOAD LEVELING; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: CLAMPED-VOLTAGE PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM SIMULATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Garrett Pneumatic Systems Div,, Phoenix, AZ, USA, Garrett Pneumatic Systems Div, Phoenix, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Facinelli, William A., Garrett Pneumatic Systems Div,, Phoenix, AZ, USA, Garrett Pneumatic Systems Div, Phoenix, AZ, USA
Abstract: Photovoltaic systems with electrical storage commonly have a 'clamped-voltage' configuration. In this arrangement, the photovoltaic array is in parallel with the battery, so that the array voltage cannot be independently varied to obtain its maximum possible output at all times. Results of computer simulations demonstrate the dependence of array output upon the series ratio (SR), the number of solar cells in series per battery cell in series. A clamped-voltage system with optimum series ratio (SR* ) will produce approximately 98% of the electrical output by the same size system operated in the max-power mode. The predicted dependence of monthly array output upon SR can be explained by considering the relationship of instantaneous solar cell output to voltage across the cell.
Index Keywords: CLAMPED-VOLTAGE PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS; MONTHLY ARRAY OUTPUT; SERIES RATIO; COMPUTER SIMULATION; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR CELLS - Applications; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA

Abstract: A solar powered space station based on a Brayton cycle is described. A key component is the thermal energy storage module, which is of crucial importance during periods of darkness. A computer program, FPAK1. F, simulating one possible storage design, is described.

Title: CORRELATED PROTON AND HEAVY ION UPSET MEASUREMENTS ON IDT STATIC RAMS.
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Campbell, A.B., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Stapor, W.J., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Koga, R., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Kolasinski, W.A., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Measurements of upset cross-sections and linear energy transfer thresholds have been made on two 16K CMOS/NMOS static RAMs, using both bulk process parts and radiation-hardened epitaxial process parts. Test beams include 62-MeV protons at 0 degrees produced at the University of California Davis cyclotron as well as beams of 140-MeV krypton, 178- MeV argon, 89-MeV neon, and 67-MeV nitrogen, at various incident angles from 0 to 70 degrees produced at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory 88-in. cyclotron. In conjunction with these measurements, a single-event latch-up threshold was obtained for the four types of devices.

Authors: Lau A.S., Beckman W.A., Mitchell J.W.
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF COMPUTERIZED CONTROL STRATEGIES FOR A LARGE CHILLED WATER PLANT.
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lau, A.S., Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA; Beckman, W.A., Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA; Mitchell, J.W., Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA
Abstract: A minicomputer monitoring and control system is part of the HVAC system of a 1. 4 million square foot commercial facility. The chiller system at the central plant consists of four 1250 ton centrifugal chillers, a six-cell cooling tower, five 100,000 gallon chilled water storage tanks, and associated pumps and piping. Computer models of the chilled water system were developed to study the energy conservation potential of control strategies intended for the minicomputer control system. Comparisons of modeled performance with measured data showed good agreement both at the component and system levels. Optimal control strategies for the number of chillers, cooling tower fan speeds, and condenser pump flow rates were developed. These resulted in an estimated combined savings of 4,400 a year. Demand limiting using the chilled water storage reduced annual peak demand by 161 kW and saved an additional 5,500. Reset of the chilled water set point saved an additional 4,400 for a total combined savings of 14,300.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Control; COMPUTERS, MINICOMPUTER; COOLING TOWERS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; CHILLER SYSTEM; HVAC SYSTEM; TRNSYS; BUILDINGS

Title: DYNAMIC UTILITY INTEGRATION OF NEW ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Southeastern Symposium on System Theory
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta,, GA, USA, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vachtsevanos, G.J., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta,, GA, USA, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA; Kalaitzakis, K.C., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta,, GA, USA, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA
Abstract: The authors introduce a new methodology for the dynamic integration of new energy technologies into the electric utility distribution network operations. Dispersed sources are viewed as active devices contributing to the regulation of real and reactive power flows while improving the stability of the power system. Conceptual means are developed for an effective DSG-utility grid interface. Computer models of appropriate interconnection and control equipment are used in simulation studies to test the effectiveness of control strategies and to optimize design parameters. Simulation results indicate that load frequency control and voltage regulation may effectively be accomplished with dispersed generators within a fraction of the time required for conventional regulating units. Appropriate modulation and conditioning of the DSG-output power can assist in damping out undesired power oscillations. Implementation of the proposed policies should reduce the load-following requirements for conventional power generating units, increase the value and acceptability of new energy technologies, and improve the power quality and stability of the interconnected system.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION - Control; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Interconnection; ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Energy Management; SYSTEM STABILITY; DISPERSED STORAGE AND GENERATION (DSG); DSG-OUTPUT POWER; ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES INTEGRATION; INTERCONNECTED SYSTEMS POWER STABILITY; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A LIGHTWEIGHT, LOW COST FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM FOR A REGENERATIVE BRAKING APPLICATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: British Petroleum Co, British Petroleum Co
Authors with affiliations: Medlicott, P.A.C., British Petroleum Co, British Petroleum Co
Abstract: The BP Kinetic Energy Storage System (KESS), designed to meet a regenerative braking requirements for passenger-carrying vehicles is described. Based on a high-speed composite flywheel, it represents a stand-alone, fully integrated system adaptable to meet a wide range of applications. Performance, safety, cost and reliability are discussed. Endurance and containment tests are described.
Index Keywords: LOW COSTS; PASSENGER-CARRYING VEHICLES; REGENERATIVE BRAKING; BRAKES - Energy Storage; FLYWHEELS

Title: DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT OF A HIGH EFFICIENCY EFFECTOR FOR THE CONTROL OF ATTITUDE AND POWER IN SPACE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA
Authors with affiliations: O'Dea, Stephen, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Burdick, Patricia, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Downer, James, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Eisenhaure, David, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Larkin, Laura, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA
Abstract: An advanced combined attitude, reference, and energy storage (CARES) effector used to perform spacecraft attitude control, attitude determination, and energy storage is described. Currently, these three functions are performed independently. The CARES system, in combining these three functions, offers hardware simplification as well as weight and life-cycle cost reductions. The CARES model consists of a flywheel and its attachment mechanism, a Lorentz-force magnetic suspension, and a high-efficiency motor/generator and its control electronics. The unique spherical design of the electromechanical components allows attitude control without mechanical gimbals. This system may be considered as a preprototype CARES system for a small satellite or a laboratory scale model of a space station system. Component development as well as system specifications and integration are described.
Index Keywords: ATTITUDE CONTROL; HIGH EFFICIENCY EFFECTORS; CONTROL, MECHANICAL VARIABLES - Position; ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEELS; SATELLITES

Title: ENERGY STORAGE AT HIGH SURFACE AREA CARBON ELECTRODES.
Affiliations: Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland,, OH, USA, Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Currie, J.C., Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland,, OH, USA, Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland, OH, USA; Boos, D.L., Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland,, OH, USA, Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland, OH, USA; Gaylor, V.F., Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland,, OH, USA, Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland, OH, USA; Bennett, P.D., Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland,, OH, USA, Standard Oil Co (Ohio), Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The charge stored in the electrical double-layer can be effectively transformed into a relatively high energy density device by utilizing high surface area electrodes. The 'double-layer capacitor' (DLC) is characterized by large capacitance per unit volume, almost unlimited cycle and shelf life and inexpensive and simple cell design. High surface area electrodes fabricated with activated carbon of suitable surface properties and pore geometry are capable of providing capacitance values of approximately 100 farads per gram of carbon. In this paper the basic concepts, performance characteristics, material selection and application of double-layer capacitors are described.
Index Keywords: CARBON - Electrodes; FUEL CELLS - Electrolytes; CAPACITANCE; DOUBLE LAYER CAPACITOR; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; HIGH SURFACE AREA CARBON ELECTRODES; CAPACITORS

Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF SOLAR HEAT PUMP SYSTEM WITH REFRIGERANT FILLED SOLAR COLLECTOR.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Matsuki, Kenji, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn; Yoshikawa, Masaharu, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn; Shinobu, Yoshiharu, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn; Yanagisawa, Nobuhiro, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn; Yamaguchi, Hiroshi, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn, Sharp Corp, Nara, Jpn
Abstract: The results of an experimental study for evaluating the performance of a solar heat pump system for domestic water heating are discussed. The system consists of a refrigerant-filled bare solar collector (as an evaporator), a variable capacity compressor, a double wall copper tube heat exchanger (as a condenser) and a thermal storage tank. A series of indoor experiments with a solar simulator in an environmental chamber were conducted to determine the effects of insulation, ambient temperature, humidity, wind velocity, and water temperature in the condenser on the collector and system performance. The results show that a collector efficiency above 1. 0 is possible and that under moderate climates the system can heat water to 55 degree C with a coefficient of performance of 3. 5-4. 0 almost all the year round.
Index Keywords: RESIDENTIAL WATER HEATING; SOLAR COLLECTOR PERFORMANCE; SOLAR HEAT PUMP SYSTEM; SOLAR HOT WATER SYSTEM; HEAT EXCHANGERS; REFRIGERANTS - Applications; SOLAR ENERGY - Collectors; WATER - Heating; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Downer James, Eisenhaure David, Hockney Richard, Johnson Bruce, O'Dea Stephen
Title: MAGNETIC SUSPENSION DESIGN OPTIONS FOR SATELLITE ATTITUDE CONTROL AND ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA
Authors with affiliations: Downer, James, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Eisenhaure, David, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Hockney, Richard, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; Johnson, Bruce, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA; O'Dea, Stephen, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, USA
Abstract: A suspension system in which magnetic actuators are used to simultaneously support and gimbal a flywheel rotor is described. The use of a large-angle magnetic suspension (LAMS) system enables an array of flywheels to provide the functions of energy storage and attitude control in a low-earth-orbiting (LEO) satellite. The current state of the art in magnetic suspension technology is examined and candidate LAMS systems are identified. Parametric studies show that a LAMS that uses the Lorentz force is a viable alternative to suspensions that operate via the attraction of ferromagnetic bodies when gimbaling requirements are small ( greater than 10 degree ). When the gimbaling requirement is increased (10-15 degree ), a Lorentz-force LAMS shows distinct advantages in terms of reduced mass and power consumption.
Index Keywords: ATTITUDE CONTROL; MAGNETIC ACTUATORS; MAGNETIC SUSENSION; CONTROL, MECHANICAL VARIABLES - Position; ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEELS; SATELLITES

Title: POWER MANAGEMENT OF GRID-CONNECTED WIND GENERATOR CLUSTERS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Democritus Univ of Thrace, Sch of, Engineering, Xanthi, Greece, Democritus Univ of Thrace, Sch of Engineering, Xanthi, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Kalaitzakis, K.C., Democritus Univ of Thrace, Sch of, Engineering, Xanthi, Greece, Democritus Univ of Thrace, Sch of Engineering, Xanthi, Greece; Vachtsevanos, G.J., Democritus Univ of Thrace, Sch of, Engineering, Xanthi, Greece, Democritus Univ of Thrace, Sch of Engineering, Xanthi, Greece
Abstract: This paper introduces a new methodology for the real and reactive power control, stability and coordination of a power system penetrated by a cluster of wind energy conversion devices. The proposed methodology is based upon the utilization of an appropriate voltage-fed, self-commutated dc to ac inverter with a capability of transferring variable amounts of real and reactive power from the inverter to the utility bus. An optimized storage facility provides necessary buffering and reserve power capabilities for the successful operation of the control mechanism. The paper develops appropriate models for the interconnected operation of wind generator clusters with an autonomous power system.

Abstract: An analysis of low-earth-orbit laboratory test data on a 6. 5 ampere-hour bipolar nickel hydrogen battery designed and built at the NASA Lewis Research Center is presented. During the past several years, the Storage and Thermal Branch has been deeply involved in the design, development, and optimization of nickel hydrogen devices. The bipolar concept is a means of achieving the goal of producing an acceptable battery of higher energy density that is able to withstand the demands of low-earth-orbit regimes. Watt-hour efficiencies in the 75% range have been demonstrated.

Abstract: Thermally powered, fully implantable artificial heart power sources have been under continuous development since 1967. The University of Washington/Joint Center for Graduate Study has recently tested a prototype of their eighth generation hardware (System 8). System 8 is designed to satisfy the primary objective of a biologically compatible and physiologically effective power source with a ten-year, maintenance-free operating life. First use in humans is anticipated about 1990, following extensive preclinical qualification testing. System 8 incorporates technology proven in earlier systems, but adds significant enhancements including 8 hours of operation on internal thermal energy storage after a 1-hour transcutaneous transformer recharge.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL HEARTS; IMPLANTABLE STIRLING ENGINE; PROSTHETICS - Energy Resources; BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING

Title: HIGH-VOLTAGE, HIGH-POWER ARCHITECTURE CONSIDERATIONS.

Affiliations: Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Moser, R.L., Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, CO, USA
Abstract: Three basic EPS architectures, namely direct energy transfer, peak-power tracking, and a potential EPS architecture for a nuclear reactor, are described and compared. Considerations for the power source and energy storage are discussed. Factors to be considered in selecting the operating voltage are pointed out. Other EPS architecture considerations are autonomy, solar array degrees of freedom, and EPS modularity. It is concluded that selection of the power source and energy storage has major impacts on the spacecraft architecture and mass.
Index Keywords: EPS ARCHITECTURE; SPACECRAFT ARCHITECTURE; ENERGY RESOURCES - Space Applications; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: ENERGY STORAGE MATERIALS FOR SOLAR DYNAMIC SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Boretz, John E., TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: Potential candidate energy conversion cycles for solar dynamic space power systems are ORCEPS (organic Rankine cycle electric power system), Brayton, and Stirling. These are characterized by various peak cycle temperatures and working fluids. Hence, the selection of the energy storage materials (ESM) must be compatible with their peak cycle temperatures and heat transfer characteristics. The impact that these materials have on the overall weight and volume of the energy storage subsystem is discussed for space power systems in the 20 to 140 kWe range.
Index Keywords: SOLAR DYNAMIC SYSTEMS; SPACE POWER; ENERGY STORAGE - Materials; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Abstract: Energy demand has ever been rising, and the safety of storage vessels and the quality of steels used for these have come to be more important. Presented in this paper are, the trends in the quality requirements of steels, specifically for LPG and LNG storage vessels, and recent developments and improvements of these steels in response to these requirements.

Title: PRODUCTION OF ICE WITH LONG-TERM STORAGE.
Affiliations: Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Francis, C.Edward, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA
Abstract: The cold air of winter is used for producing relatively large amounts of ice in long-term underground storage. The stored cooling capacity of the ice is recovered during the following summer. Initial research indicates that in regions where the winter is sufficiently cold and of sufficient duration, this type of system could provide summer air conditioning, refrigeration, or process cooling. The water-saturated earth storage mass of 4000 ft**3 (113 m**3) was frozen with 1013 hours of system operation between the dates of November 17, 1983, and March 6, 1984. During midsummer 1984, the cooling recovery operation ran for a total of 32 days. During this period, 743 ton-hours of cooling or 8,921,856 Btu (2613 kWh) were recovered with an estimated 5% to 8% of the stored cooling capacity remaining. However, all of the ice had been melted. Approximately 52% of the stored energy had been recovered, indicating a probable 45% to 50% loss to the surrounding earth.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; ICE - Storage; PIPE, PLASTIC; POLYETHYLENES - Applications; SOILS - Frozen; FARENHEIT FREEZING DEGREE HOURS; PROPYLENE GLYCOL-WATER MIXTURE; SOIL'S VOID SPACE; WATER-SATURATED EARTH MASS; COLD STORAGE

Title: WIND ENERGY AND RESIDENTIAL ELECTRICITY USE: THE EXPERIMENTAL PROJECT 'CAMPERDUIN'.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Univ of Amsterdam, Interfaculty Dep, of Environmental Science, Amsterdam,, Neth, Univ of Amsterdam, Interfaculty Dep of Environmental Science, Amsterdam, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Wolsink, M., Univ of Amsterdam, Interfaculty Dep, of Environmental Science, Amsterdam,, Neth, Univ of Amsterdam, Interfaculty Dep of Environmental Science, Amsterdam, Neth; Westra, C.A., Univ of Amsterdam, Interfaculty Dep, of Environmental Science, Amsterdam,, Neth, Univ of Amsterdam, Interfaculty Dep of Environmental Science, Amsterdam, Neth
Abstract: In March 1983 the test-project in Camperduin was started within the framework of the Netherlands Programme on Wind Energy. Two turbines are producing electricity for a group of 28 houses. All electricity is supplied for residential use without storage. Part of the project is a study on the amount of immediate utilization of wind energy; a system of price incentives; a form of voluntary load control. Problems related to the justification of tariff-switches and the optimalization of managing the load are being discussed. In order to study the potential possibilities of utilization (delivery factor) and self-supply, an extensive measurement programme was set up. All individual residential uses, wind-supply, grid-supply etc. are measured. Social research is part of the study.
Index Keywords: WIND POWER - Applications; PRICE INCENTIVES; RESIDENTIAL ELECTRICITY; VOLUNTARY LOAD CONTROL; WIND ENERGY; HOUSES

Authors: Schmidt H.J., Scott M.H., Dicks J.B.
Title: HISTORY AND FUTURE OF LIGHT WEIGHT MHD POWER SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA, Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, H.J., Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA, Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA; Scott, M.H., Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA, Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA; Dicks, J.B., Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA, Univ of Tennessee Space Inst, USA
Abstract: For short-duration, high-power-production applications, compact magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) generator systems using explosive or combustion-driven plasmas are unsurpassed in performance potential. They possess superior power density characteristics, a rapid start-up and a long shelf life. The history and development of pulse power MHD systems is reviewed and their future potential is assessed on the basis of their proven past coupled with the more recent developments in plasma production and magnet self-excitation. Packaged MHD systems are a viable electrical energy source in the multimegawatt power range for durations up to a minute. For many specific applications, however, power conditioning or storage will be required to load-match with MHD generators which are inherently high-impedance energy sources in the most efficient two-terminal configuration.
Index Keywords: HISTORY AND FUTURE; MHD POWER SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS; MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMICS

Authors: Kirk James A., Anand Davinder K., Khan Asad A.
Title: ROTOR STRESSES IN A MAGNETICALLY SUSPENDED FLYWHEEL SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, James A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA; Anand, Davinder K., Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA; Khan, Asad A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: For spacecraft applications a magnetically suspended multiring flywheel offers significant advantages in specific energy density (SED) compared to electrochemical systems. To realize these advantages the high specific strengths of filament-wound composite materials will be required. To overcome the limited radial tensile strength of composite materials an interference assembly of nested rings is proposed. A complete stress analysis of a multiring/multimaterial flywheel is discussed and it is shown that the SED of a given geometry can be increased by a fact of 2 or more through interference assembly. It is also shown that the radial stresses can be redistributed with interference assembly so that the outer flywheel rings will separate at their interfaces if a given flywheel speed is exceeded. Proper use of this condition will minimize containment weight requirements for the system.
Index Keywords: MULTIRING FLYWHEELS; ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEELS; ROTORS - Stresses; SPACECRAFT

Authors: Pickel James C., Blandford Jr. James T., Waskiewicz A.E., Strahan Jr. V.H.

Authors with affiliations: Pickel, James C., IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA, IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA; Blandford Jr., James T., IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA, IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA; Waskiewicz, A.E., IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA, IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA; Strahan Jr., V.H., IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA, IRT Corp, Placentia, CA, USA
Abstract: Heavy-ion-induced permanent damage in MNOS gate insulators has been investigated using a Cf**2**5**2 fission source. The electric field and ion linear energy transfer thresholds for onset of the damage has been characterized. The results are consistent with a thermal runaway mechanism in the silicon nitride layer initiated by a single heavy ion and leading to a permanent high conductivity path through the dielectric layers.

Title: SECOND LAW ANALYSIS OF A THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM WITH JOULEAN HEATING OF THE STORAGE ELEMENT.
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical, & Aerospace Engineering,, Knoxville, TN, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Knoxville, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Krane, Robert J., Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical, & Aerospace Engineering,, Knoxville, TN, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Dep of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Knoxville, TN, USA
Abstract: The techniques of Second Law analysis are applied to the optimal design of a thermal energy storage system with Joulean heaters. The resulting model accounts for three major sources of entropy generation: (1) Joulean heating, (2) heat transfer through finite temperature differences between the gas in the heat exchanger duct and the storage element, and (3) viscous losses in the heat exchanger duct. The model is used in conjunction with an optimization program to perform a parametric study for ranges of the independent variables which include most systems of practical interest. The results of this study indicate that the systems examined destroy approximately 60 to 80 percent of the entering availability. Thus, the thermodynamic efficiency of a thermal energy storage system with Joulean heating of the storge element is extremely low.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRICALLY-HEATED THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; ENTROPY GENERATION SOURCES; OPTIMIZATION PROGRAM; PREVIOUS SECOND LAW ANALYSES; REMOVAL PROCESS ANALYSIS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES) THERMODYNAMIC EFFICIENCY; THERMODYNAMICS

Affiliations: Universal Energy Systems Inc,, Dayton, OH, USA, Universal Energy Systems Inc, Dayton, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ponnappan, R., Universal Energy Systems Inc,, Dayton, OH, USA, Universal Energy Systems Inc, Dayton, OH, USA; Beam, J.E., Universal Energy Systems Inc,, Dayton, OH, USA, Universal Energy Systems Inc, Dayton, OH, USA; Van Griethuysen, V.J., Universal Energy Systems Inc,, Dayton, OH, USA, Universal Energy Systems Inc, Dayton, OH, USA; Mahefky, E.T., Universal Energy Systems Inc,, Dayton, OH, USA, Universal Energy Systems Inc, Dayton, OH, USA
Abstract: Thermal Energy Storage (TES) using phase-change materials (PCM) is an attractive concept in the 1000 K regime. Heat transfer and corrosion characteristics of fluoride salts are described. TES samples prepared in an inert gas environment reveal no significant salt-clad corrosion during steady-state tests of 10,000 hours, whereas vacuum thermal cycling tests show complete corrosive attack of the container after only 200 hours of cyclic operation. The causes of the failure are believed to be calcium impurities in the salt, pin holes in the grains of the as-received Inconel bar stock, and fabrication of samples in an oxygen environment. Processing of pure TES samples under controlled conditions, vacuum thermal cycling tests, and the method of casting 100% solid slugs is explained.
Index Keywords: FLUORIDE SALTS; PHASE-CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER

Abstract: Records indicate that the College Park thermal storage system has paid for itself in less than five years. A major share of the savings has come from waste heat reclaim, and some lessons in operation have been learned as well.

Authors with affiliations: Arnold, G.W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Cantilever beam measurements of induced lateral stress have been made for He, Xe and Pb ion-implantation into the complex borosilicate radioactive waste glasses (PNL 76-68, SRP), a commercial borosilicate (Pyrex), and into fused SiO//2 (Suprasil 1). It is suggested that the B//2O//3 phase may be more easily compacted than the SiO//2 phase. The evidently greater effectiveness of the ionization component of the ion energy in creating damage in borosilicate glasses should be of considerable interest in waste glass studies.
Index Keywords: GLASS - Radiation Damage; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; BOROSILICATE GLASS; ION IMPLANTATION DAMAGE; NUCLEAR WASTE GLASS; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Authors with affiliations: Schoch, K.F., GE, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Schenectady, NY, USA
Abstract: Since 1981 the literature relating to the storage and transfer of cryogenic fluids has focused increasing attention on two applications. These are applications involving large superconducting magnets and long flight-time experiments in space. Large containment vessel designs for bulk storage of LNG continue to be examined, in addition to methods of transfer of these fluids to avoid 'roll-over' behavior and to assure better fire safety. Hydrogen-fueled vehicle application studies are also described. Recent literature also includes results of research on heat transfer of thermal insulations. This includes foams and multilayer types of insulation as well as discussion of thermal radiation shielding and fabrication and measurement of low emittance surfaces. References on vacuum-sealing techniques for cryogenic vessels as well as leak detection methods are included.

Abstract: Ice-making thermal storage is among many economic elements incorporated in the air-conditioning/heating system of the two-million square foot complex. A most important criterion for HVAC loads is a watts per square foot allowance for such appliances as distributed computer terminals, word processors, etc. This, together with lighting loads, comprises a substantial part of the cooling system load. The building design decisions arose from a number of comprehensive studies and reports prepared by various members of the design team. Many of the studies included the use of the computerized annual energy program, DOE 2. 1, as well as the principals of value engineering and life-cycle costing.

Authors with affiliations: Giron de la Pena, Hector, Ecosfera, Mexico City, Mex, Ecosfera, Mexico City, Mex
Abstract: An energy efficient residence research and demonstration program is being conducted by the Ecosfera Foundation, showing how energy use can be reduced by using passive air systems for space heating and a solar roofing system for water heating and giving the possibility of a high level of self-sufficiency in performance and maintenance. The demonstration residence shows the design concept of an envelope design with a passive convective air flow for space heating and a solar roofing system with a convective water flow of a low-cost solar collector for domestic water heating. The residence includes a greenhouse space for heat-gain and storage together with a food production facility. It incorporates and combines different passive systems in an overall system that acts like an envelope.

Abstract: This paper examines today's thermal storage issues. High cost and safety risks associated with advanced heat storage systems have created some market resistance to new products. Masonry type heat storage materials are not more widely used due to perceived technical, cost and labor barriers. Recent evidence suggests technical difficulties are being overcome, but technology utilization may be retarded by lack of market 'pull. '
