Title: CROSSATRON MODULATOR SWITCH: AN EFFICIENT, LONG-LIFE COMPONENT FOR PULSED-POWER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA, Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schumacher, R.W., Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA, Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA; Harvey, R.J., Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA, Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Abstract: The Crossatron modulator switch (CMS) is shown to be an efficient, long-life switch component for pulsed-power systems such as line-type modulators, inductive-energy-storage (IES) circuits, hard-tube modulators, and command-charging circuits. Efforts are being made to develop the CMS device into a product (e. g. , packaging, reliability, determination of useful life). A vacuum-sealed, prototype switch has demonstrated greater than 10**9 shots without failure. Experimental CMS devices have also been developed for demonstrating high-power, command-charging service (5-MW average, 100 kV, less than equivalent to 10-ms pulse length) and for demonstrating fast recovery, thyratron-replacement service in line-type modulators.

Authors: Converse James C., Holmes Brian J.
Title: NUTRIENT RETENTION, ENERGY, AND LABOR REQUIREMENTS FOR ABOVE-GROUND MANURE STORAGES.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Converse, James C., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA; Holmes, Brian J., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: Two bottom loading above-ground dairy manure storage systems were evaluated for nutrient retention, energy inputs and labor requirements. One farm consisted of a 58 cow stall barn and bull barn and the other farm consisted of a 108 cow solid floor free stall barn with a milking parlor. Fixed solids recovery ranged from 93. 6 to 99. 8%, indicating good accountability. Nutrient retention for TN, TP and K for all periods and both farms averaged 100%, 101% and 102% respectively, indicating that essentially no nutrients were lost during the storage period. Ammonium increased an average of 30% while in storage, with a higher percent in the summer and less in the winter. Energy input to collect, agitate and pump the manure to storage ranged from 14 to 30. 1 kWh/d. Approximately 83% of the larger value went for gasoline to scrape the free stall. All other energy uses were electric. It took approximately one man-hour/cow-year to haul and inject the manure for the 108 cow herd.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING; DAIRIES; MATERIALS HANDLING - Energy Utilization; ABOVE-GROUND MANURE STORAGES; DAIRY MANURE; LABOR REQUIREMENTS; NUTRIENT RETENTION; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Abstract: The paper presents a review of current solar energy storage systems, It covers sensible heat storage, phase change storage, chemical storage and other less common forms of storage systems. Short and long term storage is also discussed with some economic assessment as well as the advantages of using an appropriate solar energy storage system.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; CHEMICAL STORAGE; LONG TERM; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE; SHORT TERM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: ELASTIC SCATTERING AND TOTAL CROSS SECTION AT VERY HIGH ENERGIES.
Source title: Annual Review of Nuclear and Particle Science
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy, Istituto Nazionale Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Castaldi, Rino, Istituto Nazionale Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy, Istituto Nazionale Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy; Sanguinetti, Giulio, Istituto Nazionale Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy, Istituto Nazionale Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy
Abstract: The aim of this review is to summarize the recent progress in the field of elastic scattering and total cross section in this new energy domain. A survey of the experimental situation is outlined. Hadron scattering at high energy is described in an impact parameter picture, which provides a model-independent intuitive geometrical representation. The diffractive character of elastic scattering, seen as the shadow of inelastic absorption, is presented as a consequence of unitarity in the s-channel. Some relevant theorems are recalled on the limiting behavior of hadron-scattering amplitudes at infinite energy. There is also a brief discussion on how asymptotically rising total cross sections imply scaling properties in the elastic differential cross sections. A quick survey of eikonal models is presented and their predictions are compared with Intersecting Storage Rings and Super Proton Synchrotron Collider data.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Colliding Beam; EIKONAL MODELS; ELASTIC SCATTERING; HADRONS; SUPER PROTON SYNCHROTRON COLLIDER; TOTAL CROSS SECTION; PHYSICS

Authors: Shannon J., Wilkinson M., Miller R., Cole O.
Title: MODULAR INDUCTIVE STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA, Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Shannon, J., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA, Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Wilkinson, M., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA, Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Miller, R., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA, Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Cole, O., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA, Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: A modular inductive-energy storage (IES) system is described that is being developed to test fast-vacuum-opening switches. Since the facility is for testing fast-switch and imploding-plasma-load concepts it is designed to minimize shot-turnaround time. A modular design allows better access to the fuse region and makes containment of fuse debris and shock easier. The mechanical and electrical designs of the module are presented and preliminary performance is discussed.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES - Inductance; ELECTRIC SWITCHES; FAST-VACUUM-OPENING SWITCHES; IMPLODING-PLASMA-LOAD CONCEPTS; INDUCTIVE-ENERGY STORAGE (IES) SYSTEM; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: ELECTRIC UTILITY LOAD FACTOR IMPROVEMENT WITH SOLAR HOMES.
Affiliations: Energy Control Systems, Raleigh, NC,, USA, Energy Control Systems, Raleigh, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reeves, G.George, Energy Control Systems, Raleigh, NC,, USA, Energy Control Systems, Raleigh, NC, USA
Abstract: Space heating and cooling presents the electric utility system with large peak loads that are served only on extreme weather days. Passive solar homes with their larger glass areas and thermal mass can present larger peaks than conventional homes of the same size. Solar homes with active air collectors usually include rock storage bins, which exhibit temperature stratification and no heat exchanger penalty. Calculations and performance results are presented to show how these bins permit backup thermal energy to be stored off-peak for use during on-peak times. A utility program to encourage low peak load homes is suggested.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Applications; HEATING - Solar; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; ELECTRIC UTILITY LOAD FACTOR IMPROVEMENT; HYBRID SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS; SOLAR HOMES; SPACE HEATING AND COOLING; HOUSES

Title: MAGNETIC PRESSURE VARIATION IN COAXIAL PLASMA EXPERIMENTS WITH LOW INDUCTANCE DRIVERS.
Affiliations: Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Saghir, M.Z., Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Gupta, R.P., Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: The authors have investigated the azimuthal symmetry of the magnetic pressure in Z-pinches and other coaxial plasma loads connected to low-inductance drivers with one, two, and four striplines. They have used a commercial 3-D finite-element package NISA for the purpose. It was found that in the transient, non-diffusive magnetic field approximation, the magnetic pressure asymmetry is large enough to adversely affect the plasma pinching.

Authors: Kim S.H., McKinley M.C., Chen K.W.
Title: HYBRID CIRCUIT SYSTEM ANALYSIS FOR THE GENERATION OF A FAST-RISING PINCHING MAGNETIC FIELD.
Affiliations: Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kim, S.H., Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA; McKinley, M.C., Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA; Chen, K.W., Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Arlington, TX, USA
Abstract: The fast-rising, high-voltage pulse generation circuit system of a theta pinch is theoretically analyzed. The idealized model of this circuit system is a hybrid circuit system composed of three parts: a lumped-circuit part consisting of a capacitor bank and a spark switch connected in series, another lumped-circuit part consisting only of a single-turn pinch coil, and a distributed-circuit part consisting of the Blumlein transmission line. The voltage difference between two ends of the pinch coil is formulated by analyzing this hybrid system by means of the law of the signal propagation in the transmission line and Kirchhoff's law. An expedient numerical method for computer calculation is developed to generate the pulse profile of the voltage difference across the pinch coil.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY - Mathematical Models; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, PULSE SHAPING; FAST RISING PULSE GENERATION; HYBRID CIRCUIT SYSTEM ANALYSIS; THETA PINCH; PLASMA DEVICES

Title: EXTERNAL CONTROL OF DIFFUSE DISCHARGE SWITCHES.
Affiliations: Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schaefer, G., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Schoenbach, K.H., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Abstract: Electron-beam-sustained diffuse discharges have attracted considerable interest as submicrosecond opening switches for inductive energy storage systesm. Opening is accomplished through turning off the ionizing e-beam. To increase the switch efficiency (switch current/e-beam current) at high holdoff voltages and to reduce the opening time, attachers are used with a high attachment rate at high values of reduced field strength (E/N) and a low attachment rate at low values of E/N. These attachers will decrease the net source term and will obstruct the closing phase. Additional control through photodetachment and optically enhanced attachment will also allow the closing phase to be optimized. The results of model calculations and experimental studies on various control mechanisms are discussed.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRON BEAMS - Applications; DIFFUSE DISCHARGE SWITCH; ELECTRON BEAM CONTROL; ELECTRIC SWITCHES

Authors: Cooper J.R., Schoenbach K., Schaefer G., Byszewski W.W., Proud J.M.
Title: MAGNETICALLY CONTROLLED DISCHARGES FOR SWITCHING APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, J.R., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Schoenbach, K., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Schaefer, G., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Byszewski, W.W., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Proud, J.M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Abstract: External control of diffuse discharges has been suggested as a means of producing a fast opening switch for inductive energy storage. One potential control mechanism is the application of a crossed magnetic field to a low-pressure discharge operated on the right hand side of the Pashen minimum. The effect of the magnetic field is to alter the characteristics of the discharge from a positive column-dominated to an electrode-dominated discharge with lower electron generation. This discharge control mechanism is theoretically investigated by means of computer modeling. The results of these calculations show a strong increase in discharge resistivity with the application of crossed magnetic fields in attaching gas mixtures. The results of experiments performed to test this concept show good agreement with the computational results.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC SWITCHES; DIFFUSE DISCHARGES; INDUCTIVE ENERGY STORAGE; OPENING SWITCHES; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES

Authors: Johnson D.E., Barber J.P., Laquer H.L.
Title: MAPPS - A MEGAMPERE PULSED POWER SUPPLY.
Affiliations: IAP Research Inc, Dayton, OH, USA, IAP Research Inc, Dayton, OH, USA

Abstract: The authors have demonstrated a pulse transformer/energy storage concept which combines the good features of cryogenic and superconducting stores with the high-current output of normal inductors. They have completed the design of a demonstrator that is being fabricated and tested in 1986. The demonstrator delivers 20-kJ pulses at 100 kA and 5 Hz to a railgun-type load. The authors also present the important design relationships for the highly-coupled, air-core transformer, and the vacuum interrupter-based opening switch.

Abstract: Results are reported for testing of 'solar photovoltaic station-storage battery-solar stand' and 'solar photovoltaic station, wind-energy unit-storage battery-solar stand' systems.

Authors: Somogyi G., Toth-Szilagyi M., Hunyadi I., Hafez Abdel-Fattah
Title: EFFECT OF CERTAIN PRODUCTION PARAMETERS AND POST-PRODUCTION TREATMENTS ON THE ETCHING CHARACTERISTICS OF CR-39 SHEETS.

Abstract: There is a permanent need in producing track recording detectors of well defined behavior from CR-39 monomer. Therefore, more studies on the role of production parameters determining the stability of main etching characteristics (bulk etch rate, v//B; etch rate ratio, v//T/v//B; opaqueness after longer etching periods) are highly required. In our studies we have examined different commercial CR-39 sheets (Homalite, Pershore, MA-ND) to compare their registration sensitivity to selected alpha and proton energies. In addition, we have investigated the main etching parameters of CR-39 sheets manufactured under different casting conditions varying the concentration of IPP initiator and certain additives (DOP, HCB). Finally, the effect of some post-production treatments, annealing and storage in vacuum, on the V//B and V//T/V//B values is studied.

Abstract: MJB, a multimegamp fast-capacitor bank is described for use in the development of high-power vacuum opening switches. MJB stores one MJ, operates at 100 kV, and delivers 7 MA to a 6-nH load. MJB is designed to investigate the energy scaling of opening switches, and to collect engineering data on fast capacitor bank operation, bank closing switches, vacuum insulators, and diagnostics. The design of MJB is described, data from electrical checkout of its performance is presented, and opening switch experiments are discussed.

Authors: Kurochkin A.K., Leper D.P., Chuchukin G.V.
Title: USE OF INDUCTIVE ENERGY STORES IN SYNTHETIC TEST CIRCUITS FOR A. C. BREAKERS.
Authors with affiliations: Kurochkin, A.K.; Leper, D.P.; Chuchukin, G.V.
Abstract: The parameters of a scheme for a definite type of inductive store are estimated. Test results verify linear decrease of the current to zero in a scheme simulating one proposed with an inductive energy store. It is expected power station generator breakers with rated trip current up to 250-300 kA will eventually need to be tested and investigated.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INDUCTORS, POWER TYPE - Energy Storage; AC BREAKERS; INDUCTIVE ENERGY STORE; PATENTED CIRCUIT; SYNTHETIC TEST CIRCUIT; ELECTRIC CIRCUIT BREAKERS

Title: MARX GENERATOR ENGINEERING AND ASSEMBLY LINE TECHNOLOGY FOR THE PBFA II ACCELERATOR.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Woolston, T.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Ives, H.C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The energy storage section of the Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator II (PBFA II) requires 36 Marx generators. The Marx generator was designed to minimize the total number and types of parts in order to speed the assembly process and maintain simplicity. Some mechanical highlights include a shorting system, a quick-connect spark gap fitting (using unmodified existing spark gaps), and an arrangement allowing insertion and removal of the Marx from a filled oil tank. A rapid-assembly system for the Marx generators was also designed and consists of a trolley system; an industrial manipulator; and a gantry crane. Three persons can safely assemble at least two Marxes per week using the equipment. The system also will be used to expedite disassembly required for routine maintenance.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; PULSE GENERATORS; MARX GENERATORS; PBFA II; ACCELERATORS

Title: PRACTICAL DEVELOPMENTS IN COMMERCIAL VEHICLE CVT'S & REGENERATIVE BRAKING SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Leyland Vehicles Ltd, Engl, Leyland Vehicles Ltd, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Flinn, P., Leyland Vehicles Ltd, Engl, Leyland Vehicles Ltd, Engl
Abstract: Engineers have struggled for nearly a century to develop an effective mechanical continuously variable transmission. The purpose of this paper is to go beyond the present level of public knowledge and to describe its extension into the field of energy storage - regenerative braking systems. This essential rationale for CVTs in commercial vehicles is the improvement of fuel economy. This is achieved by providing a transmission which allows the engine always to operate at its most efficient for the power demanded by the driver. The savings achieved depend very much on the mode of operation of the vehicle and could be as little as a few percent or as much as 25%. As a general rule, the greater the proportion of time the vehicle spends at low power and high rotational speeds, the greater will be the fuel saving.
Index Keywords: BRAKES - Design; CONTROL SYSTEMS; ENERGY STORAGE; RELIABILITY; COMMERCIAL VEHICLES; CONTINUOUSLY VARIABLE TRANSMISSION; REGENERATIVE BRAKING SYSTEMS; TRANSMISSION CONTROL SYSTEM; VEHICLES

Title: ENERGY STORAGE DEVICES BASED ON FLYWHEELS.
Affiliations: BP Research Cent, Sundry, Engl, BP Research Cent, Sundry, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Mayer, R.M., BP Research Cent, Sundry, Engl, BP Research Cent, Sundry, Engl; Duff-Barclay, I., BP Research Cent, Sundry, Engl, BP Research Cent, Sundry, Engl
Abstract: Much has already been achieved in improving the fuel economy of the heavier range of road transport vehicles. However, further significant improvements should still be possible by employing regenerative braking systems, which involve the transfer of the kinetic energy of the vehicle, normally dissipated as heat through the brakes, to some form of energy storage device. The stored energy is then used to restart the vehicle. One such device is that based on the use of a flywheel. This enables the kinetic energy of a vehicle to be transferred to inertial energy and vice-versa thereby offering the potential for savings in fuel, reduction in exhaust pollution and engine noise and optimisation of the drive-line. This paper describes such an energy storage device which has been designed and developed at the BP Research Centre, Sunbury-on-Thames and is designated KESS - Kinetic Energy Storage System. The device is compact and lightweight and makes extensive use of composite materials. It possesses high power density, provides good reliability and requires low maintenance. The manufacturing methods are amenable for volume production. Brief aspects of the design, manufacture and testing of the system are given together with general comments on its performance characteristics.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE DEVICES; ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM DESIGN; FABRICATION METHODS; SPECIFICATIONS; FLYWHEELS

Authors: Smy P.R., Santiago J., Way-Nee D.
Title: Momentum imparted by plasma igniters to the surrounding gas
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Dept. of Electr. Eng., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, Alta., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Smy, P.R., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, Alta., Canada; Santiago, J., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, Alta., Canada; Way-Nee, D., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, Alta., Canada
Abstract: It is expected that the momentum transfer from a plasma igniter to the surrounding gas plays a critical part in determining the subsequent combustion process. The momentum imparted by several types of plasma plug igniter has been measured by mounting each igniter in a simple pendulum and recording the steady state amplitude attained when the igniter is energised in sychronism with the swings of the pendulum. This technique, being far more sensitive than the previous single-shot method, allows relatively fine comparisons to be made between different types of igniter. The individual momentum measurements lie reasonably close to a theoretical limit based on the conversion of the translational energy of the Joule heated gas within the cavity to kinetic energy. On this basis it seems unlikely that substantial increases in imparted momentum can be expected from plug redesign etc. A separate series of measurements with energy storage at capacitor voltages of 5-20 kV instead of the usual range of 0.3-1 kV reveals that the imparted momentum decreases by less than 30%. Since recent measurements have demonstrated that the marginal igniter lifetime can be substantially extended by working at such high voltages, the above small decrease encourages the view that high voltage operation may be a desirable option.
Index Keywords: COMBUSTION; GASES; PLASMA IGNITERS; PLASMA DEVICES

Title: Magnetically induced pulser laser excitation
Affiliations: National Research Council of Canada, Division of Physics, Ottawa, Ont. K1A OR6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, R.S., National Research Council of Canada, Division of Physics, Ottawa, Ont. K1A OR6, Canada; Leopold, K.E., National Research Council of Canada, Division of Physics, Ottawa, Ont. K1A OR6, Canada
Abstract: A novel excitation scheme has been developed for excimer discharge lasers. The technique uses pulse transformer technology to induce a fast, high voltage pulse directly onto a ground potential laser electrode resulting in the breakdown of the laser gas mix. Saturation of the pulse transformer core inductance then permits efficient energy transfer from the main energy storage circuit into the discharge. When this excitation technique was used in a XeCl laser an output energy density of 2.5 J/l and an overall electrical to optical efficiency of 2% were obtained. The technique appears promising for the development of high energy, high average power excimer lasers.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC TRANSFORMERS, PULSE - Manufacture; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, PULSE SHAPING; MAGNETIC CORES; EXCIMER DISCHARGE LASERS; METAL ALLOY RIBBONS; PULSAR CIRCUIT; PULSE TRANSFORMER TECHNOLOGY; LASERS, GAS

Title: Electron transport in green photosynthetic bacteria
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Amherst, Amherst College, Amherst, 01002, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blankenship, R.E., Department of Chemistry, Amherst, Amherst College, Amherst, 01002, MA, United States
Abstract: Green bacteria make up two of the four families of anoxygenic photosynthetic prokaryotes. The two families have similar pigment compositions and membrane fine structure, and both contain a specialized antenna structure known as a chlorosome. The primary photochemistry and electron transport pathways of the two groups are, however, quite distinct. The anaerobic green bacteria (Chlorobiaceae) contain low-potential iron-sulfur proteins as early electron acceptors and can directly reduce NAD+ in a manner reminiscent of Photosystem I of oxygenic organisms. The facultatively aerobic green bacteria (Chloroflexaceae) contain quinone-type acceptors and have an overall pattern of electron transport very similar to that found in purple bacteria. Many aspects of energy storage in green bacteria, especially photophosphorylation and the role of cytochrome b/c complexes in electron transport, remain poorly understood. © 1985 Martinus Nijhoff/Dr W. Junk Publishers.
Author Keywords: bacteriochlorophyll; cytochrome; green bacteria; photosynthesis; reaction center

Authors: Cavasinni V., Del Prete T., Morganti M., Schiavo F., Owen D.L., Paternoster G., Patricelli S., Anzivino G.
Title: Observation of double-Pomeron exchange in alpha-alpha collisions at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C Particles and Fields
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Pisa, I-56100, Italy; CERN, Geneva, CH-1211, Switzerland; Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Naples, I-80100, Italy; State University of New York, Stony Brook, 11790, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cavasinni, V., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Pisa, I-56100, Italy; Del Prete, T., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Pisa, I-56100, Italy; Morganti, M., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Pisa, I-56100, Italy; Schiavo, F., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Pisa, I-56100, Italy; Owen, D.L., CERN, Geneva, CH-1211, Switzerland; Paternoster, G., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Naples, I-80100, Italy; Patricelli, S., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università and INFN, Naples, I-80100, Italy; Anzivino, G., State University of New York, Stony Brook, 11790, NY, United States
Abstract: We observed the process αα→ααX in which the α′s were emitted uncorrelated in the forward direction and the charged component of the cluster X was confined to a limited portion (|η|≲2) of the central region. We identified such reactions as being due to double-Pomeron exchange, for which we found a cross-section of (720±140)μb. The raw mean charged multiplicity of the cluster X was found to be 6.76±0.07 with a dispersion D=4.8. The measurements were performed at the CERN ISR at a centre-of-mass energy of {Mathematical expression} GeV. Similarities are drawn between double-Pomeron exchange in αα and in pp collisions. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Seasonal and diurnal variation of energy budget components in coniferous forests
Affiliations: Department of Ecology and Environmental Research, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-750 07 Uppsala 7, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Lindroth, A., Department of Ecology and Environmental Research, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-750 07 Uppsala 7, Sweden
Abstract: This study was part of the large multidisciplinary ecosystem investigations undertaken in Sweden during the 70's. One of the main aims of the abiotic research was to deepen our understanding of the physical processes governing the local- and microclimate of northern coniferous forests. As part of this, the energy budget of a sparse pine forest in central Sweden was intensively studied. Analysis of Bowen ratio measurements during 1977 and 1978 showed that the fraction of net radiation (Rn) utilized for sensible and latent heat (LE) fluxes was not constant over the season. The ratio LE Rn increased from about 40% in May to about 60% in August and September. The mean daytime latent heat flux from a dry canopy was about 135 W m-2 in May, increasing to 150-160 W m-2 in July and August and then decreasing to 100 W m-2 in September. The sensible heat flux decreased from about 190 W m-2 in May to 55 W m-2 in September. The mean daytime energy storage rate was largest in May and September with about 23 W m-2 and smallest in July with 12 W m-2. The Bowen ratio at noon decreased from about 2 in May to 0.5-1 in August and September. During a period of six days, simultaneous measurements of evapotranspiration from the ground vegetation and the whole forest were made. Averaged over the daytime period, about 59% of the net radiation was used for latent heat flux, 32% for sensible heat flux and 9% for storage. Only 13% of the latent heat flux came from the ground vegetation while more than 50% of the sensible heat flux originated from the ground. Comparison between four European coniferous forests showed that the mean daytime latent heat flux varied relatively little. The mean rate was 135 ± 27 W m-2 and there was no correlation between density of forest and rate of latent heat flux. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ATMOSPHERIC THERMODYNAMICS; HYDROLOGY; SOLAR RADIATION; CONIFEROUS FORESTS; ENERGY BUDGET COMPONENTS; FORESTRY; ecosystem investigations; microclimate; Sweden

Abstract: Using the ARGUS detector at the e+e- storage ring DORIS II, we have measured the vτ energy spectrum in the decay π+π-π±vτ of τ leptons produced near s=10 GeV. From this energy spectrum, we derive an upper limit of m(vτ)<70 MeV c2 at the 95% confidence level. © 1985.

Authors: Black J.A., Acott K.M., Bufton L.
Title: A futile cycle in erythrocyte glycolysis
Affiliations: Division of Medical Genetics, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR 97201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Black, J.A., Division of Medical Genetics, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR 97201, United States; Acott, K.M., Division of Medical Genetics, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR 97201, United States; Bufton, L., Division of Medical Genetics, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR 97201, United States
Abstract: The storage lesion which limits the shelf life of human blood in blood banking is associated with a metabolic loss of 2,3-diphosphoglycerate and ATP. This metabolic loss is driven by intracellular ATPases which are usually considered to include the ion pumps and the reactions which maintain the discoid shape of the human erythrocyte. Under the acidic conditions of blood storage, the energy-yielding reactions of the glycolytic pathway are restricted at the hexokinase and phosphofructokinase steps. We show here that under such circumstances the enzyme of the diphosphoglycerate shunt, diphosphoglycerate mutase/phosphatase and the glycolytic enzyme phosphoglycerate kinase can form a futile cycle with ATPase activity. This ATPase activity responds to 2-phosphoglycolate which is known to activate both diphosphoglycerate mutase and diphosphoglycerate phosphatase reactions. When the enzymes of the futile cycle are combined with the enzymes of the lower glycolytic pathway in a reconstitution experiment designed to represent conditions within the stored erythrocyte, the futile cycle does provide an ATPase activity which results in the metabolic loss of 2,3-diphosphoglycerate. An isotope incorporation experiment demonstrates that the futile cycle is active in glucose-depleted erythrocytes. © 1985.
Author Keywords: ATPase; Diphosphoglycerate mutase; Diphosphoglycerate phosphatase; Erythrocyte; Glycolysis; Rapoport-Luebering shunt
Index Keywords: 2,3 diphosphoglyceric acid; adenosine triphosphatase; adenosine triphosphate; blood and hemopoietic system; blood bank; erythrocyte; glycolysis; human; human cell; priority journal; 2,3-Diphosphoglycerate; Adenosine Triphosphate; Diphosphoglyceric Acids; Erythrocytes; Glycolysis; Human; NAD; Phosphoglycerate Kinase; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Title: Prospects for visible chemical lasers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Short Wavelength Laser Branch, Air Force Weapons Laboratory, Kirtland AFB, NM, 87117, United States; Physical Sciences Inc., Dascomb Research Park, Andover, MA, 01810, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davis, S.J., Short Wavelength Laser Branch, Air Force Weapons Laboratory, Kirtland AFB, NM, 87117, United States, Physical Sciences Inc., Dascomb Research Park, Andover, MA, 01810, United States
Abstract: The search for a short wavelength chemical laser (λ < 1.3 μ) has been, so far, unsuccessful but far from fruitless. The kinetic and spectroscopic data collected in studies concerned with laser development are truly impressive. Numerous chemiluminescent reactions have been reported, and many radiative lifetimes and quenching rates for excited molecular states have been measured. In addition, energy transfer among excited vibrational and rotational levels has been an active area of research. © 1985, SPIE.

Authors: Blinov A.E., Bondar A.E., Groshev V.R., Eidelman Yu.I., Klimenko S.G., Mishnev S.I., Nikitin S.A., Onuchin A.P., Panin V.S., Protopopov I.Ya., Shamov A.G., Tayursky V.A., Telnov V.I., Tikhonov Yu.A., Tumaikin G.M., Vorobiov A.I., Zholents A.A.
Title: Measurement of particle polarization in e+e- storage rings by means of synchrotron radiation scattering on the colliding beam
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Authors with affiliations: Blinov, A.E., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Bondar, A.E., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Groshev, V.R., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Eidelman, Yu.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Klimenko, S.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mishnev, S.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Nikitin, S.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Onuchin, A.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Panin, V.S., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Protopopov, I.Ya., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Shamov, A.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Tayursky, V.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Telnov, V.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Tikhonov, Yu.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Tumaikin, G.M., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Vorobiov, A.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Zholents, A.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: A new method for measuring the polarization of e+e- in storage rings is described. It is based on the scattering of synchrotron radiation on the colliding beam. The method is simple in operation and allows a simultaneous measurement of the polarization of the electron and positron beam. This method was applied to the energy calibration of the storage ring VEPP-4 in the high precision measurements of the Υ{hooked}-mesons' masses with MD-1 detector. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVES - Polarization; UPSILON-MESONS; VEPP-4; CHARGED PARTICLES

Title: Self-radiolysis of iodobenzene labelled with125I
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry Letters
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Ege University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey; Faculty of Sciences, Ege University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Ünak, P., Faculty of Engineering, Ege University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey; Ünak, T., Faculty of Sciences, Ege University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey
Abstract: The radiolysis of iodobenzene labelled with125I has been investigated at liquid nitrogen and room temperatures, in the presence and absence of oxygen. After various storage times the samples were analyzed by gas chromatography, and benzene, vinyl iodide, biphenyl, and iodobiphenyl were detected. Biphenyl, benzene, and iodobiphenyl were found to be formed as a result of local radiolytic effect of Auger electrons of125I, and vinyl iodide was probably produced due to the decay effect of125I in labelled iodobenzene molecules. At the site of125I decay the Auger electrons are radiolytically effective within a spherical volume with diameter of about 30 Å. Outside this sphere the energy absorbed by iodobenzene molecules is not high enough to produce any radiolytical damage. © 1985 Akadémiai Kiadó.

Title: HEATERLESS DRYERS ARE NOT HEATLESS.
Affiliations: Henderson Engineering Co, Sandwich,, IL, USA, Henderson Engineering Co, Sandwich, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Peacock Jr., Edwin M., Henderson Engineering Co, Sandwich,, IL, USA, Henderson Engineering Co, Sandwich, IL, USA
Abstract: Although heaterless (or pressure-swing) dryers contain no heaters, like all thermodynamic devices they depend upon a rather sensitive thermal-energy balance. Therefore, they should not really be considered, or called, 'heaterless'. Their successful operation depends upon the capture and storage of the ehat of adsorption that is liberated during the exothermic adsorption (or drying) step. This stored energy later becomes available to provide the bulk of the energy needed for the endothermic desorption (or desiccant reactivation) step. This article consists of an analysis which shows just how important 'adequate' capture of the liberated heat of adsorption is, and how the degree or quality of capture influences both the delivery of dry compressed air and the costs of the drying process.
Index Keywords: HEATERLESS DRYERS; PRESSURE-SWING DRYERS; DRYERS

Authors: Braat K.B., van Lohuizen H.P.S., de Haan J.F.
Title: UNDERGROUND PUMPED HYDRO-STORAGE PROJECT FOR THE NETHERLANDS.
Authors with affiliations: Braat, K.B.; van Lohuizen, H.P.S.; de Haan, J.F.
Abstract: In a country with only few hills and no mountains, serious consideration is being given to a large-scale underground project with a substantial element of rock tunnelling. Located in the Netherlands, it will involve the construction of an underground pumped hydro storage (UPHS) power station for large-scale storage of electrical energy.
Index Keywords: ROCK DRILLING; STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Underground; TUNNELS AND TUNNELING - Construction; NETHERLANDS; ROCK FORMATIONS; UNDERGROUND WATER RESERVOIR; WATER TUNNELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Oglevie Ronald E., Eisenhaure David B.
Title: ADVANCED INTEGRATED POWER AND ATTITUDE CONTROL SYSTEM (IPACS) STUDY.
Affiliations: Rockwell Int Corp, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int Corp, Downey, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oglevie, Ronald E., Rockwell Int Corp, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int Corp, Downey, CA, USA; Eisenhaure, David B., Rockwell Int Corp, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int Corp, Downey, CA, USA
Abstract: Integrated Power and Attitude Control System (IPACS) studies performed over a decade ago established the feasibility of simultaneously satisfying the demands of energy storage and attitude control through the use of rotating flywheels. It was demonstrated that, for a wide spectrum of applications, such a system possessed many advantages over contemporary energy storage and attitude control approaches. This study was undertaken to define an advanced IPACS and to evaluate its merits for a Space Station application. System and component designs are developed to establish the performance of this concept, and system trade studies are conducted to examine the viability of this approach relative to conventional candidate systems. It is clearly demonstrated that an advanced IPACS concept is not only feasible but also offers substantial savings in mass and life-cycle cost for the Space Station mission.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS - Energy Storage; SPACECRAFT

Title: FLEET CONVERSION TO COMPRESSED NATURAL GAS PRODUCES BIG SAVINGS.
Affiliations: Thermal Efficiency Inc, Seattle, WA,, USA, Thermal Efficiency Inc, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Berdan, Larry, Thermal Efficiency Inc, Seattle, WA,, USA, Thermal Efficiency Inc, Seattle, WA, USA; Epling, Ralph, Thermal Efficiency Inc, Seattle, WA,, USA, Thermal Efficiency Inc, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: The city fleet of Kirkland, Washington, is saving some 20,000 per year in fuel costs and reduced maintenance. Kirkland chose Dual Fuel System's 'BiPac' conversion kit, which allows a standard gasoline engine to run on either gasoline or CNG and requires no modifications of the engine itself. The system consists of a refueling connection, gas/air mixer, pressure regulators, CNG storage cylinders, fuel selector control, and fuel gauge. The city also installed Dual Fuel's 'Dual Curve' ignition, which electronically compensates for the different combustion characteristics of gasoline and CNG, virtually eliminating the power loss that otherwise might be expected. Kirkland's switch to CNG was part of a gasoline effort to achieve cost savings through energy efficiency.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILE ENGINES - Dual Fuel; AUTOMOBILES - Fuel Economy; NATURAL GAS - Applications; BIPAC CONVERSION KIT; DUAL CURVE IGNITION; AUTOMOTIVE FUELS

Title: NEW GAS SUPPLIES.
Affiliations: British Gas Corp, REA Div, UK, British Gas Corp, REA Div, UK
Authors with affiliations: Hartill, Ian J., British Gas Corp, REA Div, UK, British Gas Corp, REA Div, UK
Abstract: This paper reviews the prospects for supplying natural gas to British Gas from the UKCS and from imports, and describes British Gas' SNG (Synthetic natural gas) Program. It concludes that the UKCS supplemented by supplies from Sleipner, will continue to be the main source of British Gas' supplies for many years to come and that as the UKCS eventually declines as a source there will be adequate reserves elsewhere in the world that can be imported either through pipelines or as LNG. To provide an additional option for use in the long term when natural gas declines, British Gas has a program described in this paper, directed towards the development of effective and economical processes for the manufacture of SNG at estimated costs which will permit the gas industry to remain competitive.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - Economics; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; NATURAL GAS PIPELINES - Planning; NATURAL GAS, LIQUEFIED - Storage; RESERVES; SUPPLIES; WESTERN EUROPE; NATURAL GAS

Title: Effects of long-term low-level exposure to radiation as observed in acrylic scintillator. Cause and prevention of radiation disease in uranium calorimeters
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Sirois, Y., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wigmans, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The acrylic scintillator which was used for several years as the active medium in the Axial Field Spectrometer uranium calorimeter at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings was found to be severely damaged. The observed light output has decreased on the average by a factor of 2, and the attenuation length by a factor of 3, causing a severe degradation of the energy resolution of the system for the detection of both electromagnetic and hadronic showers. It could be shown that the effects are due to the radiation induced by uranium decay. The fact that the integrated dose obtained from this process (50 Gy) is 2 orders of magnitude smaller than what was currently believed to be a safe level, strongly suggests that the dose rate is a dominating factor in these radiation damage problems. It could be shown that the radiation resistivity is improved by at least an order of magnitude if contact with oxygen is avoided. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ACRYLICS - Radiation Damage; CALORIMETERS; PHYSICS - High Energy; AXIAL FIELD SPECTROMETER; CERN INTERSECTING STORAGE RINGS; SCINTILLATION COUNTERS
