Abstract: The ARGUS detector at the e+e- storage ring DORIS II has been used as a pair spectrometer to study the photon transitions in the reaction Υ{hooked}(2S)→γχb(13P2,1, 0). Three photon lines were observed with energies (110.6±0.3±0.9) MeV, (131.7±0.3±1.1) MeV and (162.1±0.5±1.4) MeV, respectively. The corresponding branching ratios were found to be (9.8±2.1±2.4)%, (9.1±1.8±2.2)% and (6.4±1.4±1.6)%. Upper limits for full widths at the 90% confidence limit are 1.0 MeV for the χb(13P2) and 2.6 MeV for the other two states. © 1985.

Title: UTILITY CYCLE TESTING OF A 500-kWh ZINC CHLORIDE BATTERY AT THE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE TEST (BEST) FACILITY.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Advanced batteries for energy storage and other utility load management applications promise rapid response, few restrictions on siting, and fast installation. These systems charge during periods of low demand and discharge into the power network when demand is high. DOE and EPRI cosponsored the development of a zinc chloride battery for this use through the delivery, installation, and acceptance testing of a 500-kWh developmental system. The developmental system included ten 50-kWh zinc chloride batteries connected in series to operate at 500 Vdc. A 13. 8-kv distribution system provided utility interface to the ac/dc converter and battery.
Index Keywords: ZINC COMPOUNDS; CUSTOMERS; TEST FACILITIES; ZINC CHLORIDE BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: MICROWAVE INSTABILITY ACROSS THE TRANSITION ENERGY.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.Y., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Wang, J.M., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: It is well known that during the acceleration of hadrons in a storage ring, the beam always goes above the microwave instability threshold near the transition energy gamma //T. The reason is that the longitudinal revolution frequency spread of the beam which otherwise provides Landau damping vanishes at the transition energy. The amount of the beam dilution near the transition energy is determined by the tau th, the length of time when the beam stays unstable, and the growth rate of the instability. It is pointed out that tau th is proportional to the fourth power of gamma //T, and thus the choice of a large gamma //T is not desirable from this point of view. An analysis is also given of the microwave-instability-induced beam dilution for the proposed relativistic heavy ion collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory.
Index Keywords: MICROWAVES; PARTICLE BEAMS - Stability; HADRONS; LANDAU DAMPING; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Momose T., Narushima K., Kanazawa K., Mizuno H., Watanabe H., Ishimaru H.
Title: OPERATIONAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE TRISTAN ACCUMULATION RING VACUUM SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Momose, T., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Narushima, K., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Kanazawa, K., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Mizuno, H., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Watanabe, H., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Ishimaru, H., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn
Abstract: The operational characteristics of the TRISTAN vacuum system are described. The vacuum system is made of aluminum alloys using specially extruded aluminum pipes. The best base pressure, on the order of 10** minus **8 Pa, was obtained without any baking or discharge cleaning. The thermal gas desorption rate of the aluminum chambers was on the order of 10** minus **1**0 Pa-l/s-cm**2. For a time integrated beam current of 13. 5 A-h, the pressure rise due to synchrotron radiation was 2. 1 multiplied by 10** minus **8 Pa/mA and the maximum beam lifetime was about 2 hours at several mA. The pressure rise is approximately inversely proportional to the time integrated beam current and is initially proportional to the beam energy, changing after about 7 A-h to being proportional to the square root of the beam energy. A pressure independent lifetime of 357 min. was observed. The lifetime at higher beam currents is proportional to the time integrated beam current. No thermal problems due to synchrotron radiation were observed.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; TRISTAN ACCUMULATION RING; VACUUM SYSTEM; VACUUM PUMPS

Authors: Botman J.I.M., Craddock M.K., Suzuki T.
Title: MAGNET LATTICES FOR THE PROPOSED TRIUMF KAON FACTORY.
Affiliations: TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can, TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can
Authors with affiliations: Botman, J.I.M., TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can, TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can; Craddock, M.K., TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can, TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can; Suzuki, T., TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can, TRIUMF, Vancouver, BC, Can
Abstract: The magnet lattices of a chain of two proton synchrotron and three dc storage rings for the proposed TRIUMF KAON Factory are described. The KAON Factory will provide pulsed and dc proton beams of 30 GeV and 100 mu A and will be fed from the existing TRIUMF cyclotron. The rapid cycling booster (50 Hz) accelerates from 440 MeV to 3 GeV; the 10-Hz main ring is five times larger and brings the energy to 30 GeV. The lattices are all of the separated-function type. For avoiding serious beam losses at transition, the transition energy is driven far above the top energy of the accelerators. This feature is obtained mainly be creating a superperiodic structure with missing magnet cells and by choosing the horizontal tune just below the number of superperiods. A special arrangement of the RF accelerating cavities is used to avoid synchro-betatron coupling. Fast extraction systems are described.
Index Keywords: PROTONS; DC STORAGE RINGS; KAON FACTORY; PROTON SYNCHROTRONS; TRIUMF; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Guignard G., Potter K., Verdier A.
Title: INTERACTION REGIONS FOR E-P AND P-P COLLISIONS IN THE LEP TUNNEL.
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Guignard, G., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Potter, K., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Verdier, A., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: Studies have shown the feasibility of a p-p collider (LHC) in the LEP tunnel with center-of-mass energies from 10 to 18 TeV. The proximity of the LEP storage ring, with maximum energy of 100 GeV per beam, offers the possibility of e-p interactions. Because of limitations in space and deflection, it is assumed that e-p insertions are in a straight section between two arcs, which does not contain RF cavities. Among the envisaged insertions, head-on collisions give the highest luminosity. In this case, the electron beam is deflected vertically so that there is a path common to both beams between the LEP insertion quadrupoles used for separating the beams outside this region. In p-p mode, this insertion gives a luminosity of 1 to 2 multiplied by 10**3**2 cm** minus **2S** minus **1. In e-p mode, the luminosity reaches 1. 23 multiplied by 10**3**2 cm** minus **2S** minus **2 for a center-of-mass energy of 1. 5 TeV. The use of collimators reduces the photon background in the experimental region to a tolerable level.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS; PROTONS; BEAM LUMINOSITY; LEP STORAGE RING; RF CAVITIES; ACCELERATORS

Title: PERIODIC PLASMA WAVEGUIDE ACCELERATOR.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cole, F.T., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: The increasing cost of synchrotrons and storage rings has given new impetus to the search for new methods of acceleration. The primary goal of this search is very large accelerating fields. Very large electric fields are possible in plasma and in lasers, and many geometries are being studied that make use of plasmas, lasers, or combinations of them. The device proposed here is an attempt to separate the two functions of providing a medium and providing an energy source. A relatively low-energy electron beam is used as a nonneutral plasma only to make a slow-wave medium for the propagation of an externally generated wave. The wave is a TM electromagnetic wave and the device may be thought of as a conventional electron linear accelerator with the evacuated volume and metallic envelope replaced by the electron beam. A separate second beam, which may comprise electrons or heavier particles, is accelerated. The application in mind is a single-pass collider.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS - Acceleration; PARTICLE BEAMS - Acceleration; WAVEGUIDES - Plasma Filled; HEAVIER PARTICLES; NONNEUTRAL PLASMA; PERIODIC PLASMA WAVEGUIDE ACCELERATOR; SINGLE PASS COLLIDER; SLOW-WAVE MEDIUM; ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Authors: Muelhaupt G., Derikum K., Egan-Krieger G.v., Flessner H.-H., Hoberg H.-G., Klotz W.-D., Kuske P., Lehr H., Maier R., Martin M., Richter R., Schiele A., Schulz L., Weihreter E.
Title: BESSY REACHES FULL SCALE OPERATION.
Affiliations: BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Muelhaupt, G., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Derikum, K., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Egan-Krieger, G.v., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Flessner, H.-H., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Hoberg, H.-G., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Klotz, W.-D., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Kuske, P., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Lehr, H., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Maier, R., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Martin, M., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Richter, R., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Schiele, A., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Schulz, L., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger; Weihreter, E., BESSY, Berlin, West Ger, BESSY, Berlin, West Ger
Abstract: The Berlin Storage Ring for Synchrotron Radiation (BESSY) is now running in routine operation with stored currents of 600 mA (multi-bunch operation) with lifetimes of 3 h (increasing to 6 h at lower currents). The beam cross sections at the source points are sigma //x equals 0. 2 mm and sigma //z equals 0. 5 //2 60 at 600 mA and sigma //x equals 0. 2 mm and sigma //z equals //2 mm at 10 mA. Injection rates are higher than 0. 5 A/min. At the present time, 26 experimental stations equipped with 16 monochromators are in operation. Additional information is given about single bunch operation, current limits, and energy calibration of the electron beam by spin resonance depolarization.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS - Acceleration; BERLIN STORAGE RING FOR SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; STORED CURRENTS; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: BREEDING NEW LIGHT INTO OLD MACHINE (AND NEW).
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spencer, J.E., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Brodsky, S.J., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: Photons produced by lasers or wigglers backscattered on high energy electron or proton beams can provide high energy, high luminosity photon-electron, photon-photon or photon-proton collisions. This allows the study of short-distance QCD processes such as high transverse momentum photon-photon and photo-production reactions, deep inelastic Compton scattering, the photon structure function, direct photon reactions, or searches for pseudo-Goldstone bosons and supersymmetry particles like the photino or goldstino. The relative reaction rates should be quite high since (1) photo-production cross sections are significantly larger than the corresponding electro-production cross sections and (2) the absence of the conventional beam-beam interaction allows significantly higher currents and smaller interaction areas. It thus seems possible to have photon luminosities much larger than for electrons. Examples are given using the PEP storage ring with the SLAC linac beam.
Index Keywords: PHOTONS - Scattering; BACKSCATTERED PHOTONS; BEAM-BEAM INTERACTIONS; ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Title: PRESENT LIMITS FOR THE LUMINOSITY, THE BEAM CURRENT AND THE BEAM LIFETIME IN DORIS II.
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Nesemann, H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger; Sarau, B., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: The e** plus e- storage ring DORIS II has been operating for high-energy physics experiments in the region of the Y resonances aroung 2 multiplied by 5 GeV and as a source for synchrotron radiation near 3. 7 GeV. A luminosity of nearly 3 multiplied by 10**3**1 cm** minus **2s** minus **1/day or more than 1500 (nb)** minus **1/day has been achieved. For synchrotron radiation, e - currents of about 100 mA are stored in 4 bunches (out of 480 buckets). As long as the beam-beam interaction does not limit the luminosity the optimum performance of the ring is obtained for both modes of operation if the currents stored are large, the cross section of the beam is small and the lifetime is long. The authors focus on these topics.
Index Keywords: CHARGED PARTICLES; ELECTRONS; BEAM CURRENT; BEAM LIFETIME; LUMINOSITY; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: CURRENT DEPENDENT BUNCH LENGTHENING IN THE SRS.
Affiliations: Science & Engineering Research, Council, Daresbury Lab, Warrington,, Engl, Science & Engineering Research Council, Daresbury Lab, Warrington, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Garvey, T., Science & Engineering Research, Council, Daresbury Lab, Warrington,, Engl, Science & Engineering Research Council, Daresbury Lab, Warrington, Engl
Abstract: Measurements are reported of beam-current-dependent bunch lengthening in the SRS. The results show that even for the short ( 200 ps) high-frequency (500 MHz) bunches the functional dependence of bunch length on beam current is characteristic of that which one might expect to find in the presence of turbulent bunch lengthening. A study of the relationship betwen single-bunch current and measured bunch length is made under varying conditions of RF power and energy. The information obtained is used to provide an estimate of the broadband impedance of the electron storage ring.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, ELECTRON RING - Storage Rings; BEAM BUNCHING; RF POWER; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION SOURCE (SRS); ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: SOME USES OF REPMM'S IN STORAGE RINGS AND COLLIDERS.
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spencer, J.E., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: Improvements for existing rings and techniques for building new rings composed entirely of passive rare earth permanent magnet multipoles (REPMMs) are considered using circular dipoles, quadrupoles, and sextupoles. Over the past years, such magnets have been made by using a single size SmCo//s block with up to five easy-axis orientations. The final production scheme is modular in that magnets are built-up from quantized layers. All multipole layers are made in exactly the same way using algorithms differing only by the desired multipole symmetry. The method is simple, efficient, and inexpensive and allows a 'do-it-yourself' approach to constructing new magnetic elements. For rings these might include focusing optical klystrons, rotatable multipoles for diagnostics, correction or extraction, or possibly combined function systems for the unit cells. A high quality, low-beta, PMQ insertion which can change beta, tune, and energy is described as well as the PMSs for the SD and SF elements of the North SLC damping ring. Because these sextupoles will be the first optical use of PMs in storage rings, they are discussed in detail together with the advantages, problems, and requirements of such applications.
Index Keywords: MAGNETS - Applications; RARE EARTH PERMANENT MAGNET MULTIPOLES; STORAGE RINGS/COLLIDERS; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Kim K.-J., Bisognano J., Chattopadhyay S., Cornacchia M., Garren A., Halbach K., Jackson A., Lancaster H., Peterson J., Zisman M., Pellegrini C., Vignola G.
Title: STORAGE RING DESIGN FOR A SHORT WAVELENGTH FEL.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kim, K.-J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Bisognano, J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Chattopadhyay, S., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Cornacchia, M., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Garren, A., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Halbach, K., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Jackson, A., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Lancaster, H., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Peterson, J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Zisman, M., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Pellegrini, C., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Vignola, G., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: A high gain free electron laser (FEL) operating in a special bypass of a storage ring can provide tens of megawatts of coherent power at wavelengths shorter than 1000 angstrom. The requirements on beam qualities are demanding, a few hundred amperes of peak current in an emittance of about 10** minus **8 m-rad with a relative energy spread of 10** minus **3. Designing an electron storage ring with the required characteristics involves a comprehensive analysis of the restrictions from, and relationships between, the FEL physics, the multiparticle beam phenomena, and the ring lattice structure. A summary of such a study is reported and some design examples are given.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS - Laser Applications; LASERS, FREE ELECTRON; HIGH GAIN FEL; STORAGE RING DESIGN; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Kasuga T., Yonehara H., Kinoshita T., Hasumoto M.
Title: PRESENT STATUS OF UVSOR.
Affiliations: Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn, Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kasuga, T., Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn, Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn; Yonehara, H., Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn, Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn; Kinoshita, T., Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn, Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn; Hasumoto, M., Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn, Inst for Molecular Sciences, Jpn
Abstract: UVSOR, constructed at the Institute for Molecular Science, is an electron storage ring dedicated to synchrotron radiation research in molecular science and related fields. The construction started in 1981, and the first beam was stored in 1983. The maximum beam current up to this time was 200 mA and the e-folding lifetime of the beam was about 2 hours at beam current of 100 mA. The injection energy of the ring was 600 MeV, and the injected beam can be accelerated up to 750 MeV. The critical wavelength of the synchrotron radiation from the ordinary bending magnets was 56. 9 angstrom at an electron energy of 600 MeV. A superconducting wiggler with a magnetic field of 4 T was installed in 1984. This field strength gives a critical wavelength of 16. 2 angstrom at 600 MeV. An undulator with permanent magnets was also constructed. Single bunch operation was tried successfully. Experimental work using synchrotron radiation was begun in 1984.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Applications; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION RESEARCH; UVSOR FACILITY UV SYNCHROTRON ORBITAL; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: EVALUATION OF THE GTO FOR 270 MVA INTERRUPTER APPLICATIONS.
Authors with affiliations: Ehsani, M.; Kernaghan, W.H.
Abstract: The fundamental problem of interrupting a direct current is producing a current zero which will allow for the elimination of current flow. Historically, external circuits have been used to extinguish a plasma (arc) conducting medium by counterpulsing the arc current to zero. Preliminary results show that solid-state dc interrupters utilizing gate turn-off thyristors can provide for reduced capacitive energy storage requirements over vacuum interrupters and SCRs in creating a current zero. The hardware required in the gate circuit of the GTO is significantly reduced over the counter-pulse circuits in vacuum interrupters and SCRs by taking advantage of the turn-off gain available in the GTO. Interrupters designed around the GTO can have applications in the power conditioning and protection circuits of particle accelerators and fusion reactors.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CIRCUIT BREAKERS - Analysis; GTO THYRISTORS; THYRISTORS

Title: STORAGE RING PARAMETERS FOR HIGH GAIN FEL.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kim, K.-J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Peterson, J.M., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: One-dimensional free electron laser (FEL) theory was used to find criteria for choosing electron beam and undulator parameters for operation of a high gain FEL at 400 angstrom. The criteria are (i) moderate electron beam energy ( greater than 1 GeV), (ii) high peak current (several hundred amperes), (iii) small emittance (10** minus **8 m-rad), (iv) small relative momentum spread (0. 001), and (v) narrow undulator gap (3 mm). Results of two-dimensional simulations on FEL performance are presented.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS - Laser Applications; LASERS, FREE ELECTRON - Theory; 1-D FEL THEORY; HIGH GAIN FEL; STORAGE RING PARAMETERS; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: DEVELOPMENTS IN ACCELERATORS FOR HEAVY ION FUSION.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Keefe, Denis, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: The long-term goal of heavy ion fusion (HIF) is the development of an accelerator with the large beam power, large beam stored-energy, and high brightness needed to implode small deuterium-tritium capsules for fusion power. While studies of an RF linac/storage ring combination as an inertial fusion driver continue in Japan and Europe, the US program in recent times has concentrated on the study of the suitability of linear induction acceleration of ions for this purpose. Novel features required include use of multiple beams, beam current amplification in the linac, and manipulation of long beam bunches with a large velocity difference between head and tail. The discussion covers driver studies, the Single Beam Transport Experiment, and multiple beam experiments.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; PLASMAS - Confinement; HEAVY-ION ACCELERATORS; INERTIAL CONFINEMENT; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Thieberger P., Wegner H.E., Alonso J., Gould H., Munger C., Anholt R., Meyerholf W.E.
Title: FULLY STRIPPED HEAVY ION YIELD VS ENERGY FOR Xe AND Au IONS.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thieberger, P., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Wegner, H.E., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Alonso, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Gould, H., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Munger, C., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Anholt, R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Meyerholf, W.E., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: The Bevalac is now capable of accelerating **2**3**8U ions to approximately 1 GeV/amu and measurements have shown that fully stripped **2**3**8U ions are produced with good yield at these energies. However, knowing the stripping yields at different energies for **2**3**8U does not allow an accurate prediction for other, lower Z projectiles. Consequently, extensive stripping yield measurements were made for **1**9**7//7//9Au and **1**2**9//5//4Xe ions. In addition to the stripping measurements from the direct Bevalac beam, pickup measurements were also made with specially prepared bare, one-electron, and two-electron ions. Since many research groups are considering heavy ion storage rings and/or synchrotrons, the pickup cross section for bare ions is important for estimating beam lifetime in terms of the average machine vacuum. Since the Mylar target provides a pickup probability similar to air, a preliminary analysis of the Xe**5**4** plus and U**9**2** plus data is presented along with predictions for other ions ranging down to Fe**2**6** plus .
Index Keywords: GOLD AND ALLOYS; IONS; XENON; BEVALAC; MYLAR TARGET; PICKUP CROSS-SECTION; STRIPPING YIELDS; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Oide K., Fukuma H., Kamada S., Kikuchi M., Momose T., Satoh K., Shintake T., Tejima M.
Title: GAMMA RAY SOURCE USING INTERNAL TARGETS IN THE TRISTAN ACCUMULATION RING.
Affiliations: Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Oide, K., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Fukuma, H., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Kamada, S., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Kikuchi, M., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Momose, T., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Satoh, K., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Shintake, T., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn; Tejima, M., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics,, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, KEK, Ibaraki, Jpn
Abstract: A gamma ray source using internal targets in an electron storage ring, the TRISTAN Accumulation Ring (AR), has been operated since May 1984. Two detectors for high energy physics experiments, called TOPAZ and VENUS, are to be installed in the TRISTAN main ring. They have several thousands of lead glass counters as calorimeters. Each counter needs calibration using electron beams of several GeV before the installation. Such high energy electron beams could be obtained in the KEK 12 GeV proton synchrotron; however, this synchrotron was not operational due to the construction of the TRISTAN project in 1984. The discussion covers the target system and control system. Operational results are summaized.
Index Keywords: X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION; INTERNAL TARGETS; TRISTAN ACCUMULATION RING; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Yamazaki T., Noguchi T., Sugiyama S., Mikado T., Chiwaki M., Tomimasu T.
Title: GENERATION OF QUASI-MONOCHROMATIC PHOTON BEAMS FROM COMPTON BACKSCATTERED LASER LIGHT AT ETL ELECTRON STORAGE RING.
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Yamazaki, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Noguchi, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Mikado, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Chiwaki, M., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn
Abstract: A generation of quasi-monochromatic photon beams of energy variable between 1. 7 and 6. 5 MeV has been observed by inducing the Compton backscattering of laser light quanta on electrons of energy 305-606 MeV at the injection straight section of the 600-MeV ETL storage ring. A Nd-YAG laser of wavelength 1. 0641 mu m has been used with output power 0. 7-1. 2 W. The resultant photon spectra are measured with a pure Ge detector. Some of these are presented, together with a description on the experimental methods. The absolute yields are being measured by the use of an 8 in. phi multiplied by 8 in. long NaI scintillation counter.
Index Keywords: LASER BEAMS - Scattering; COMPTON SCATTERING; LASER LIGHT BACKSCATTERING; PHOTON BEAM GENERATION; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Yu L.H., Nawrocky R.J., Galayda J.
Title: STUDIES OF POSITIONAL STABILITY OF THE ELECTRON BEAM IN THE NSLS STORAGE RING.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Yu, L.H., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Nawrocky, R.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Galayda, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: Positional stability of the electron beam is critically important to experimental beam line users. The beam position vibration increases the effective beam size and thus reduces the brightness. So the positional stability measurement provides important information for beam lines. Data about amplitude and frequency of beam vibration and long term beam movement at different beam ports can be useful in locating the noise source for accelerator physicists. For the noise which can not be eliminated, a beam position monitor can provide the signal for the feedback system to stabilize the beam position. These considerations become more evident as higher brightness and better energy resolution are sought. Preliminary results of the beam position stability measurement at the NSLS are reported.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Control; BEAM POSITION MONITOR; BEAM POSITION STABILITY; ELECTRON BEAMS

Title: BILATERAL POWER SUPPLY WITH ENERGY STORAGE BUFFER FOR THE SUPERCONDUCTIVE COILS OF LARGE PARTICLE ACCELERATORS.
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ehsani, M., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA; Kustom, R.L., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: Development and testing of the active control of current in superconducting coils using dc-ac-dc thyristor converter networks with superconductive magnetic energy storage are reported. The charging and discharging cycles of the magnet are decoupled from the power grid, and since these networks are asynchronous with the line, operation at any practical frequency for the switching devices is possible. These systems avoid putting large power bumps on the utility grid during charging and converter systems, and reduce the size of magnet ripple. Operation and design of thyristor networks in closed-loop feedback with variable phase and frequency modes are discussed. Techniques for switching operation at one phase and frequency to another are described. Operating data on a bang-bang controller for 100 A 4 Hy load and storage coils are given.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Power Supply; BILATERAL POWER SUPPLY; ENERGY STORAGE BUFFER; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Authors: Knott M., Gunderson G., Lenkszus F., McDowell W.
Title: CONTROL SYSTEM FEATURES OF THE ARGONNE 6 GEV SYNCHROTRON LIGHT SOURCE.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Knott, M., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA; Gunderson, G., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA; Lenkszus, F., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA; McDowell, W., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: The Argonne 6-GeV synchrotron light source design consists of an electron/position linac, a fast-cycling 6-GeV synchrotron, and the storage ring itself. Three aspects of the overall design call for special attention in the control system design: first, the operation of a high-energy positron accelerator in a fast-cycling mode may demand high processing performance and high data throughput rates. Second, the high energy and small beam size projected (100 multiplied by 200 microns) will call for high-resolution data processing and control precision in many areas. Finally, the necessity to provide independent, orthogonal control for each of up to 32 insertion device light beams both from the point of view of the experimental requirements and from the need to remove the effects of component vibration will require dedicated, high-performance processors.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; DATA PROCESSING; ELECTRON BEAMS; LIGHT SOURCES; POSITRONS; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Arnolds-Mayer G., Bernard Ph., Bloess D., Cavallari G., Chiaveri E., Haebel E., Lengeler H., Stierlin R., Tueckmantel J., Weingarten W., Piel H.
Title: SUPERCONDUCTING 352 MHZ PROTOTYPE CAVITY FOR LEP.
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Arnolds-Mayer, G., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Bernard, Ph., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Bloess, D., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Cavallari, G., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Chiaveri, E., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Haebel, E., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Lengeler, H., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Stierlin, R., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Tueckmantel, J., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Weingarten, W., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Piel, H., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: It is proposed to upgrade the large electron-positron storage ring LEP to energies above the initial 55 GeV by superconducting accelerating cavities operated at 352 MHz. A new cavity geometry has been developed which will make it possible to locate the main and higher order mode couplers at the beam tubes of the cavities. Experimental results obtained with monocell cavities fabricated from niobium material of different thermal conductivity and with a 4-cell prototype cavity are discussed.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Design; MONOCELL CAVITIES; SUPERCONDUCTING ACCELERATING CAVITIES; ACCELERATORS

Title: LATTICE STUDIES OF CRYRING.
Affiliations: Research Inst of Physics, Stockholm, Swed, Research Inst of Physics, Stockholm, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Heikkinen, P., Research Inst of Physics, Stockholm, Swed, Research Inst of Physics, Stockholm, Swed
Abstract: CRYRING is a small storage and acceleration ring for very heavy, highly charged ions from an EBIS type ion source (CRYSIS). The kinetic energy range is from 100 keV/u to 10 MeV/u. The functions of the ring and the respective beam optical constraints are discussed.
Index Keywords: ION SOURCES; BEAM OPTICAL CONSTRAINTS; CRYRING; IBIS TYPE ION SOURCE (CRYSIS); LATTICE STUDIES; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Martin S.A.M., Berg G.P.A., Hacker U., Hardt A., Kôhler M., Meiôburger J., Osterfeld M., Prasuhn D., Riepe G., Rogge M., Schult O.W.B., Speth J., Turek P., Gaul G., Hagedroorn H., van der Heide J.A., Hinterberger F., Huber M., Jahn R., Mayer-Kuckuk T., Poth H., Gen H.P.
Title: Cosy - a cooler synchrotron and storage ring
Affiliations: Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Univ. Münster, United States; Techn. Univ. Eindhover, United States; Univ. Bonn, Germany; CERN Genf and KFK, Karlsruhe, Germany; Univ. Köln, United States
Authors with affiliations: Martin, S.A.M., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Berg, G.P.A., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Hacker, U., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Hardt, A., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Kôhler, M., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Meiôburger, J., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Osterfeld, M., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Prasuhn, D., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Riepe, G., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Rogge, M., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Schult, O.W.B., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Speth, J., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Turek, P., Kernforschungsanlage, Jülich, Germany; Gaul, G., Univ. Münster, United States; Hagedroorn, H., Techn. Univ. Eindhover, United States; van der Heide, J.A., Techn. Univ. Eindhover, United States; Hinterberger, F., Univ. Bonn, Germany; Huber, M., Univ. Bonn, Germany; Jahn, R., Univ. Bonn, Germany; Mayer-Kuckuk, T., Univ. Bonn, Germany; Poth, H., CERN Genf and KFK, Karlsruhe, Germany; Gen, H.P., Univ. Köln, United States
Abstract: The storage ring COSY with phase space cooling and RF acceleration is designed to accept protons and light ions injected from the existing cyclotron JULIC or protons from the LINAC of the proposed neutron spallation source (SNQ). The lay-out of COSY was developed in cooperation with the Universities in Nordrhein-Westfalen and meets the experimental requirements of variable and high quality beams which are necessary for future nuclear research under discusion. The motivation for the cooler-synchrotron COSY emerged from discussions of nuclear physicists in Nordrhein-Westfalen on future research activities. The “Workshop on Electron Cooling” in 1982 came to the conclusion that a cooler-synchrotron1 is an excellent tool for advanced nuclear research experiments. It should be built at the KFA in cooperation with the surrounding Universities. The three essential properties of the storage ring will be: - high luminosities and very efficient use of the beam in the storage ring by thin internal targets - energy variability in the range of 20 MeV to 1.5 GeV by RF acceleration - very high beam quality through phase space cooling. Two classes of experiments will be feasible in the first step of construction. At proton energies up to about 200 MeV it will be possible to excite selectively fundamental nuclear spin isospin modes and to resolve the corresponding nuclear levels with the existing high resolution spectrometer BIG KARL2. At higher energies single nucleons in the nucleus can be excited internally and coherent meson production can be studied, processes which reflect details of the subnuclear structure. Copyright © 1985 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: NEUTRONS - Sources; PROTONS; SPECTROMETERS; LIGHT IONS; NEUTRON SPALLATION SOURCE; STORAGE RINGE COSY; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Ogata A., Ieiri T., Nakajima K., Mizumachi Y.
Title: TRANSVERSE AND LONGITUDINAL BEAM PROFILE MEASUREMENT USING OPTICAL TECHNIQUES IN TRISTAN ACCUMULATION RING.
Affiliations: Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ogata, A., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Ieiri, T., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Nakajima, K., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Mizumachi, Y., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn
Abstract: A report is presented on electron beam profile measurement using synchrotron radiation form the TRISTAN (Transposable Ring Intersecting STorage Accelerators in Nippon) accumulation ring. Experimental setups are described. Four devices are available: a streak camera, a fiber array profile monitor enabling revolution-by-revolution observation, a high-speed camera with shutter speed shorter than the revolution time, and the usual TV camera for a quiet beam. Their applications are then described for a bunch lenthening study and a vertical beam instability study. In the former case, the correlation between the bunch lenthening and the energy widening is obtained as a function of beam current, energy, and RF voltage. In the latter case, the equipment is triggered synchronously with the instability to give the time history of the profile evolution.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; BUNCH LENGTHENING AND ENERGY WIDENING; OPTICAL MEASUREMENT TECHNIQUES; PROFILE MONITOR; TRANSPORTABLE RING INTERSECTING STORAGE ACCELERATOR; TRISTAN ACCUMULATION RING; ELECTRON BEAMS

Authors: Russo Rosario, Richardson John, Allen Peter
Title: DESIGN OF BURDEKIN FALLS DAM.
Source title: Institution of Engineers, Australia, Civil Engineering Transactions
Affiliations: Queensland Water Resources, Commission, Design Div, Aust, Queensland Water Resources Commission, Design Div, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Russo, Rosario, Queensland Water Resources, Commission, Design Div, Aust, Queensland Water Resources Commission, Design Div, Aust; Richardson, John, Queensland Water Resources, Commission, Design Div, Aust, Queensland Water Resources Commission, Design Div, Aust; Allen, Peter, Queensland Water Resources, Commission, Design Div, Aust, Queensland Water Resources Commission, Design Div, Aust
Abstract: Burdekin Falls Dam is the main storage for the Burdekin River Irrigation Project being constructed on the Burdekin River in North Queensland. The dam will create the largest storage in Queensland and will consist of a main concrete gravity dam across the river and three auxiliary saddle dams. The paper describes the design of the main concrete gravity dam and the three high capacity high head radial gates which make up the outlet works. The flood hydrology is briefly dealt with, the foundation conditions are described and design criteria are given for the stability of the gravity sections. No attempt has been made to provide a conventional energy dissipator but the simple horizontal apron downstream of the spillway will be provided with splitter piers to facilitate aeration of the discharging water during floods. The saddle dams are briefly described. Construction of the main dam commenced in March, 1984, and completion is expected by the end of 1988.
Index Keywords: DAMS, GRAVITY - Design; HYDRAULIC GATES - Design; IRRIGATION - Water Supply; RESERVOIRS - Queensland, Australia; RIVER BASIN PROJECTS - Queensland, Australia; BURDEKIN FALLS DAM, AUSTRALIA; FLOOD HYDROLOGY; SADDLE DAMS; SPILLWAYS; SPLITTER PIERS; DAMS, CONCRETE

Title: Thermoanlytical investigation of latent heat thermal energy storage materials
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ozawa, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: For solar energy utilization, waste heat recovery and load levelling, latent thermal energy storage is a useful tool, and the thermophysical properties, such as latent heat and specific heat capacity, of the materials are very important as well as thermal stability. DSC and TG have been applied for the purpose to the materials, such as polyethylene, urea, pentaerythritol and eutectic mixtures of alkaline hydroxides with alkaline nitrates or nitrites. Performance of polyethylene latent thermal energy storage equipment is also described. © 1985.

Title: Absorbed doses due to synchrotron radiation in the tunnel of the storage ring petra
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, D-2000 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dinter, H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, D-2000 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: Absorbed doses due to synchrotron radiation were measured in the accelerator tunnel of the high-energy electron-positron storage ring PETRA, at beam energies between 17 and 22.8 GeV. For energies between 17 and 30 GeV calculations were performed using the Monte Carlo code EGS. An agreement with the measured values was obtained within a factor of 2. In addition, the absorbed doses in a straight part of the accelerator tunnel were studied. © 1985.
Index Keywords: DOSIMETRY; ABSORBED DOSES; ACCELERATOR TUNNEL; MONTE CARLO CODE; STORAGE RING PETRA; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Grunhaus, J., Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Tel Aviv, 69978, Israel
Abstract: The reactions e+e-→μ+μ-γ and e+e-→e+e-γ have been studied with the CELLO detector at the PETRA storage ring. Data have been collected from s=14 GeV up to46.8GeV. In a Dalitz plot analysis of the data, good agreement is found with QED, except for the region Mxμγe>0.8 where the probability that QED describes the high energy data is at the percent level. © 1985.

Title: Review of Components for Passive Solar Energy Utilization
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmansstr. 22, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Goetzberger, A., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmansstr. 22, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany; Schmid, J., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmansstr. 22, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: Components for passive solar energy utilization can be generally treated as consisting of translucent insulation, radiation control, absorber and storage. Although even in central Europe the total radiation upon a building amounts to more than the heating energy needed during the winter season, closer inspection shows that the available storage capacity is not sufficient to cover the entire load by radiation: auxiliary heat is always required. On the other hand, overheating must be avoided by means of control devices. Components in use at present are: windows, conservatories and, to a lesser extent, trombe walls. Newer developments are based on materials exhibiting high light transmission and good heat insulation properties. Such materials can be used as outside insulation of old building stock and offer prospects for significant energy savings. © 1985 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Zwingmann W., Schindler K., Birn J.
Title: On sheared magnetic field structures containing neutral points
Affiliations: Theoretische Physik IV, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Bochum, 4630, Germany; Los Alamos Nat. Lab., Los Alamos, 87545, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zwingmann, W., Theoretische Physik IV, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Bochum, 4630, Germany; Schindler, K., Theoretische Physik IV, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Bochum, 4630, Germany; Birn, J., Los Alamos Nat. Lab., Los Alamos, 87545, NM, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the occurence of current sheets near the separatrix in sheared magnetic field structures containing an x-type neutral point, as suggested by a number of previous authors. Our approach is based on selfconsistent theory. In analogy to the theory of quasistatic convection by Grad, we interpret the break-down of the quasistatic theory near the separatrix as evidence for the occurence of a boundary layer. In particular, this picture suggests large (however integrable) current sheets, with the current flowing parallel to the poloidal magnetic field. This concept is also tested by numerical computations. Here the discretization procedure simulates those physical effects that in a real case would keep the current from becoming infinitely large. The results fully confirm the formation of current sheets. Our findings have potential applications to energy storage for solar flares and to the heating of the solar corona. © 1985 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: Materials aspects of solar energy use in buildings
Source title: Journal of Materials for Energy Systems
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, 87545, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moore, S.W., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, 87545, NM, United States; McFarland, R.D., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, 87545, NM, United States
Abstract: Advances in materials for solar energy utilization have the potential to produce large performance improvements (both present and future concepts) in use of solar energy or conservation. Because approximately one-third of the total national energy budget is consumed by buildings, solar and conservation improvements can have a large effect on our overall energy consumption. There have been a large number of materials research programs funded through the Department of Energy (DOE) in an attempt to expand the use of solar energy. These materials programs have covered the areas of sealants and gaskets, insulations, glazings, glazing- surface treatments, polymers, selective absorber surfaces, phase-change storage, and heat mirrors. In addition to developing the materials, a large effort has been directed toward determining the reliability and durability of solar materials. The present state-of-the-art and status of these solar materials will be discussed. Although much progress has been made in recent years, many improvements are still needed. For many of the more routine materials, simple cost reductions or durability improvements would suffice. For the more advanced concepts of controlling energy flow into or out of buildings, basic materials research remains a necessity. There are a large number of potentially viable concepts that appear promising, but which have not yet been developed into usable materials. © 1985 American society for metals.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Heating; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEATING - Solar; ENERGY SAVINGS; GLAZING MATERIALS; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Thomas Ronald L., Hallinan George J., Hieatt James L.
Title: ELECTRIC POWER: PHOTOVOLTAIC OR SOLAR DYNAMIC?
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space, Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, Ronald L., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space, Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA; Hallinan, George J., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space, Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA; Hieatt, James L., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space, Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Space Systems Office, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Electric power will be the lifeblood of the space station, and definition of the entire station hinges on design of the system for generating and distributing it. The major technical issue is whether, from an overall systems integration, cost, and growth viewpoint, solar-generated power is best supplied by photovoltaic (PV) arrays or by a solar dynamic (heat engine) system. Photovoltaic technology is well developed and proven, but projected costs would be higher than those estimated for the less well-defined solar dynamic system. PV's major limitation is its low overall efficiency, resulting from 11-16% solar-cell efficiency and 55-65% electrochemical energy storage efficiency. Hence the solar array must have a large area, which significantly affects station dynamics, control, and drag compensation. Solar dynamic systems have higher overall efficiency and therefore need less deployed area. However, since the solar dynamic technology is still in its infancy, it is not certain whether it is possible to count on its successful development.
Index Keywords: FUEL CELLS - Electrolytes; HEAT ENGINES - Design; SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; SPACE PLATFORMS

Authors: Dietz E., Braun W., Bradshaw A.M., Johnson R.L.
Title: A high flux toroidal grating monochromator for the soft X-ray region
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Max-Planck-Institut für Festkörperforschung, Heisenbergstr. 1, D-7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dietz, E., Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Braun, W., Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Bradshaw, A.M., Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Johnson, R.L., Max-Planck-Institut für Festkörperforschung, Heisenbergstr. 1, D-7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Abstract: A toroidal grating monochromator designed for operation in the soft X-ray region at the synchrotron radiation source BESSY is described. With three in situ interchangeable gratings the instrument covers the spectral range 180 to 1150 eV. The current (source size-limited) resolution is 0.39, 0.7 and 2.6 eV at photon energies of 250, 400 and 800 eV, respectively. The photon flux is typically 8 × 1011 photons s-1 (100 mA)-1 (Δ h {combining short stroke overlay}ω)-1. Photoemission experiments on free molecules and on solid surfaces have been used to demonstrate the performance of the monochromator. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; BESSY; RESOLUTION; TOROIDAL GRATING; MONOCHROMATORS

Title: ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY OF ENERGY STORAGE FOR RURAL AND MUNICIPAL UTILITIES.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Prior to this project, many screening studies indicated the potential benefits of compressed-air energy storage (CAES) and advanced battery storage technologies to municipal and rural utilities. To test this preliminary finding, three utilities - Alabama Electric Cooperative, Lincoln Electric System, and Oglethorpe Power Corporation - agreed to cofund this study and to contribute substantial manpower. The intent of the project was to critically assess the benefits of CAES and advanced batteries under real circumstances and to derive results that could be used by utilities applying for project financing.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, STORAGE - Applications; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Planning; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; ADVANCED BATTERY STORAGE TECHNOLOGIES; COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE (CAES); PROJECT FINANCING; RURAL AND MUNICIPAL UTILITIES; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Title: DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING OF A LARGE LITHIUM MOLYBDENUM DISULFIDE BATTERY.
Source title: Research and Development Report - Canadian Electrical Association
Affiliations: Moli Energy Ltd, Vancouver, BC, Can, Moli Energy Ltd, Vancouver, BC, Can
Authors with affiliations: Anon, Moli Energy Ltd, Vancouver, BC, Can, Moli Energy Ltd, Vancouver, BC, Can
Abstract: The objective of this project was to demonstrate the feasibility of the scale-up of the lithium molybdenum disulfide ambient temperature rechargeable battery technology to a . 5 kWh storage battery. Using technology developed for 'C' size cells, 50 Ah cells were constructed and tested. With a battery consisting of 6 cells in series, an energy storage capacity of 686 Wh, a gravimetric energy density of 94 Wh/kg, and a peak power density of 128 W/kg were demonstrated. It was concluded that this technology, with some further improvements, is suitable for traction applications such as electric vehicles.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; . 5 KWH STORAGE BATTERY; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; LITHIUM MOLYBDENUM DISULFIDE BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: PROBLEMS OF HYDROGEOLOGY WHEN STUDYING WATER RESOURCES IN THE BOWELS OF THE EARTH.
Affiliations: All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Hydrogeology & Engineering, Geology, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Hydrogeology & Engineering Geology, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Kiselev, P.A., All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Hydrogeology & Engineering, Geology, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Hydrogeology & Engineering Geology, USSR; Tolstoi, M.P., All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Hydrogeology & Engineering, Geology, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Hydrogeology & Engineering Geology, USSR
Abstract: Hydrogeology studies all types of water contained in the lithosphere and mantle, history of their formation, composition, dynamics, storage, regime, and interaction with rocks. The total amount of natural water in the bowels of the earth - liquid, in the form of ice, vapor related to biomass and rocks - is a function of geological time. It has a regime of variation which is determined both by the course of diverse processes inside and on the surface of earth, in the biosphere, in space. Global mass and energy exchange and mass and energy transport occur. The rates of the interconversion processes are different in different parts of the section of the lithosphere and mantle. The structure of the phase states of water also changes with increase of depth, pressure, and temperature. Problems of the replenishment and reproduction (storage) of subsurface waters are acquiring particular importance. Investigations of the conservation of the earth's water resources are included in this important direction of hydrogeology. Among the most important directions of general and regional hydrogeology for fulfilling the Food and Energy Programs in the twelfth and subsequent Five-Year Plans, are a study of subsurface waters of the biosphere and, in particular, the upper stages of the earth's crust; a study of subsurface waters of deeper hydrodynamic stages of the crust and upper mantle.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; WATER RESOURCES - Analysis; WATER, UNDERGROUND; HYDROGEOLOGY; GEOLOGY

Title: FOURIER TRANSFORM MECHANICAL ANALYSIS TECHNIQUE FOR DETERMINING NON-LINEAR DYNAMIC VISCOELASTIC BEHAVIOR OF POLYMERS.
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Philip Morris Research Cent,, Richmond, VA, USA, Philip Morris Research Cent, Richmond, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ganeriwala, S.N., Philip Morris Research Cent,, Richmond, VA, USA, Philip Morris Research Cent, Richmond, VA, USA; Rotz, C.A., Philip Morris Research Cent,, Richmond, VA, USA, Philip Morris Research Cent, Richmond, VA, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the use of digital spectral techniques, hereafter referred to as Fourier Transform Mechanical Analysis (FTMA), to study the non-linear dynamic viscoelastic properties of polymers. The FTMA method to measure the linear dynamic viscoelastic properties of polymers over a broad range of frequency in one test have been reported by the authors. The first three terms of the general multiple integral constitutive equation derived by the Green and Rivlin were used to model the one-dimensional shear behavior of polymers. The energy dissipation mechanism and physical meanings of terms in the above model are also discussed here.
Index Keywords: RUBBER - Mechanical Properties; DIGITAL SPECTRAL TECHNIQUES; NON-LINEAR PROPERTIES; SHEAR BEHAVIOR; STORAGE MODULUS; ELASTOMERS

Title: SALT-GRADIENT POND ADVANCES USEFUL SOLAR-ENERGY STORAGE.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Salt-gradient solar ponds are beginning to attract international attention as a fairly simple, but effective, technology for collecting and storing solar energy. The most serious remaining problem is how to cut cost and effort of maintaining the upper boundary of the central, insulating layer of salt-water. This article, adapted from the LOGOS bulletin published by Argonne's Components Technology Division, addresses this problem.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Plastics Applications; WATER RESOURCES - Saline Water; SALT-GRADIENT POND; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: NEW ELECTRIC POWER TECHNOLOGIES - PROBLEMS AND PROSPECTS FOR THE 1990s.
Affiliations: Congress of the US, Office of, Technology Assessment, Washington,, DC, USA, Congress of the US, Office of Technology Assessment, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Anon, Congress of the US, Office of, Technology Assessment, Washington,, DC, USA, Congress of the US, Office of Technology Assessment, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: A recent report by the OTA reviews a number of alternative generating technologies, examining their technical readiness and the conditions under which they could contribute to meeting electricity demand in the 1990s. (Not included in the study are advanced nuclear or combined-cycle systems, or more mature renewable technologies such as low-head hydropower or refuse- or wood-fired steam plants. ) While the complete study reviews two basic groups of technologies - the first, primarily for direct utility applications, the second, those suitable for either utilities or non-utilities - only the latter group are discussed here as being of primary interest to the readers of this journal. (Author asbstract)
Index Keywords: COGENERATION PLANTS; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Planning; FUEL CELLS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SOLAR ENERGY; ATMOSPHERIC FLUID BED COMBUSTORS; BATTERIES; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; PUBLIC UTILITIES REGULATORY POLICIES ACT (PURPA); WIND ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: ANTIMATTER PROPULSION FOR SPACE EXPLORATION.
Source title: JBIS. Journal of the British Interplanetary Society
Affiliations: Telespazio SpA, Rome, Italy, Telespazio SpA, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Vulpetti, Giovanni, Telespazio SpA, Rome, Italy, Telespazio SpA, Rome, Italy
Abstract: This is chiefly a review paper with additional considerations and suggestions about aspects of matter-antimatter propulsion for space exploration. The paper is divided into six main sections. In the first section the fundamentals of the low-energy antiproton-nucleon annihilation physics are presented. In the second section geocentric, interplanetary and interstellar flights possible by means of antimatter engines are reviewed. In the third section the big problems related to the antimatter handling (production, storage, control) are discussed. In the fourth section proposed matter-antimatter thruster design concepts for Earth-space, interplanetary and out-of-Solar-System missions are examined and some results from computer simulations are discussed. In the fifth section a comparative cost between antimatter-based engines and conventional engines is made. Finally, aspects of a world-wide cooperation to try to make antimatter propulsion a reality are pointed out.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Aerospace Applications; ANTIMATTER HANDLING; ANTIMATTER PROPULSION; ANTIPROTON-NUCLEON ANNIHILATION; INTERSTELLAR FLIGHTS; SPACE EXPLORATION; SPACE FLIGHT

Title: SUBNANOSECOND HIGH-CURRENT ELECTRON ACCELERATOR.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Authors with affiliations: Zheltov, K.A.; Petrenko, A.N.
Abstract: A single-charge electron accelerator with double high-voltage-pulse peaking and a short storage line that is switched by a discharger with two high-surge spark gaps is described. The electron-current pulse has a rise time of 0. 12 nsec; the half-amplitude duration is 0. 25 nsec, the peak current is approx. 10 ka, and the maximum elctron energy is approx. 300 kev.

Abstract: The effect of ageing for a period of two years upon chemically pre-oxidized and irradiated cellulose was investigated. Changes in the chemical structure and energy excitation of atomic groups of oxycellulose skeleton were evaluated from the qualitative and quantitative points of view. The numerical interpretation and complex comparison of the quantities (activation energy, energy quantity EW, values of the thermal effect (areas of DTA peaks) and weight losses) of four degradation phases of pyrolysis were employed, when applying the oxidation pyrolysis method with derivatograph. © 1985 Wiley Heyden Ltd., Chichester and Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest.

Abstract: An independent battery-powered supply for an electric-discharge magnetic pump for maintaining a high vacuum is described. Abstract: A high-voltage frequency-pulse generator with inductive energy storage is described. Current cutoff is accomplished by a two-stage switching circuit, which is implemented by a high-voltage thyristor unit and electron tubes. The generator outputs to a nonlinear load pulses with U equals 50 kv, I equals 800 A, a duration of greater than equivalent to 1 msec, a rise time of less than equivalent to 5 mu sec, a fall time of less than equivalent to 20 mu sec, and a repetition rate to 100 Hz.
