Title: A possible energetic role of mineral surfaces in chemical evolution
Source title: Origins of Life and Evolution of the Biosphere
Affiliations: Dept. of Chemistry, San Jose State University, NASA Ames Research Center, Mail Stop 239-12, Moffett Field, 94035, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coyne, L.M., Dept. of Chemistry, San Jose State University, NASA Ames Research Center, Mail Stop 239-12, Moffett Field, 94035, CA, United States
Abstract: The postulated roles of clays and other minerals in chemical evolution and the origin of life are reconsidered in terms of the interaction of these minerals with penetrating sources of energy such as ionizing radiation and mechanical stress. This interaction, including such facets as excitation, degradation, storage, and transfer, is considered here with regard to its profound potential for altering the capabilities of minerals to serve both as substrates for prebiological chemistry and as inorganic prototypic life forms. The interaction of minerals and energy in relationship to surface chemistry is discussed in terms of the spectroscopic properties of minerals, the interaction of energy with condensed phases, some commonly accepted concepts of heterogeneous catalysis in the absence of electronic energy inputs, and some commonly accepted and novel means by which surface activity might be enhanced in the presence of energy inputs. An estimation is made of the potential contribution of two poorly characterized prebiotic energy sources, natural radioactive decay and triboelectric energy. These estimates place a conservative lower limit on their prebiotic abundance. Also some special properties of these energy sources, relative to solar energy, are pointed out which might give them particular suitability for driving reactions occurring under geological conditions. Skeletal support for this broadly defined framework of demonstrated and potential relationships between minerals, electronic excitation, and surface reactivity, as applied to chemical evolution, is provided from the results of our studies on 1/1 clays. We have discovered and partially characterized a number of novel luminescent properties of these clays, that indicate energy storage and transfer processes in clays. These luminescent properties are interpreted in relationship to the electron spin resonance phenomena, to provide a basis for estimating the potential significance of energy storage and transduction in monitoring or driving clay surface chemistry. Consideration of the electronic structure of abundant minerals in terms of band theory and localized defect centers provides a predictive theoretical framework from which to rationalize the capacity of these materials to store and transduce energy. The bulk crystal is seen as a collecting antenna for electronic energy, with the defect centers serving as storage sites. The clay properties produced by isomorphic substitution appear to be intimately associated with all of the life-mimetic chemical processes that have been attributed to clays. It appears sensible to postulate that the energetic properties of these substitutional defect centers may also be influential in these biomimetic processes: the promotion of surface reactions, storage of information, replication with transfer of information, and asymmetric separation of electrical charges, as well as their more recently hypothesized roles in energy storage and transduction. The identity of the sites implicated in all of the biomimetic functions of clays as well as their capacity for energy storage is seen to offer significant potential for coupling these functions to an environmental energy source. A yet more specific and experimentally testable hypothesis is offered for a new biomimetic process performed by clays. This hypothesis is that energy stored near isomorphically substituted sites provides the energetic basis for the coupled transport of electrical charge and/or electronic energy through the clay layer, which operates via environmental activation of electron/hole mobility. This is to say that mobility of charge/electronic excitation between defect centers serves as the basis for a primordial inorganic electron transport chain. © 1985 D. Reidel Publishing Company.
Index Keywords: kaolin; mineral; biogenesis; biological model; chemistry; energy transfer; photochemistry; review; Biogenesis; Chemistry; Energy Transfer; Kaolin; Minerals; Models, Biological; Photochemistry

Authors: Kim K.-J., Bisognano J.J., Garren A.A., Halbach K., Peterson J.M.
Title: Issues in storage-ring design for operation of high-gain FEL
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94702, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, K.-J., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94702, United States; Bisognano, J.J., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94702, United States; Garren, A.A., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94702, United States; Halbach, K., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94702, United States; Peterson, J.M., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94702, United States
Abstract: A high-gain free electron laser (FEL), placed in a special by-pass of a storage ring, can provide tens of megawatts of coherent power at wavelengths shorter than 1000 Å. The requirements on beam quality (few hundred amperes of peak current, emittance of the order of 10-8 m·rad, and relative energy spread less than 0.002), are demanding but lie within the limits of modern storage ring technology. In this paper, we study various issues in storage ring design and FEL physics for operation of a high-gain FEL. Topics included are the requirements on beam parameters for FEL operation, coherent instabilities and intrabeam scattering effects in the storage ring, lattice design, and FEL performance computed by 2-D simulations. © 1985.

Title: Current and current density limitations in existing electron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Centre d'Orsay, Bât. 200, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Le Duff, J., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Centre d'Orsay, Bât. 200, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: Storage rings dedicated for synchrotron light sources must show good beam performances in order to obtain high flux and brilliance. In particular bunch length, energy spread, beam intensity and transverse emittances have to satisfy special requirements. We intend here to briefly overview twenty years of experience obtained with small and medium size storage rings which were initially built as high energy physics facilities. The limiting effects will be extensively discussed by comparing theoretical models with systematic experimental studies. The possible means to remedy the inconveniences are also mentioned. © 1985.

Authors: Carpentier R., Nakatani H.Y., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Photoacoustic detection of energy conversion in a Photosystem II submembrane preparation from spinach
Affiliations: Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Carpentier, R., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Nakatani, H.Y., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: Photoacoustic spectroscopy has been used to monitor the energy conversion in Photosystem II submembrane fractions isolated from spinach. The extent of detected photochemistry was studied as a function of the modulated light intensity. Half of the reaction centers were saturated at an intensity of 0.5 W·m-2. However, the energy storage yield extrapolated to a modulated light intensity of zero was comparable to the yields reported for chloroplasts or algae. It is suggested that the molecular component responsible for the energy storage detected by photoacoustics at a modulation frequency of 35 Hz is located at the level of electron transport. © 1985.
Author Keywords: (Spinach chloroplast); Electron transport; Energy conversion; Photoacoustic spectroscopy; Photosynthesis; Photosystem II

Title: GAS UTILIZATION IN NIGERIA: OVERVIEW ON GAS REINJECTION PROSPECTS FOR PRESSURE MAINTENANCE AND UNDERGROUND STORAGE.
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, (Paper) SPE
Affiliations: Nigerian Agip Oil Co, Port Harcourt, Nigeria, Nigerian Agip Oil Co, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ezeudembah, Agodi S., Nigerian Agip Oil Co, Port Harcourt, Nigeria, Nigerian Agip Oil Co, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Abstract: Gas reinjection procedures, for pressure maintenance, cycling, and underground storage purposes, form an aspect of gas utilization mainly for enhanced primary oil recovery. This paper aims at stimulating interest in the judicious use of Nigeria's gas to economic advantage in terms of revenue earning and motive energy for better oil recovery through gas reinjection. To effect this objective, a general overview treats the reservoir, the energy and drive mechanisms as well as the importance of data acquisition on reservoir development.
Index Keywords: NATURAL GAS PIPELINES; DATA ON RESERVOIR; ENHANCED RECOVERY; FLARING; GAS HANDLING; NATURAL GAS WELLS

Title: X-e- coincidence Mössbauer scattering experiment
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Jagellonian University, Reymonta 4, 30-059 Cracow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Bara, J.J., Institute of Physics, Jagellonian University, Reymonta 4, 30-059 Cracow, Poland; Bogacz, B.F., Institute of Physics, Jagellonian University, Reymonta 4, 30-059 Cracow, Poland
Abstract: The energy resolution of an He/CH4 flow proportional counter is determined for 6.36 keV electrons. The 57Fe K-shell conversion-electron contribution to a beam of backscattered electrons is separated by application, in the geometry close to 4π-2π, of the X-e- coincidence technique. A reduction of electron beam intensity caused by the application of the X-e- coincidence technique results in a prolongation of spectrum storage time by a factor of 2.82. The coincidence technique efficiently reduces the detector background and thus increases the magnitude of the Mössbauer effect. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONS - Scattering; SPECTROSCOPY, MOSSBAUER; ENERGY RESOLUTION; MOSSBAUER EFFECT; PROPORTIONAL COUNTERS

Title: COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL RESPONSE TO TIME-OF-USE RATES.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EA
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A methodology using economic-engineering analyses which provides a framework for predicting the response of utility customers in the industrial and commercial sectors to time-of-use rates is presented. Data on the energy costs and production processes of several industrial and commercial customers and on utility factors such as TOU rates were compiled. Economic-engineering models for industrial facilities were developed based on two case studies: one for a cement plant, the other for a chlor-alkali plant. A model of thermal energy storage (TES) options for plant-cooling systems was developed and the impact of TOU rates on two other conservation options - high-efficiency lighting and energy management systems, was evaluated. Model simulations identified the practical limits of using TOU rates to shape electrical loads in three technologies and demonstrated the advantages of several plant equipment systems and operating strategies under various economic conditions.
Index Keywords: CEMENT PLANTS - Electric Power; CHEMICAL PLANTS - Electric Power; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY STORAGE; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS - Electric Power; CHLOR-ALKALI PLANTS; MODEL SIMULATIONS; PLANT-COOLING SYSTEMS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; TIME-OF-USE RATES; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Title: DESIGN AND COST OF STANDARDIZED LEAD-ACID BATTERY SYSTEMS FOR UTILITY ENERGY MANAGEMENT.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The earlier phases of this four-phase study showed that commercially available lead-acid battery storage systems used with solid-state converters could be an economically and technically successful method of load management. These systems function by reducing industrial and commercial customers' power requirements during times of peak demand. It is pointed out that both utilities and their customers can benefit from using commercially available lead-acid battery systems for peak shaving and load management. With sufficient orders, design standardization can lower the overall costs of such battery systems by 30%.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; CUSTOMER-SIDE LOAD CONTROL; LEAD-ACID BATTERY; PEAK LOAD PRICING; PEAK SHAVING; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Title: Design Facades for Universal Creative Application. [DESIGNFASSADEN FUER UNIVERSELLE GESTALTUNGSMOEGLICHKEITEN.]
Authors with affiliations: Leimboeck, Rudolf
Abstract: It should be the aim of each modern building concept to eliminate the contradiction between economical restrictions and the quality of the design. Public and private building contractors are demanding nowadays more than eficiency and economy. Commercial buildings radiate once again self-confidence, individuality and a sense of social responsibility. Architects have always been ready to seek interesting architectural and urban design solutions to commercial and industrial building structures, but were frequently hindered to realize these plans by all too strick specificaions. The advantages of the technique employed and the particular physical properties of the Hebel material are evident also in the Design facade. The cost-effective erection method speeds up the construction work process; highly-effective thermal insulation results in noticeable energy saving; heat storage and diffusion behavior ensure a healthy indore climate. In addition there is the stability in value for solid construction parts; high sound insulation, good sound absorption, and the fact that the material is fire proof.
Index Keywords: ARCHITECTURE - Design; CONCRETE - Light Weight; CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY - Economics; COST-EFFECTIVE BUILDINGS; FACADE CREATIVE DESIGN; GAS CONCRETE PRODUCTS; BUILDINGS

Title: STEADY STATE RESPONSE OF AN ELASTIC HALF SPACE CONTAINING A POINT SOURCE OF HEAT.
Source title: Res Rep Univ Sydney Sch Civ Min Eng
Authors with affiliations: Booker, J.R.; Carter, J.P.
Abstract: Closed form solutions are presented for the steady state distributions of temperature, displacement and stress around a point source of heat embedded in a homogeneous, isotropic elastic half space. These solutions have been evaluated for a typical case of a heat source buried in rock and quantities such as the heave of the ground surface and the maximum horizontal tensile stress at the surface have been estimated.

Title: SHARP EL512 CALCULATOR HELPS SIZE ACCUMULATORS: PART 1 - SUPPLEMENTING PUMP FLOW, AUXILIARY POWER SOURCE, ENERGY STORAGE, HOLDING PRESSURE, AND LEAKAGE COMPENSATION.
Affiliations: Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough,, NC, USA, Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Flippo, W.T., Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough,, NC, USA, Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough, NC, USA
Abstract: Dry nitrogen should be used to charge hydropneumatic accumulators to prevent corrosion and oxidation. Because nitrogen's compressibility factor changes at higher pressures and temperatures, and because most applications compress the accumulator gas to high pressure and temperature, care must be taken when sizing accumulators because their gas charge will not behave as predicted by the ideal gas laws. This article explains the programming of a calculator to size accumulators, taking into consideration pump flow, auxiliary power, energy storage, holding pressure, and leakage compensation.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS; HYDRAULIC MACHINERY; MATHEMATICAL INSTRUMENTS - Pocket Calculators; PUMPS; PROGRAMMING; HYDRAULIC ACCUMULATORS

Title: The dietary management of inborn errors of metabolism.
Authors with affiliations: Collins, J.E.; Leonard, J.V.
Abstract: Many inborn errors have now been described that can be treated by alterations in diet. Such treatment requires an understanding of both the biochemistry of the defect and of normal nutritional requirements. The principal strategies are cofactor therapy, steps to prevent accumulation of toxic metabolites and the replacement of essential nutrients that are deficient as a result of the metabolic block. It is essential to make sure that any diet used for more than a brief period is complete and capable of sustaining normal growth and development. The treatment of disorders of carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism including organic acidaemias and disorders of the urea cycle and of fat oxidation are discussed.

Title: Elemental sulfur in the gills of three species of clams containing chemoautotrophic symbiotic bacteria: a possible inorganic energy storage compound
Affiliations: Marine Biology Research Division, A-002, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, La Jolla, 92093, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vetter, R.D., Marine Biology Research Division, A-002, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, La Jolla, 92093, California, United States
Abstract: Sulfur content and fine structure were studied for tissues of three species of clams, Lucinoma annulata, Calyptogena elongata and Lucina floridana, which inhabit sulfide-rich environments and whose gills harbor symbiotic sulfur bacteria. Lucinoma annulata and C. elongata were dredged from the Santa Barbara basin, California, USA, at a depth of 480 to 490 m, and Lucina floridana were dug from below the roots of seagrasses in Saint Joseph Bay, Florida, at a depth of 0.25 to 2m. Foot tissue of Lucinoma annulata, without symbionts, had a total sulfur content of 1.4±0.1 (SD) mg 100 mg-1 dry weight of tissue (%DW). The symbiont-containing gill tissue of different individuals of L. annulata varied in color from dark red to pale yellow, and the total sulfur content was 2.5±0.4% DW in red gills and was 5.6±3.3 % DW in the yellowest gills. Maintenance of L. annulata in the laboratory for 21 d in the absence of sulfide resulted in the loss from the gill of yellow deposits which were elemental sulfur in the form of liquid-crystalline sulfur globules rather than solid orthorhombic sulfur crystals. The foot tissue did not contain elemental sulfur. When examined by freeze-etch microscopy, sulfur globules were found only within bacteria and not in the animal host cytoplasm. Sulfur globules were confined to the periplasmic space of the bacteria. C. elongata and Lucina floridana resembled Lucinoma annulata in the physical form and distribution of elemental sulfur. The absence of elemental sulfur in the animal cytoplasm suggests that its formation from sulfide is not a detoxification scheme to protect animal tissue from sulfide toxicity. The sulfur deposits probably represent inorganic energy reserves that permit the symbiotic bacteria to function even during the temporary absence of external sulfide. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Study of image structure in the focal plane in microphotolithography system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept of Precision Instruments, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Duanyi, X., Dept of Precision Instruments, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: Optical projection microlithography for fabricating fine line and optical data storage technique have extended into submicron region. But many new technical problems will be appeared in transferring such exacting structure by optical method. One of the important subjects is the investigation of the light energy distribution on focal plane. this paper described the experimental results using an automatic focusing system which was produced by Tsinghua Univ. within +0.1u accurasy. Those have been compared with the calculating results of perfect lens and residual aberration system, and the relation of them was also discussed. © 1985 SPIE.

Authors: Canaani O., Motzan Z., Malkin S.
Title: Comparison of photosynthetic parameters of an aurea mutant (Su/su) of tobacco and the wild-type by the photoacoustic method
Affiliations: Biochemistry Department, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Canaani, O., Biochemistry Department, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Motzan, Z., Biochemistry Department, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Malkin, S., Biochemistry Department, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Abstract: Oxygen evolution and energy storage yields in tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum L.) wild-type (cv. John Williams Broadleaf) and a mutant (Su/su) deficient in chlorophyll were compared using the photoacoustic technique. Oxygen-evolution and energy-storage quantum yields in the mutant were higher when measured in red light (640-690 nm) than green or blue light (540 nm and 440 nm, respectively), indicating that carotenoids in this mutant do not transfer energy efficiently to the photochemical reaction centers. It is suggested that carotenoids may play a role in protecting the photosynthetic apparatus against damage by high energy fluxes. In the wild-type, the oxygenevolution yield did not change drastically throughout the visible spectrum. The mutant had a higher quantum yield of oxygen evolution than the wildtype. Similarly maximum rates obtained from saturation curves for the mutant were more than twice higher per leaf area and about five times higher per chlorophyll, as compared to the wild-type. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Blue drop; Mutant (Nicotiana); Nicotiana (aurea mutant); Photoacoustics; Photosynthesis (oxygen evolution, energy-storage yield)

Authors: Doyle J.G., Byrne P.B., Dennis B.R., Emslie A.G., Poland A.I., Simnett G.M.
Title: Energetics of a double flare on November 8, 1980
Affiliations: Armagh Observatory, Armagh, BT61 9DG, United Kingdom; Laboratory for Astronomy and Solar Physics, NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, 20771, MD, United States; Dept. of Physics, University of Alabama, Huntsville, 35899, AL, United States; Dept. of Space Research, University of Birmingham, P.O. Box 363, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Doyle, J.G., Armagh Observatory, Armagh, BT61 9DG, United Kingdom; Byrne, P.B., Armagh Observatory, Armagh, BT61 9DG, United Kingdom; Dennis, B.R., Laboratory for Astronomy and Solar Physics, NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, 20771, MD, United States; Emslie, A.G., Dept. of Physics, University of Alabama, Huntsville, 35899, AL, United States; Poland, A.I., Laboratory for Astronomy and Solar Physics, NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, 20771, MD, United States; Simnett, G.M., Dept. of Space Research, University of Birmingham, P.O. Box 363, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Here we complete an energy balance analysis of a double impulsive hard X-ray flare. From spatial observations, we deduce both flares probably occur in the same loop within the resolution of the data. For the first flare, the energy in the fast electrons (assuming a thick-target model) is comparable to the convective up-flow energy, suggesting that these are related successive modes of energy storage and transfer. The total energy lost through radiation and conduction, 2.0 × 1028 erg, is comparable to the energy in fast electrons 2.5 × 1028 erg. For the second flare, the energy in the fast electrons is more than one order of magnitude greater than the energy of the convective up-flow. Total energy losses are within a factor of two lower than the calculated fast electron energy. We interpret the observations as showing that the first flare occurred in a small loop with fast electrons heating the chromosphere and resulting in chromospheric evaporation increasing the density in the loop. For the second flare most of the heating occurred at the electron acceleration site. The two symmetrical components of the Ca xix resonance line and a high velocity down-flow of 115 km s -1 observed at the end of the second hard X-ray burst are consistent with the flare eruption (reconnection) region being high in the flare loop. The estimated altitude of the acceleration site is 5500 km above the photosphere. © 1985 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: Thermal dependence of isotonic contractile properties of skeletal muscle and sprint performance of the lizard Dipsosaurus dorsalis
Affiliations: Department of Developmental and Cell Biology, University of California, Irvine, 92717, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marsh, R.L., Department of Developmental and Cell Biology, University of California, Irvine, 92717, California, United States; Bennett, A.F., Department of Developmental and Cell Biology, University of California, Irvine, 92717, California, United States
Abstract: 1. Contractile properties of the fasttwitch glycolytic (FG) portion of the iliofibularis muslce and sprint running performance were studied at approximately 5°C intervals from 15-44°C in the lizard Dipsosaurus dorsalis. 2. Maximal running velocity (VR) and stride frequency (f) were both greatest when body temperature (Tb) was 40°C, the field-active, Tb in Dipsosaurus. At 40°C VR was 4.3±0.2 m/s and f was 13.5±0.5 s-1. 3. Between 25 and 40°C, the thermal dependencies of VR and f were approximately constant (Q10's of 1.31 and 1.36 for VR and f, respectively). Below 25°C performance declined more markedly with decreasing temperature. At 20°C strides were qualitatively normal, but VR was only half of the value at 25°C. At 15°C the lizards were substantially incapacitated, and VR was 10% of the value at 20°C. Stride length was approximately 0.33m and changed very little with Tb from 20-44°C. 4. The time dependent contractile properties of FG muscle were affected more by temperature than was sprint performance. The maximal velocity of shortening at zero load (Vo) was 18.7 l0/s at 40°C and had a Q10 of 1.7 from 25-40°C. Maximal power output ( {Mathematical expression}) determined from the forcevelocity curve was 464 W/kg at 40°C. Below 40°C {Mathematical expression} varied with temperature with a Q10 of 2-3. The shape of the force-velocity curve changed little with temperature ( {Mathematical expression}/POVO=0.11). 5. Between 25 and 40°C a relatively temperature-independent process must modulate the effects of temperature on the contractile properties of the muscles that supply the power for burst locomotion. Storage and recovery of elastic energy appears to be a likely candidate for such a process. 6. Below 25°C, however, the contraction time is prolonged to such an extent that the f attainable is limited by the minimum time taken to contract and relax the muscles. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: animal; article; body temperature; electrostimulation; lizard; locomotion; muscle; muscle contraction; muscle isometric contraction; physiology; Animal; Body Temperature; Electric Stimulation; Isometric Contraction; Lizards; Locomotion; Muscle Contraction; Muscles; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: CURRENT TRENDS IN COMMERCIAL COOL STORAGE.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Commercial cool storage installations, stimulated by utility marketing and incentive programs, have more than doubled in the past four years. This survey documents that growth, describing 85 recent installations and summarizing new designs and applications.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY STORAGE; CHILLED-WATER STORAGE; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; COOL STORAGE; ICE STORAGE; BUILDINGS

Title: ENERGY STORAGE USING LOW-PRESSURE FEEDWATER.
Source title: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
Affiliations: Duke Univ, Durham, NC, USA, Duke Univ, Durham, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Harman, C.M., Duke Univ, Durham, NC, USA, Duke Univ, Durham, NC, USA; Loesch, S., Duke Univ, Durham, NC, USA, Duke Univ, Durham, NC, USA
Abstract: A method for increasing the peak output of steam power plants through use of a low-pressure feedwater storage system is presented. The generalized availability analysis involves only the low-pressure turbine, low-pressure feedwater heaters, and the storage system. With daily cycling and storage charging at near base load conditions, the turnaround efficiency of the energy storage system was found to approach 100 percent. Storage system turnaround efficiency is decreased when the energy is stored during plant part-load operation.
Index Keywords: STEAM POWER PLANTS; FEEDWATER STORAGE; LOW PRESSURE FEEDWATER; FEEDWATER HEATERS

Title: CASE STUDIES IN TECHNOLOGY CHOICE.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EA
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: EPRI's technology choice model (TCM) offers an explicit way of incorporating factors that are hard to quantify into the decision-making process. Tests of this model show that it works well in a wide range of utility applications, from generation problems to fuel management issues. Volumes 3 (Georgia Power) and 4 (TVA) of this report present illustrative case studies that examine technology choice complexities including multiple objectives, uncertainties, and the need to consider public values. For example, the TVA case study showed how a preliminary application of TCM addressed two ways to deal with long-standing questions about the management of spent fuel. The Georgia Power study involved choices on generating peak power from an energy storage facility.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Mathematical Models; ENGINEERING - Public Policy; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; POWER GENERATION; POWER PLANTS; GEORGIA POWER STUDY; MANAGEMENT OF SPENT FUEL; PUBLIC ATTITUDES; TECHNOLOGY CHOICE MODEL; TVA STUDY; TECHNOLOGY

Authors: Kuhara Y., Terauchi H., Nishizawa H.
Title: RELIABILITY OF InGaAsInP LONG-WAVELENGTH P-I-N PHOTODIODES PASSIVATED WITH POLYIMIDE THIN FILM.
Affiliations: Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn, Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kuhara, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn, Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn; Terauchi, H., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn, Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn; Nishizawa, H., Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn, Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Osaka, Jpn
Abstract: The long-term reliability of InGaAs/InP p-i-n photodiodes passivated with polyimide thin film was studied by means of a room temperature life test and thermally accelerated life tests. No degradation in dark current was observed in a room temperature life test at a reverse bias of -15 V after aging for 7000 h. However, the dark current increased gradually in the accelerated life tests at 110 degree C, 130 degree C, and 150 degree C. It was found that the activation energy of degradation in dark current is 0. 85 eV and the average lifetime is estimated to be 10**7 h at room temperature. The dark current recovered in high temperature storage tests. The phenomenon of degradation and recovery is qualitatively explained by a model of accumulation and diffusion of mobile ions at a junction perimeter.

Title: Platelet metabolism and activation
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Holmsen, H., Department of Biochemistry, University of Bergen, Norway
Abstract: Stimulation and execution of platelet responses are intimately coupled to the cells' energy metabolism. The turnover of cytoplasmic ATP is higher than in most other cells; when it is lowered, platelet responses are powerfully inhibited. One-third of the total adenine nucleotides are present in the cytoplasm and a small fraction of these, 50% of the ADP, is bound to actin and not available to metabolism. These nucleotides are not synthesized de novo in platelets which readily form them from adenine, adenosine, and hypoxanthine. The remaining two-thirds are sequestred in the dense granules together with serotonin and divalent metal ions. NMR studies show that this ATP and ADP are stacked in large aggregates together with the divalent cations. Serotonin is incorporated into the aggregates by being positioned between, and in close proximity to, adjacent adenine rings. In the congenital platelet disorder, "Storage Pool Deficiency," the dense granule content is absent or markedly reduced, which may be caused by an impaired transport of ATP across the dense granule membrane. The content of the dense granules, the β-thromboglobulin, albumin, fibrinogen, certain coagulation factors, fibronectin of the α-granules, and the acid hydrolases of the lysosomes are discharged by exocytosis, but the exact mechanisms are not known. This discharge, platelet secretion, is complete for the dense granule and α-granules contents, but is only 30% to 55% for the acid hydrolases. After pretreatment of platelets with certain amines, thrombin causes secretion of all β-hexosaminidase, indicating that the β-hexosaminidase usually retained during secretion is bound within the lysosomes at the acid pH but becomes dissociated by raising the pH with the amines. Agonist-induced platelet aggregation and secretion are accompanied by rapid changes in phosphoinositide metabolism which are usually monitored as the radioactivity in phospholipids of platelets preincubated with radioactive arachidonate, glycerol, inositol, or orthophospate. The mechanisms for precursor incorporation are not well known and interpretations of published results are hampered by much uncertainty. Experimental support for the widely accepted coupling of receptor occupancy to the phospho-diesteratic hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol or phosphatidylinositol-4,5-biphosphate is nonexistent. These two hydrolytic steps occur concomitantly and together with formation of diglyceride and phosphatidate; all four steps cannot be temporally resolved. Another approach, with association-dissociation-reassociation of thrombin to its receptor with hirudin, indicates that the phosphatidate formation is tightly coupled with receptor occupancy. The 32P3H ratio of the phosphatidate formed by thrombin occupancy increases five- to seven-fold in platelets prelabeled with both 32P-orthophosphate and 3H-arachidonate. This heterogeneity can be explained by phosphorylation of two pools of diglyceride with different 3H content; one pool may be derived from phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate and the other from phosphatidylinositol. The disappearance of phosphatidylinositol is abolished by ATP deprivation suggesting a disappearance by two phosphorylations (to phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate) rather than by hydrolysis by phospholipase C. It is the bisphosphate that is hydrolyzed diesteratically and yields diglyceride. There is a transient decrease in the 32P-radioactivity of the bisphosphate followed by a marked increase in platelets pulse-labeled with 32P-orthophosphate; ATP deprivation has no effect on the decrease but abolishes the increase, which agrees with the above mechanism for diglyceride production. However, one would expect that all 32P of phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate would be consumed by ATP deprivation, but this is not the case. Apparently there is only a small fraction of the labeled phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate that participates in signal processing. Further understanding in this area clearly require more knowledge about the metabolism of the phosphoinositides in non-stimulated platelets. Cytoplasmic Ca2+ can mediate platelet responses and is made available through receptor occupancy. However, there is increasing evidence that other second messengers (ie, diglyceride and perhaps inositol-1,4,5-triphosphate) also mediate the responses and can act synergistically with Ca2+. Both substances are formed together in the diesteratic hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate. Ca2+ may originate from intracellular stores and or from the extracellular phase. A distinctly lower concentration of cytoplasmic Ca2+ is associated with the shape change response than with dense granule secretion, suggesting that the various responses may have different thresholds for Ca2+. Stimulated platelets provide several agonists (positive feedback) that may interact synergistically with the primary agonist, and it is presently unclear whether the potential second messengers are produced by one agonist only. © 1985.
Index Keywords: actin; adenine nucleotide; adenosine triphosphate; calcium; phosphatidylinositol; serotonin; animal; blood; cell compartmentalization; cell granule; energy metabolism; glycolysis; human; in vitro study; physiology; review; thrombocyte; Actins; Adenine Nucleotides; Adenosine Triphosphate; Animal; Blood Platelets; Calcium; Cell Compartmentation; Cytoplasmic Granules; Energy Metabolism; Glycolysis; Human; In Vitro; Phosphatidylinositols; Serotonin

Authors: Burgess E.M., Poggi M.L., Hittenberger D.A., Zettl J.H., Moeller D.E., Carpenter K.L., Forsgren S.M.
Title: Development and preliminary evaluation of the VA Seattle foot
Affiliations: Model and Instrument Works, Inc., Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burgess, E.M., Model and Instrument Works, Inc., Seattle, WA, United States; Poggi, M.L., Model and Instrument Works, Inc., Seattle, WA, United States; Hittenberger, D.A., Model and Instrument Works, Inc., Seattle, WA, United States; Zettl, J.H.; Moeller, D.E.; Carpenter, K.L.; Forsgren, S.M.
Abstract: A prosthetic foot is described, which consists of a monolithic composite keel engineered to store potential energy and release kinetic energy (force) during ground contact. Extensive clinical evaluation indicates high user acceptance. The present design is stabilized. Technology transfer for commercial availability has been carried out. The VA Seattle foot conceptually provides storage of potential energy and is converted to kinetic energy throughout the weight-bearing phase of the gait cycle. This stored energy is progressively released as the foot continues through the toe-off phase to rebound and propel the body forward. In simple terms, weight deflects the keel through a predetermined range, then the keel 'springs back' as weight is removed.
Index Keywords: VA SEATTLE FOOT; VETERANS ADMINISTRATION (VA); BIOMECHANICS - Biped Locomotion; BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING - Patient Rehabilitation; PROSTHETICS; below knee prosthesis; biomechanics; foot prosthesis; human; musculoskeletal system; nonbiological model; preliminary communication; sports medicine; therapy; Artificial Limbs; Consumer Satisfaction; Foot; Gait; Humans; Prosthesis Design; Running

Title: ULTRAVIOLET COHERENT GENERATION FROM AN OPTICAL KLYSTRON.

Abstract: The optical klystron, previously successfully optimized for the realization of free-electron laser (FEL) on the ACO (anneau de collisions d'Orsay) storage ring at Orsay, has been used as a nonlinear medium for producing harmonics of an external 1. 06 mu m Nd:YAG laser focused into it. Detailed experimental data are reported. A comparison with theoretical calculations shows very good qualitative and quantitative agreement between the experimental data and the theory. Three major points are emphasized: the input power dependence of the coherent emission, the spatial and spectral structure of the emitted light, and the effect of the energy spread.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON TUBES, KLYSTRON; LASERS, SOLID STATE; ENERGY SPREAD EFFECTS; OPTICAL KLYSTRON; UV COHERENT EMISSION; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION

Authors: Verkhovskii S.Ya., Lyulyaev A.V., Flat F.A.
Title: HIGH-POWER HIGH-VOLTAGE PULSE GENERATOR.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Verkhovskii, S.Ya., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR; Lyulyaev, A.V., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR; Flat, F.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of Applied Physics, Gorki, USSR
Abstract: A generator of millisecond pulses with power to 400 mw is described. The pulses are generated by discharging to a capacitive storage unit through a thyristor commutator. The capacitor of the storage unit is 0. 17 F and the stored energy is 1. 72 MJ. The 432 thyristors of the commutator are connected by a control unit consisting of cascaded pulse transformers. The thyristors operate in the current-overload mode.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, PULSE SIGNAL - Applications; THYRISTORS - Applications; CAPACITIVE STORAGE UNIT; CASCADED PULSE TRANSFORMERS; HIGH-VOLTAGE PULSE GENERATOR; MILLISECOND PULSES; THYRISTOR COMMUTATOR; PULSE GENERATORS

Title: ANALYSIS OF A NEW CONCEPT IN POWER PLANTS FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES.
Affiliations: Univ of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR,, USA, Univ of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR, USA
Authors with affiliations: Renfroe, D.A., Univ of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR,, USA, Univ of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR, USA
Abstract: There is a growing research effort at the University of Arkansas in the area of advanced heat engines. This paper discusses how this engine may be applied to replacing the battery/electric motor system of an electric car with a thermal energy storage system and a Stirling engine which utilizes a phase-changing component in the working fluid. As a part of this discussion the effect on total energy and oil consumption in the US is presented, if all of the cars were to utilize such a method of power. Also, the most recent results of the current research pertaining to the engine is presented, including the effects of water in the working fluid of a Stirling engine and the further effects of modifying the regenerator with a hydrated salt. Refs.
Index Keywords: AIR ENGINES; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; ELECTRIC/THERMAL STORAGE CAR; ENGINE OPERATION; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; VEHICLES

Title: A plan for an FEL experiment in the SOR-RING
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, 3-2-1, Midori-cho, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyahara, Y., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, 3-2-1, Midori-cho, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan
Abstract: A feasibility study of an FEL experiment planned in a 400 MeV electron storage ring, the SOR-RING is given. An undulator made of a SmCo permanent magnet will be installed in a straight section of the ring. Since the length of the section is as short as 1.1 m, the undulator is installed in a vacuum chamber to obtain an undulator period as many as possible for a higher FEL gain. The FEL is operated in the visible region at an electron beam energy of about 100 MeV with an expected gain of about 0.7% for a beam current of 100 mA. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; FEL GAIN; FREE ELECTRON LASER; SOR-RING; UNDULATOR; LASERS

Authors: Peterson J.M., Bisognano J.J., Garren A.A., Halbach K., Kim K.J., Sah R.C.
Title: A storage ring FEL for the VUV
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, J.M., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Bisognano, J.J., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Garren, A.A., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Halbach, K., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Kim, K.J., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Sah, R.C., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: A free electron laser for the VUV operating in a storage ring requires an electron beam of high density and low energy spread and a short wavelength, narrow-gap undulator. These conditions tend to produce longitudinal and transverse beam instabilities, excessive beam growth through multiple intra-beam scattering and a short gas-scattering lifetime. Passing the beam only occasionally through the undulator in a by-pass straight section, as proposed by Murphy and Pellegrini [1], allows operation in a high-gain, single-pass mode and a long gas-scattering lifetime. Several storage ring designs have been considered to see how best to satisfy the several requirements. Each features a by-pass, a low-emittance lattice and built-in wigglers for enhanced damping to counteract the intra-beam scattering. © 1985.
Index Keywords: LASERS; FREE ELECTRON LASERS; HIGH INTENSITY EFFECTS; UNDULATOR; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Ortega J.M., Elleaume P., Billardon M., Deacon D., Girard B., Lapierre Y.
Title: Energy spread measurements on the ACO storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electromagnétique, LP CNRS 008, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 209C, 91405 Orsay Cédex, France

Abstract: Absolute and relative energy spread measurements have been made on the ACO storage ring using two different methods. The first one consists of a spectral analysis of the electron bunch length based on the proportionality of the longitudinal bunch length versus energy spread. The second one constitutes a direct measurement using the on axis synchrotron radiation emitted by an optical klystron. The two measurement techniques present a very high signal/noise ratio allowing time resolved records. Examples are presented of the energy spread time evolution in the FEL oscillator and of harmonic generation experiments. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Beam Dynamics; ELECTRON BEAMS; BUNCH SPECTRAL ANALYSIS TECHNIQUE; ENERGY SPREAD; FREE ELECTRON LASER; STORAGE RING; LASERS

Abstract: Recent results obtained with the Orsay free electron laser are summarized in this paper. The laser oscillator was operated at two different wavelengths (6500 and 5800 Å) and at energies ranging from 166 MeV to 224 MeV. The main results presented here concern the Q-switched operation, the macro-temporal structure and the saturation mechanism of the storage ring free electron laser. © 1985.
