Abstract: A search has been made for particles with charge Q = 1 3, Q = 2 3 and Q = 4 3 produced in e+e- annihilation using the ARGUS detector at the e+e- storage ring DORIS, operating at a centre of mass energy around 10 GeV. No candidate events were found in 84.5 pb-1 of collected data. Upper limits are established for the cross section for the production of fractionally charged particles with masses up to 4 GeV c2, improving on previously obtained limits. © 1985.

Title: Tremiti Desalination Plant
Affiliations: c/o ltafenergie, 1-67039 Sulmona, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fonzi, F., c/o ltafenergie, 1-67039 Sulmona, Italy
Abstract: The Tremiti desalination plant assures the drinkable water supply to the lsland of S. Nicola in the Adriatic Sea. The system is a stand-alone plant for sea water desalination using the reverse osmosis process, energized by a photovoltaic power plant. A p.v, array gives a 65 kWp nominal peak power. DC/DC converters feed the main d.c. bus and the storage battery which assures the uninterrupted operation of the desalination plant during overcast periods. The total plant area is 5000 sq. m; 1800 of them covered by the p.v. field: The layout of the rows of modules has been designed to optimize the efficiency of the array subsystem, to minimize atmospheric overvoltage, and to assure easy operation and maintenance. Good fitting with the natural characteristics of land is obtained. The final solution of the supporting structure satisfies to the last Italian codes for seismic areas: Pv modules are bolted to galvanized steel beams supported by walls of vibrated concrete. The electric appliance load consists of a.c. induction motors driven by single inverters. The R.O plant produces about 5000 cu. m. of water with an average power requirement of 13 kWh/cu. m. A power flow supervisory system optimizes, in every possible operating condition and system status, the utilization of available energy. A data acquisition system monitors continuously the system and records the relevant parameters. © 1985, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: Biochemical fractionation of primary production by phytoplankton in Belgian coastal waters during short- and long-term incubations with 14C-bicarbonate - I. Mixed diatom population
Affiliations: Laboratoire d'Océanographie, Université Libre de Bruxelles, 50 Avenue F.D. Roosevelt, Bruxelles, B-1050, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Lancelot, C., Laboratoire d'Océanographie, Université Libre de Bruxelles, 50 Avenue F.D. Roosevelt, Bruxelles, B-1050, Belgium; Mathot, S., Laboratoire d'Océanographie, Université Libre de Bruxelles, 50 Avenue F.D. Roosevelt, Bruxelles, B-1050, Belgium
Abstract: Short- and long-term time course studies of radiocarbon accumulation in the intracellular end-products of photosynthesis (proteins, polysaccharides, lipids, small metabolites) and extracellular monomers and polymers were conducted at natural light intensity during a 24-h period in Belgian coastal waters dominated by large diatoms species in September, 1983. It is shown that carbon losses observed during the long-term incubation are due to the catabolism of reserve products (polysaccharides and lipids), which occurs both during the light and dark periods and provides carbon and energy for pursuing protein synthesis during the dark. Catabolism rates, as calculated by means of a simple mathematical model, indicate reduced rates of lipid catabolism (1-2% h-1, respectively for the light and dark periods), although polysaccharide catabolism proceeds at much higher rates, namely 20% h-1 during the light and 8% h-1 during the dark period. Assuming that protein synthesis proceeds at a constant rate during the 24-h period and that β 1-3 glucan constitutes the main storage product of this diatom population, it is shown that at least 65% of the gross primary production is catabolized by the cells. From this, only 16% are mobilized for dark protein synthesis. The remaining is respired, especially during the light period. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.

Title: The legs of ostriches (Struthio) and moas (Pachyornis)
Affiliations: Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Alexander, R.M., Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Abstract: Ostriches were filmed running at maximum speed, and forces on the feet were calculated. Measurements were made of the principal structures in the legs of an ostrich. Hence peak stresses in muscles, tendons and bones were calculated. They lay within the range of stresses calculated for strenuous activities of other vertebrates. The ostrich makes substantial savings of energy in running, by elastic storage in stretched tendons. Pachyornis was a flightless bird, much heavier than ostriches and with massively thick leg bones. These bones are shorter than predicted for its estimated body mass, by extrapolation from allometric equations for flying birds. An attempt is made to calculate the stresses that acted in the leg bones in running, for all possible patterns of leg movement. The stresses were probably rather low, unless Pachyornis was capable of running fast. It is argued that the optimum factor of safety for moo leg bones may have been exceptionally high, as a consequence of the absence of predators. © 1985 Martinus Nijhoff/Dr W. Junk Publishers.

Title: HYDRONIC ENERGY ECONOMICS.
Affiliations: Charles J. R. McClure &, Associates Inc, St. Louis, MO, USA, Charles J. R. McClure & Associates Inc, St. Louis, MO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Coad, William J., Charles J. R. McClure &, Associates Inc, St. Louis, MO, USA, Charles J. R. McClure & Associates Inc, St. Louis, MO, USA
Abstract: If one were to itemize the design characteristics of the ideal generic large chilled water system, the listing would likely include the following: Supply water temperature stays constant as the load changes. Both primary and auxiliary power requirements must be minimal. Primary refrigeration and refrigerating system power reduces with load reduction. Pumping power reduces with load reduction (ideally as the cube of the load). Comparative first cost must not be excessive. Should be capable of functioning in a chilled water storage mode. It has taken about 50 years or so in the evolution of chilled water systems for a system satisfying these requirements to evolve.
Index Keywords: COST ACCOUNTING - Analysis; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Pumps; CONTROL VALVE; HYDRAULIC SYSTEM; THERMAL LOADS; VARIABLE FLOW RATES; BUILDINGS

Authors: Kihara Motohiro, Hashimoto Hiroshi, Yoshida Shingo, Tanaka Toshio
Title: MAGNETS AND POWER SUPPLY SYSTEM OF 'PHOTON FACTORY'.
Affiliations: Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kihara, Motohiro, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Hashimoto, Hiroshi, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Yoshida, Shingo, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn; Tanaka, Toshio, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn, Ministry of Education, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Jpn
Abstract: In Japan, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics of the Ministry of Education is currently operating a dedicated synchrotron radiation facility termed the 'Photon Factory'. For generating photons, high energy (high speed) electrons transmitted from a linear accelerator (linac) are stably stored in a circular orbit of the electron storage ring for a long period of time. For this purpose, bending magnets to deflect the beam and quadrupole magnets to focus the beam are installed along the electron orbit. Hitachi manufactured the magnet and power supply system for the Photon Factory. The technological details of these components are described in this article.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, LINEAR; ELECTRIC POWER SUPPLIES TO APPARATUS; ELECTROMAGNETS; ELECTRON BEAMS; PHOTONS; BENDING MAGNETS; PHOTON FACTORY; QUADRUPOLE MAGNETS; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS

Title: STRUCTURALLY RELATED PHENOMENA IN Mg//2NiH//4.
Affiliations: Univ of Stockholm, Stockholm, Swed, Univ of Stockholm, Stockholm, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Noreus, Dag, Univ of Stockholm, Stockholm, Swed, Univ of Stockholm, Stockholm, Swed
Abstract: A short background on metal hydrides as hydrogen storage systems is given. Specific problems encountered in structural investigations of metal hydrides will be discussed in the form of a review of the work on the ternary hydride Mg//2NiH//4. Structure-related phenomena give evidence for covalent bonding in this hydride. It is compared with similar covalently bonded hydrides, for example K//2ReH//9.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES; HYDROGEN - Storage; METALLIC COMPOUNDS; COVALENT BONDING; METAL HYDRIDES; STORAGE ALLOYS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS

Title: ADVANCED ARCHITECTURE EXTENDS INDUSTRY PERFORMANCE STANDARDS.
Affiliations: Control Data Corp, Control Data Corp
Authors with affiliations: Boos, Thomas C., Control Data Corp, Control Data Corp
Abstract: There has been an increasing need for large-scale computer systems that offer more advanced applications and a broader family of compatible architectures. The CYBER 180 series was designed to provide effective solutions for manufacturing, energy development, education, research, computer-aided design, petroleum, as well as commercial and general scientific applications. The development strategy was a total systems architecture approach. The CYBER 180 systems feature a storage-management architecture that simplifies applications, improves software portability and configuration flexibility, and supports large main storage capacity as well as secure data sharing.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE; ADVANCED COMPUTER ARCHITECTURES; CYBER 180 ARCHITECTURE; LARGE-SCALE COMPUTER SYSTEMS; COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL

Authors: Saucier Joseph R., Phillips Douglas R.
Title: STORING WHOLE-TREE FUELWOOD CHIPS FOR MAXIMUM ENERGY.
Affiliations: USDA Forest Service, Forestry, Science Lab, Athens, GA, USA, USDA Forest Service, Forestry Science Lab, Athens, GA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Saucier, Joseph R., USDA Forest Service, Forestry, Science Lab, Athens, GA, USA, USDA Forest Service, Forestry Science Lab, Athens, GA, USA; Phillips, Douglas R., USDA Forest Service, Forestry, Science Lab, Athens, GA, USA, USDA Forest Service, Forestry Science Lab, Athens, GA, USA
Abstract: Studies were conducted to measure the effects of pile geometry and pile venting to limit moisture increase from rainfall and loss of heat value of whole-tree chips from mixed hardwoods in open storage. Other variables examined were interior pile heating and loss of wood substance over storage time. Internal temperatures reached a maximum of 145 degree F within 2 weeks and decreased thereafter, but remained above ambient. Conical piles had smaller moisture increases from rainfall, but, after prolonged storage (6 mo. and longer), only a small central zone of the pile remained dry. Wood substance losses became significant after 3 months of open storage.
Index Keywords: FUELS - Calorific Value; MOISTURE CONTROL; WOOD PRODUCTS - Storage; FUELWOOD CHIPS; WHOLE-TREE CHIPS; WOOD

Title: QUICK DESIGN AND EVALUATION OF HEAT REGENERATORS.
Affiliations: Washington Univ, Chemical Reaction, Engineering Lab, St. Louis, MO, USA, Washington Univ, Chemical Reaction Engineering Lab, St. Louis, MO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dudukovic, Milorad P., Washington Univ, Chemical Reaction, Engineering Lab, St. Louis, MO, USA, Washington Univ, Chemical Reaction Engineering Lab, St. Louis, MO, USA; Ramachandran, P.A., Washington Univ, Chemical Reaction, Engineering Lab, St. Louis, MO, USA, Washington Univ, Chemical Reaction Engineering Lab, St. Louis, MO, USA
Abstract: Heat regenerators are often employed when the use of heat recuperators is either uneconomical, because of the enormous heat-transfer areas required, or impractical, due to the likelihood of surface fouling by particulate-laden gases. The use of regenerators abounds in the metallurgical industry, glass manufacturing, air-separation plants, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, storage of solar energy, etc. In Europe, the use of small, rotary (Ljungstrom) regenerators has been widespread for recovering heat from exhaust gases and preheating inlet air in commercial and residential oil- and coal-fired furnaces. The article familiarizes chemical engineers with heat regenerator concepts, briefly reviews what these devices are, and discusses which types are frequently used and how they are modeled. Simple formulas for evaluation of regenerator performance are presented.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; FLUE GASES; HEAT TRANSFER; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; EXHAUST GASES; HEAT RECOVERY; HEAT REGENERATORS; HEAT EXCHANGERS

Title: ENERGY STORAGE IN GRAVEL BEDS.
Source title: Journal of the Institute of Energy
Affiliations: Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Harker, J.H., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl; Martyn, E.J., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl
Abstract: One relatively cheap way of storing low-grade energy particularly from air streams, is to use a bed of a granular solid such as gravel. An experimental investigation is reported in which heat was transferred to and from air streams passing vertically upwards through a bed of gravel up to 1. 65 m in height. Data on pressure drops and on the efficiency of the system as a storage device are reported and equations have been developed which predict outlet temperatures from the bed. The use of such beds for space heating is considered in economic terms as is an air-conditioning application.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Packed Beds; HEATING - Heat Storage; SAND AND GRAVEL - Heat Transfer; GRANULAR BEDS; GRAVEL BEDS; LOW-GRADE ENERGY; VOLUMETRIC COEFFICIENT OF HEAT TRANSFER; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Substrate catabolism related to reproduction in the bay scallop Argopecten irradians concentricus, as determined by O/N and RQ physiological indexes
Affiliations: Department of Marine Science, University of South Florida, St. Petersburg, 33701, Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barber, B.J., Department of Marine Science, University of South Florida, St. Petersburg, 33701, Florida, United States; Blake, N.J., Department of Marine Science, University of South Florida, St. Petersburg, 33701, Florida, United States
Abstract: Weight specific rates of oxygen consumption carbon dioxide production, and ammonia-N excretion, measured for a Florida population of the bay scallop Argopecten irradians concentricus between May and September, 1982 and October and November, 1983 were significantly correlated (P<0.0005) to environmental factors that co-varied seasonally with metabolic shifts related to reproduction. Mean O/N and CO2/O2 (RQ) molar ratios indicates that scallop energy metabolism varied over the course of the reproductive cycle. Resting stage individuals (May-early June) had RQ values close to 0.7, indicative of a predominantly lipid-based metabolism. During the initial stages of gametogenesis (late June-early July) scallops catabolized primarily carbohydrate, as evidenced by maximum O/N (>22) values and RQ values close to 1.0 RQ values >1.0 indicated a possible carbohydrate to lipid conversion during the period of cytoplasmic growth (late July-early September). As gametes matured and spawning commenced (late September-November), metabolism became primarily protein based, as indicated by O/N and RQ values around 9.0 and 0.8, respectively. This pattern of substrate catabolism supports existing data on the storage and utilization of specific energy reserves with respect to reproduction in this species. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Martin S.A., Prasuhn D., Schott W., Wiedner C.A.
Title: A storage ring for the JULIC cyclotron
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institut für Kernphysik, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich, Jülich, Fed. Rep. Germany; Physik-Department der Technischen Universität München, Munich, Germany; Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Martin, S.A., Institut für Kernphysik, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich, Jülich, Fed. Rep. Germany; Prasuhn, D., Institut für Kernphysik, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich, Jülich, Fed. Rep. Germany; Schott, W., Physik-Department der Technischen Universität München, Munich, Germany; Wiedner, C.A., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: The storage ring COSY is planned to provide higher intensity and resolution for nuclear structure experiments using the light heavy ion beams (p, d, τ, α) of the JULIC cyclotron and the magnet spectrograph BIG KARL. The ring contains the measuring target of BIG KARL as an internal target, two rf cavities for compensating the mean energy loss in the target and providing additional acceleration of the stored beam and an e--cooling section. In the recirculator mode, i.e., without e--cooling, a luminosity of L = 3.64 × 1030 particles/(cm2 s) is obtained for an experiment with 41 MeV protons and a 50 μg/cm2 12C target at a spectrograph resolution p/dp = 104 and 100% duty factor. This corresponds to a gain in L of 546.5 in comparison with the same experiment without a storage ring. In the recirculator mode with acceleration L = 1.17 × 1032 p/(cm2 s) and 98.8% duty factor results for 1500 MeV protons on the same target at the same resolution. Using e--cooling L and the feasible p/dp can be enhanced, however, at a reduced duty factor. © 1985.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS - Nuclear; JULIC CYCLOTRON; NUCLEAR STRUCTURE; RESOLUTION; ACCELERATORS, CYCLOTRON

Title: Stored multi-charged ion research: current status and plans
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Church, D.A., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: Low energy multi-charged ions have been produced in Penning ion traps by electron-impact ionization, and as recoil ions from fast, highly-charged heavy ion impact on target gases. Studies of charge transfer from gases and hydrogen atoms to these ions have been completed and are being extended. New multi-charged ion production methods using photoionization by synchrotron radiation, and ionization of atomic beams, are being considered. Certain potential precision spectroscopy measurements on ions stored in radio-frequency traps are also being developed. These new measurements and techniques are expected to be difficult to implement, but may lead to significant advances in the understanding of multi-charged ion collision processes at near-thermal energies, and to spectroscopic precisions not previously possible with high charge states. © 1985.
Index Keywords: CHARGED PARTICLES - Research; SPECTROSCOPY; CHARGE TRANSFER; ION COLLISION PROCESSES; ION STORAGE; PENNING ION TRAPS; IONS

Authors: Friesel D.L., Pollock R.E., Ellison T., Jones W.P.
Title: Beam pulse stacking with a low energy storage ring at The Indiana University cyclotron facility (IUCF)
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Indiana Univ. Cyclotron Facility Research supported by the National Science Found. under grants NSF, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Friesel, D.L., Indiana Univ. Cyclotron Facility Research supported by the National Science Found. under grants NSF, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Pollock, R.E., Indiana Univ. Cyclotron Facility Research supported by the National Science Found. under grants NSF, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Ellison, T., Indiana Univ. Cyclotron Facility Research supported by the National Science Found. under grants NSF, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Jones, W.P., Indiana Univ. Cyclotron Facility Research supported by the National Science Found. under grants NSF, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Abstract: An isochronous storage ring for the DC beams from the 0.62 MV external ion source ("pre-injector") was installed in the beam line to the Indiana University k = 15 (k = AE q2 MeV) cyclotron ("injector") to provide a variable reduction of the duty factor the accelerated beams while also increasing the peak beam brightness. Ions are injected into the ring via electron removal which allows the beam to accumulate. The stored beam is ejected from the ring by a pulsed electrostatic deflector after an arbitrarily selected integer multiple of the cyclotron RF period. The peak intensity is enhanced by the accumulation between extracted pulses. Recent development tests using a 615 keV H2+ beam have demonstrated the capability of the device to provide cyclotron beams with pulse periods ranging from 1.1 to 100 μS. Peak beam intensities increase in proportion to accumulation time up to 3 μS and have reached 5 times the best intensity without using the ring. The design of the ring and the results of recent operating experience are reported. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ION SOURCES; BEAM LINE; BEAM PULSE STACKING; CYCLOTRON BEAM; ACCELERATORS, CYCLOTRON

Title: Electronic Structure of a Single Hydrogen Centre in Magnesium Crystals
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences
Affiliations: Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Morgenstelle, 7400 Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Duscher, R., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Morgenstelle, 7400 Tübingen, Germany; Maichle, J.K., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Morgenstelle, 7400 Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: In the present work, the problem “hydrogen storage in metals” is treated with the aid of the so-called New Tamm-Dancoff (NTD) procedure. We employ this method in lowest approximation for the evaluation of the electronic energy difference eigenvalue between a metal crystal with and without hydrogen centre. As an example we use Magnesium with hexagonal structure. For this system we calculate the difference eigenvalue with dependence on the displacement of the nearest neighbours and next nearest neighbours of the hydrogen centre, respectively. Finally we calculate the radial electron density distribution in the environment of the proton. © 1985, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Title: A radiation and energy balance study of mature forest and clear-cut sites
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Queen's University, Kingston, K7L 3N6, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: McCaughey, J.H., Department of Geography, Queen's University, Kingston, K7L 3N6, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: Components of the radiation and energy balances were measured over a clear-cut area and a mature, mixed forest during the summer of 1981 at the Petawawa National Forestry Institute, Chalk River, Ontario. The work concentrated on the clear-cut site which supported a canopy layer composed primarily of bracken fern and logging remnants. Forty days of radiation data were collected at the clear-cut site. After the first four weeks of measurements (the 'green' season), most of the ferns quickly died, and their foliage changed appearance from a green to brownish colour (the 'brown' season). The daily mean reflection coefficient of solar radiation determined over the 'green' season was 0.20 and decreased to 0.13 for the 'brown' season. The corresponding value for the forest was 0.13, based on a limited amount of data. The clear-cut site received 11% and 21% less net radiation than the forest on a 24-hr and daylight-hours basis, respectively, as a consequence of the higher reflection coefficient and larger daytime longwave radiation emission. A reversing temperature difference measurement system (RTDMS), incorporating ten-junction thermopiles was employed at each site in order to determine Bowen ratios (β) via differential psychrometry. Both systems performed well, especially the RTDMS over the forest which was capable of resolving very small differences of temperature, typically less than 0.2 °C over a height of 3 m. The mean hourly Bowen ratio, calculated from values from 0800 to 1600 hr, varied from 0.2 to 1.0 for the forest and from 0.4 to 0.8 for the clear-cut site in the 'green' season. A significant canopy heat storage component of the energy balance, QS, was found at the clear-cut site. In the early morning, a portion of the available energy was used to heat the biomass materials and air within the canopy layer. The stored heat within the canopy was released later in the day, increasing the available energy total. The daily mean value of the Priestley-Taylor coefficient α (Priestley and Taylor, 1972) for the 'green' season at the clear-cut site was 1.14, and individual values tended to increase during wet surface conditions and decrease when the surface dried. The daylight mean α value during dry canopy conditions at the forest was 1.05, and much higher values occurred when the canopy was wet. The enhancement of α for the wet forest was a result of the evaporation of intercepted rain (which is not limited by stomatal resistance) and the concomitant transfer of sensible heat to the forest. © 1985 D. Reidel Publishing Company.
Index Keywords: canopy layer; heat storage; Ontario

Title: CHEMICAL LASER REVIEW: EFFICIENT ENERGY STORAGE ALLOWS CHEMICAL LASERS TO PRODUCE VERY HIGH POWERS.
Affiliations: Lasers & Applications, Torrance,, CA, USA, Lasers & Applications, Torrance, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hecht, Jeff, Lasers & Applications, Torrance,, CA, USA, Lasers & Applications, Torrance, CA, USA
Abstract: Chemical lasers are those in which the excited light emitting species is produced by a chemical reaction. Most chemical lasers operate on infrared vibrational transitions of diatomic molecules. The hydrogen halides are the most important family of chemical lasers; the archetype and most practical member of the family is the hydrogen-fluoride laser. Other chemical lasers rely on reactions which produce excited atomic species. The most important of these is the iodine laser, in which excited iodine atoms are produced by chemical or photochemical reactions. The main attraction of chemical lasers is their ability to produce very high powers. This is largely because energy can be stored quite efficiently as chemical reactants.
Index Keywords: AMPLITUDE NOISE; CAVITY LENGTH; LASERS, CHEMICAL

Title: CRITICALITY SAFETY.
Affiliations: UKAEA, Safety & Reliability Directorate, Engl, UKAEA, Safety & Reliability Directorate, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Walker, G., UKAEA, Safety & Reliability Directorate, Engl, UKAEA, Safety & Reliability Directorate, Engl
Abstract: When a sufficient quantity of fissile material is brought together a self-sustaining neutron chain reaction will be started in it and will continue until some change occurs in the fissile material to stop the chain reaction. The quantity of fissile material required is the 'Critical Mass'. This is not a fixed quantity even for a given type of fissile material but varies between wide limits depending on a number of factors which will be dealt with later in this article. In a nuclear reactor the critical mass of fissile material is assembled under well-defined conditions to produce a controllable chain reaction. The same materials have to be handled outside the reactor at all stages of fuel element manufacture, storage, transport and irradiated fuel reprocessing and frequently in less well-defined conditions than obtained within the reactor. At any of these stages it is possible - at least in principle - to assemble a critical mass and thus initiate an accidental and uncontrolled chain reaction. It is the job of the Criticality Safety Specialist to ensure that these conditions are avoided.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Criticality; PHYSICS - Nuclear; CHAIN REACTION; MODERATION; NUCLEAR ENERGY

Title: STRATEGIES TO OPTIMIZE ICE STORAGE.
Affiliations: Gale Corp, USA, Gale Corp, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rawlings, Lyle, Gale Corp, USA, Gale Corp, USA
Abstract: Ice storage systems are proposed for the mechanical cooling of office buildings, theaters, churches, etc. , for the purpose of lowering the operating cost of the building by reducing the electrical demand charges resultingn from air conditioning. The incentive for installing an ice storage system is maximized by designing the system to obtain the highest possible demand reduction while retaining a low installed cost for the equipment and low energy use. In a brine-type ice storage system, a low installed cost can be obtained by first optimizing the sizing of the ice tanks vs. the chiller relation to the design load.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Cooling; TANKS - Optimization; ENERGY DEMAND CONTROL; ICE STORAGE SIZING; ICE-PRIORITY CONTROL; MECHANICAL SYSTEM COSTS; OPERATING COSTS; ICE

Authors: Smith R.D., Peart R.M., Liljedahl J.B., Barrett J.R., Doering O.C.
Title: CORNCOB PROPERTY CHANGES DURING OUTSIDE STORAGE.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN,, USA, Purdue Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smith, R.D., Purdue Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN,, USA, Purdue Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Peart, R.M., Purdue Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN,, USA, Purdue Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Liljedahl, J.B., Purdue Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN,, USA, Purdue Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Barrett, J.R., Purdue Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN,, USA, Purdue Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Doering, O.C., Purdue Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN,, USA, Purdue Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Abstract: Farm and commercial scale outside storage piles of corncobs were studied to determine physical and chemical changes that occurred during storage of up to 18 months. Dry matter, cellulose and pentosan losses were highest in wet layers between the surface and 0. 9 m depth into the piles. Gross heat of combustion per kg of remaining dry matter increased with deterioration of the cobs. Losses of up to 33% of the energy available in small cob piles were due to dry matter loss and increased moisture content during storage. The combined effects of mass loss and composition change resulted in losses of 43% of available pentosans from wet layers after 18 months storage.
Index Keywords: BIOMASS - Physical Properties; CORNCOB; OUTSIDE STORAGE; PROPERTY CHANGES; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Authors: Holmes B.J., Klemme R.M., Lindholm J.
Title: ECONOMIC EVALUATION OF CORN DRYING SYSTEMS IN THE UPPER MIDWEST.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Holmes, B.J., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA; Klemme, R.M., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA; Lindholm, J., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: A total economic analysis of five grain drying processes was conducted to establish the costs of drying and storing corn on the farm. The systems were selected so L. P. gas intensive conventional drying systems could be compared with less energy-intensive drying systems. Continous flow, batch-in-bin, dryeration, combination and ambient air corn drying processes were designed for up to six storage capacities. Significant cost economies due to size were apparent as storage capacity increased. The ambient air and batch-in-bin drying processes were cost effective for smaller corn drying systems. Systems studied at larger capacities had similar unit costs.
Index Keywords: DRYERS - Analysis; ECONOMICS - Analysis; CORN DRYING SYSTEMS; UPPER MIDWEST; GRAIN

Title: ICE-MAKING SHOWCASE.
Affiliations: Alabama Power Co, Birmingham, AL,, USA, Alabama Power Co, Birmingham, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reardon, J.Gregory, Alabama Power Co, Birmingham, AL,, USA, Alabama Power Co, Birmingham, AL, USA; Penuel, Kenneth M., Alabama Power Co, Birmingham, AL,, USA, Alabama Power Co, Birmingham, AL, USA
Abstract: In June of 1980, in order to consolidate all corporate headquarters personnel into a single facility, Alabama Power Company management initiated the design and construction of a major addition to the existing corporate headquarters. Specific objectives for the project include: Reduce peak building demand by 1500 kilowatts through the use of a cool storage system; Incorporate features on the 'leading edge' of proven energy conservation and energy management technology; Evaluate design alternatives based on life cycle costs, with the owner participating in the design-making process; Design a facility to accommodate public tours with the ability to demonstrate the systems.

Title: GEOTHERMAL, HYDRO POTENTIAL OFFERS OPPORTUNITIES AT TWO UTILITIES.
Affiliations: Power, New York, NY, USA, Power, New York, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Elliot, Thomas C., Power, New York, NY, USA, Power, New York, NY, USA
Abstract: Tapping low-to-moderate-temperature brines at a geothermal plant and assuring equitable usage at a shared pumped-storage facility were engineering challenges that required innovative solutions. The Heber geothermal project located in the Imperial Valley of southern California is described. It will be the first commercial-scale, binary-cycle geothermal powerplant in the US. The powerplant and brine-production facilities are side-by-side on a 20-acre site. The Heber reservoir is capable of supporting 500 MW of capacity for 30 years. The Bath County pumped-storage facility, in the Blue Ridge Mountains of West Virginia with the capacity of 2100 MW, will be the largest of its type ever built. It will develop an energy-storage capacity of 23. 7 GW, enough to permit generation at full capacity for 11 hours; by reversing the 350-MW units, pump up will be completed in 13 hours to end the 24-hr cycle.

Abstract: The Centralized Reliability Data Organization (CREDO) is a database and data analysis center that focuses on reliability, availability, and maintainability data from advanced reactors. Sponsored by the U. S. Department of Energy's (DOE's) Office of Breeder Technology Projects, CREDO is located at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL). The primary functions of CREDO are collection, screening, cataloging, storage, retrieval, analysis, and dissemination of reliability, availability, and maintainability data for advanced reactors. CREDO's two primary data sources are the Fast Flux Test Facility in Richland, Wash. , and the Experimental Breeder Reactor-II (EBR-II) in Idaho Falls, Idaho.

Abstract: The high circumferential voltage of a high-energy electron storage ring leads to the requirement of a very large amount of radio-frequency power. This is explained and the main design features of the LEP radio-frequency system are presented.

Abstract: It is well known that Acetobacter is extremely sensitive in high total concentrations (GK)1 of ethanol and acetic acid. In the acetator, at a total concentration (GK) of 13%, ATP pool and growth show reverse behaviour. During the stationary, acidifying phase, the extracellular adenylate concentration amounts to 70% of the total edenylate pool (AN=ATP+ADP+AMP). In this range, the average value of the intracellular energy charge [EC=(ATP+1/2ADP)/(ATP+ADP+AMP)] is 0.82. After 45 s of interruption of aeration, the EC of the total culture dropped to a value of 0.58. After several weeks of storage, the EC of the inoculum amounted to 0.50. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Mansuripur M., Ruane M.F., Horenstein M.N.
Title: Magnetic properties of amorphous rare earth-transition metal alloys for erasable optical storage
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Computer and Systems Engineering, Boston University, 110 Cummington Street, Boston, MA, 02215, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mansuripur, M., Department of Electrical, Computer and Systems Engineering, Boston University, 110 Cummington Street, Boston, MA, 02215, United States; Ruane, M.F., Department of Electrical, Computer and Systems Engineering, Boston University, 110 Cummington Street, Boston, MA, 02215, United States; Horenstein, M.N., Department of Electrical, Computer and Systems Engineering, Boston University, 110 Cummington Street, Boston, MA, 02215, United States
Abstract: A mean-field modelfor amorphous rare earth-transition metal (RE-TM) alloys is developed and compared with available experimental data on GdCo-, GdFe-and TbFe-based alloys. The model assumes the existence of two iron subnetworks, one with ferromagnetic and the other with antiferromagnetic exchange coupling. The fraction of iron ions in each subnetwork and the magnetic moment of the TM ion are the only adjustable parameters of the model. Good agreement is obtained in all cases between the model calculations and the experimental data. Preliminary measurements of the magneto-optic Kerr effect on TbFe samples are also reported and the results are compared with the mean-field model predictions. A phenomenological model for the anisotropy energy density constant (Ku) is proposed and the results are tied to the mean-field model for calculations of domain wall properties. Finally, the magnetization reversal process and the nature of coercivity in thin films of TbFe are investigated, and the nucleation, growth, and stability of domains are discussed in terms of simple phenomenological models. © 1985 SPIE.

Abstract: Sn-Te-Se amorphous-crystalline phase change recording film is analyzed on write/erase cyclability, erasing speed, and activation energy of crystallization. The Sn-Te-Se thin film, sandwiched by two SiO2 thin film layers, is deposited on an organic-thick-film coated glass substrate. Then, another organic thick film is coated onto these layers. For these samples, the maximum erasure(crystallization) speed by laser beam irradiation and other wrjte/erase characteristics are measured. Information can be written and erased more than 10 times. The crystallization activation energy is also measured and found to be about 2.3eV. The life of the amorphous state is estimated to be about 10 years at 40°C. These experimental results show that Sn-Te-Se thin film is promising as a reversible phase change recording film. © 1985 SPIE.

Title: Contribution of hard QCD interactions to the pp̄-pp total inelastic cross-section difference at the CERN ISR energies

Authors with affiliations: Cavasinni, V., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Pisa, Italy, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Del Prete, T., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Pisa, Italy, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Morganti, M., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Pisa, Italy, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Tripiccione, R., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, INFN, Pisa, Italy, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: We have performed a first-order QCD calculation to evaluate a possible contribution of large-Q02 scattering to the pp̄/pp total inelastic cross-section difference at the CERN intersecting storage rings (ISR). We found that at s=31 GeV and for Q2≳6 GeV2 there is a small (a few microbarns, but definitely not 0) difference in favour of the pp̄ reaction. This effect is confined to the central rapidity region (|y|≲1) and diminishes with increasing centre-of-mass energy. © 1985.

Authors: Kniep R., Laumen M., Zachos A.
Title: Latent heat stores and phase change materials - an extensive area for thermal analysis, calorimetry and chemical thermodynamics
Affiliations: Institut für Anorganische Chemie, Strukturchemie II Universität Düsseldorf, Universitätsstr. 1, D-4000 Düsseldorf, Germany; Hawart GmbH, Heckerweg 5, D-4154 Tonisvorst 2, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kniep, R., Institut für Anorganische Chemie, Strukturchemie II Universität Düsseldorf, Universitätsstr. 1, D-4000 Düsseldorf, Germany; Laumen, M., Hawart GmbH, Heckerweg 5, D-4154 Tonisvorst 2, Germany; Zachos, A., Hawart GmbH, Heckerweg 5, D-4154 Tonisvorst 2, Germany
Abstract: Standard thermoanalytical techniques such as TG, DTA and DSC are used in search of suitable Phase Change Materials (PCMs) for high-capacity latent heat storage. We investigated eutectic mixtures of the ternary system NaOH-NaOH·H2O-KOH·H2O (ref.1) and found them excellent storage media in the low-temperature range 46-62°C with storage capacities between 482 and 526J/cm3. Reinvestigation of the proposed (ref.2) reversible reaction Ba(OH)2·8H2O + 2KNO3⇌2KOH + Ba(NO3)2 + 8H2O (65°C;ΔH=445J/cm3) revealed the system not to react in the sense of a double conversion; generally, reciprocal salt pairs seem to be less suited for thermal energy storage. The main problems of static latent heat stores are prevented by a new dynamic concept (ref.3): the system works with an auxiliary PCM (liquid⇌vapour) ensuring optimized conditions of heat transfer and homogenization of the storage material. © 1985.

Title: ENERGY CONSERVATION IN A FERTILISER INDUSTRY - IFFCO'S EXPERIENCE.
Affiliations: IFFCO, Kalol, India, IFFCO, Kalol, India
Authors with affiliations: Mathur, C.P., IFFCO, Kalol, India, IFFCO, Kalol, India
Abstract: A description is given of an energy-conservation program being carried out by a manufacturer of ammonia and urea. Under this program, a number of modifications have been implemented, including the use of boiler blowdown and process condensates, the use of a better catalyst, an extension of the cooling tower, the use of an amino-inhibiting system in the condensing turbine, hydrogen recovery from purge gas, the use of an on-line oxygen analyzer, recirculation of boiler feed water back to the deaerator, the addition of a surface condenser, an improvement in ammonia storage refrigeration, the installation of a capacitor bank, and flash steam generation from a 9 ata condensate.

Title: Intake of the Zagorsk and Kaisiadorys pumped-storage stations
Authors with affiliations: Berezinskii, S.A.; Ivanov, I.I.; Sarkisova, M.F.
Abstract: 1. For the Zagorsk PSS a new design of the intake-offtake with an extended portal was developed, which is characterized by stable hydraulics of the flow, high energy characteristics in the turbine regime, and improved characteristics in the pump regime. Further improvement of the shape of the offtake (in a pump regime) is possible by greater compression of the outlet diverging duct (to 8-12°) and elliptical shaping of the upper boundary of the portal. 2. The elimination of the trash rack of the intake in the upper reservoir, the water area of which is confined and has special preparation of the bed and facing of the upper part of the slopes, is a progressive decision making it possible to reduce head losses and to increase the efficiency of operating the equipment of the PSS. © 1985 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Title: HOW A BUILDING GETS BUILT: 'ICING' ENERGY COSTS AT CHICAGO'S STATE OF ILLINOIS CENTER.
Affiliations: Specifying Engineer, Boston, MA, USA, Specifying Engineer, Boston, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Nasenbeny, Robert J., Specifying Engineer, Boston, MA, USA, Specifying Engineer, Boston, MA, USA
Abstract: A heat pump system is introduced that is based on ice storage during off-peak hours to heat and cool a 17-story government building. The system consists of eight 10- by 10- by 40-ft ice tanks, three industrial screw compressors that operate as heat pumps and seven interconnected variable-air-volume systems. The screw compressors compress freon gas with rotating screws into smaller volumes. When that happens, the gas temperature rises and is used to generate hot water for winter heating. By using screw compressors the system operates over a wider range of pressures and temperatures ( minus 20 degree F to 120 degree F) than a standard centrifugal compressor. Its ability to cool below freezing allows the heat pump to make ice. The heat pump can store cooling and extract heat by lowering the temperature and changing the state of water. Heat removed from the water to make ice is used to heat the building during the winter in the unoccupied evening hours. With the capacity to produce ice, the heat pump is, in effect, storing the electrical energy that allowed the compressor to make the ice thus permitting the building to consume only half as much energy as a similar-sized high-rise.
Index Keywords: HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS - Energy Management; ICE - Storage; SCREW COMPRESSOR HEAT PUMP; OFFICE BUILDINGS

Title: ENERGY FLOW DIAGRAMS FOR DIABATIC AIR-STORAGE PLANTS.
Affiliations: Brown Boveri & Co, Gas Turbine, Engineering Dep, Baden, Switz, Brown Boveri & Co, Gas Turbine Engineering Dep, Baden, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Zaugg, P., Brown Boveri & Co, Gas Turbine, Engineering Dep, Baden, Switz, Brown Boveri & Co, Gas Turbine Engineering Dep, Baden, Switz
Abstract: A diabatic air-storage plant is a complex thermodynamic system in which the energy balance is made up of different types of energy flows. These flows may consist of exergy alone, anergy alone or exergy and anergy together. For practical reasons it is useful to leave certain flows comprising exergy and anergy as uniform energy flows. These can then be shown graphically in the form of an energy flow diagram which combines the Sankey diagram with the exergy flow diagram. Thus, both the conversion of electrical work into stored-air pressure energy (compressor operation) - or vice versa (turbine operation) - and the heat and enthalpy flows necessary to dimension the plant components, and which can be measured in the plant itself, can be shown in the same diagram.
Index Keywords: ANERGY; DIABATIC AIR-STORAGE PLANTS; ENERGY FLOW DIAGRAMS; EXERGY; ENERGY STORAGE; THERMODYNAMICS; COMPRESSED AIR

Title: ULTRASONICALLY ENHANCED MAGNETIC INK FILTRATION.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Current procedures for producing magnetic ink for use in coating data storage disks utilize a filtration operation in the final stage of ink preparation. The objective of this filtration is the removal of unwanted process debris, undispersed magnetic particles, and other foreign material from the ink. This removal improves the performance level of the resultant disk by minimizing the number of defects caused by nonhomogeneities in the magnetic coating. The flow of magnetic ink through a filter is enhanced by the application of ultrasonic energy. This flow enhancement permits the use of a finer filter and/or increased filter efficiency with a resultant improvement in magnetic disk performance.
Index Keywords: INK - Filtration; ULTRASONIC APPLICATIONS; MAGNETIC COATING; MAGNETIC INK FILTRATION; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE (CAES): OVERVIEW, PERFORMANCE AND COST DATA FOR 25Mw TO 220Mw PLANTS.

Affiliations: EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schainker, R.B., EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA; Nakhamkin, M., EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Abstract: CAES Plants store off-peak energy from coal and nuclear baseload plants by compressing air into underground reservoirs. The air is then withdrawn from storage when needed, heated and expanded through turbine-generators to satisfy peaking and intermediate duty power and energy requirements. Comparative results are presented for the performance and cost data of 25Mw-220Mw compressed-air energy storage (CAES) power plants. The data include steady-state and dynamic load following characteristics, turbomachinery versus storage costs and siting flexibility for this type of energy storage power plant. Also presented is a description of the various types of air storage geologic formations available in about 3/4 of the United States.

Authors with affiliations: Isler, Heinz, Ingenieurbuero, Burgdorf, Switz, Ingenieurbuero, Burgdorf, Switz
Abstract: Constructional physics in the first instance deals with the wandering of temperature and moisture through walls and roofs. It therefore can determine the balance of energy for a structure and is, as such, of great actual importance. Constructional physics secondly states where and when condensation appears, where gases diffuse or corrosive liquids arise. Thirdly constructional physics interprets the rules of comfort and enables fair protection, against negative environmental influences. Knowledge of radiation, storage, absorption of moisture and noise insulation are integral aspects.

Abstract: The speed of solidification of a paraffin, n-octadecane in a copper tube with an inside diameter of 30. 8 mm was studied experimentally. The heat transfer rates were measured by heat flux meters on the wall of an acrylic tube. The wall temperatures of the tubes were variable with time at a rate of less than 1 degree C per minute. Both of the results for solidification agreed well with the analytical results which were solved using the assumption of quasi-steady state. For melting, the experimental and the analytical results agreed with each other initially.

Title: SOLAR AND WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS FOR ISOLATED AREAS.
Authors with affiliations: Pfeiffer, Heinz
Abstract: In future, wind power plants and photo-voltaic solar generators will be a means of boosting or even assuming sole responsibility for the power supply in various countries. Both technologies have already proved their individual worth in a whole range of experimental and demonstration plants. In certain circumstances, it can be advantageous to combine solar and wind energy systems in one plant. The probability of obtaining a guaranteed power supply is thus increased, a particularly important aspect in isolated areas not connected to the grid, and the energy storage capacity can be lowered.

Title: Glucose metabolism in rat mast cells. Stimulation of the pentose phosphate pathway by compound 48/80
Affiliations: Department of Pharmacology, Odense University, J.B. Winsløws Vej 19, Odense C, DK-5000, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Chakravarty, N., Department of Pharmacology, Odense University, J.B. Winsløws Vej 19, Odense C, DK-5000, Denmark
Abstract: The glycogen content of rat peritoneal mast cells (mean: 3 nmoles/106 cells) was increased 15% by incubation with glucose (1 m M) and reduced 35% when incubated without glucose at 37°C for 15 min. The storage capacity for glycogen is thus low. Lactate production at 37°C in a substrate-free medium was low (2.5-6.3 nmoles/106 cells in 40 min), but was stimulated 5-fold in the aerobic medium and 10-15 fold in the anaerobic medium by glucose. Both aerobic and anaerobic glycolysis in presence of glucose can thus provide energy for histamine secretion. The initial enzymes of the pentose phosphate pathway, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase, have been demonstrated in mast cells. The enzyme activity in mast cells was, however, low compared to the high activity in the other peritoneal cells. The extent of the pentose cycle activity was determined from the conversion of14C1-- and14C6-glucose to14CO2, expressing the specific14CO2 yields as fractions of the total glucose utilization. The normal pentose cycle activity with 1 m M glucose was 0.4% of the glucose metabolism. This was remarkably simulated by an electron acceptor, phenazine methosulfate. The pentose cycle was enhanced to 0.71% (80% stimulation) after exposure of the mast cells to compound 48/80, causing 68% histamine release. The stimulation of the pentose cycle by compound 48/80 seems to be due to the enhancement of biosynthetic processes during the regenerative phase. We have previously reported stimulation of CO2 and lactate production from glucose in mast cells by secretagogues. The present experiments also show a stimulation of total glucose utilization and increased incorporation of14C from glucose to lipids. © 1985 Birkhäuser Verlag.

Authors: De Rougemont F., Xian D.K., Frey R., Pradere F.
Title: Pulse compression by Raman induced cavity dumping
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du C.N.R.S, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: De Rougemont, F., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du C.N.R.S, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, Cedex, France; Xian, D.K., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du C.N.R.S, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, Cedex, France; Frey, R., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du C.N.R.S, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, Cedex, France; Pradere, F., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du C.N.R.S, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, Cedex, France
Abstract: High efficiency pulse compression using Raman induced cavity dumping has been studied theoretically and experimentally. Through stimulated Raman scattering the electromagnetic energy at a primary frequency is down-converted and extracted from a storage cavity containing the Raman medium. Energy storage may be achieved either at the laser frequency by using a laser medium inside the storage cavity, or performed at a new frequency obtained through an intracavity nonlinear process. The storage cavity may be dumped passively through stimulated Raman scattering either in an oscillator or in an amplifier. All these cases have been studied by using a ruby laser as the pump source and compressed hydrogen as the Raman scatter. Results differ slightly accordingly to the technique used, but pulse shortenings higher than 10 and quantum efficiencies higher than 80 % were obtained. This method could also be used with large power lasers of any wavelength from the ultraviolet to the far infrared spectral region. © 1985, SPIE.

Title: ARE PRE-OBESE PEOPLE ENERGY THRIFTY?
Affiliations: Nutrition Research Group, Clinical Research Centre, Watford Road, Harrow, HA1 3UJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Garrow, J.S., Nutrition Research Group, Clinical Research Centre, Watford Road, Harrow, HA1 3UJ, United Kingdom; Webster, J., Nutrition Research Group, Clinical Research Centre, Watford Road, Harrow, HA1 3UJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Metabolic rate and fat-free mass tend to be higher in obese people than in lean people. It has been suggested that pre-obese people have a low metabolic rate and only acquire their high metabolic rate from the storage of lean tissue which they gain while becoming obese. To test this hypothesis resting metabolic rate was related to percentage fat, with fat-free mass held constant, in 104 women with body fat ranging from 6% to 60% of body-weight. Results showed that the greater the percentage fat, the greater the metabolic rate. It is difficult to believe that fat people with a high metabolic rate relative to fat-free mass once had a low metabolic rate. © 1985.

Abstract: We report the transmittance spectra in the wavelength region 0.2-2.0 microm of discontinuous composite Ag/Au films evaporated onto quartz and Mylar substrates and irradiated at various power densities using a pulsed laser. The changes in the optical response are explained in terms of a modification of the sample morphology and an alloying process, both of which are induced by the laser annealing. Significant transmittance differences between irradiated and non-irradiated films and the relatively low energy required to obtain them indicate that these systems are suitable for optical storage applications. © 1985.

Abstract: Wormser Scientific Corporation has designed, provided construction surveillance, and performed testing on a large number of sizeable active solar energy systems over the past ten years. In solar energy systems, the energy or heat generated in individual solar collectors is transferred using a heat transfer fluid to a storage reservoir and from the storage reservoir to an industrial or institutional user. For best efficiency of operation, the system should be designed and adjusted to result in uniform temperature increase in the solar collectors when they are exposed to the sun and heat transfer fluid is circulated through the system. Since the author had previous experience with non-contact temperature measurement and scanning, he used these techniques in testing and adjusting the solar systems. The paper briefly describes typical large active solar energy systems and discusses methods of using remote infrared temperature sensors for testing and adjusting these systems. © 1985 SPIE.

Abstract: A vessel containing a saturated fluid is a common component of an industrial plant. A dynamic model which predicts the response of the pressure, mass, and void fraction distribution in the vessel to a transient initiator is presented. Title: ON THE POTENTIAL PERFORMANCE OF NON-NUCLEAR INTERSTELLAR ARKS.
Source title: JBIS. Journal of the British Interplanetary Society
Affiliations: Pratt Inst, Educational Technology, Group, Brooklyn, NY, USA, Pratt Inst, Educational Technology Group, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Matloff, Gregory L., Pratt Inst, Educational Technology, Group, Brooklyn, NY, USA, Pratt Inst, Educational Technology Group, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Abstract: Previous publications which have presented various aspects of non-nuclear interstellar flight, are reviewed. These papers have demonstrated the utility of optimized hyperthin or perforated solar sails deployed behind occulters during close perihelion passes limited only by sail internal thermal constraints, multiple sail missions, and electric propulsion during the pre-perihelion trajectory leg. After accounting for the acceleration tolerance of the human occupants, trip times substantially less than 1000 years are possible for one-way missions to Alpha Centauri of payloads of 5 multiplied by 10**6 kg or larger. This paper extends this analysis and considers utilization of the light sail windmill as a 'storage battery' and electric propulsion for the early post-perihelion trajectory leg of the mission. The light sail windmill's energy storage capability will also be useful for on-board power during the long interstellar cruise phase of the mission. Appropriate combination of various propulsive techniques reveals that trip times of less than 800 years may ultimately be feasible.
Index Keywords: SPACE RESEARCH; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; ALPHA CENTAURI; INTERSTELLAR FLIGHT; LIGHT SAIL WINDMILL; NON-NUCLEAR INTERSTELLAR ARKS; SOLAR SAILS; SPACE FLIGHT

Abstract: Eutectic compositions and congruently melting intermetallic compounds in binary and multi-component systems among common elements such as AI, Ca, Cu, Mg, P, Si, and Zn may be useful for high temperature heat storage. In this work, heats of fusion of new multicomponent eutectics and intermetallic phases are reported, some of which are competitive with molten salts in heat storage density at high temperatures. The method used to determine unknown eutectic compositions combined results of differential thermal analysis, metallography, and microprobe analysis. The method allows determination of eutectic compositions in no more than three steps. Abstract: Selecting the wrong hot water system can result in higher than necessary building costs, installation costs, maintenance and energy costs, and possibly poor performance as well. Therefore, careful consideration should be given to water heater selection and the effect of design factors on overall cost and performance. The basic types of indirect-fired systems available today for domestic water heating in institutional and commercial buildings such as hospitals, hotels, schools, dormitories, and restaurants follow. These include three basic types of heaters: bulk storage heaters, instantaneous, semi-instantaneous. Three basic factors should be considered in the selection of an indirect-fired domestic water heating system for a given application: dependability, temperature control, and life cycle costs. Each of these types of heaters and selection factors is discussed in the article.

Authors: Hendry J.H., Cowie F.G., von Wangenheim K.-H.
Title: The reversion phenomenon in irradiated fern prothalli: Effects of acute or chronic anoxia and LET
Affiliations: Paterson Laboratories, Christie Hospital and Holt Radium Institute, Manchester, M20 9BX, United Kingdom; Kernforschungsanlage, Institut für Medizin, Jülich, D-5170, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hendry, J.H., Paterson Laboratories, Christie Hospital and Holt Radium Institute, Manchester, M20 9BX, United Kingdom; Cowie, F.G., Paterson Laboratories, Christie Hospital and Holt Radium Institute, Manchester, M20 9BX, United Kingdom; von Wangenheim, K.-H., Kernforschungsanlage, Institut für Medizin, Jülich, D-5170, Germany
Abstract: In several systems a paradoxical reduction of radiation damage with increasing dose, termed reversion, has been observed. In the fern Osmunda regalis the percentage of cells which does not die but stays alive, although reproductively sterile, increases with dose. The assumed mechanism of this effect is a continuation of cytoplasmic growth during radiation-induced mitotic delay which induces terminal differentiation (early differentiation) thus preventing mitosis and the expression of chromosomal injury. Suppression of cytoplasmic growth after irradiation should abrogate reversion. This was tested using anoxia. Reversion was suppressed by storage of the sporelings in nitrogen for 8 h or more after X-rays, but was not suppressed by storage in 0.27 μM oxygen nor by a 60-min exposure to air after irradiation and before storage in nitrogen. Anoxia before irradiation in air had no effect. Anoxia only during irradiation showed an OER of about 2 for the reversion peak. The partial abrogation of reversion is consistent with the assumed mechanism. Marked reversion also was observed after 14.7 MeV neutrons. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: etiology; hypoxia; linear energy transfer; methodology; nonhuman; plant; radiation injury; revertant; Cell Survival; Dose-Response Relationship, Radiation; Energy Transfer; Mitotic Index; Neutrons; Oxygen; Plants; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Time Factors; X-Rays

Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Department of Applied Physics, Tohoku University, Japan; Physics Department, College of Arts and Sciences, Tohoku University, Japan; Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Isobe, H., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Sato, E., Department of Physics, School of General Education, Iwate Medical University, Morioka 020, Japan; Hayasi, Y., Department of Applied Physics, Tohoku University, Japan; Suzuki, M., Physics Department, College of Arts and Sciences, Tohoku University, Japan; Arima, H., Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan; Hoshino, F., Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan
Abstract: Flash radiographic bio-medical studies at sub-microsecond intervals were performed by using both a new type of flash X-ray(FX) apparatus with spectrum control functions and Fuji Computed Radiography(FCR). This single flasher tends to have a comparatively long exposure time and the electric pulse width of the FX wave form is about 0.3>usec. The maximum FX dose is about 50mR at lm per pulse, and the effective focal spot varies according to condenser charging voltage, A-C distance, etc., ranging from 1.0 to 3.0mm in diameter, but in the low dose rate region it can be reduced to less than 1.0mm in diameter. The FX dose is determined by the condenser charging voltage and the A-C distance, while the FX spectrum is determined by the average voltage of the FX tube and filters. Various clear FX images were obtained by controlling the spectrum and dose. FCR is a new storage medium for medical radiography developed by the Fuji Photo Film Co., Ltd. and this apparatus has various image forming functions: Low dose radiography, film density control, image contrast control, subtraction management and others. We have used this new apparatus in conjunction with our FX radiography and have obtained some new and interesting bio-medical radiograms: The edge enhancement image, the instantaneous enlarged image, and the single exposure energy subtraction image using the FX spectrum distribution. © 1985 SPIE.

Abstract: The FB double port buffer memory, developed at the LPNHE of the University Paris VI, is described. Its purpose is to make available the same features useful in the high energy environment, to reduce, for a given amount of memory, the dead time data collection in a large size (in terms of read-out channels) high energy experiment, and to obtain a reliable buffer of memory as cheaply as possible. The FB protocol on the crate and cable side is exploited using the coupler on 4 PALs. Authors: Haller G.M., Freytag D.R., Walker J.T., Chae S.I.
Title: PERFORMANCE REPORT FOR STANFORD/SLAC MULTI-CHANNEL SAMPLE-AND-HOLD DEVICE.
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haller, G.M., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Freytag, D.R., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Walker, J.T., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Chae, S.I., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: The results on a newly developed multi-channel sample-and-hold calorimeter data unit (CDU) are presented. The device is organized as 32 input channels, each consisting of four storage cells to take samples of the 32 analog signals at four separate times. The design goals for the development were wide dynamic range and long hold times. Therefore, each storage cell is laid out in a fully differential way, and consists of a sampling stage for the signal, and another identical stage for a reference voltage. Results on the performance of the device are described.

Title: LEP OPAL TRIGGER AND VME BASED DATA COLLECTION.
Affiliations: CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Brisson, J.C., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Farthouat, Ph., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Gandois, B., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Gentit, F.X., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Hajjar, V., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Le Du, P., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Lesquoy, E., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Mallet, J., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Rougevin-Baville, P., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr; Zylberajch, S., CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr, CEN Saclay, Gif-sur-Yvette, Fr
Abstract: The LEP OPAL data collection process is based on a distributed architecture of the 16/32 bit MC 68000 microprocessors associated with a coherent use of the VME bus. The authors describe the system which collects data from each detector branch and delivers the information through a hierarchical tree structure to a VME matrix interface. Here, individual events are assembled and filtered, ready for delivery to mass storage.

Authors: Baumbaugh A.E., Knickerbocker K.L., Wegner C.R., Baumbaugh B.W., Ruchti R.
Title: REAL TIME DATA COMPACTOR (SPARSIFIER) AND 8 MEGABYTE HIGH SPEED FIFO FOR HEP.
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Baumbaugh, A.E., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Knickerbocker, K.L., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Wegner, C.R., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Baumbaugh, B.W., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Ruchti, R., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA
Abstract: A Video-Data-Acquisition-System (VDAS) was developed to record image data from a scintillating glass fiber-optic target developed for high energy physics. The major components of the VDAS are a flash ADC, a 'real-time' high speed data compactor, and high speed 8 megabyte FIFO memory. The data rates through the system are in excess of 30 Mbyte/s. The compactor is capable of reducing the amount of data needed to reconstruct typical images by as much as a factor of 20. The FIFO uses only standard NMOS DRAMS and TTL components to achieve its large size and high speed at relatively low power and cost.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL - Parallel Processing; DATA STORAGE UNITS; FIBER OPTICS - Applications; SCINTILLATION - Computer Applications; HEP COMPUTER; HIGH-SPEED FIFO MEMORY; REAL-TIME DATA COMPACTOR; VIDEO DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS; DATA PROCESSING

Title: LOW-COST GENERAL PURPOSE SPECTRAL DISPLAY UNIT USING AN IBM PC.
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, Sandra L., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, CA, USA
Abstract: Many physics experiments require acquisition and analysis of spectral data. Commercial minicomputer-based multichannel analyzers collect detected counts at various energies, create a histogram of the counts in memory, and display the resultant spectra. They acquire data and provide the user-to-display interface. The system discussed here separates functions into the three modular components of data acquisition, storage, and display. This decoupling of functions allows the experimenter to use any number of detectors for data collection before forwarding up to 64 spectra to the display unit, thereby increasing data throughput over that available with commercial systems. An IBM PC was chosen for the low-cost, general-purpose display unit. Up to four spectra may be displayed simultaneously in different colors. The histogram saves 1024 channels per detector, 640 of which may be distinctly displayed per spectra. The IEEE-488 standard provides the data path between the IBM PC and the data collection unit. Data are sent to the PC under interrupt control, using direct memory access. Display manipulations available via keyboard are also discussed.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, MICROCOMPUTER; DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; DATA STORAGE UNITS; SPECTROSCOPY - Equipment; SPECTRUM ANALYSIS; IBM PC; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; SPECTRAL DISPLAY UNIT; DISPLAY DEVICES

Title: COAL PORT DEVELOPMENT FOR BALTIMORE.
Affiliations: Swan Wooster, Seattle, WA, USA, Swan Wooster, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Laccinole, S.E., Swan Wooster, Seattle, WA, USA, Swan Wooster, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: The design of the Consolidation Coal Sales Company (CCSC) Terminal at Baltimore, MD, features innovative energy-efficient thawing, state-of-the-art dumping, automatic conveyors, independent sampling and sophisticated dust suppression controls, all of which are monitored and controlled by a central computerized system. The conveying systems and storage, and the terminal control and management systems are also discussed.
Index Keywords: COAL TRANSPORTATION; CONVEYORS - Vibrating; PORT TERMINALS - Control Systems; COAL PORT DEVELOPMENT; DUMPER SYSTEM; TERMINAL CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT SYSTEM; COAL HANDLING

Title: Optical recording using hydrogen phthalocyanine thin films
Source title: Applied Physics A Solids and Surfaces
Affiliations: AT and T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, 18103, PA, United States; AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dautartas, M.F., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, 18103, PA, United States; Suh, S.Y., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, 18103, PA, United States; Forrest, S.R., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States; Kaplan, M.L., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States; Lovinger, A.J., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States; Schmidt, P.H., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States
Abstract: Vacuum sublimed thin films of the blue dye hydrogen phthalocyanine (H2Pc) were incorporated into various optical recording structures. The dye was shown to be thermally, hydrolytically, and oxidatively stable. In all cases, the writing mechanisms are dependent on the sublimation of H2Pc. Several recording structures which take advantage of the sublimation property of H2Pc are demonstrated, including pit forming and bubble forming media. These H2Pc-based optical recording structures show very high optical contrast and low writing threshold energies. In addition, very thin films (50-75Å) of H2Pc were incorporated into a tellurium-based medium, which significantly enhanced the writing contrast observed in that medium. © 1985 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: DYES AND DYEING; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN PHTHALOCYANINE; LOW WRITING THRESHOLD ENERGIES; OPTICAL RECORDING; WRITING MECHANISMS; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: ARTIFACT FREE IMAGING OF PROMS USING SCANNING TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY.
Affiliations: Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab, Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stacy, W.T., Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab, Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA; Ritz, K.N., Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab, Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA; Norcott, M.H., Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab, Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Philips Research Lab Sunnyvale, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Abstract: Removing the passivation glass covering a programmed memory cell in a fusible link PROM to image it using an SEM often creates artifacts and destroys important information. The Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) technique, on the other hand, can provide excellent images without disturbing the structures of interest. STEM contrast results from thickness and density variations. STEM/EDX (energy-dispersive X-ray detector) probes elemental compositions and is useful for in-depth profiling.

Authors: Takeuchi N., Nagashima M., Tsuruga S.
Title: AUTOMATED WELDING IN TANK CONSTRUCTION AND ITS COST-REDUCING EFFECT.
Affiliations: Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div,, Fujisawa, Jpn, Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div, Fujisawa, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Takeuchi, N., Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div,, Fujisawa, Jpn, Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div, Fujisawa, Jpn; Nagashima, M., Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div,, Fujisawa, Jpn, Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div, Fujisawa, Jpn; Tsuruga, S., Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div,, Fujisawa, Jpn, Kobe Steel Ltd, Welding Div, Fujisawa, Jpn
Abstract: Preservation of energy in Japan is a national priority, and a number of storage tanks for crude oil, LNG and LPG have been constructed to help solve this problem. In constructing these tanks at their respective sites, manual covered electrode arc welding was conventionally adopted. Development and practical application of various high efficiency welding processes and automatic welding equipment that is suitable for on-site welding of such tanks, however, has made it possible to produce most welded joints by automatic welding methods. This paper describes how automatic welding equipment is being applied to actual tank construction work, and its cost-reducing effect.
