Title: COMMERCIAL MINING OF HEAT: HOT ROCK HEAT EXCHANGER IS GOAL OF GEOTHERMAL R&D.
Affiliations: Engineering & Mining Journal,, New York, NY, USA, Engineering & Mining Journal, New York, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: White, Lane, Engineering & Mining Journal,, New York, NY, USA, Engineering & Mining Journal, New York, NY, USA
Abstract: At Rosemanows Quarry near Falmouth, Cornwall, a Camborne School of Mines research project is investigating the potential of artificially developed geothermal reservoirs as commercial sources of electric power. The project, with a staff of 65 and funding of POUND 11 million for its 1983-1986 Phase 3 program, has already sunk two drill holes to a depth of 2,000 m in Cornish granite. Using explosives and hydrofracturing techniques, a reservoir has been established that acts as a heat exchanger for water circulated from the surface. A third hole, scheduled for completion in late 1984, will provide a deeper access to the established reservoir, at a depth of about 2,700 m, and will be used to study engineering requirements for sustained long-term circulation at high rates of return flow. If economic technology can be established for power generation from hot dry rock geothermal reservoirs, such systems may make significant future contributions to the world power supply. The heat resource to be 'mined' is virtually inexhaustible, and the systems envisaged would be more amenable to use with commercial-scale generating stations than other alternative power sources, such as solar and wind power.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; ROCK - Energy Storage; ROCK DRILLING; HEAT RESERVOIRS; HOT DRY ROCK SYSTEM; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY

Title: High-energy charged-particle accelerators
Affiliations: Institute of High Energy Physics, Serpukhov, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Ado, Y.M., Institute of High Energy Physics, Serpukhov, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: A review is given of accelerators and colliding-beam installations operating at center-of-mass energies between 7 GeV and about 50 TeV. The basic principles underlying the design of such systems and ways of increasing the energy and intensity of accelerated-particle beams are briefly discussed. The scale of modem machines is illustrated by considering the examples of the proton synchrotron at the Institute of High Energy Physics at Serpukhov, the accelerating and storage complex at CERN, the accelerators at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in the USA, the electron-positron storage complex in Hamburg, and the Stanford Linear Accelerator in the USA. © 1985 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Image quality of optical systems for truncated gaussian laser beams
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Optische Werke G. Rodenstock, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kuttner, P., Optische Werke G. Rodenstock, Munich, Germany
Abstract: In general the Gaussian intensity distribution of a laser beam is truncated at the pupil of the image forming system. Ihe more the truncation effect is pronounced the less is the energy portion used and it deteriorates towards zero for a very pronounced beam expansion with an almost homogeneous illumination. For an image forming system the Gaussian intensity distribution of the incident beam may be interpreted as an apodization with a Gaussian amplitude in the pupil. Point image, encircled energy, MTF and depth of focus can be calculated from the pupil function that is defined in this way. For diffraction limited lenses it is shown how different pronounced truncations of the incident Gaussian beam will affect these image quality criteria. Applications of this effect occur e.g. in the optical data storage technology and in infrared laser applications. Ihe smallest point image is obtained for homogeneous illumination of the pupil but the needed beam expansion utilizes only a small portion of the total incident energy. Ihe central core is becoming wider the more the apodization effect is pronounced in the truncated Gaussiar. beam. Ihe encircled energy functions for less pronounced apodi- zations are similar in the central region to those without apodization. Off a diameter corresponding to the first dark Airy ring an increase of the apodization effect that means a less pronounced truncation is reducing the fraction of the total energy contained in the outer region of the point image. For a 3x Airy disk diameter almost the total energy is encircled for a Gaussian distribution whereas only some 9 0% are encircled for homogeneous illumination. © 1985 SPIE.
Index Keywords: IMAGE PROCESSING - Image Analysis; LASER BEAMS; APRODIZATION AND IMAGE QUALITY; ENCIRCLED ENERGY; GAUSSIAN INTENSITY DISTRIBUTION; MODULATION TRANSFER FUNCTION; TRUNCATED GAUSSIAN LASER BEAMS; OPTICAL SYSTEMS

Title: Optical writing mechanism of textured media
Affiliations: AT and T Bell Laboratories, 555 Union Boulevard, Allentown, PA, 18103, United States; AT and T Bell Laboratories, Crawfords Corner Road, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suh, S.Y., AT and T Bell Laboratories, 555 Union Boulevard, Allentown, PA, 18103, United States; Craighead, H.G., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Crawfords Corner Road, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States
Abstract: Theoretical analysis of the writing mechanism of textured optical storage media revealed a fundamental sensitivity advantage due to the absence of an energy barrier other than melting the material. The melting limited optical writing has been experimentally achieved both in textured germanium samples and textured silicon samples. The analysis also predicted that an instability exists in the fluid motion of the textured column during spot formation, which grows exponentially on a subnanosecond time scale. This instability coupled with the excessive Laplace-Young surface pressure ensures the spot formation before the resolidification of the molten material. This writing process facilitates the optimization of a given medium and greatly simplifies the materials research. © 1985 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS - Analysis; OPTICAL INSTRUMENTS - Testing; ABLATIVE HOLE OPENING PROCESS; INFORMATION GENERATION RATE; TEXTURED GERMANIUM SAMPLES; TEXTURED OPTICAL STORAGE MEDIA; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: Molten salt thermal energy storage subsystem research experiment. Volume 2. Final Technical Report.
Abstract: This report documents work sponsored by the US Department of Energy to design, build, and test a thermal storage subsystem research experiment using molten nitrate salt as the working fluid. The project is part of a continuing program to develop molten salt components and subsystems for central receiver systems. The work was performed by Martin Marietta Aerospace in association with American Technigaz Inc., Arizona Public Service Company, and Stearns-Roger. The design is based on a two tank system, one tank to hold cold (550 exp 0DEGREESF) salt and one to hold hot (1050 exp 0DEGREESF) salt. The cold tank is a conventional design with a carbon steel wall and external insulation. The hot tank empolys new technology; it has firebrick insulation internal to a structural shell, with a corrugated liner inside the insulation to contain the salt. The liner is similar to those used in transportation and storage of liquid natural gas. The testing showed that this concept of thermal storage is technically feasible and potentially cost effective. The contract began in November 1980 and testing was completed in August 1982. This report is in two volumes: Volume I is an Executive Summary which gives highlights of the project. Volume II is the full technical report covering the same information in greater detail.

Title: Hydraulic accumulator storage for use in wind/diesel generating systems.
Authors with affiliations: Slack, G.; Musgrove, P.J.
Abstract: Discusses experimental assessment of an energy buffer which uses a hydraulic accumulator as the storage device. Briefly surveys energy storage options and the role of storage in a wind/diesel hybrid system. The hydraulic accumulator system studied uses a mechanical gearing to drive the alternator; a compact hydraulic pump/motor coupled to the alternator shaft then allows the obsorption of power fluctuations due to turbulence. A computer model of the system operation was constructed from the test data. Outlines how the number of diesel starts per day may be calculated, using a known wind turbine characteristic. Shows that even a few minutes storage can reduce the number of diesel starts per day from 50 to less than 10. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: U.K

Title: CORROSION OF MATERIALS IN A SIMULATED CAES EXHAUST GAS ENVIRONMENT.
Affiliations: Encotech Inc, Schenectady, NY, USA, Encotech Inc, Schenectady, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lukas, Holger, Encotech Inc, Schenectady, NY, USA, Encotech Inc, Schenectady, NY, USA
Abstract: Cold end corrosion due to sulfuric acid is a phenomenum not uncommon in boilers and exhaust gas waste heat boilers. Normally, the operating conditions can be changed to reduce or eliminate the corrosion. In a Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant, this is not a practical solution. This paper presents the preliminary results of corrosion testing of various materials in a simulated CAES recuperator environment.
Index Keywords: GAS TURBINES - Exhaust Gases; MATERIALS - Corrosion; COLD END CORROSION; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE (CAES); GAS TURBINE RECUPERATORS; LARGE ELECTRIC GENERATING SYSTEMS; SULFURIC ACID WATER SYSTEM; THERMAL STRESS ANALYSIS; Compressed air

Title: TRANSIENT ANALYSIS OF GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS, USING THE HUNTORF COMPRESSED AIR STORAGE PLANT AS AN EXAMPLE.
Affiliations: Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden Switz, Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden Switz
Authors with affiliations: Schobeiri, T., Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden Switz, Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden Switz; Haselbacher, H., Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden Switz, Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden Switz
Abstract: The design of modern gas turbines requires the predetermination of their dynamic behavior during transients of various kinds. This is especially true for air storage and closed cycle gas turbine plants. The present paper is an introduction to a computational method which permits an accurate simulation of any gas turbine system. Starting with the conservation equations of aero/thermodynamics, the modular computer program COTRAN was developed, which calculates the transient behavior of individual components as well as of entire gas turbine systems. For example, it contains modules for compressors, turbines, combustion chambers, pipes etc. To demonstrate the effectiveness of COTRAN the shut-down tests of the air storage gas turbine plant Huntorf were simulated and results compared with experimental data.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Energy Storage; GAS TURBINES - Computer Simulation; COMPRESSOR TECHNICAL DETAILS; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANT COMPONENTS; GAS TURBINE SYSTEM SIMULATION; HUNTORF AIR STORAGE GAS TURBINE; MODULAR COMPUTER PROGRAM COTRAN; TURBINES DYNAMIC BEHAVIOR; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANT

Title: FUEL FLEXIBILITY IN COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE PLANTS.
Affiliations: Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden, Switz, Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Basler, B., Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden, Switz, Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden, Switz; Zaugg, P., Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden, Switz, Brown, Boveri & Co, Baden, Switz
Abstract: The pneumatic storage of energy is one of the few economical storage processes which can be considered at present for large quantities of energy. Present Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plants are designed on the basis of construction and operating experience at Huntorf, the world's first air-storage plant. That means that the turbine of the plant is equipped with combustors to increase the power output during turbine operation, and to reduce the volume and cost of the air storage facility as well as the quantity and cost of the required charging energy.

Title: THERMAL STORAGE ANALYSIS FOR LARGE MANNED SPACE PLATFORMS.
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Satellite Systems Div,, Seal Beach, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Satellite Systems Div, Seal Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lehtinen, A.M., Rockwell Int, Satellite Systems Div,, Seal Beach, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Satellite Systems Div, Seal Beach, CA, USA; Sadunas, J.A., Rockwell Int, Satellite Systems Div,, Seal Beach, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Satellite Systems Div, Seal Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: High electrical power and waste heat rejection is projected for future manned low earth orbit space platforms, such as Space Station. The high heat rejection, optical coating degradation, long operating life with minimum maintenance requirements pose a challenging thermal management design problem. System optimization, with respect to radiator area and weight, indicate the requirement for thermal storage. This paper examines the thermal storage benefits, determines the characteristics as applied to different TMS concepts (e. g. , centralized, decentralized), and examines the similarities and differences of thermal storage integration with single-phase and two-phase systems for a study baseline 75 kW//e low earth orbit platform.

Authors: Tollefson S., Beachley N.H., Fronczak F.J.
Title: Studies of an accumulator energy-storage automobile design with a single pump/motor unit
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical Engrg., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tollefson, S., Dept. of Mechanical Engrg., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States; Beachley, N.H., Dept. of Mechanical Engrg., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States; Fronczak, F.J., Dept. of Mechanical Engrg., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Abstract: An internal combustion engine/hydropneumatic accumulator energy storage automobile can provide for regenerative braking and more efficient engine operation. A configuration is considered which requires only a single hydrostatic pump-motor (P/M) unit. The engine drives through a gearbox to a final reduction unit at the drive axle. The variable-displacement P/M unit is geared to the gearbox input shaft and controlled to alternately put energy into or take energy out of the accumulator. Computer simulations covering a wide range of parameter variations show that, with a proper control strategy, the concept has the potential of providing significant fuel savings. Copyright © 1985 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Drive axles; Fuel economy; Gears; Internal combustion engines; Metallurgy; Regenerative braking; Shaft displacement; Automobile design; Control strategies; Engine drives; Engine operations; Fuel savings; Hydrostatic pumps; Reduction unit; Variable displacement; Energy storage

Authors: Wu P., Luo N., Fronczak F.J., Beachley N.H.
Title: Fuel economy and operating characteristics of a hydropneumatic energy storage automobile
Affiliations: Harbin Institute of Technology, China; Southwestern Jiaotong Univ., China; Mechanical Engineering Dept., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, P., Harbin Institute of Technology, China; Luo, N., Southwestern Jiaotong Univ., China; Fronczak, F.J., Mechanical Engineering Dept., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States; Beachley, N.H., Mechanical Engineering Dept., University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Abstract: Recent advances in hydrostatic transmission efficiency and accumulator technology make the hydropneumatic energy storage automobile appear quite attractive as a means of improving fuel economy. The system examined in this paper utilizes a conventional internal combustion engine, and two hydrostatic pump/motor units with an accumulator between them. The accumulator allows regenerative braking and permits the engine operation to be uncoupled from the road load. Detailed, second-by-second driving cycle simulations have been used to study the fuel economy possible with various combinations of component parameters. The design can provide excellent fuel economy with a moderate size accumulator. Copyright © 1985 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fuel storage; Fuels; Hydraulics; Hydrostatic pressure; Internal combustion engines; Powertrains; Regenerative braking; Component parameters; Driving cycle; Engine operations; Hydrostatic pumps; Hydrostatic transmission; Operating characteristics; Road loads; Fuel economy

Authors: Allen R.D., Doherty T.J., Kannberg L.D.
Title: Summary of selected compressed air energy storage studies.
Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D.; Doherty, T.J.; Kannberg, L.D.
Abstract: A descriptive summary of research and development in compressed air energy storage technology is presented. Research funded primarily by the Department of Energy is described. Results of studies by other groups and experience at the Huntorf plant in West Germany are included. Feasibility studies performed by General Electric are summarized. The feasibility of air storage in dissolved salt cavities is also demonstrated.

Title: Wind power application in electricity supply to light houses.
Authors with affiliations: Sadhu, D.
Abstract: A wind energy group in Brazil developed a Filippini rotor with two blades, one fixed at 60 DEGREE and the other on the same central axis for charging storage batteries in light houses. The rotor diameters are 0.8 m with a height of 0.65 m. The rotational rotor speed is increased to 17.1 through two sets of nylon gears and a 12V dynamo is fixed at the high speed shaft through a flexible coupling. A brake is fixed to the intermediate shaft to avoid speeding of more than 3500 rpm of the dynamo. The rotor, transmission system and dynamo are encased in glass reinforced plastic to prevent corrosion in the marine environment. A 6 bladed horizontal axis windmill is also being developed to charge batteries. (A.J.)

Authors: Fiorentini L., Honorati O., Santini E.
Title: Project optimization of wind - diesel integrated systems.
Authors with affiliations: Fiorentini, L.; Honorati, O.; Santini, E.
Abstract: An integrated system involving a wind turbine with a fixed pitch screw propeller working at a given velocity and an electrochemical battery storage scheme is used to illustrate the use of a small to middle sized power unit not connected to a large grid. An algorithm was devised for the cost of energy production that takes into account the main parameters affecting cost. (A.J.)

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Hutchinson F.D., Stange J.R., Canova F., Schainker R.B.
Title: Compressed air energy storage: plant integration, turbomachinery development.
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M.; Hutchinson, F.D.; Stange, J.R.; Canova, F.; Schainker, R.B.
Abstract: Results of engineering and optimization of 25 MW and 50 MW turbomachinery trains for compressed air energy storage (CAES) power plant application are presented. Proposals submitted by equipment suppliers are based on commercially available equipment. Performance data and budget prices indicate that the CAES power plant is one of the most cost effective sources of providing peaking/intermediate power and load management. CAES power plant integration procedure is discussed, and the specifics of turbomachinery design are itemized. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Some results for the experimental plant (absorption heat pump, energy roof, vertical tube earth storage) of Musile di Piave, Italy.
Authors with affiliations: Lazzarin, R.M.; Schibuola, L.
Abstract: An experimental plant was built and operated at Musile di Piave near Venice, supported by the Commission of the European Communities DGXII. The purpose was the study of the behaviour of an absorption heat pump (water ammonia type) coupled either to an energy roof or to a seasonal earth storage composed of vertical tubes. The connection between energy roof and earth storage all summer was also of interest. In the heating mode the absorption heat pump receives heat at a low level from the energy roof or the earth storage, according either to the researchers' interest or to the choice of an automatic controller. The absorption heat pump is a machine which appears very suitable to the Italian energy needs, as it requires a natural gas input. Energy roofs can be utilized all year round if it charges a seasonal earth storage when no ambient heating is required. (from paper)

Title: A simple model for a subsoil heatexchanger and practical experiences from a solar heated heatpump system with vertical ground storage.
Authors with affiliations: Fordsmand, M.; Fordsmand, M.
Abstract: A heating and cooling system with a solar collector and storage with vertical pipes in the ground was investigated. A simple calculation model was verified by the comparison of results from this model, finite element data supplied by TNO, Apeldorn and the solar installation in Denmark. Seasonal performance factors were calculated. Energy savings of 40% were achieved compared with traditional boilers. Operational experiences are discussed together with the results of a feasibility study on a combined summer cooling and winter heating system. (P.M.T.)

Title: Comparative evaluation of ground-coupled heat pumps that use solar energy.
Authors with affiliations: Andrews, J.W.; Catan, M.A.
Abstract: A study of combined building space conditioning systems using both solar energy and heat pumps was conducted for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). Several of these systems used the ground as a source of storage element for thermal energy, in order to reduce or eliminate the need for backup energy. This paper summarizes the results obtained for these systems in the United States, and describes the relationship of ground coupling to the overall U.S. solar assisted heat pump program. (A)

Title: Solar heating of a large office building using a heat pump and seasonal heatstorage.
Authors with affiliations: Crooymans, A.; Groeneveld, G.J.
Abstract: In early 1983 a study was started to examine the feasibility of the combined application of the use of solar heating and seasonal heat storage in an aquifer for space heating in an office building. The study was carried out by Heidemij Adviesbureau and Bredero Energy Systems. In June 1983 it resulted in positive conclusions and the decision was taken to realize a system based on low temperature collectors and the addition of a heat pump. In December 1984 the installation was completed, excluding the solar collectors. The building was inhabited in January 1985. (from paper)

Title: Theory of the geyser pump solar collector. Final report.
Authors with affiliations: Haines, E.
Abstract: The geyser pump solar collector is a self controlling, self pumping active collector having no moving or electronic parts, drawing its mechanical pump energy from boiling in the collector's risers. Computer simulations show that most design and algorithm parameters have only negligible impact on solar fraction, F. The only parameter which affects F is the length of the storage heat exchanger. Episodic cloud cover does not hamper the geyser pump collector's ability to restart. Daylong simulations show that the energy cost of geyser pumping is only about 3% of the absorbed insolation. The geyser pump collector is found to be as efficient as an electrically pumped collector. Initial costs are estimated to be about the same for the geyser pump and conventional collectors, but lifetime costs of the geyser pump are substantially lower, perhaps only half, because of low maintenance. (from author's abstract)

Title: The coaxial vertical heat probe with solar recharge: numerical solution and performance evaluation.
Authors with affiliations: Gilby, D.J.; Hopkirk, R.J.
Abstract: Recently in Switzerland vertical tube earth heat exchangers in combination with heat pumps have become increasingly popular as an economically attractive domestic energy source. Model studies of long term performance characteristics have been carried out on systems with and without energy recharge during the summer. These studies have shown that ground coupled solar energy storage offers technical advantages over the simple direct heat pump systems for long term operation at no economic disadvantage. (A)

Title: Solar assisted gas heat pump with ground coupled storage for twelve family houses. Technical performance and thermal balance after one year.
Authors with affiliations: Mathey, B.; Pillonel, B.
Abstract: The production, consumption and energy storage of the system is described. The system includes the combination of an earth store, a large surface of solar panels and a cogeneration system. The project was financed by the National Energy Research Foundation and has run since 1981 in Mont de Pitie, Cortaillod-Neuchatel. (P.M.T.)

Title: A solar heating plant with heat pump and seasonal storage - system design influence on thermal performance and economy.
Authors with affiliations: Dalenback, J.O.
Abstract: The solar heating plant in Lambohov was built primarily as an experimental installation for large scale solar heating applications in Sweden. It consists of 2800 m SUP 2 of flat plate roof integrated solar collectors, and an insulated 10.000 m SUP 3 water pit in rock combined with heat pumps for seasonal storage. The design objective was to meet 100% of the annual heating requirements of 55 terraced houses with a solar energy coverage of 85%. Comprehensive measurements of the system performance were made during 1983. One of the results of this work was to show that the solar energy coverage amounted to about 70%. The heat losses from the storage were higher than expected during the design stage due to penetration of ground water into the insulation. The economic results consider both the actual solar energy heating costs achieved and the estimated costs for a similar plant built today without heat pumps and shows promising low energy costs. (from author's abstract)

Title: Intersol 85, Extended Abstracts from the Biennial Congress of the International Solar Energy Society (ISES), held at Montreal, Canada on June 23-29, 1985.
Authors with affiliations: Bilgen, E.; Hollands, K.G.T.
Abstract: Provides extended abstracts of 11 invited papers, nine keynote papers and 18 invited poster papers and 503 poster papers. Sections encompass: (1) active and passive heating and cooling of buildings; (2) industrial commercial and agricultural process heat; (3) solar thermal power; (4) photovoltaics; (5) biomass; (6) chemical conversion and storage; (7) wind systems; (8) economics and policy and (9) resources. At the beginning of each section there is the full version of a relevant keynote paper. An author index is given. (C.J.U.)

Title: An economic survey of wind generated electricity for heat pumps at a community school on the Western Isles.
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, J.R.M.; Twidell, J.W.
Abstract: An aerogenerator is proposed to augment the electricity supply of a new school in the Outer Hebrides, heated entirely by heat pumps. The wind resource was estimated and the performance of 12 commercial machines predicted. From the manufacturer's prices and with estimates of other capital and recurring costs, the financial benefits of aerogeneration at the site were studied. Machines with capacities of about 60 kW would have the shortest pay back times. Larger machines would be attractive investments if grid buy back prices were higher. The building fabric and swimming pool will provide important energy storage to smooth both wind operation and grid peak demand. (A)

Title: Experimental analysis of a wind turbine/battery system.
Authors with affiliations: Sexon, B.A.; Dunn, P.D.
Abstract: Deals with the operating characteristics and performance of a wind turbine/diesel generator system with a short term storage facility of lead acid batteries. The experimental system is described and its operating charcteristics defined. A series of test runs were performed to measure the operating performance of the system; these are outlined and the results given. The measured operating characteristics of the system components were then used to create a detailed computer model of the system. This model was verified by comparing its performance with the experimental results and the paper ends with a discussion of the uses of this model. A user with a 2 kW average load at a site with a mean wind speed of 6 m/s should be able to obtain 52% of the total load from the wind energy resource. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Assessing the economics of wind energy at high penetrations: a statistical method for combining reliability and operational considerations.
Authors with affiliations: Grubb, M.J.
Abstract: Discusses important system factors in the economic analysis of intermittent sources, and proposes a model which can properly consider these. The factors are grid reliability, cycling costs, storage, load management and outage costing, operating reserve, electricity trade and optimization. The model is a probabilistic load duration and cycling frequency (PLDCF) model. Deals with probabilistic production costing, probabilistic scheduling of thermal units, reliability/spot pricing, and derivation of the transition frequency function. The model relies heavily on the mathematical convolution operations. (C.J.U.)

Title: Impact of water quality on aquifer thermal energy storage ( USA).
Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D.
Abstract: Ground-water quality may affect the regional potential for aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES). Six mechanisms can impair reservoir permeability: 1) particulate plugging, 2) chemical precipitation, 3) liquid-solid reactions, 4) formation disaggregation, 5) oxidation reactions, and 6) biological activity. Countermeasures to reduce these effects are identified. The chemistry of groundwater depends upon solution, precipitation, and fluid mixing. Aquifers composed of quartz sands and sandstones are promising for low temperature and chilled water storage. Quartz-bearing rocks are promising for high temperature storage, if silica dissolution and precipitation is insignificant. Of the 19 US hydrologic regions reviewed, 10 were identified as having characteristics necessary for ATES development. -from STAR, 24(11) , 1986

Title: Wind energy research and development in Japan.
Issue: (ed.), Bedford, U.K., H.S. Stephens & Assocs., 1985, Paper U14, p.974-979. (EUR 9622)
Authors with affiliations: Ushiyama, I.
Abstract: Describes wind power development in Japan. NEDO is involved in the development of the 100 kW wind turbines, part of the programme to promote large scale systems to provide 6000 MW from thirteen to fifteen sites. The Futopia project concerns small scale systems for water pumping, charging electric cars etc. and includes work on storage systems. Gives brief details of the operation of examples of each type of application. Notes the role of universities and colleges in promoting expertise in wind power. Future prospects are indicated. (C.J.U.)

Authors: Freris L.L., Attwood R., Bleijs J.A.M., Infield D.G., Jenkins N., Lipman N.H., Tsitsovits A.
Title: An autonomous power system supplied from wind and diesel.
Issue: (ed.), Bedford, U.K., H.S. Stephens & Assocs., 1985, Paper M3, p.669-673. (EUR 9622)
Authors with affiliations: Freris, L.L.; Attwood, R.; Bleijs, J.A.M.; Infield, D.G.; Jenkins, N.; Lipman, N.H.; Tsitsovits, A.
Abstract: Describes a project which involves the collaboration of Hawker Siddeley Power Plant Ltd., Imperial College and Rutherford Appleton Laboratory. The aim is to study theoretically and experimentally the dynamics and logistics of a wind/diesel supplied power system in which the wind input could vary from zero to 100% of the load demand. The theoretical aspects of the project involve computer simulations of (a) the dynamics of the system and the necessary control policies to maintain network voltage and frequency within bounds and of (b) the logistics and associated control policies required to minimize diesel fuel alternatives. In parallel with these studies experimental work is being pursued on a system consisting of a 7 kW diesel generator set and a 16 kW WECS. Test results are shown of the autonomous system during synchronization and under steady state running. Computer logistic results point to problems for the diesel set due to the highly variable output from the WECS. It is shown that inclusion of energy storage in the system reduces dramatically the expected stop/start cycles of the diesel and that useful savings in fuel can only be achieved if the diesel is run intermittently. (A)
Index Keywords: turbine; Wind

Title: Hydraulics for wind.
Issue: (ed.), Bedford, U.K., H.S. Stephens & Assocs., 1985, Paper J1, p.534-541. (EUR 9622)
Authors with affiliations: Salter, S.H.
Abstract: Discusses the possible application of high pressure oil hydraulics to wind power energy storage systems. A vacuum storage scheme would incorporate a rolling Bellofram seal, with concrete piston. Cost would be 15 per kilowatt. Proposes a variable displacement hydraulic machine for the flywheel storage system. The cost of flywheel storage would be 60 per kilowatt. Discusses design of the input pump, noting a novel scheme for cutting leakage losses. Ring cams are recommended. The most difficult aspect is the high speed axial piston motor, and work on reduction of compressibility losses is mentioned. (C.J.U.)

Title: Wind energy and residential electricity use: the experimental project 'Camperduin'.
Issue: (ed.), Bedford, U.K., H.S. Stephens & Assocs., 1985, Paper M12, p.718-723. (EUR 9622)
Authors with affiliations: Wolsink, M.; Westra, C.A.
Abstract: Discusses the Camperduin project in The Netherlands (part of the NOW II programme). Two wind turbines with synchronous generators produce electricity, without storage, to a group of 28 houses. The aim is to restrict the exchange of electricity within the grid as much as possible, and a reduced tariff operates when wind energy output is high. A switch from high to low rate occurs as soon as the combined power of the wind turbine stays over 10 kW for a 10 minute period. Discusses the fairness of this method of voluntary load control, for both comsumer and supplier. Describes the programme to assess the social aspects of this system. Household behaviour in the pattern of equipment use is being studied. (C.J.U.)

Title: Renewable energy: hydropower.
Abstract: In Florida, hydropower will continue to supply some baseload electrical capacity using existing facilities such as Jim Woodruff Dam. New hydro facilities may meet local needs in some cases, such as in Tallahassee and Leesburg. However, hydropower is not expected to make important contributions to Florida's energy needs largely because of the state's flat topography. The use of hydro for generating peaking electric power is technically and environmentally undesirable in Florida since lakes have minimal storage capacity and water fluctuations have adverse effects on fish and wildlife as well as water quality. Limited potential may exist for small hydro installations to serve local and individual needs at existing dams in Florida. Nationwide, small hydro will be at a disadvantage because it will not have a dependable capacity and will have high capital costs. Small hydro will probably not off set the need to build new power plants for this reason. Advantages of reliability, efficiency and lack of atmospheric or thermal pollution will continue to make hydropower worthy of consideration. It is possible that small hydro will be able to contribute 8000 MW to the nation's energy picture with minimal impacts on land and water resources. Large hydro projects can contribute 46,000 MW, but with potential major impacts on water resources. (A)

Title: Aquifer thermal energy storage in the US.
Authors with affiliations: Kannberg, L.D.
Abstract: The scope of the ATES investigation has encompassed numerical modeling, field testing, economic analyses, and evaluation of institutional issues. ATES has received the bulk of the attention becuse of its widespread potential in the US. US efforts are now concentrated on a high temperature (up to 150C) ATES field test on the St. Paul campus of the University of Minnesota. Four short- term test cycles and the first of 2 long-term test cycles have been completed at this site. Utilization of chill ATES to meet summer air conditioning demands has been monitored at 2 operating sites in Tuscaloosa, Alabama. The systems utilize a cooling tower to directly chill groundwater pumped from a water table aquifer for storage in the same aquifer. The first of the 2 systems has exhibited relatively poor performance. -from STAR, 24(11), 1986

Title: Economics of wind energy in South Africa.
Issue: (ed.), Bedford, U.K., H.S. Stephens & Assocs., 1985, Paper R5, p.849-854. (EUR 9622)
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, G.E.
Abstract: Summarizes a dissertation (for the University of Cape Town) on the economics of wind power in South Africa. Nine sites were studied (annual average wing speed between 1.5 and 4.4 m/s). The four wind turbines (DVI 15-3, WTS-75, Windane 29, Windane 9) vary in rating from 15265 to 2000 kW. Describes how time based records of wind power supply are calculated. Results of analyses are expressed in terms of the loss of load probability. Considers the reliability of the wind turbine and its back up (either diesel or pumped storage). Wind power is not competitive with conventionally generated power for the cases studied. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: thesis

Title: Power management of grid-connected wind generator clusters.
Issue: (ed.), Bedford, U.K., H.S. Stephens & Assocs., 1985, Paper M8, p.696-701. (EUR 9622)
Authors with affiliations: Kalaitzakis, K.C.; Vachtsevanos, G.J.
Abstract: Introduces a new methodology for the real and reactive power control, stability and coordination of a power system penetrated by a cluster of wind energy conversion devices. The proposed methodology is based upon the utilization of an appropriate voltage fed, self commutated DC to AC inverter with a capability of transferring variable amounts of real and reactive power from the inverter to the utility bus. An optimized storage facility provides necessary buffering and reserve power capabilities for the successful operation of the control mechanism. The paper develops appropriate models for the interconnected operation of wind generator clusters with an autonomous power system. The quality of system performance is specified in terms of operational constraints and the resultant penetration strategy is implemented via a microprocessor based control scheme. Simulation studies while power quality and stability of the interconnected system are improved. The dynamic penetration strategy, on the other hand, assures a satisfactory level of system performance while optimizing the available energy transfer from the wind generators to the utility grid. (A)

Authors: Curtis G.D., Auker B.H., Takahashi P.K.
Title: Wind energy battey storage. Phase II, Final Report.
Authors with affiliations: Curtis, G.D.; Auker, B.H.; Takahashi, P.K.
Abstract: The wind energy battery storage (WEBS) project performed by the Hawaii Natural Energy Institute (HNEI) is a research and development effort funded by the U.S. Department of Energy (USDOE) through the Sandia National Laboratories at Alburquerue (SNLA) battery storage program. The three phase project is intended to design and construct a battery storage system that will be used in conjuction with wind power generating systems for connections to a utility grid serving a small community (Molokai Island). In Phase II, major efforts included expanding and improving the computer model to include interaction with the utility, collection of additional wind and load data, updating the information of WEBS components, final design of a battery storage facility and application of the simulation of various configurations and operating strategies. (A)

Title: Semi-active magnetic bearings for space application.
Issue: (Meersburg, Fed. Rep. Germany: Oct. 9-11, 1985), Noordwijk, The Netherlands, European Space Agency P
Authors with affiliations: Gauthier, M.; Rouyer, C.
Abstract: In a magnetic bearing there is no contact between the rotor and the stator; in a one axis bearing, a passive radial centering is ensured by permanent magnets and the axial stability is obtained thanks to an electromagnet controlled by a servoloop. In a two axis bearing, the axial centering is passive while the radial one is active. An ironless motor/generator using permanent magnets creates the control torques. Such bearings are used in reaction and momentum wheels for satellite attitude control. Three units fly on the SPOT satellite this year. The development capabilities of the spin rate without life time reduction makes possible the development of kinetic energy storage systems. Discussion of the paper is included on p.145. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Analysis of wind-power systems connected to air-lift pump.
Authors with affiliations: Feitosa, E.A.N.; Soares, A.M.C.
Abstract: Presents an analysis of the air lift pump driven by simple fixed geometry wind turbines (multi blade type). An air compressor is directly coupled to the windmill. Advantages of pneumatic transmissions are discussed. These include overall system simplicity, energy storage and the fact that the windmill and the well can be separated. (The windmill can be placed on a hill where the wind potential is higher whereas the well can be drilled at the bottom of the hill closer to the water). Experimental and theoretical results indicate the great potential use of the system. A simulation strategy was developed to analyze the load matching effects due to the water level variation in wells. The results of an experimental application in the arid region of Brazil are presented. (A)

Authors: Neill L.C., Takahashi P.K., Neill D.R.
Title: A research program for wind energy-utility interface concerns.
Authors with affiliations: Neill, L.C.; Takahashi, P.K.; Neill, D.R.
Abstract: The goal of the Hawaii Natural Energy Institute and State of Hawaii research programme is to increase the amount of wind power a utility can employ while maintaining stability. Outlines the status of present wind power development on Hawaii. Phase I and II of the wind energy battery storage programme studied: (1) increased available WECS energy; (2) reduction of utility operating costs; and (3) reduction of load fluctuations at a utility pump/storage/hydro. Describes wind forecasting research. Various other options to assist utility interface problems are noted. (C.J.U.)

Title: Economic feasibility of energy storage for rural and municipal utilities.
Abstract: The report summary presents the outline of a project which investigated the role of compressed air energy storage and advanced battery storge tehnology in municipal and rural electric power stations. The feasibility study identified potential sites for compressed air energy storage (CAES) and advanced battery storge, provided system data and economic criteria for analysing power supply expansion plans. The advantages of CAES compared to pumped storage installations are also mentioned. (A.J.)

Title: Energy storage using low-pressure feedwater
Source title: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
Affiliations: Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Dynalantic, Inc., Farmingdale, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harman, C.M., Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Loesch, S., Dynalantic, Inc., Farmingdale, NY, United States
Abstract: A method for increasing the peak output of steam power plants through use of a low-pressure feedwater storage system is presented. The generalized availability analysis involves only the low-pressure turbine, low-pressure feedwater heaters, and the storage system. With daily cycling and storage charging at near base load conditions, the turnaround efficiency of the energy storage system was found to approach 100percent. Storage system turnaround efficiency is decreased when the energy is stored during plant part-load operation. © 1985 by ASME.

Authors: Morozumi S., Nishiya K., Hasegawa J., Fujiwara H.
Title: Optimal operating strategies of energy storage systems including various operating losses
Source title: IEEJ Transactions on Power and Energy
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Morozumi, S., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Nishiya, K., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Hasegawa, J., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Fujiwara, H., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Heat Transfer During Melting from a Vertical Cylinder (1st Report, Analysis and Experiments of the Melting Without Subcooling)
Source title: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B
Authors with affiliations: Okada, M.
Abstract: A vertical cylinder embedded in a horizontal plate-like solid initially at its fusion temperature was subjected to a step change in temperature. The resulting melting process with natural convection in the time-dependent melt region was analyzed by means of a finite difference method. The shapes of melting front and the temperatures along the one-half height of the phase-change material (PCM) were measured in the experiments using n-octadecane as a PCM. The analytical results agreed well with the experimental results. The variations of Nusselt number on the heated cylinder and the dimensionless volume of melt region with Rayleigh number and the dimensionless time were clarified. © 1985, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy Storage; Melting; Natural Convection; Numerical Analysis; Phase Change; Vertical Cylinder

Title: Study of heat recovery from ground heat storage of solar energy using a vertical pipe system.
Authors with affiliations: Ochifuji, K.; Nakamura, M.
Abstract: The principal purpose of the experiment was to study the heat recovery of seasonal ground heat storage. Two methods of heat recovery were considered. One was a natural heat recovery method without using a heat pump in which heat storage was started in August and ended in October 1981: the house was left in its natural condition without heating from November; the indoor temperature remained above 6 DEGREE C even in mid February, the coldest season of the year. The other was a mechanical heat recovery method using a heat pump. With this system, heat was stored starting in September and ending in October 1982, and then from early December, the heat pump was operated. The indoor temperature was maintained at 20 DEGREE C. The amount of heat extracted from the soil was larger than that of the heat stored, demonstrating the effects of the mechanical heat recovery method. However, due to the existence of heat restoration from the house to the soil, thorough floor insulation is considered essential for the house with the heat storage system positioned directly under it. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Energy Storage and Transfer System for Excitation of Large Scale Pulsed Superconducting Magnets.
Source title: Nippon Genshiryoku Gakkaishi/Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Authors with affiliations: Onishi, T.; Tateishi, H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Saito A., Nagakubo S.-I., Utaka Y., Katayama K.
Title: A study on the heat transfer of letent heat thermal energy storage (3rd report, Natural convection effects on the performance of a thermal energy storage apparatus with dense plate fins)
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Saito, A.; Nagakubo, S.-I.; Utaka, Y.; Katayama, K.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Author Keywords: Convective Heat Transfer; Latent Heat; Numerical Analysis; Thermal Conduction; Thermal Energy storage

Authors: Ogawa H., Araki S., Oohusa T., Kayama M.
Title: Browning of Dried Laver “Hoshi-nori’
Affiliations: Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo, 143, Japan; Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Applied Biological Science, Hiroshima University, Midori, Fukuyama, Hiroshima, 720, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ogawa, H., Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo, 143, Japan; Araki, S., Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo, 143, Japan; Oohusa, T., Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo, 143, Japan; Kayama, M., Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Applied Biological Science, Hiroshima University, Midori, Fukuyama, Hiroshima, 720, Japan
Abstract: We studied an influence of water activity (aw) on the rate of non-enzymic browning reaction in hoshi-nori (dried laver, Porphyra spp.) stored at 10-30°. The browning was determined by measuring the extinction value at 420nm of 5% metaphosphoric acid extracts. The browning was accelerated on increasing the water activity and the temperature while almost no browning could be observed below BET's monolayer moisture value at 10-30°. How ever, the maximum browning was found between aw 0.4-0.8 since the reaction rate was rather reduced at the higher water activity. The position of the maximum browning shifted to a lower water activity with increasing the storage temperature. Therefore, the existence of the maximum is attributed to both the effects of the increasing mobility and the dilution of the reactants by the influence of the water. The browning was inhibited in an oxygen free atmosphere, irrespective of the water activity. Thermodynamic parameters for the browning were obtained from the rate constants of the reaction. The activation entropy change (ΔS0) depended on the altering of the water activity more than the temperature. A highly linear correlation between ΔS and ΔH (the activation ent halpy change) became evident, regardless of the temperature, which was known in the denaturation of the proteins. The change of activation free energy (ΔG) was maximum at aw 0.05 corre sponding to the water activity for the most safe storage of hoshi-nori. We postulated that the influence of the water activity on hoshi-nori during the storage can be reflected in the browning reaction. Consequently, the browning of hoshi-nori (i.e. extinction value at 420nm) may be able to be used as an index to estimate a background about humidity conditions during the storage. © 1985, The Japanese Society of Fisheries Science. All rights reserved.

Authors: Iwamoto M., Ioka H., Saito M., Yamanaka H.
Title: Relation between Rigor Mortis of Sea Bream and Storage Temperatures
Affiliations: Marine Products Utilization Division, Shimane Prefectural Fisheries Ex-, perimental Station, Setogashima 25-1, Hamada, Shimane, 697, Japan; Department of Food Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Fisheries, Konan 4, Minato, Tokyo, 108, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Iwamoto, M., Marine Products Utilization Division, Shimane Prefectural Fisheries Ex-, perimental Station, Setogashima 25-1, Hamada, Shimane, 697, Japan; Ioka, H., Marine Products Utilization Division, Shimane Prefectural Fisheries Ex-, perimental Station, Setogashima 25-1, Hamada, Shimane, 697, Japan; Saito, M., Marine Products Utilization Division, Shimane Prefectural Fisheries Ex-, perimental Station, Setogashima 25-1, Hamada, Shimane, 697, Japan; Yamanaka, H., Department of Food Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Fisheries, Konan 4, Minato, Tokyo, 108, Japan
Abstract: nfluences of storage temperatures on the prolongation of pre-rigor period of sea bream Pagrus major were examined. The amounts of ATP in the muscle of sea bream decreased more rapidly and rigor mortis proceeded faster at 0° than at 10°. In the muscle stored at 10° the onset of rigor mortis occurred seven hours later than at 0°. The formation of lactic acid in the muscle of sea bream was parallel with the development of rigor mortis, i.e., the large amounts of ATP supplied through glycolysis were considered to be used as the contraction energy. K value as theindex of freshness at 10° was twice as high as at 0°, however, after 48h of storage at10° it was below 10% which is thought to be very fresh. The production of inosinic acid during the storage at 0° was more prompt than at 10°. The decrease in ATP amounts was also examined in the muscle of plaice Paralichthys olivaceus stored at -3°, 0°, 5° and 10°. At -3° and 0° ATP decomposed very rapidly, followed by 5° and most slowly at 10°. © 1985, The Japanese Society of Fisheries Science. All rights reserved.

Title: Integrated power and attitude control systems for space station
Affiliations: Rockwell International, Space Station Systems Division, Downey, CA, United States; Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, Inc., Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oglevie, R.E., Rockwell International, Space Station Systems Division, Downey, CA, United States; Eisenhaure, D.B., Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, Inc., Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: Integrated Power and Attitude Control Systems (IPACS) studies performed over a decade ago established the feasibility of simultaneously storing electrical energy in wheels and utilizing the resulting momentum for spacecraft attitude control. It was shown that such a system possessed many advantages over other contemporary energy storage and attitude control systems in many applications. More recent technology advances in composite rotors, magnetic bearings, and power control electronics have triggered new optimism regarding the feasibility and merits of such a system. The paper presents the results of a recent Study whose focus was to define an advanced IPACS and to evaluate its merits for the Space Station application. A system and component design concept is developed to establish the system performance capability. A system level trade study, including life-cycle costing, is performed to define the merits of the system relative to two other candidate systems. It is concluded that an advanced IPACS concept is not only feasible, but offers substantial savings in mass, and life-cycle cost. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1985. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Attitude control; Communication satellites; Control systems; Life cycle; Power control; Space stations; Component design; Composite rotors; Electrical energy; Integrated power and attitude control system; Life cycle costing; Performance capability; Spacecraft attitude control; Technology advances; Electric power system control

Title: Solar concentrator for space power generation
Affiliations: Department of Aeronautics & Astronautics, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lindsay, J.E., Department of Aeronautics & Astronautics, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Nerheim, C.S., Department of Aeronautics & Astronautics, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: A solar collector of Cassegrainian type, designed to collect over 1000 kilowatts of solar energy, is presented. When combined with energy storage, a dynamic energy conversion cycle, and a liquid droplet radiator for heat rejection, the system has great potential for space station applications. Wrapped ribs provide the supporting structure for the mirrors, and the reflective surface is to be aluminized Kapton. An opening at the base of the large mirror provides the entrance to energy storage. Located at this opening is a conic concentrator to enhance the energy gathering capability of the system. The component and total mass of a typical system is computed. Computerized ray tracing is used to examine the interaction between the structural and optical aspects of the mirror system. The aiming accuracy of the configuration is very sensitive to vibrations of the secondary mirror. The effects of these on the focusing power of the mirrors is investigated, and the maximum allowable displacement is determined. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astonautics, Inc., 1985. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Concentration (process); Energy conversion; Energy storage; Mirrors; Ray tracing; Solar energy; Space stations; Spacecraft power supplies; Allowable displacement; Heat rejection; Liquid droplet radiators; Mirror systems; Reflective surfaces; Secondary mirror; Supporting structure; Total mass; Space power generation

Title: Performance Evaluation of Forced Stratified Thermal Energy Storage Tank and Comparison with the Perfect Stratified and the Perfect Mixed Thermal Energy Storage Tank
Affiliations: National Chemical Laboratory for Industry, 305, Tsukuba, Japan; Government Industrial Development Laboratory, Hokkaido, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakashima, Y., National Chemical Laboratory for Industry, 305, Tsukuba, Japan, Government Industrial Development Laboratory, Hokkaido, Japan; Fujiwara, I., National Chemical Laboratory for Industry, 305, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The concept of a forced stratified thermal energy storage tank which has multiple compartments divided by insulating and permeable horizontal plates is proposed for energy conservation. Performance of this tank is evaluated by a relatively simple evaluationmethod and compared with the ideal perfect stratified thermal energy storage tank and perfect mixed thermal energy storage tank. It is suggested that the performance of the forced stratified thermal energy storage tank is high and nearly comparable with the perfect stratified thermal energy storage tank. It is also shown that exergy loss with thermal energy accumulation by the forced stratified thermal energy storage tank having 8 compartments is about one-fifth that of the perfect mixed thermal energy storage tank. © 1985, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Design; Energy; Evaluation; Heat Tranfer; Sensible Heat; Thermal Energy Storage

Authors: Matsuda H., Ishizu T., Lee S.K., Hasatani M.
Title: Kinetic Study of Ca(Oh)2/Cao Reversible Thermochemical Reaction for Thermal Energy Storage by Means of Chemical Reaction
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., 464, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuda, H., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., 464, Nagoya, Japan; Ishizu, T., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., 464, Nagoya, Japan; Lee, S.K., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., 464, Nagoya, Japan; Hasatani, M., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., 464, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: The following reversible thermochemical reaction involving both an exothermic and an endothermic process was studied from the fundamental point of view of reaction kinetics in order to apply this reaction system to thermal energy storage by means of chemical reaction. [equation omitted] Both the hydration of CaO and the dehydration of Ca(OH)2 were studied in the chemical reaction control region by a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) with the reactant solid particle size under 5 μm, the reaction temperature 356.2-723.2 K and the steam concentation 1.515.7 vol%. Reaction parameters such as rate constant, activation energy and reaction order of the individual reaction were determined by the obtained TGA experimental results on the basis of the Grain Model by assuming the presence of a reaction intermediate, CaO·H2O*, in the course of reaction. It was found that the reaction orders of both the hydration of CaO and the dehydration of Ca(OH)2 with respect to the concentration of solid reactant and the partial pressure of steam were 1.0. Further, it was found that the overall reaction rate constants of both reactions could be expressed in non-linear form, which gave a maximum value at about 473.2 K for the hydration of CaO. © 1985, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Calcium Oxide; Complex Reaction Kinetics; Gas Solid Reaction; Thermal Energy Storage; Thermochemical Reaction

Title: Daily Utilization and Consumption of Energy in Food by the Silkworm, Bombyx mori (Lepidoptera: Bombycidae)
Affiliations: National Institute of Agrobiological Resources, Ibaraki 305, Yatabe, Japan; Sericultural Experiment Station, Ibaraki 305, Yatabe, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Horie, Y., National Institute of Agrobiological Resources, Ibaraki 305, Yatabe, Japan, Sericultural Experiment Station, Ibaraki 305, Yatabe, Japan
Abstract: Daily utilization and consumption of energy in food by the silkworm, Bombyx mori, were determined, and the quantitative distribution of the energy absorbed into the body of the larva, pupa, adult, and in the eggs and cocoon-shell was estimated. The amounts of energy ingested and absorbed during the 4th and 5th instars were 24.7 and 11.7 kcal for the male larva, and 28.5 and 13.6 kcal for the female, respectively. The rate of energy utilization was 47 to 48%. The average daily ingestion of energy was approximately 1.0 kcal/g of fresh body weight in both sexes during the larval stage and average daily absorption of energy was 0.49 kcal in both sexes. Energy gain in a larva was 6.7 and 7.9 kcal for the male and female during the same period. Energy consumption in relation to catabolism was 5.0 and 5.4 kcal/larva in the male and female, and the average daily consumption of energy was 0.18 and 0.17 kcal/g of fresh body weight for the male and female. The efficiency of storage of the energy ingested and absorbed in the larva, pupa and adult was also calculated. Approximately 25% of the energy absorbed was utilized for the formation of cocoon-shell and 10% was accumulated in the eggs. © 1985, JAPANESE SOCIETY OF APPLIED ENTOMOLOGY AND ZOOLOGY. All rights reserved.

Authors: Itaya Y., Arai N., Hasatani M.
Title: Characteristics of Radiative Energy Collection by a Fine-Particle Semitransparent Suspension (Fpss) Used as a Heat Vehicle and Storage Medium of “Volume Heat-Trap” Type Solar Collector
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng, Nagoya Univ, 464, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Itaya, Y., Dept. of Chem. Eng, Nagoya Univ, 464, Nagoya, Japan; Arai, N., Dept. of Chem. Eng, Nagoya Univ, 464, Nagoya, Japan; Hasatani, M., Dept. of Chem. Eng, Nagoya Univ, 464, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: The effects of suspension concentration, depth of layer and boundary optical condition on the rate and efficiency of radiative energy collection of a volume heat-trap type solar collector in which a FPSS is used as a heat vehicle and storage medium were studied experimentally and theoretically. Experiments were conducted for the stagnant layer of a graphitediethylphthalate suspension, heated stepwise by a Xe-lamp from the upper side. The theoretically calculated results were in satisfactory agreement with the experimental data, and it was shown that the efficiency of radiative energy collection in this type of solar collector could surpass easily that in the surface heat-trap collector. In addition, peak efficiency was observed at a certain suspension concentration, and the optical thickness at the peak was almost constant regardless of the depth of the suspension layer. © 1985, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy; Fine Particle Suspension; Fine Particle Suspension; Heat Storage; Heat Transfer; Semitransparent Liquid; Solar Collector; Thermal Radiation

Authors: SAMEJIMA K., EGELANDSDAL B., FRETHEIM K.
Title: Heat Gelation Properties and Protein Extractability of Beef Myofibrils
Affiliations: Norwegian Food Research Institute, P.O. Box 50, N-1432, Norway; Dept of Dairy Science, The College of Dairying, Ebetsu, 069-01, Japan

Box 50, N-1432, Norway, Dept of Dairy Science, The College of Dairying, Ebetsu, 069-01, Japan; FRETHEIM, K., Norwegian Food Research Institute, P.O. Box 50, N-1432, Norway, Dept of Dairy Science, The College of Dairying, Ebetsu, 069-01, Japan
Abstract: At a heating rate of 1oC/min suspensions (pH 6.0) of isolated beef myofibrils were found to start forming gels at 43‐56oC, as detected by dynamic rheological measurements. The increase in gel storage modulus levelled off at temperatures > 65oC. At medium to high (0.3‐0.6M) concentrations of sodium chloride, addition of pyrophosphate (plus magnesium chloride) had the following effects: (1) both the protein extractability of non‐heated myofibrils and the storage moduli of heat‐induced gels were markedly increased; (2) the apparent activation energy for gel formation was decreased. Increasing concentrations of sodium chloride, up to 0.5‐0.6M, increased the protein concentration of the liquid phase of the gels. Copyright © 1985, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: A REVIEW OF TEXTURAL DEFECTS IN COOKED RECONSTITUTED LEGUMES– THE INFLUENCE OF STORAGE AND PROCESSING
Source title: Journal of Food Processing and Preservation
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Catholic University, Santiago, Chile; Department of Food Science, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: AGUILERA, J.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, Catholic University, Santiago, Chile; STANLEY, D.W., Department of Food Science, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: Legumes provide an important part of the world's protein requirements, as well as other nutrients, but they are underutilized as food. A major factor limiting expanded consumption is storage induced textural defects that prolong cooking time and demand correspondingly higher energy requirements for preparation. Estimates of losses due to hardening are difficult to obtain but show the economic importance of the problem. These defects, including the hard‐to‐cook phenomenon and hard shell, are initiated by structural and compositional factors but can be at least partially controlled by storage and processing conditions. The available literature on bean hardening is reviewed from which it may be concluded that adverse storage conditions (high temperatures and humidities) consistently produce these defects. A kinetic approach is taken to the hardening problem, including hydration and cooking, which should allow a better understanding of the processes involved. Methods that can be utilized to produce better cooking legumes are reviewed as are processing alternatives including disruption and dry fractionation, wet fractionation, extrusion, enzymes and animal feeding. The influence of hardening on the nutritive value of legumes, although not extensively studied, is examined and it is concluded that protein quality and the availability of essential amino acids can suffer. A course of action for future research is recommended. Copyright © 1985, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: STATISTICAL EVALUATION OF ARRHENIUS MODEL AND ITS APPLICABILITY IN PREDICTION OF FOOD QUALITY LOSSES
Source title: Journal of Food Processing and Preservation
Affiliations: Institute of Quality Control & Extension Services for the Food Industry, 76 Mazeh Street, Tel Aviv, 65789, Israel; Department of Food Sciences, Volcani Center Agricultural Research Organization, P.O. Box 6, Bet Dagan, 50–250, Israel
Authors with affiliations: COHEN, E., Institute of Quality Control & Extension Services for the Food Industry, 76 Mazeh Street, Tel Aviv, 65789, Israel; SAGUY, I., Department of Food Sciences, Volcani Center Agricultural Research Organization, P.O. Box 6, Bet Dagan, 50–250, Israel
Abstract: To minimize quality losses occurring during processing and storage and to predict shelf‐life, quantitative kinetic models, expressing the functional relationship between composition and environmental factors on food quality, are required. The applicability of these models is based on the accuracy of the model and its parameters. In this paper, the calculation of the Arrhenius parameters and the accuracy of the derived model were compared, using three statistical methods, namely: linear least squares, nonlinear least squares and weighted nonlinear least squares. Results indicated that the traditional two‐step linear method, was the least accurate and the derived energy of activation and the pre‐exponential factor had the largest confidence interval. The latter was shown to have a profound effect on the precision of the calculated rate constant and the predicted shelf life. Based on previous reports that indexes of deterioration Copyright © 1985, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: A REVIEW OF TEXTURAL DEFECTS IN COOKED RECONSTITUTED LEGUMES —THE INFLUENCE OF STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION
Affiliations: Department of Food Science, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, Canada; Department of Chemical Engineering, Catholic University, Santiago, Chile
Authors with affiliations: STANLEY, D.W., Department of Food Science, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, Canada; AGUILERA, J.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, Catholic University, Santiago, Chile
Abstract: Legumes provide an important part of the world's protein requirements, as well as other nutrients, but they are underutilized as food. A major factor limiting expanded consumption is storage induced textural defects that prolong cooking time and demand correspondingly higher energy requirements for preparation. These defects, including the hard‐to‐cook phenomenon and hardshell, are initiated by structural and compositional factors but can be at least partially controlled by storage and processing conditions. Structural components implicated include seed coat, cell walls, middle lamella, starch granules and membranes while, compositionally, proteins, carbohydrates, phytate, polyphenols and lignin may also be important. Methods of texture measurement of legumes, including mechanical, physical and sensory properties are reviewed. The most commonly held hypothesis for the mechanism of the hard‐to‐cook defect states that beans fail to soften after exposure to high temperature and humidity storage because the increased water activity potentiates phytase which hydrolyzes phytate, rendering it no longer capable of chelating the Ca++ and Mg++ ions of the middle lamella and, hence, undissoluble. More recent evidence, however, provides potential roles for lignification, starch gelatinization and perhaps other mechanisms depending upon conditions. The possibility of a nonenzymatic as well as an enzymatic route is raised and thoughts presented on a course of action for future research. Copyright © 1985, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: A simple method for the extraction of reducing and non‐reducing sugars from carrot and other storage root vegetables
Source title: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture
Affiliations: National Vegetable Research Station, Wellesbourne, Warwick, CV35 9EF, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: McKee, J.M.T., National Vegetable Research Station, Wellesbourne, Warwick, CV35 9EF, United Kingdom
Abstract: A procedure is described for the extraction of sucrose, glucose and fructose from storage root vegetables. An automatic domestic pressure cooker containing a circular test tube rack holding 36 tubes was used for the extraction. All water soluble sugars were extracted in 30 min at 110°C. The method is at least as efficient as those using hot ethanol and methanol: chloroform:water and is significantly more efficient in its use of time and energy. Copyright © 1985 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd
Author Keywords: carrot; fructose; glucose; parsnip; Sucrose; swede

Title: Storage Stability of Dehydrated and Soy‐Fortified Fermented Maize Meal
Affiliations: Dept. of Food Science & Human Nutrition, Washington State Univ, Pullman, Washington, 99164-6330, United States; Washington State Univ, the Food Research Institute, P.O. Box M20, Accra, Ghana
Authors with affiliations: PLAHAR, W.A., Washington State Univ, the Food Research Institute, P.O. Box M20, Accra, Ghana; LEUNG, H.K., Dept. of Food Science & Human Nutrition, Washington State Univ, Pullman, Washington, 99164-6330, United States
Abstract: Dehydrated fermented maize meal samples fortified with soy flour at 0, 10, and 20% replacement concentrations were stored at 25, 35, 45 and 60°C. Selected samples were analyzed for nonenzymatic browning, lipid oxidation, available lysine loss, and change in pasting properties during storage. Production of browning pigments followed zero order kinetics with activation energies of 125‐150 KJ/mole. Multi‐phase loss of available lysine was observed in soy fortified maize meal but not in unfortified samples. Total carbonyl content of the samples increased during storage. Considerable changes in pasting properties of the samples occurred during the first 2 months of storage at 25 and 35°C. Nineteen weeks of storage at 35°C caused adverse changes in sensory quality of the 10% soy fortified sample, but not in the unfortified sample. Copyright © 1985, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Kinetics of Folacin Destruction in Swiss Chard During Storage
Affiliations: Div. of Food Science & Nutrition, Dept. of Home Economics, California State Univ, Northridge, California, 91330, United States
Authors with affiliations: GAMI, D.B., Div. of Food Science & Nutrition, Dept. of Home Economics, California State Univ, Northridge, California, 91330, United States; CHEN, T.‐S., Div. of Food Science & Nutrition, Dept. of Home Economics, California State Univ, Northridge, California, 91330, United States
Abstract: The folacin activities in fresh Swiss chard leaves stored in open air at 4, 21, 35 and 40°C were determined by a microbiological assay using Lactobacillus casei. At 21°C the leaves were also stored in plastic bags and under moist conditions. Folacin was most stable when the vegetable was stored in plastic bags, followed by the moist condition, and least stable in open air at 21°C. The degradation of folacin in Swiss chard under all conditions followed firstorder kinetics. The temperature dependent folate degradation conformed to the Arrhenius equation and the activation energy was 24 kcal/mole. Copyright © 1985, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: An experimental system for X‐ray microanalysis, digital electron‐beam control and image processing
Affiliations: Universität des Saarlandes, Saarbrücken, D-6600, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fuchs, H., Universität des Saarlandes, Saarbrücken, D-6600, Germany
Abstract: An energy‐dispersive microanalyser was extended for the acquisition and processing of electron microscopic images and digital beam control. Based on fast magnetic disk storages and hardware arithmetic units, the software implementation of most functions including raster‐scan and vector‐scan sequencing, and the continuous output monitoring of stored images has proven adequate. As a consequence, few hardware extensions had to be installed, essentially consisting of analog/digital circuitry. Data processing is performed by an interactive, menu‐driven Fortran software package. Copyright © 1985 Foundation for Advances in Medicine and Science, Inc.

Authors: Tenan M.N., Ortiz C.H., Dellamora-Ortiz G.M., Mattoon J.R., Panek A.D.
Title: Relationships between mutations affecting protein kinase and accumulation of energy reserves in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
Affiliations: Departamento de Bioquímica, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Cidade Universitária, 21941 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil; Department of Biology, College of Letters, Arts and Sciences, Colorado Springs, CO 80907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tenan, M.N., Departamento de Bioquímica, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Cidade Universitária, 21941 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil; Ortiz, C.H., Departamento de Bioquímica, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Cidade Universitária, 21941 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil; Dellamora-Ortiz, G.M., Departamento de Bioquímica, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Cidade Universitária, 21941 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil; Mattoon, J.R., Department of Biology, College of Letters, Arts and Sciences, Colorado Springs, CO 80907, United States; Panek, A.D., Departamento de Bioquímica, Instituto de Química, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Cidade Universitária, 21941 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil
Abstract: Independently discovered mutations which alter cyclic-AMP dependent protein kinase activity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae are analysed in relation to trehalose and glycogen storage. The defective trehalose and glycogen accumulation in strains which bear the glc1 mutation results from abnormal activation of trehalase by a protein kinase which has partially lost its cAMP dependence. Cells bearing the bcy1 mutation produce an altered protein kinase due to extremely low levels of the cAMP-binding protein. This altered kinase activates trehalase, resulting in low trehalose contents in these cells. In cell-free extracts of control strains (S288C and 7Q-2D), which produce normal levels of glycogen and trehalose, the enzyme trehalase is mainly found in an inactive, cryptic form. Each of the haploid strains containing one of the mutant genes (glc1, glc4-1 and bcy1) is defective in both trehalose and glycogen accumulation and exhibits low activation ratios of trehalase by protein kinase. Genetic complementation experiments clearly establish that the bcy1 mutation involves a different gene to that altered by the glc1 mutation, since the resulting diploid behaved normally. Strain AM9-10D, previously classified as wild-type (normal for bcy1), is defective in the accumulation of trehalose and glycogen and exhibits almost all trehalose in the active form. © 1985.
Author Keywords: glycogen; Protein kinase; Saccharomyces cerevisiae; trehalase

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Hutchinson F.D., Sr., Stange J.R., Schainker R.B., Canova F.
Title: Compressed air energy storage: Plant integration, turbomachinery development
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: All Gibbs Hill, Inc., United States; Energy Storage Electric Power Research Institute, United States; Turbodyne Dresser Industries, Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., All Gibbs Hill, Inc., United States; Hutchinson, F.D., Sr., All Gibbs Hill, Inc., United States; Stange, J.R., All Gibbs Hill, Inc., United States; Schainker, R.B., Energy Storage Electric Power Research Institute, United States; Canova, F., Turbodyne Dresser Industries, Inc., United States
Abstract: Results of engineering and optimization of 25 MW and 50 MW turbomachinery trains for compressed air energy storage (CAES) power plant application are presented. Proposals submitted by equipment suppliers are based on commercially available equipment. Performance data and budget prices indicate that the CAES power plant is one of the most cost effective sources of providing peaking/intermediate power and load management. The paper addresses CAES power plant integration procedure and the specifics of turbomachinery design. ©1985 by ASME.
