Title: Solar thermochemical hydrogen: The heat source-process interface
Affiliations: University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY 40506, United States; Engineering Research Group, 138 West Pomona Avenue, Monrovia, CA 91016, United States
Authors with affiliations: Funk, J.E., University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY 40506, United States; England, C., Engineering Research Group, 138 West Pomona Avenue, Monrovia, CA 91016, United States
Abstract: A discussion of issues and considerations related to the interface between a solar heat source and a thermochemical hydrogen process and some details of a tubular heat exchanger operating as such an interface in a cavity-type receiver are presented. The issues include the temperature and heat input requirements for the endothermic reaction, type of receiver, heat storage, transient operations, and control. A thermal performance analysis of a tubular reactor/heat exchanger operating in a cavity-type solar receiver is applied to SO3 decomposition. The analysis produces axial distributions of temperature tube wall and process fluid, reaction rate, conversion, velocity, density, pressure and residence time. Process fluid conditions at the inlet, tube characteristics, reaction kinetics and cavity operating temperature are inputs. The cavity temperature affects average heat flux and, therefore, heat-exchanger cost and receiver efficiency and, therefore, mirror field cost. A design which minimizes the combined cost may be found and examples are shown. © 1985.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Analysis; SOLAR ENERGY; CAVITY TEMPERATURE; HEAT SOURCE-PROCESS INTERFACE; SOLAR THERMOCHEMICAL HYDROGEN; HYDROGEN

Title: SYSTEM LEVEL ELECTROCHEMICAL PRINCIPLES.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thaller, Lawrence H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: It is stated that the traditional electrochemical storage concepts are difficult to translate into high power, high voltage multikilowatt storage systems. The increased use of electronics, as well as the use of electrochemical couples that minimize the difficulties associated with the corrective measures to reduce the cell to cell capacity dispersion, have already been adopted by battery technologists. However, these concepts can become quite complicated and heavy. Actively cooled bipolar concepts are described which represent some attractive alternative system concepts. In general, they are projected to have higher energy densities lower volumes than current concepts. Grouped together, these ideas are simply referred to as system level electrochemistry. The hydrogen-oxygen RFC is probably the best example of the integrated use of these principles.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ENERGY STORAGE; BATTERY PACK APPROACHES; HYDROGEN-OXYGEN RFC; REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL (RFC); SPACECRAFT

Authors: Prakash J., Garg H.P., Datta G.
Title: A solar water heater with a built-in latent heat storage
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Ramjas College, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007, India; Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Prakash, J., Department of Physics, Ramjas College, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007, India; Garg, H.P., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Datta, G., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: In this paper, we have investigated the performance of a novel built-in storage type water heater containing a layer of PCM-filled capsules at the bottom. The PCM layer is introduced with a view of getting hot water during off-sunshine hours. The moving solid-liquid boundary layer problem for the PCM material is simplified to a stationary boundary layer problem, and the effect of latent heat is included in the specific heat by replacing the semi-melted PCM by a fictitious solid. The performance of the water heater is then predicted analytically for two depths of PCM and for different flow rates, both constant and intermittent. The case of sudden withdrawal of water over very short periods is also studied. © 1985.

Authors: Ise Toshifumi, Murakami Yoshishige, Tsuji Kiichiro
Title: SIMULTANEOUS ACTIVE AND REACTIVE POWER CONTROL OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE USING GTO CONVERTER.
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Suita, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ise, Toshifumi, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Suita, Jpn; Murakami, Yoshishige, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Suita, Jpn; Tsuji, Kiichiro, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Suita, Jpn
Abstract: By using GTOs (Gate Turn-Off Thyristor) in place of ordinary thyristors in a conventional six-pulse Greatz bridge converter, forced communication is possible, so in the usage of ac-dc power conversion the reactive power of not only lagging but also leading phase can be absorbed. This feature enables superconducting magnet energy storage (SMES) to control reactive power in the wide range between lagging and leading phases. By virtue of this control ability, SMES will be applicable for a power system stabilizer. The experiments on the developed control system were successfully performed and the ability of controlling reactive power in the wide range between lagging phase and leading phase was verified.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Energy Storage; THYRISTORS - Switching; ACTIVE/REACTIVE POWER CONTROL; GATE TURN-OFF CONVERTER; SIX-PULSE GREATZ BRIDGE CONVERTER; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors: Nimmer Ronald P., Torossian Kevorc A., Hickey John S.
Title: FABRICATION AND SPIN TESTS OF THICK LAMINATED S2-GLASS FLYWHEEL DISKS.
Affiliations: GE, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Schenectady, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Nimmer, Ronald P., GE, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Schenectady, NY, USA; Torossian, Kevorc A., GE, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Schenectady, NY, USA; Hickey, John S., GE, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Schenectady, NY, USA
Abstract: In transportation-related applications, a primary design consideration is to store the maximum amount of energy per unit weight of the flywheel. Based upon this criterion, the high strength-to-density ratios of composite materials make them attractive materials for an efficient design. This investigation reports on a program to develop a composite flywheel consisting of a laminated S2-glass/epoxy central disk and a filament-wound graphite/epoxy outer ring. It is shown both analytically and experimentally that the presence of the outer ring significantly improves the energy density available in a simple laminated disk. Consideration is given to the subjects of fabrication, failure criteria, and experimental determination of ultimate speed and strength of prototype flywheels.

Title: COMPOSITE LATENT/SENSIBLE ENERGY STORAGE MEDIA FOR HIGH-TEMPERATURE INDUSTRIAL APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olszewski, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: An advanced thermal energy storage media concept is being developed for industrial process and reject heat applications. This composite medium consists of a phase-change carbonate salt, supported and immobilized within a submicron-sized capillary structure of a particulate ceramic matrix or porous sintered ceramic. Economic viability of the concept, especially in comparison to extant sensible heat storage systems, is presented.

Title: Effect of design parameters on performance of built-in-storage solar water heaters
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Garyounis University, Benghazi, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya
Authors with affiliations: Muneer, T., Mechanical Engineering Department, Garyounis University, Benghazi, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya
Abstract: Solar domestic water heaters are usually forced circulation or thermosyphon heaters. A new design of heater in which the storage and collector are combined in one unit has been tested. The construction of the heater involves a rectangular box-like structure with the top face painted black and enclosed behind a single or double sheet of glass. The back surface and sides are insulated, with the assembly inclined at a suitable angle. The main advantages of such a heater are higher collection efficiency, due to direct contact of water with the absorber plate, and the absence of pipes connecting the collector to storage. In this study, the effect of storage volume/collector area ratio, number of glazings and mode of operation on the heater's performance was experimentally investigated. The work involved construction of three built-in-storage heaters, two of which had depths of 8 cm and one of 6 cm. The heaters were operated concurrently for 5 months in which measurements of heated water temperature, ambient temperature and insolation were made. Experimentation was carried out to study the effect of storage tank depth (volume/collector area) over a 4-month period by side-by-side operation of 6-cm and 8-cm heaters. The maximum and minimum temperatures recorded for the 6-cm heater were 76 and 46°C, respectively, while the corresponding temperatures for the 8-cm heater were 70 and 41°C, respectively. The day-average maximum efficiencies of the 6-cm and 8-cm heaters were 65 and 73%, respectively, with a difference of 8-10% throughout the observation period. The study of stratification on the two heaters showed no significant influence of the depth. The effect of glass covers was studied by tests on two heaters, both of 8-cm depth. One of these had a single glass cover while the other was double-glazed. The double-glazed heater performed better with a difference of 1-10°C in water temperature. Different modes of operation were studied by concurrent tests on two heaters of 801. capacity. The results showed that best performance could be obtained by drawing off all heated water into a separate storage as soon as it reached a pre-set temperature level (in this study 35°C). The heater was also found to be capable of handling intermittent loads quite easily. Finally, it is concluded that the built-in-storage heater performs quite well under Benghazi conditions, and the choice of 8-cm depth with double-glazing seems a good design optimum. © 1985.
Author Keywords: Bread box heaters; Solar domestic water heaters; Solar energy; Solar energy utilization
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; BREAD-BOX SOLAR HEATERS; BUILT-IN STORAGE HEATERS; OPTIMUM DESIGN; WATER HEATERS

Title: Developments in solar water heaters
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Sorour, M.M., Mechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt
Abstract: This investigation reports various design concepts of solar water heaters for intermittent use and a new concept of continuous water supply. These systems have features in common: they are without water tubes on the collector surface and without water pumps or a separate storage tank. The work highlights technical difficulties encountered in these designs and upgrades the state of the art in solar liquid heaters by proposing and testing different prototypes for a long period of time. © 1985.
Author Keywords: Design optimization; Energy conversion; Solar energy; Water heaters

Title: ENVIRONMENT CONTROL OF GREENHOUSE SOLAR SYSTEM FOR AUTOMATED HYDROPONIC CULTURE.
Affiliations: North Carolina State Univ at, Raleigh, Dep of Biological &, Agricultural Engineering, Raleigh,, North Carolina State Univ at Raleigh, Dep of Biological & Agricultural Engineering, Raleigh, NC
Authors with affiliations: Huang, B.K., North Carolina State Univ at, Raleigh, Dep of Biological &, Agricultural Engineering, Raleigh,, North Carolina State Univ at Raleigh, Dep of Biological & Agricultural Engineering, Raleigh, NC; Nassar, A.H., North Carolina State Univ at, Raleigh, Dep of Biological &, Agricultural Engineering, Raleigh,, North Carolina State Univ at Raleigh, Dep of Biological & Agricultural Engineering, Raleigh, NC
Abstract: An automated hydroponic plant culturing system was developed for the greenhouse solar system by fluctuating the nutrient solution within the vicinity of the plant root system providing proper root aeration. Appropriate climatic and cultural factors required for producing crops hydroponically could be afforded by the airflow and environmental controls available in the greenhouse solar system considered. The solar energy could be effectively utilized to heat the nutrient solution with a system of solar heat-absorber panels in conjunction with the control system. The solar energy storage using nutrient solution provided a practical means of controlling environmental temperature within the structure. Both computer simulation and experimental results showed the feasibility and advantages of the automated hydroponic plant production system.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN; PROCESS CONTROL; SOLAR ENERGY; ENVIRONMENT CONTROL; GREENHOUSE HYDROPONICS; MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS; GREENHOUSES

Title: SOLAR: GENERIC PLANS, SPECIFICATIONS, AND DESIGN GUIDE MANUAL.
Affiliations: TVA, Renewables & Special, Projects Section, Chattanooga, TN,, USA, TVA, Renewables & Special Projects Section, Chattanooga, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Burrows, David L., TVA, Renewables & Special, Projects Section, Chattanooga, TN,, USA, TVA, Renewables & Special Projects Section, Chattanooga, TN, USA; Dinse, D.R., TVA, Renewables & Special, Projects Section, Chattanooga, TN,, USA, TVA, Renewables & Special Projects Section, Chattanooga, TN, USA
Abstract: To reduce the initial design and construction costs, and avoid common problems found in early solar system designs, generic plans and specifications have been developed for commercial active solar water heating systems. The system types include open-drop and siphon-return drainback and glycol antifreeze. These generic plans and specifications must be adapted for site-specific requirements with all components being up- or down-sized relative to the collector array. The drawings include a system flow schematic, control schematic with logic, collector spacing and supports, pump and heat exchanger schedule, and general notes. The specifications cover controls, collectors, pumps, storage tanks, insulation, piping system, and heat exchangers in typical format. The manual is written in practical language covering system basics, site feasibility, preliminary design, final design, system component selection, construction, startup, troubleshooting, and operation and maintenance.

Title: Performance analysis of a solar air-conditioned villa in the arabian gulf
Affiliations: Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Osman, M.G., Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait
Abstract: An integrated system which utilizes three types of solar energy subsystems for the purpose of air-conditioning (i.e. heating and cooling) in residential buildings has been designed, installed and tested in the KISR solar house, Kuwait. The three systems are: (a) a solar photovoltaic power system, (b) a solar air heating and rock storage system and (c) a solar water heating, cooling and domestic water heating system. This paper gives a general survey of the design and operation of the solar energy systems. The performance of the different solar energy systems is reported in terms of collector efficiency, solar energy contribution and the use of electrical energy to operate the solar equipment and of fossil fuels to back up the operation of the solar energy system. The general characteristics of the three types of systems are also compared. Information concerning installation, operation and maintenance of the systems has been discussed. © 1985.

Authors: Truman C.R., Wildin M.W., Yoo J.
Title: SCALE MODELING OF STRATIFIED WATER THERMAL STORAGE TANKS.
Affiliations: Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical, Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Truman, C.R., Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical, Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Wildin, M.W., Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical, Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Yoo, J., Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical, Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Scale models of thermally stratified chilled water storage tanks were constructed and operated in a test system which modeled full scale tanks. Temperature distributions in the water and tank walls were used to estimate changes in internal energy. Flow rates and temperatures were used to calculate energy convected by the flows to and from the tanks. These data and flow visualization by dye injection were used to examine the effects of flow rate, wall heat transfer and type of stratification system. The scale model results show that temperature distributions, outlet temperatures during discharging, and thermal efficiencies reasonably approximate those for full scale tanks.

Title: NEW METHOD FOR EVALUATING COMPOSITE RESERVOIR SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth, Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Benson, S.M., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth, Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA; Lai, C.H., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth, Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: A simple new technique has been developed for evaluating interference test data in radially symmetric composite reservoirs. The technique is based on the realization that systematic variations in the apparent storage coefficient are indicative of a two-mobility reservoir. By analyzing variations in the apparent storage coefficient, both the mobility and size of the inner region can be calculated. The technique is particularly useful for evaluating heterogeneous geothermal systems. The technique is applied to an extensive interference test in the geothermal reservoir at Klamath Falls, Oregon.

Authors: Ruch J., Schmoede P., Katryniok D.
Title: BEHAVIOR OF MnO//2 CATHODES IN NONAQUEOUS ELECTROLYTES.
Affiliations: Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH &, Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke,, Brilon, West Ger, Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH & Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke, Brilon, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Ruch, J., Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH &, Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke,, Brilon, West Ger, Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH & Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke, Brilon, West Ger; Schmoede, P., Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH &, Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke,, Brilon, West Ger, Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH & Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke, Brilon, West Ger; Katryniok, D., Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH &, Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke,, Brilon, West Ger, Carl Zoellner & Sohn GmbH & Co, Accumulatorenwerke Hoppecke, Brilon, West Ger
Abstract: Among the various systems of nonaqueous Lithium cells under development those using MnO//2 as active material have long been considered as not sufficient in power to really compete with those based for instance on SO//2, SOCl//2 or SO//2Cl//2. The characteristics of the present production standard indeed more than meet the requirements for common cells of the D, C, 2/3 A, AAA, or 1/2 AA sizes, so that one can ascertain that MnO//2 is not only competitive but even combines with good electric characteristics a number of advantages among which corrosion behavior, passivation problems or safety aspects are not to be minimized. Principally, characteristics are presented of cells for various conditions of discharge rates or temperature ranges. Then the authors compare them with alternative Lithium systems for specific energy and power density.

Authors: Hoberecht Mark A., Sheibley Dean W.
Title: REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL SYSTEMS FOR SPACE STATION.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hoberecht, Mark A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Sheibley, Dean W., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Regenerative fuel cell (RFC) systems are one of the leading energy storage candidates for Space Station. Key design features include its advanced state of technology readiness and high degree of system level design flexibility. Technology readiness has been demonstrated through extensive testing at the single cell, cell stack, mechanical ancillary component, subsystem, and breadboard levels. Design flexibility characteristics include independent sizing of power and energy storage portions of the system, integration of common reactants with other Space Station systems, and a wide range of various maintenance approaches. These design features have led to selection of a RFC system as the sole electrochemical energy storage technology option for the Space Station Advanced Development Program. (Author abstract. )
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYSIS; FUEL CELLS - Electrolytes; AVERAGE CELL VOLTAGE; DESIGN FLEXIBILITY; OPERATING TIME; REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL (RFC) SYSTEMS; SPACE STATION; SPACECRAFT

Authors: Kuenisch H.-J., Kraemer K.G., Dominik H.
Title: BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE: ANOTHER OPTION FOR LOAD-FREQUENCY-CONTROL AND INSTANTANEOUS RESERVE.
Affiliations: Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger, Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Kuenisch, H.-J., Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger, Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger; Kraemer, K.G., Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger, Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger; Dominik, H., Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger, Berliner Kraft- und Licht AG, Berlin, West Ger
Abstract: Energy storage plants utilizing batteries and thyristor power converters can be operated like pumped hydro storage units. Under the conditions actually prevailing in Europe, load leveling operation of such plants is not economical. Nevertheless, a battery energy storage plant promises both operational and economical advantages for load-frequency-control and instantaneous reserve operation. Queries according to this unconventional operation of batteries have been settled in a test facility in Berlin (West). After two years of test operation a decision was made to build up a full-scale demonstration plant, which will be commissioned in early 1987.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Applications; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; LOAD LEVELING OPERATION; PUMPED HYDROSTORAGE UNITS; RESERVE OPERATION; ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE

Title: The influence of oxidative pretreatment of graphite electrodes on the catalysis of the Cr3+ Cr2+ and Fe3+ Fe2+ redox reactions
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmannsstrasse 22, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hollax, E., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmannsstrasse 22, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany; Cheng, D.Sh., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Oltmannsstrasse 22, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: Cyclic voltammetry was applied to investigate the Cr3+ Cr2+ and Fe3+ Fe2+ redox couple reactions in HCI electrolytes on highly oriented pyrographite electrodes activated by oxidative pretreatment. The activation effect observed after the oxidative pretreatment was very unstable for the Cr3+ Cr2+ reaction in comparison to the Fe3+ reduction. It is thus concluded that acidic surface oxides are participating in the redox reaction. These oxides are reduced, however, in the case of Cr3+ reduction near the potential of hydrogen evolution. © 1985.
Author Keywords: chromium; iron; oxide; pyrographite; Redox reaction; surface oxides
Index Keywords: CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; ENERGY STORAGE; SURFACES; CHROMIUM; IRON; OXIDATION; PRETREATMENT; PYROGRAPHITE; ELECTRODES

Authors: Tiwari G.N., Shukla S.N., Sodha M.S.
Title: Performance of large solar water heating system: Thermosyphon mode
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Tiwari, G.N., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Shukla, S.N., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Sodha, M.S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: Two large solar water heating systems (non-pressure type), each having 1000-1. capacity, have been installed at IIT New Delhi and their performances have been studied under the thermosyphon mode between the collectors and the storage tank. A simple transient analysis of the system, incorporating the effect of withdrawal of hot water from the storage tank, has been developed. The effect of stratification in the storage tank has been studied experimentally. It is found that the experimental observations are in good agreement with the theoretical results obtained by the present model. © 1985.
Author Keywords: Solar energy; Thermosyphon mode; Water heater
Index Keywords: HEATING - Hot Water Systems; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS - Performance; TANKS; STEADY-STATE TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; STORAGE TANKS; THERMOSYPHON MODE; TRANSIENT ANALYSIS; WATER HEATERS

Title: Thermal analysis of honeycomb solar pond
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushika, N.D., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Banerjee, M.B., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: A solar pond consisting of honeycomb panels placed on a thin layer (∼ 1 cm) of silicone oil floating on the body of a hot water reservoir is considered and analysed for the heat transfer processes in the system. An explicit expression for the transient rate of heat extraction at constant temperature is derived to obtain the annual variation of retrieved heat flux. The year-round thermal performance of the system has been investigated. For a solar pond with a 10 cm high honeycomb structure, annual average efficiencies of 65, 48, 33 and 24% are predicted for retrieved heat flux at temperatures of 40, 60, 80 and 90°C, respectively. A comparison between honeycomb solar pond and salt-gradient solar pond is also presented. © 1985.
Author Keywords: Honeycomb; Reversible energy resource; Solar collectors; Solar energy; Solar ponds; Thermal analysis
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Boundary Value Problems; SOLAR ENERGY - Measurements; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COLLECTOR/STORAGE SYSTEM; HONEYCOMB SOLAR POND; REVERSIBLE ENERGY RESOURCE; SILICONE OIL; WATER RESOURCES

Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India

Abstract: This paper presents an optical and thermal analysis of a solar cooker augmented with a planar reflector. Plate temperature as a function of phase change material properties and melting depth is presented. The transient behaviour is elucidated for a typical winter (2 December 1983) day. © 1985.

Title: LIFE CYCLE TEST RESULTS OF A BIPOLAR NICKEL HYDROGEN BATTERY.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cataldo, Robert L., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: This paper presents a history of low earth orbit laboratory test data on a 6. 5 ampere-hour bipolar nickel hydrogen battery designed and built at the NASA Lewis Research Center. During the past several years the Storage and Thermal Branch has been deeply involved in the design, development, and optimization of nickel hydrogen devices. The bipolar concept is a means of achieving the goal of producing an acceptable battery, of higher energy density, able to withstand the demands of low-earth-orbit regimes. (Author abstract. )

Title: Noise Reduction on Mechanical Punch Presses
Affiliations: Institut für Umformtechnik und Umformmaschinen, Universität Hannover
Authors with affiliations: Doege, E., Institut für Umformtechnik und Umformmaschinen, Universität Hannover; Seidel, H.-J., Institut für Umformtechnik und Umformmaschinen, Universität Hannover
Abstract: Noise emmission on punch presses is to a large extent avoided by reducing the impulse sound at the moment of breakthrough. At this moment a part of the strain energy stored in the press prior to fracture becomes available for radiation as sound. With an electronically controlled hydraulic element in the force-flow of a power press it is possible to avoid the rapid unloading of the press frame. At stroke rates up to 400 per minute a noise reduction of up to 10 dB(A) can be obtained. © 1985 CIRP.
Index Keywords: SHOCK ABSORBERS - Applications; FORCE-DISPLACEMENT DIAGRAMS; NOISE REDUCTION POSSIBILITIES; NOISE SOURCES; PRESS NOISE CHARACTERISTICS; PUNCH PRESSES NOISE EMISSION; STRAIN ENERGY STORAGE; PRESSES

Authors: Oppel F.J., Yoon H.K., Ghajar A.J., Moretti P.M.
Title: COMPUTER SIMULATION FOR STRATIFIED THERMAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Mechanical & Aerospace, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oppel, F.J., Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Mechanical & Aerospace, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA; Yoon, H.K., Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Mechanical & Aerospace, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA; Ghajar, A.J., Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Mechanical & Aerospace, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA; Moretti, P.M., Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Mechanical & Aerospace, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA
Abstract: A one-dimensional, explicit, finite difference model of a single tank for stratified thermal storage has been developed and tested on published experimental data. The model covers through-flow conditions for charging or discharging the thermal storage tank; conduction and turbulent mixing; and losses through the wall. It was demonstrated that careful design of the algorithm and choice of the time-step is necessary to avoid computation errors which create apparent mixing in the through-flow calculation. In order to handle variable flow rates, a conceptual 'buffer-tank' algorithm was developed which makes the procedure flexible and useful.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS - Turbulent; FLUIDS - Heat Transfer; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Difference Method; ALGORITHM DESIGN; BUFFER-TANK ALGORITHM; STRATIFIED THERMAL STORAGE; THROUGH-FLOW CONDITIONS; TURBULENT MIXING; WALL LOSSES; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Bruinvis I.A.D., Heukelom S., Mijnheer B.J.
Title: Comparison of ionisation measurements in water and polystyrene for electron beam dosimetry
Affiliations: Dept. of Radiotherapy, Netherlands Cancer Inst., Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bruinvis, I.A.D., Dept. of Radiotherapy, Netherlands Cancer Inst., Amsterdam, Netherlands; Heukelom, S., Dept. of Radiotherapy, Netherlands Cancer Inst., Amsterdam, Netherlands; Mijnheer, B.J., Dept. of Radiotherapy, Netherlands Cancer Inst., Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: For the determination of absorbed dose to water in electron beams, dosimetry protocols advocate ionisation measurements in plastic phantoms instead of water for practical reasons. The chamber readings in polystyrene at the depth of maximum ionisation must be corrected for the difference in physical properties between the two materials. This correction factor was determined for a Farmer 0.6 cm3 graphite-walled chamber in electron beams with mean energies at the phantom surface between 6 and 19 MeV. Experiments with white polystyrene yielded corrections for the measured ionisation ranging from 0.3 to 2.4%. For clear polystyrene, 0.6-1% higher corrections were found. For beams with the same mean energy at the phantom surface, but with different beam-flattening and collimation systems, variations in this correction up to 1.2% were observed. In contrast to recent reports on electrical charge storage in polystyrene due to electron irradiation, the authors' experiments do not show differences in the chamber readings any larger than 0.5%.
Index Keywords: polystyrene; water; dosimetry; fast electron therapy; ionization; methodology; nonbiological model; nonhuman; priority journal; Comparative Study; Electrons; Models, Anatomic; Particle Accelerators; Polystyrenes; Radiation Dosage; Radiometry; Scattering, Radiation; Water

Authors: Garvin P.J., Castaneda M., Niehoff M., Jellinek M., Codd J.E.
Title: An experimental evaluation of nucleotide enhancement techniques for kidney transplantation
Affiliations: Transplant Unit, John Cochran Veteran's Administration and Medical Center, Department of Surgery, St. Louis, MO 63104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garvin, P.J., Transplant Unit, John Cochran Veteran's Administration and Medical Center, Department of Surgery, St. Louis, MO 63104, United States; Castaneda, M., Transplant Unit, John Cochran Veteran's Administration and Medical Center, Department of Surgery, St. Louis, MO 63104, United States; Niehoff, M., Transplant Unit, John Cochran Veteran's Administration and Medical Center, Department of Surgery, St. Louis, MO 63104, United States; Jellinek, M., Transplant Unit, John Cochran Veteran's Administration and Medical Center, Department of Surgery, St. Louis, MO 63104, United States; Codd, J.E., Transplant Unit, John Cochran Veteran's Administration and Medical Center, Department of Surgery, St. Louis, MO 63104, United States
Abstract: The effect of various nucleotide-enhancing agents on renal function and intracellular nucleotide levels was evaluated in a canine autotransplant model. Thirty-five dogs (18-28 kg) underwent left nephrectomy and 30 min of warm ischemia followed by Collins C-4 flush and 24 hr of cold-storage preservation. Heterotopic autotransplantation and immediate contralateral nephrectomy was then performed. Seven equal groups were evaluated: group A-controls, group B-adenosine pretreatment (1.0 g), group C-dipyridamole pretreatment (10 mg), group D-adenosine (1.0 g), and dipyridamole (10 mg) pretreatment, group E-adenosine (200 mg) and EHNA (2.5 mg/kg) pretreatment, group F-adenosine (200 mg) and EHNA (2.5 mg/kg) in the Collins C-4 flush, and group G-adenosine (200 mg) and EHNA (2.5 mg/kg) at the time of autotransplantation. All kidneys underwent cortical biopsies at the end of preservation and 1 hr after restoration of blood flow for determinations of AMP, ADP, and ATP. In the pretreatment groups (groups B through E) there was 60% graft survival whereas the controls (group A) and the groups treated after ischemia (groups F and G) had 0, 0, and 20% graft survival, respectively. In groups B and E, ATP levels were greater than controls after preservation and 1 hr after restoration of blood flow. Group C AMP and ADP levels and group D energy charge were greater than controls in the post-transplantation biopsies. Administration of adenosine and EHNA after ischemia was not associated with increased intracellular nucleotide levels. One hour post-transplantation biopsies demonstrated greater ability to regenerate cortical nucleotides in the surviving animals but no absolute value could be identified as a predictor of viability. In conclusion, pretreatment with adenosine, dipyridamole, and EHNA alone and in combination is beneficial in ischemically injured kidneys undergoing cold-storage preservation. © 1985.
Index Keywords: 9 (2 hydroxy 3 nonyl)adenine; adenosine; dipyridamole; heparin; mannitol; nucleotide; protamine sulfate; biological model; dog; drug efficacy; kidney; kidney function; kidney transplantation; nonhuman; priority journal; Adenine; Adenosine; Animals; Dipyridamole; Dogs; Female; Graft Survival; Kidney; Kidney Transplantation; Nucleotides; Organ Preservation; Transplantation, Autologous

Title: Thyroid hormone action at the nuclear level
Affiliations: Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0311, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oppenheimer, J.H., Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0311, United States
Abstract: Recent findings have led to a greater understanding of thyroid hormone action. The nuclear receptor for triiodothyronine is an integral component of a larger chromatin fragment. A stereospecific energy-dependent transport system appears responsible for translocation of triidothyronine from cytosol to nucleus. In the liver, a multiplicative interaction between a signal from the triiodothyronine-nuclear receptor complex and a signal generated from carbohydrate metabolism results in the induction of specific mRNAs. Two-dimensional mRNA activity profiles suggest that approximately 8% of the visible mRNA sequences are differentially accepted by alterations in thyroid states. Almost 30% to 40% of these changes are mediated by an increase in pituitary growth hormone induced by triidothyronine. Sequential analyses of mRNA activity profiles have identified an mRNA sequence (mRNA(S14)) coding for a protein (S14) with Mr 17 010 and pI 4.9 which responds to triiodothyronine with a lag time of less than 20 minutes. The coordinate regulation of mRNA(S14) by carbohydrate and triidothyronine and its presence in lipogenic tissues (fat, liver, lactating mammary tissue) suggests that S14 is involved in some aspect of fatty acid synthesis degradation or storage.
Index Keywords: cell nucleus receptor; leucine c 14; liothyronine; liothyronine i 125; messenger RNA; methionine s 35; radioisotope; thyroid hormone; unclassified drug; drug efficacy; drug receptor binding; drug therapy; endocrine system; fatty acid synthesis; heredity; hormone action; human; nonhuman; pharmacokinetics; priority journal; review; therapy

Title: Synthesis, experimentation, and the biomechanics of economical movement
Source title: Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise
Affiliations: Nike Sport Research Laboratory, 156 Front Street, Exeter, NH, 03833, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frederick, E.C., Nike Sport Research Laboratory, 156 Front Street, Exeter, NH, 03833, United States
Abstract: An issue that should concern sports biomechanists is the need for more synthesis of ideas and experimental testing of those ideas. Descriptive analysis is overemphasized at present, and more stress on synthesis of existing data and experimental testing of new ideas should generate new theories that will give us insights into the mechanical behavior of structures and the kinetics and kinematics of sports movements. One area where this approach may be especially helpful is in studying the question of what makes movements energetically economical. Twenty-six behavioral and mechanical factors have been shown to have an association with the economy of movement. A synthesis should be undertaken which probes the meaning of these various data. Trends in these findings point to intra- and intersegmental energy transfer, center of mass excursion, and elastic energy storage as potential areas for expanding our understanding of the biomechanics of economical movement. These possibilities might be explored by enhancing link-segmental mathematical models to predict what makes movements economical and then testing these predictions by using biofeedback techniques to train subjects to perform the correct movements while being monitored. Optimization models might offer an additional strategy for developing a theory of mechanically and energetically economical movement. © 1985 by the American College of Sports Medicine.
Author Keywords: Biomechanics; Energetic economy; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Kinematics; Kinetics; Modelling; Synthesis
Index Keywords: biomechanics; human; musculoskeletal system; normal human; sport; theoretical study; Biomechanics; Energy Metabolism; Exertion; Feedback; Human; Kinetics; Models, Biological; Movement

Authors: Bogardus C., Lillioja S., Mott D., Zawadzki J., Young A., Abbott W.
Title: Evidence for reduced thermic effect of insulin and glucose infusions in Pima Indians
Affiliations: Phoenix Clinical Research Section, National Institute of Arthritis, Diabetes, and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bogardus, C., Phoenix Clinical Research Section, National Institute of Arthritis, Diabetes, and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States; Lillioja, S., Phoenix Clinical Research Section, National Institute of Arthritis, Diabetes, and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States; Mott, D., Phoenix Clinical Research Section, National Institute of Arthritis, Diabetes, and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Phoenix, AZ 85016, United States; Zawadzki, J.; Young, A.; Abbott, W.
Abstract: Several authors have reported a reduced thermic effect of food in obese subjects. The hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp technique has been used to measure one component of the thermic effect of food, insulin and insulin-mediated glucose disposal. We used this technique to measure the thermic responses to insulin and glucose infusions in 120 glucose-toleranct Pima Indians, a population with a high prevalence of obesity. During high-dose insulin infusions (400 mU/m2 per min) the measured increase in energy expenditure (MEE), 150 ± 6 cal/min, was greater than the predicted increase in energy expenditure (PEE), 72 ± 2 cal/min, for glucose storage as glycogen. During low-dose insulin infusions (40 mU/m2 per min) the mean MEE, 6 ± 5 cal/min, was not significantly different from zero and was not greater than the mean PEE, 9 ± 1 cal/min. These data were in contrast to results obtained from Caucasians by others and suggested a markedly reduced thermic effect of low-dose insulin and glucose infusions in Pima Indians. We also studied 23 glucose-tolerant male Caucasians and compared their results with the results from male Indians matched for glucose storage rates and obesity. The results showed that the thermic response to insulin and glucose infusions was similar in the two racial groups during high-dose insulin infusions but was markedly reduced in the Indians compared with the Caucasians during low-dose insulin infusions.

Title: EXPERIENCES IN APPLYING DIGITAL OPTICAL TECHNOLOGY TO THE AUTOMATION OF ENGINEERING DRAWING STORAGE AND RETRIEVAL.
Affiliations: GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep,, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep, Schenectady, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Searle, Don R., GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep,, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep, Schenectady, NY, USA; Lechner, Bruce E., GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep,, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep, Schenectady, NY, USA; Fichtel, Kenneth T., GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep,, Schenectady, NY, USA, GE, Steam Turbine-Generator Dep, Schenectady, NY, USA
Abstract: Digital optical storage and retrieval of engineering drawings is helping General Electric's Steam Turbine-Generator Operation (ST-GO) respond quickly to customer requests and orders. With replacement energy costs for a large turbine-generator typically 125,000 to 350,000 or more per day, immediate access to the engineering drawings necessary to respond to service requests is critical. As part of GE's 10-year program in computer-integrated manufacturing (CIM) the automated document storage and retrieval system (ADSRS), developed by Integrated Automation of Alameda, California, will store the 1. 4 million engineering drawings needed to service the 1,000 Schenectady-built turbine-generators in use today.

Title: ANALYSIS OF THE ELASTIC AND STRENGTH PROPERTIES OF YUCCA MOUNTAIN TUFF, NEVADA.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Geomechanics Div,, Albuquerque, NM, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Geomechanics Div, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Price, R.H., Sandia Natl Lab, Geomechanics Div,, Albuquerque, NM, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Geomechanics Div, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Bauer, S.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Geomechanics Div,, Albuquerque, NM, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Geomechanics Div, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Yucca Mountain, located near the southwest margin of the Nevada Test Site, in southern Nevada, is being evaluated as a potential site for a nuclear waste repository. Yucca Mountain consists primarily of layered volcanic tuff. Samples from four stratigraphic units have been tested for physical, thermal and mechanical properties as part of the Nevada Nuclear Waste Storage Investigations Project, administered by the Nevada Operations Office of the U. S. Department of Energy.

Title: A new implicit solution procedure for multidimensional finite-difference modeling of the Stefan problem
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Raw, M.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada; Schneider, G.E., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada
Abstract: A new procedure is presented for multidimensional modeling of the energy transport by conduction in problems involving solid-liquid phase transition. The method is formulated as an enthalpy model, with a fully simultaneous equation formulation made possible by a novel nonlinear iteration algorithm. This algorithm, based on the problem physics, is easily implemented. The procedure has been tested on a number of two-dimensional test cases, and comparisons of computational cost with the con-ventional nonsimuttaneous procedure have been made for a variety of boundary conditions, Stefan numbers, and time step sizes. The results demonstrate that in practical problems the new procedure is faster by a factor in excess of two orders of magnitude. © 1985 Taylor 8 Francis Group, LLC.

Title: An analytic model for the long-term performance of solar thermal systems with well-mixed storage
Affiliations: Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84990, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Gordon, J.M., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84990, Israel; Zarmi, Y., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84990, Israel
Abstract: A simple analytic method is presented for predicting the long-term performance of solar thermal systems with well-mixed storage and loads that do not vary significantly from day to day. Recognizing that most conventionally designed systems have effective relaxation times that are long relative to the time scale of variations in insolation, but short compared to the time scale for day-to-day variations in insolation, we invoke a constant radiation model and solve the problem within that framework. The results of the analytic method are simple closed-form expressions which enable the user to understand clearly the dependence of system performance on the physically important variables. Good agreement is found between the predictions of the analytic method and the corresponding results of the F-f-chart method and computer simulations. The analytic method is furthermore applicable to all collector types and storage fluids and is not restricted to flat plates and hot water storage. The limitations of the analytic method are discussed and found not to introduce a serious restriction for commonly designed conventional systems. © 1985.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; CONSTANT RADIATION MODEL; SOLAR THERMAL SYSTEMS; YEARLY SOLAR FRACTION; YEARLY USEFUL ENERGY; HEATING

Title: SUBSURFACE USE FOR ENERGY REQUIREMENTS.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Jansson, Birger; Winqvist, Torbjorn
Abstract: Utilization of subsurface space and the properties of the subsurface in order to obtain energy efficiency has of late been given considerable attention in Sweden. This review of recent experience and research was prepared for the annual meeting of ITA - the International Tunnelling Association - in Warsaw 1983. It constitutes the Swedish contribution to the ITA working group on Subsurface Planning, which this year concentrated on the theme 'Potential use of subsurface with respect to energy'. The surface ground and the underground offer a low-grade heat source which can be utilized directly by means of heat pumps. Other characteristics of the subsurface are, however, of greater importance for future energy conservation. Of particular interest is the storage capacity of heat and cold of the underground. Refs.

Authors: Feuermann D., Gordon J.M., Zarmi Y.
Title: A typical meteorological day (TMD) approach for predicting the long-term performance of solar energy systems
Affiliations: Applied Solar Calculation Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Feuermann, D., Applied Solar Calculation Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, Israel; Gordon, J.M., Applied Solar Calculation Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, Israel; Zarmi, Y., Applied Solar Calculation Unit, Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, Israel
Abstract: A method for predicting the long-term performance of solar energy systems, based on the analysis of system performance for one particular day-the typical meteorological day (TMD)-is presented. The TMD is constructed from the cumulative time distribution of insolation values on the collector aperture. The TMD method requires little calculational effort and a small data base relative to standard yearly computer simulations. Good agreement is found between the predictions of the new method and the corresponding results of the F-f-chart method. The TMD method is of particular value for cases that may often be treated inaccurately by simple calculational methods: (1) high threshold problems; (2) systems with short response times (e.g., due to small storage); and (3) systems in which collectors other than flat plates are used (the method is applicable to all solar collector types). © 1985.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; SOLAR RADIATION - Measurements; COLLECTOR APERTURE; INSOLATION; LONG-TERM PERFORMANCE; SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS; TYPICAL METEOROLOGICAL DAY (TMD); SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: OPERATIONAL AND TECHNICAL RESULTS FROM THE SPENT FUEL TEST-CLIMAX.
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Technical Meeting - Institute of Environmental Sciences
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Earth, Sciences Dep, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Earth Sciences Dep, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Patrick, Wesley C., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Earth, Sciences Dep, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Earth Sciences Dep, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: The technical feasibility of short-term storage and retrieval of spent nuclear fuel assemblies has recently been demonstrated in a test of deep geologic storage at the U. S. Department of Energy Nevada Test Site (NTS). Handling systems and procedures developed and deployed on this test functioned safely and reliably to emplace eleven intact spent-fuel assemblies and retrieve them three years later. Three exchanges of spent fuel were conducted at regular intervals during the storage period to maintain the proficiency of personnel and the readiness of the handling system. Technical data were collected using nearly 1,000 instruments. These data show that the mechanical and thermal properties of granites are compatible with nuclear waste isolation objectives. Measured and calculated temperatures are in agreement, confirming the adequacy of available heat transfer codes. (Edited author abstract. )
Index Keywords: NEVADA TEST SITE (NTS); NUCLEAR WASTE ISOLATION; PROFICIENCY OF PERSONNEL; RADIATION TRANSPORT CALCULATIONS; SHORT-TERM STORAGE AND RETRIEVAL; SPENT FUEL TESTS; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: BEHAVIOUR OF A STRATIFIED SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE DURING RELAXATION PHASES.
Affiliations: CNRS, Lab d'Energetique Solaire,, Poitiers, Fr, CNRS, Lab d'Energetique Solaire, Poitiers, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Blay, D., CNRS, Lab d'Energetique Solaire,, Poitiers, Fr, CNRS, Lab d'Energetique Solaire, Poitiers, Fr
Abstract: Thermal relaxation of a highly stratified fluid in a sensible heat storage tank is studied. A one-dimensional analysis is carried out and the characteristic dimensionless parameters are defined. The importance of the wall conduction is pointed out and discussed. Theoretical and experimental results are then compared in the particular case of a one cubic meter tank using oil at a temperature varying between 50 and 220 degree C.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEAT TRANSFER; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; HEAT STORAGE TANK; STRATIFIED FLUID; THERMAL RELAXATION; WALL CONDUCTION; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: DESIGN AND PERFORMANCE OF A LATENT HEAT STORAGE SYSTEM FOR HIGH TEMPERATURE APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: CNRS, Lab d'Energetique Solaire,, Poitiers, Fr, CNRS, Lab d'Energetique Solaire, Poitiers, Fr

Abstract: The paper describes the design and performance of a thermal accumulator using the sensible and latent heats of Zamak, a 95% Zn alloy encapsulated in vertical steel cylinders installed in a thermal insulated chamber according to a spiral scheme, with a high packing factor. In addition to an experimental work which has shown the technical feasibility and the performance of such a prototype, a numerical model using a finite difference scheme has been developed to simulate the transient thermal behaviour of the accumulator during periods of charge and discharge.

Authors with affiliations: Avanzini, P.G.; Ognibene, I.; Repeto, F.
Abstract: This paper covers thermal energy storage by means of the melting latent heat of metallic alloys The advantages of this technique and possible applications of heat storage also are covered.

Title: ENERGY ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT IN INDUSTRY, PROCEEDINGS OF THE EUROPEAN CONGRESS.
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 124 papers. Various aspects of energy management and energy economics in industries are covered. The topics include energy resources, energy conservation, heat pump systems, foundries, electric power utilization, industrial furnaces, waste heat utilization, food products plants, and cogeneration plants.

Title: TASK OF THE SWEDISH COUNCIL FOR BUILDING RESEARCH.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Affiliations: Swedish Council for Building, Research, Stockholm, Swed, Swedish Council for Building Research, Stockholm, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Anon, Swedish Council for Building, Research, Stockholm, Swed, Swedish Council for Building Research, Stockholm, Swed
Abstract: The Swedish Council for Building Research (BFR) is responsible for that part of the national energy research program concerned with energy use in the built environment, i. e. research, development and experimental building and demonstration activities concerned with solar energy, heat pumps, heat storage and heat distribution, as well as with system and implementation aspects. The Council is also responsible for support for research, development, experimental building and demonstration activities relating to energy conservation and energy management measures in new and existing buildings and built environments. The objective of the research and development work is to progressively provide platforms for a number of decisions concerning the introduction of solar energy and heat pumps in various system combinations, and to contribute to production of the information base necessary for fulfilment of the SOL 85 program. Refs.
Index Keywords: ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Research; HEATING - Solar; BUILT ENVIRONMENT; ENERGY CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES; ENERGY USE DEVELOPMENT; HEATING SYSTEMS; NEW ENERGY TECHNOLOGY; BUILDINGS

Authors: Kaushik S., Sheridan N., Lam K., Kaul S.
Title: Dynamic simulation of an ammonia-water absorption cycle solar heat pump with integral refrigerant storage
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushik, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Sheridan, N., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Lam, K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Kaul, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: A detailed computer simulation model of an ammonia-water absorption cycle solar heat pump with integral refrigerant storage is reported. Incident solar radiation, ambient and room temperatures and the constant flow rate of the pump are the input to the computer model based on the usual heat and mass balances. First the system is optimised by running the model at average conditions and selecting the best values of the design parameters-heat exchanger UA-values, mass flows, etc. System component temperatures, energy flows and coefficient of performance can be predicted. Next the dynamic model is developed with hourly average data for a typical house in Melbourne to predict the feasibility of the refrigerant storage for matching the heating load of the house during the off-generation period by careful control of the refrigerant flow from the store. The system is shown to be technically feasible and to be marginally more effective than other storage alternatives. Its economic feasibility will depend on the cost benefits that can be attributed to the advantageous storage volume and the low storage losses. © 1985.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; REFRIGERANTS - Ammonia; ABSORBERS; CONDENSERS; INTERNAL/REFRIGERANT STORAGE; SOLAR HEAT PUMP; SYSTEM MODELLING; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: AIR KETCHUM SOLAR HANGAR.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Inspired by the cold weather and sunny skies of Sun Valley, Idaho, Air Ketchum took advantage of an opportunity to build a new hangar by constructing the most energy-efficient building of its type in the world. Heated by the sun alone, the hangar maintains an interior temperature of 16 degree C to 21 degree C for well over 90% of the time and operates on a total energy bill of about 40. 00 per month, winter and summer. That energy bill is generated almost entirely by two items, the overhead lighting and the air-moving blowers.
Index Keywords: AIRPORTS - Buildings; BUILDINGS - Insulation; HEATING - Solar; HANGARS; HEAT CAPACITY; HEAT STORAGE; PASSIVE SOLAR SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: LOW TEMPERATURE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE USING SOLID-STATE PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS.
Affiliations: Univ de Coimbra, Dep de Quimica,, Coimbra, Port, Univ de Coimbra, Dep de Quimica, Coimbra, Port
Authors with affiliations: de Lima, M.C.P., Univ de Coimbra, Dep de Quimica,, Coimbra, Port, Univ de Coimbra, Dep de Quimica, Coimbra, Port; Maycock, C.D., Univ de Coimbra, Dep de Quimica,, Coimbra, Port, Univ de Coimbra, Dep de Quimica, Coimbra, Port
Abstract: Some polyhydroxymethyl-methanes exhibit solid-solid phase changes, involving relatively large quantities of energy, which manifest themselves as thermal transitions. These are reversible over many cycles of heating and cooling. These properties make them candidates for solid state energy stores which, in some cases, could be used at temperatures approaching ambient. This latter in the cases studied, is mainly due to a high degree of supercooling. Differential scanning calorimetry has been used to study the temperature and enthalpy of the solid-solid transitions.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; LOW TEMPERATURE STORAGE; POLYHYDROXY COMPOUNDS; SOLID-LIQUID TRANSITION; SOLID-STATE PHASE CHANGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: LARGE ELECTRICAL-ENERGY STORAGE FACILITIES.
Authors with affiliations: Ershevich, V.V.; Kir'yanova, N.A.
Abstract: Problems associated with the utilization of various types of energy-storage facilities are considered, three areas being singled out: operation during the variable portion of the load curve with double regulation effect, handling of peaks and the filling in of off-peak dips in the load curve; the generation of power impulses through the use of stored energy for short-term supply of load; and the conversion of one form of energy to another. The present-day state of development and introduction of storage facilities of various kinds is described. The conditions for utilization of large-scale storage on the power systems of the USSR are evaluated, and the principles for determining the economic efficiency are formulated.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION; FOSSIL FUEL POWER PLANTS; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; CAPACITORS; COMPRESSED-AIR GAS-TURBINE POWER PLANTS; ENERGY CONVERSION; STORAGE FACILITIES; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Fifth world hydrogen energy conference 15-19 July 1984 division D "conversion and utilization". The development and practical application of fuel cells: Keynote address
Affiliations: 34 High Street, Little Shelford, Cambridge, CB2 5ES, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bacon, F.T., 34 High Street, Little Shelford, Cambridge, CB2 5ES, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper is concerned only with hydrogen fuel cells, and it is suggested that the most likely commercial application will initially be for the propulsion of short-range city traffic, especially buses. For a start, it seems likely that the hydrogen will be stored as a compressed gas, using the latest developments in lightweight pressure vessels, although other methods of hydrogen storage will probably follow, for example metal hydrides. It is suggested that fuel cells are still in an early stage of development, and that considerable improvements should be achieved in the future, as experience is accumulated from the use of fuel cells in space, and other special applications. The use of pure hydrogen in fuel cells probably means that this will provide a new and improved method of energy storage, when compared with conventional storage batteries; and advantage would naturally be taken of the great improvements which are now being made in the design of electrolyzers, which should help to reduce the cost of pure hydrogen, especially in countries such as Canada, which have large reserves of hydro-electric power and a successful nuclear power industry. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN - Storage; ELECTROLYZERS; HYDROGEN FUEL CELLS; METAL HYDRIDES; FUEL CELLS

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF ENERGY TECHNOLOGY.
Authors with affiliations: Billington, N.S.
Abstract: The origins of concepts in the field of energy use are described. Progress occurs only when certain technical, economic and social factors coincide. Their relationship with the growth of civilisation is noted, and the social factors leading to, or stemming from, technical change are mentioned.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; FUELS; REFRIGERATION; ENERGY TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT; HEAT STORAGE; INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION; ENERGY UTILIZATION

Title: INVERTED CAVE HOUSE.
Authors with affiliations: Loxley, Thomas E.
Abstract: The article describes the theory of thermally coupling buildings to the subsoil under them in order to exploit the earth's annual absorption of solar energy. In effect, low-rise buildings can function as inverted caves, it is suggested. In the application of the concept to a two-storey house, a radiant floor storage arrangement links a water-source heat pump and a modest solar array to supplement a 'natural' winter base temperature of 11-12 degree C.
Index Keywords: Heat pump systems; HEATING - Solar; Soils; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; 'INVERTED CAVE' CONCEPT; WATER-SOURCE HEAT PUMP; Houses

Title: Performance of a salt-gradient solar pond for power production
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Garyounis University, Benghazi, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya
Authors with affiliations: Hawas, M.M., Faculty of Engineering, Garyounis University, Benghazi, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya; Elasfouri, A.S., Faculty of Engineering, Garyounis University, Benghazi, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya
Abstract: An analytical model of the thermal behaviour of salt-gradient solar ponds is presented. The model is used to predict the performance of a solar pond intended for electric power production. The pond dimensions and heat extraction rate are optimized to achieve a high mean value and small amplitude of pond temperature. The upper convective zone is found to have a deleterious effect on pond performance. The optimum depth of the non-convective zone which maximizes the pond yield is presented. It is found that careful selection of the depth of the lower convective zone and of the amplitude and phase lag of the heat extraction rate can lead to a small value of the amplitude of the pond temperature fluctuations. © 1985.
Author Keywords: Non-convecting ponds; Salt-gradient ponds; Solar ponds; Solar power production
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; LONG-TERM HEAT STORAGE; NON-CONVECTING PONDS; SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR POND; POWER GENERATION

Authors: Le Goff P., Le Goff H., Barkaoui M., Dietrich E., Ramadane A.
Title: ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF SYSTEMS FOR STORING AND UP-GRADING ENERGY BASED ON SEPARATION AND MIXING.
Affiliations: CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Le Goff, P., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Le Goff, H., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Barkaoui, M., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Dietrich, E., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Ramadane, A., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr
Abstract: In an absorption heat pump, the components of a mixture are separated on the one hand and re-mixed on the other hand, by vaporisation-condensation, using thermal energy. A generalisation of this operation is presented, using other forms of energy: mechanical, electrical. For comparing the economic value of these various processes, a new concept, 'the coefficient for upgrading energy' measures the 'value added' to each unit of energy passing through the system.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY STORAGE; COEFFICIENT OF PERFORMANCE; ENERGY UPGRADING; EXERGY-BASED SCALE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: Study of three different underground storage systems
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Bansal, N.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Singh, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: A novel way of reducing temperature swings of the living space in the direct gain concept and, simultaneously, providing large solar gains is to provide storage under the floor. Three different storage systems have been considered and a theoretical model developed to stydy the effect of various storage media on the temperature of the living space corresponding to typical weather conditions of a harsh North American winter day. © 1985.

Authors: Cowley Martyn B., Morgan W.Ray, MacCready Paul
Title: BIONIC BAT - STORED ENERGY HUMAN POWERED AIRCRAFT.
Affiliations: AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat, Project, CA, USA, AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat Project, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cowley, Martyn B., AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat, Project, CA, USA, AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat Project, CA, USA; Morgan, W.Ray, AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat, Project, CA, USA, AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat Project, CA, USA; MacCready, Paul, AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat, Project, CA, USA, AeroVironment Inc, Bionic Bat Project, CA, USA
Abstract: A considerable advance in the flight performance of low powered, (under 1 horsepower or 1 kW) very lightweight (under 100 lbs or 50 kg) aircraft has been achieved by the human powered aircraft, 'Bionic Bat'. This vehicle has consistently demonstrated its ability to fly around a 1500 m (0. 93 mile) perimeter triangular course at speeds over 20 mph (32. 2 km/h). The vehicle utilizes aerodynamic and structural technology. The following have contributed to the Bionic Bat's performance: minimizing airframe weight by the use of efficient lightweight composite structures, including carbon fiber, Kevlar, expanded plastic foam and Mylar film; particular attention to aerodynamic design and reduction of drag; optimization of the bioelectro- mechanical propulsion system; statically stable configuration with excellent flight handling using three-axis control.
Index Keywords: AERODYNAMICS - Wings and Airfoils; ELECTRIC MOTOR/GENERATOR; ENERGY DISTRIBUTION ANALYSIS; ENERGY STORAGE AND PROPULSION SYSTEM; LIGHTWEIGHT AIRCRAFT FLIGHT PERFORMANCE; PRE-FLIGHT ENERGY STORAGE; AIRCRAFT

Authors: Niggemann R.E., McKenna R.F., Chaudoir D.W., Thollot P.A.
Title: SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER CONVERSION SYSTEM FOR SPACE STATION.
Affiliations: Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Niggemann, R.E., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; McKenna, R.F., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; Chaudoir, D.W., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; Thollot, P.A., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Abstract: Dynamic (i. e. , nonphotovoltaic) electric power generating systems are becoming more attractive as power needs of various space applications increase. A solar dynamic power system can provide the high power requirements of the Space Station at higher efficiencies and potentially lower cost than a photovoltaic system. The significant benefit is more recognizable in the reduction of frontal area or energy collection area of a spacecraft. For vehicles in low earth orbit (LEO), this relates to less drag, reduced susceptibility to jet exhaust disturbance, and less viewing and operational interference. Discussed here is a solar dynamic power generating system, based on the Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC), suitable for the power generating requirements of NASA's Space Station. Also described is a power management and distribution scheme that provides the user directly with high quality, ac power at a frequency that is user friendly.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Space Applications; SPACE RESEARCH - Concentrators; ORGANIC RANKINE CYCLE (ORC); PHOTOVOLTAIC VS. SOLAR DYNAMIC SIZE COMPARISON; POWER GENERATION/ENERGY STORAGE EFFICIENCY COMPARISON; ROTARY FLUID MANAGEMENT DEVICE (RFMD); SOLAR DYNAMIC ORC RECEIVER; SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER CONVERSION SYSTEM; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Chandra S., Kumar R., Kaushik S., Kaul S.
Title: Thermal performance of a non-air-conditioned building with PCCM thermal storage wall
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Chandra, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Kumar, R., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Kaushik, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Kaul, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: This paper presents a time-dependent periodic heat transfer analysis of a non-air-conditioned building having a south-facing wall of phase-changing component material (PCCM). A rectangular room (6 × 5 × 4 m) based on the ground is considered. The effects of heat transfer through walls and roof, heat conduction to the basement ground and furnishings, heat gain through window and heat loss due to air ventilation have been incorporated in the periodic time-dependent heat transfer analysis. The time-dependent heat flux through the PCCM south-facing wall has been obtained by defining the effective thermal properties of the PCCM for a conduction process with no phase change. Numerical calculations are made for a typical mild winter day (7 March 1979) at New Delhi for heat flux entering through the wall and inside air temperature. Further, a PCCM wall of smaller thickness is more desirable, in comparison to an ordinary masonry concrete wall, for providing efficient thermal energy storage as well as excellent thermal comfort in buildings. © 1985.
Author Keywords: Non-air-conditioned building; Periodic analysis; Phase-change component material; Space heating system; Thermal performance; Thermal storage wall

Authors: Jones R.L., Botti J.J., Anderson W.M., Bennett N.L.
Title: Thermoregulation during aerobic exercise in pregnancy
Affiliations: Department of Family and Community Medicine, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine, The Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey, PA, United States; Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Harrisburg Hospital, Harrisburg, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jones, R.L., Department of Family and Community Medicine, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine, The Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey, PA, United States, Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Harrisburg Hospital, Harrisburg, PA, United States; Botti, J.J., Department of Family and Community Medicine, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine, The Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey, PA, United States, Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Harrisburg Hospital, Harrisburg, PA, United States; Anderson, W.M., Department of Family and Community Medicine, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine, The Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey, PA, United States, Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Harrisburg Hospital, Harrisburg, PA, United States; Bennett, N.L., Department of Family and Community Medicine, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine, The Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Hershey, PA, United States, Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Harrisburg Hospital, Harrisburg, PA, United States
Abstract: To characterize maternal thermal balance during pregnancy, the authors recorded the thermal response to moderate weight bearing exercise stress in four aerobically conditioned pregnant women. Studies were performed in a climate-controlled environment in each trimester of pregnancy and postpartum after modifying the exercise protocol for changes in maternal exercise condition. Core, vaginal, and mean skin temperatures were recorded at rest and during maximum exercise. Mean resting skin temperature increased during pregnancy; mean resting core and vaginal temperatures did not change. Core temperatures did not exceed 39C during exercise. Heat storage (heat content/kg) was not increased as a result of exercise with advancing pregnancy. According to these findings, thermal balance can be maintained with advancing gestation when exercise prescriptions are appropriately modified for conditioned women. © 1985 by The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
